Title: Saju Sreenivas: An Indo-French music project to conserve nature
Content:
Many artistes use their talents not only to entertain the audience, but also to create awareness on the various social and ecological issues. The upcoming French-Malayalam music album that is conceived by Malayali playback singer Saju Sreenivas , photographer and artiste Praveen Muraleedharan and French singer and composer Jo Ziako is one such venture. It sheds light on nature conservation and the fight against the use of plastic.

The idea of such a project had germinated after Ziako was moved by Praveen’s wildlife photography exhibition in France last year. Ziako says, “I was heartbroken to see the photographs that showed how humans have polluted the lush green forests and their ecosystems. A photo of a lion-tailed macaque holding a plastic water bottle stirred something in me. That’s when I thought of turning my music as a tool to create awareness on nature conservation and eradicating the use of plastic. Thus, we decided to do an Indo-French collaboration with musician Praveen and Saju Sreenivas, who will write the Malayalam lyrics for our project. I believe music has a universal language that can reach all.”

The music album which is yet to be named will have seven songs in total that will focus on nature and its importance. The team is currently busy shooting and recording their music album at various landscapes across the State.

According to Praveen, the project will be an eye-opener for many in the society and it will persuade them to save wildlife and stop the usage of single-use plastics. “Though the song recordings are progressing, we have managed to perform at colleges and some schools as we believe that the future of the world lies in the hands of the next-generation and they are the ones that must be informed about the perils if our wildlife and ecology are destroyed.”

The team will be using a blend of Kerala and French musical instruments for its orchestration. They have mixed, chenda, idaykka, madhalam and other traditional percussion instruments to the hues of French music, Praveen says. “The songs include themes like anti-plastic, travel, forest, Bohemian life and so on. We have focused on rendering simple lyrics in Malayalam too, so that everyone can sing it,” he explains, as he thumps on a Cajon (a box-like instrument) matching Ziako’s guitar notes.

Meanwhile, Valiyaperunnal singer Saju Sreenivas says that it’s “an organic music venture” for him. “I felt it was a refreshing and novel idea in our music culture. The album is rich in organic music as we have recorded the live instruments and avoided processed music. The album will be unique as it has used French tunes with a touch of gypsy music. Praveen translates what Ziako says and that itself was a new experience. I worked on the lyrics after understanding the meaning of the French lines by Ziako. Also, the songs are performed in a way that they can be interpreted by the audience,” says Saiju.

Title: Chennai Times Most Desirable Woman 2019: Aditi Rao Hydari
Content:
Rank 2019 HOTTIES GAINERS/LOSERS IN 2019 Rank 2018 1 Aditi Rao Hydari Up 9 2 Aishwarya Rajesh Down 1 3 Amala Paul Up 20 4 Nayanthara Down 2 5 Malavika Mohanan New Entrant - 6 Keerthy Suresh Down 5 7 Samantha Akkineni Down 3 8 Athulya Ravi New Entrant - 9 Yashika Aannand Down 6 10 Sameea Bangera Re-Entry - 11 Raiza Wilson Up 19 12 Rakul Preet Singh Down 11 13 Kajal Aggarwal Up 14 14 Srinidhi Shetty New Entrant - 15 Nakshathra Nagesh New Entrant - 16 Trisha Down 7 17 Taapsee Pannu Re-Entry - 18 Anukreethy Vas Down 4 19 Priya Bhavani Shankar Down 12 20 Chinmayi Sripaada New Entrant - 21 Nivetha Pethuraj New Entrant - 22 Sai Pallavi Down 10 23 Raashi Khanna Down 22 24 Tamannaah Down 18 25 Andrea Jeremiah Down 16 26 Oviya Down 8 27 Shraddha Srinath New Entrant - 28 Shruti Haasan Down 26 29 Regina Cassandra Down 21 30 Nikki Galrani New Entrant -







Everything about Aditi Rao Hydari is regal — her looks, her attitude, the way she carries herself, her fiercely loyal personality, and her generosity with praise and gratitude for those who she feels truly deserve credit. When we tell Aditi that she has been voted Chennai Times Most Desirable Woman of 2019 from a bunch of achievers under the age of 40, her first reaction is, “I feel like a kid who’s been told everyone in class likes her. I’m full of gratitude for those who voted for me, and my people who have stood by me throughout.” In a heartfelt chat with Chennai Times, the actress talks about her idea of desirability, her definition of beauty and more. Read on…When I’m told that a huge number of people find me desirable, I feel like, ‘Yessss, thank you! I want to do a little jig’. Because on most days, you wake up feeling very normal, you get to work and do your job, and somewhere, I’m aware that there’s a whole team that creates that person — either the characters that I play or me as an individual. Apart from how we look naturally, there are so many people who collectively come together to create that image that gets portrayed to the outside world. On one level, it feels exciting to be called the most desirable woman, and at the same time, I’m also thankful to all those people who make me who I am. I truly believe that the beauty that people see in others is a reflection of them and their eyes that see us like that. And I’m thankful for that.To me, it’s an intangible thing. The moment you are able to pinpoint that, you become self-conscious of it. Desirability is a collective quality and comes from deep within. I think if you are desirable on the surface — like you look good and have a great body — then beyond a point, that can become cumbersome and boring. I think desirability comes from talent, your attitude, the way you treat people, your heart… it’s all very sub-conscious.I love it and it makes me feel great when people write to me. It’s because of people who like me, follow me, say great things about me and encourage me that I am here. You’ve come into a difficult industry where you don’t have a backing; you learn as you grow and these are the people who are with you and support you. These are the people who vote for you, buy tickets for your films, watch your films repeatedly and send sweet messages to you on a day that could have been the worst day for you. It’s their love that makes you grow and I love it.Fans are never difficult to handle. They are good people who come with a warm heart and lack ego. I think most of the time, they only want a photo with you. It takes so much courage to come up to a person who is surrounded by so many people and ask them for a photo, knowing very well that the person may turn you away. So, I rarely deny them. The people who are difficult are the trolls, not the fans. Even with them, I try and send them some love. Maybe they are having a bad day, so that doesn’t mean I should behave badly with them. I feel we can control our attitude with love.Well, there’s no downtime because you are being judged 24X7. Their eyes are always on you, they pass judgement, and you don’t have personal time. But there are also positives of being an actress. I feel like a child in a playground when I’m on a film set. While so many people spend their whole life trying to find that one thing they love doing, I’m lucky that I have figured out what it is. There are so many positive aspects in being an actress that they outweigh the few difficulties we might have.When I came into the industry, there was a lot of pressure on me to look a certain way. I didn’t like wearing too much makeup. I used to wear sweatshirts and flats. A lot of people advised me, saying I should be glamorous and sexy. But somewhere inside, I used to be like, ‘But that’s not me’. I used to feel I was wearing somebody else’s shoes and clothes and trying to be somebody else. But one day, I realised that was not right. A lot of things changed, I found a team of people who believed I was perfect the way I was, and I realised that when you are authentically yourself and accept yourself for who you are, that’s when people will also see you and love you for who you are. I have been told so many times that I was too petite, too skinny and my face was so small, but ultimately, people have to love that about you. So today, I happily roam around in my sweatshirt and sweatpants, don’t wear makeup every day…. And it was from Mani sir (Mani Ratnam) that I learnt that the camera can capture your real beauty and you don’t have to wear makeup for that. I feel the day you are comfortable with yourself, that’s when people will see you for who you are. I used to feel like a factory prototype image of beauty and for me, that was a burden. Anything that’s a burden is not going to make you happy. Yes, we all are obsessed about some feature or the other; like, I have an OCD about my eyebrows. That’s normal human tendency. But that can’t dictate your life.It’s effortlessness. You can be in the same room with the person and you don’t have to speak a word, but you both know what you want to communicate. It’s like, you share a soul. Love is also respect because I have to be able to respect that person to truly be able to love that person.If a person talks down to people, use their position of power to treat others badly, are twisted and complicated, then I can’t be with that person — either in a romantic way or just as a friend. I like simple, happy people. I’m a heart person and trust my instincts. And, in any relationship, loyalty is sacred.A rumour is called a rumour for a reason. I hear one every second day. It affects me sometimes because it can be disrespectful to the other person who’s also part of the rumour! I don’t like negativity. Even if I take myself out of the equation, it affects the other person and I don’t like that.I’d say I’m doing every film of Mani sir.I like to be with people I love and trust, and get along with. I like MY people. Actually, people call me an energiser bunny because I’m jumping and dancing all night and still function the next day. That’s because I’m generally high on life, not because I consume any intoxicating substance.Using pick-up lines is the worst way to speak to a girl. When someone flirts with me, I’m like, ‘See you never!’. Once, I was in Turkey and this guy asked me where I was from. I told him, ‘India’. He went, ‘OMG! Really?’ I have heard people tell me I look like a Colombian. So, I asked him if he thought I was from Colombia. But he said, ‘No, I thought you were from paradise’. I just walked away from there.On sets, I’m Mother Teresa. My empathy metre is 180 on 100. So I don’t create difficult situations for anyone. I think there was just this one time where I offered people cream biscuits with toothpaste. That’s very harmless, no?People think we have a glam life and that we go to sleep and wake up like that. But no. It’s a lot of sweat, hard work, no sleep and working with puffy face!

Title: Ashi Singh: In the race to look glamorous, most girls look the same
Content: Actress Ashi Singh , who played Naina in ' Yeh Un Dinon Ki Baat Hai ', was on a break for the last seven months. The actress confesses that the character had taken over her life and she needed to break free from it. She says, “I lived Naina for two-and-a-half years, until the show ended in August, last year. Like Naina, I, too, am a simple girl. So, for a long time, I felt that I may not be able to portray a character, which is drastically different.” Ask the actress what kept her busy for the last seven months and she says, “I was busy pursuing all the hobbies that I had forgotten in the past two years. I was also focussing on fitness, spending time with family and travelling.”She is glad that she has bagged the lead role in 'Dil Jaise Dhadke… Dhadakne Do', which is undergoing a leap. Ashi says, “The show revolves around banishing age-old superstitions, and I play an interesting character. When I played Naina, I had firmly resolved that I would not play a typical sari-clad bahu role in the future. So, there were offers, but I refused all of them. Though I will be seen wearing saris in my new show, I don’t play a typical bahu in it. I am glad that I am doing something different.”With most actresses posing for bold photoshoots and playing glamorous characters , we ask Ashi if she ever felt the need to shed her simple image, and she replies, “I am an actress and it is my job to look glamorous if the role requires it. Having said that, I take pride in the fact that I have a simple personality and simplicity is my virtue. One can look glamorous, but it is important to be talented, too. If you look around, you will see many girls who are glamorous. But in the race to look glamorous, most of them end up looking the same. That way, I stand out.”

Title: Despite Coronavirus scare, these music groups went ahead with shows in Bengaluru
Content: Even as Bengaluru began reacting to the COVID-19 pandemic scare and shutting down activities, public gatherings, etc., over the last few days, a few events did take place without a hitch. British rock band Alexis Kings was in the city as part of its maiden India tour, performed and has already left for its next destination, Mumbai.The band, says lead vocalist Brendan Aherne , has no intention of calling off its tour, even though every other artiste worth his/her salt is doing just that. The reason? “We might be safer here in India, than in the UK. They have more number of cases than India and the level of panic there has definitely dampened the spirit of many people from attending music shows. Taking precautions seriously should have been more than enough, but completely stopping one’s way around life is ridiculous. If quarantine measures were better implemented and awareness surrounding the breakout heightened, we’d be a lot better off without the hysteria. People are also falling sick because of anxiety on whether they will contract the virus or not,” he says.Meanwhile, Sufi artiste Mir Mukhtiyar Ali’s show in Bengaluru went low profile, but didn’t get cancelled. “Given growing concerns over coronavirus , a sizeable number of people did cancel their tickets, but we managed to have a good audience for the show. Mukhtiyar had performed in Canada and Rajasthan before coming for the Bengaluru concert. Of course, precautionary measures were in place, and we even had members of the audience wearing masks and keeping a distance from each other inside the auditorium, it was good to see that music lovers in Bengaluru were not panicking as such,” says Menaka Rodriguez , from India Foundation for the Arts that organised the show.

Title: Apple WWDC 2020 to be online-only due to Coronavirus risk
Content:
Apple has announced that it will host its annual Worldwide Developers Conference in June, however, this will be online-only as the world fights back against the Coronavirus pandemic.

“WWDC 2020 will take on an entirely new online format packed with content for consumers, press and developers alike,” said Apple in a press statement.

“We are delivering WWDC 2020 this June in an innovative way to millions of developers around the world, bringing the entire developer community together with a new experience. The current health situation has required that we create a new WWDC 2020 format that delivers a full program with an online keynote and sessions, offering a great learning experience for our entire developer community, all around the world. We will be sharing all of the details in the weeks ahead,”said Phil Schiller, Apple’s senior vice president of Worldwide Marketing.

Apple also announced it will commit $1 million to local San Jose organisations to offset associated revenue loss as a result of WWDC 2020’s new online format,” it added.

Google, Microsoft, Facebook and other tech brands have also cancelled their flagship annual events and shifted to an online-only format like Apple. Not to forget even the Mobile World Congress , held every year in Barcelona, also got cancelled to avoid further spread of the Coronavirus disease.

“With all of the new products and technologies we’ve been working on, WWDC 2020 is going to be big. I look forward to our developers getting their hands on the new code and interacting in entirely new ways with the Apple engineers building the technologies and frameworks that will shape the future across all Apple platforms,” said Craig Federighi , Apple’s senior vice president of Software Engineering.

Title: Chennaiyin, ATK Chase third ISL title behind closed doors at Fatorda
Content:
Margao: Chennaiyin FC have fond memories of their time at the Nehru Stadium in Fatorda. It was here that they recorded their debut win, here that they stunned hosts FC Goa for their maiden Indian Super League ( ISL ) crown in 2015. Since then, they have added one more trophy to their cabinet, and on Saturday they can create history once again by becoming the first club to clinch their third trophy.

It won’t be easy. At the other end, there is ATK , a team which is as successful and with similar ambitions. Even though the match will be played behind closed doors because of fears over the coronavirus, nobody will need an added dose of motivation.

ATK were always the favourites to make it to the final. Chennaiyin, however, are the dark horses, who galloped ahead of everyone else. They have come a long way since being at the bottom and just one win from their first six games.

Much of the credit goes to head coach Owen Coyle, who transformed the team after taking over from John Gregory in December.

“I took over for the Jamshedpur game and our next match against NorthEast (United) was postponed which gave me eight days to work with the team. We changed the team and discovered outstanding Indian midfielders like (Anirudh) Thapa, Germanpreet (Singh), Edwin (Vanspaul),” said Coyle.

The former Burnley manager has brought the best out of winger Lallianzuala Chhangte, who has seven goals to his credit, most from open play. The 22-year-old is the first Indian to score in both legs of the semifinals and is the second highest domestic goal-scorer behind India captain Sunil Chhetri.

“I think as a group we have worked very hard. We are not here by accident and had to win every week. It was our mentality of winning in different situations and it was just incredible,” said Coyle.

ATK and Chennaiyin are the most successful teams in the ISL but they meet for the first time in the final. Interestingly, both have never lost a final. In their first meeting this season in Chennai, ATK walked away with a solitary goal win. But Chennaiyin went all out in the return leg and won 3-1 in Kolkata.

Unlike their opponents, ATK had to claw their way back into the second leg semifinal after suffering a 0-1 defeat in Bengaluru. Although Ashique Kuruniyan gave the defending champions an early lead, ATK showed character to bounce back with Roy Krishna’s equaliser and a second half brace from David Williams. The duo forged a strong partnership which comes having played together for Wellington Phoenix in Australia.

“We have the same purpose, an idea and it will be important for ATK to win. In football , every match and final is different. We have to enjoy the match and win the final,” said coach Antonio Habbas , who won ATK’s first title in 2014.

ATK have won both their previous finals with a slender margin. They defeated Kerala 1-0 in the inaugural final and edged them out again 4-3 via tiebreaker after the teams were locked 1-1 at full time in 2016.

Chennaiyin have gone on to produce high-scoring finals. On both occasions, they won 3-2, first defeating FC Goa, and then Bengaluru in 2018. It will be interesting to see what Fatorda has in store for the teams.

TALKING POINTS

In ISL history, the team which defeated FC Goa in the semis, has never lost the final.

If Chennaiyin win, they will have a unique record of winning ISL every alternate season.

If ATK win, Antonio Habas will be the first ISL coach to win the league on multiple occasions. He also won the ISL title with ATK in 2014

Title: ISL final: Empty stands, but enough motivation
Content:
Margao: The sixth edition of the Indian Super League ( ISL ) final will see fierce competition between Chennaiyin FC and ATK , both of whom are the most successful teams in the competition.

But more than skills and technical ability, mental strength will count as the clubs will have to play behind closed doors at the Nehru Stadium in Fatorda on Saturday.

With fears of the deadly coronavirus, sports ministry sent out an advisory on Thursday asking national sports federations to “ensure that no public gathering takes place in any sporting event.” Only accredited team officials, ground staff and media would be allowed at the venue.

“It is a big problem in the world and in India. We have to respect the decision of the organisers because the safety of the people is more important than football . It is obviously different to play with support and without support,” said ATK head coach Antonio Habbas .

The home venue of FC Goa attracted an average crowd of 13,000 for each match and would have certainly exceeded the number considering travelling fans.

“This is the first game I will play without fans. I think everybody will agree that football without fans is not the same, but first of all we have to think about the safety of the people and that was a good decision of the league. I don't think about this too much and be focused on this game to be the champions of the ISL,” said Chennaiyin captain Lucian Goian.

Title: I-League behind closed doors, foreign players raise an alarm
Content:
Panaji:

The All India Football Federation ( AIFF ) has decided to play the remaining 28 matches in the I-League behind closed doors but that hasn’t eased fears over the deadly coronavirus A few I-League clubs have raised concerns that their players, particularly those from foreign shores, will hold them responsible, should things go wrong.A leading club has already withdrawn a goalkeeper from their squad before travelling for an outstation game after he showed signs of fever. Unwilling to take any risk, the player was sent for tests and initial reports suggest there is nothing to worry.“It has been decided by the AIFF to complete the I-league season with the remaining matches being played behind closed doors. Only officials and players of the teams, match officials, limited number of LOC members, medical staff, TV crew and registered journalists and photographers other than security personnel can be present within the stadium complex on matchdays,” the AIFF said in a statement on Friday.The AIFF also said they are in the process of reworking the fixtures “so that we can try and finish the league earlier.”The email sent to all participating clubs received favourable responses from clubs like Mohun Bagan and Punjab FC, but others like Chennai City were not entirely convinced.“I personally feel that the league should consider to postpone since health and safety of all players comes first. We already have faced couple of issues from foreign players and especially from their families abroad on this concern. The initial problem or worry is not about conducting the games closed doors, but the fact that the virus can be spread while travelling as well, especially in airports,” Chennai City said their email to the AIFF.The former champions though said, “considering the importance of finishing the league and also taking logistics into concern, we will look to convince our players and support staff on the decision.”

Title: #CoronaScare: With Delhi halls shut, will people flock to Gurgaon or Noida?
Content: In response to the coronavirus threat and as a precautionary measure, the Delhi government on Thursday evening decided to shut down cinema halls till March 31. The announcement has impacted the release of four Bollywood films – 'Angrezi Medium' (which released yesterday), 'Sandeep Aur Pinky Faraar', 'Sir and ' Sooryavanshi '. While all shows in Delhi have been cancelled, the cinemas in Noida and Gurgaon will continue to run, since both Uttar Pradesh and Haryana haven't yet issued any orders to shut theatres. However, exhibitors and distributors say that they can't predict whether moviegoers will head to Noida and Gurgaon to watch recently released films.A couple of hours after the announcement, the makers of Akshay Kumar-starrer Sooryavanshi announced that the film, which was to release on March 24, has been postponed. The statement read, "Due to the recent coronavirus outbreak, we, the makers, have decided to postpone the release of Sooryavanshi, keeping in mind the health and safety of the audience. Sooryavanshi will be back when the time is right."Tillotama Shome-starrer Sir, which was to be released on March 20, has also been postponed. Shiladitya Bora, who is spearheading the India release of the film, tweeted, "Bearing in mind public health concerns and the advisory from the health ministry, we have decided to postpone the release of Sir. We look forward to sharing the film with our home audience in India and will announce an updated release date ASAP. Meanwhile, we urge everyone to stay safe and take all necessary health precautions."On Thursday, a statement released by Angrezi Medium’s makers confirmed that the film will be released "as scheduled across India except for Kerala, Delhi and the Union Territory of Jammu & Kashmir."Exhibitors say that the shutdown of theatres in Delhi will affect 'Angrezi Medium''s box office collection as Delhi was expected to contribute a major chunk to it. Rajendra Singh Jyala from INOX says, "Around 15% of Angrezi Medium’s business, which would have come from Delhi, will be affected. However, safety comes first, and if other states will follow suit, then obviously we will be closing cinemas until further notice." Joginder Mahajan, a Delhi-based distributor, pointed out that since the announcement came on Thursday, there was no time to reconsider the film’s release. "If the decision would have come on Monday, it would not have affected Angrezi Medium as much as it will now,” he says. Sanjay Suri, who's involved with the India release of the French film Les Miserables, which also hit theatres yesterday, says, “We shall wait for the situation to improve and see if a phase-wise release (in Delhi) is possible when the shutdown is lifted. Safety is most important."The makers of 'Sandeep Aur Pinky Faraar', which is supposed to release on March 20, did not respond to our queries, but as per sources, they are sticking to the scheduled release for now.With Delhi theatres shut, will the Delhi audience go to Noida and Gurgaon now? Maybe not, say exhibitors. Yogesh Raizada of Wave Cinemas says, "We're not sure if the shutdown in Delhi will lead to a higher occupancy in Gurgaon and Noida. Since the last couple of weeks, people have been avoiding theatres and the occupancy is down by over 30%."A Delhi-based exhibitor says, "Unfortunately, we have some good family films in cinemas right now, like 'Angrezi Medium' and 'Thappad', but most of the moviegoers are avoiding visiting cinemas with kids. The shutdown of Delhi theatres will have its effect in Noida and Gurgaon as well, as a huge section of moviegoers will now avoid going to cinema halls." Shaaminder Mallik, a distributor, adds, "We have information that other states are also planning to shut theatres. Most major films scheduled to release in April-May are likely to be postponed."S Bansal, a distributor in the Rajasthan-Delhi belt, says, "Other states like Haryana, Punjab and Rajasthan might also follow suit and shut down their theatres for a few weeks. It will take the business over a year to recover from that. Release dates will also get affected and the calendar will be disturbed in a big way and box office clashes might become inevitable."The spread of coronavirus and the resulting shutdown in Delhi will also affect the business of films that were released in the previous weeks. Yogesh Raizada of Wave Cinemas says, "Had the occupancy in cinema halls not dipped last week because of coronavirus scare, 'Baaghi 3' would have done even better."Ahmed Khan, director of 'Baaghi 3', says, "The safety of the audience is extremely important. We would never want their lives to be at risk. It’s unfortunate that the theatres in Delhi will be shut for a while now and that will affect the overall collections of my film, but some things are beyond our control. We must follow what the government bodies decide."Anubhav Sinha, whose directorial 'Thappad' is also still in cinemas, says, "Thappad has completed 80% of its run at the box office. Delhi contributes about 15% to the collections. That will be impacted but we have to live with it because logon ki jaan se badhkar kuch nahi hota. But we should not panic because that can just make the situation more difficult to handle. Apart from pulling down shutters of theatres in Delhi, governments across states and UTs need to educate people about this disease."— Inputs from Rachana Dubey

Title: Sara Arfeen Khan: ‘How can I find faults in my body after I’ve given life to two lovely babies?’
Content: Actress Sara Arfeen Khan , who has been part of shows like ‘ Dhoondh Legi Manzil Humein ’ and ‘ Love Ka Hai Intezaar ’, had taken a break from work to embrace motherhood. She delivered twins — a girl and a boy — in the UK last year and returned to India a couple of months ago. She says, “I suffered a miscarriage around seven years ago. It took me a while to recover from it and be healthy again. I was working constantly and one day, I realised that it would be a never-ending cycle if I didn’t take a break to start a family. I knew that I could come back to acting anytime.”While Sara is glowing with happiness in her social media posts, the new mommy says that it’s not been an easy journey. She shares, “I suffered from baby blues and my hormones were all over the place. It wasn’t easy to breast-feed two babies and three months into it, I was hospitalised for dehydration. While motherhood is one of the happiest experiences in a woman’s life, I wondered why every little thing affected me. I was tired and lethargic, and was crying every day. Though my husband (Arfeen) is a life coach, one can never train a close family member. So, I started taking therapy.”Seeking professional advice did help. Sara says, “One day, I decided to take charge of my life and I realised that I needed to step out, to begin with. It seemed difficult in the beginning, as I couldn’t step out of the room, let alone the house. Even dressing up took a lot of effort. I had to coach my mind and make conscious efforts to get over that phase. The most difficult part was getting used to my bloated body. Once I returned to India, five months after my delivery, I rested for about 20 days and started working out slowly. It’s important to lose postpartum weight the right way. I am way happier now and can’t wait to get back to acting, but it will depend on the kind of offers I get and how my babies react to me leaving for work.”Talking about losing postpartum weight, does she feel that the society puts pressure on a woman to look perfect post pregnancy? “I don’t let society put any pressure on me. After delivering twins, I am amazed by how God has made a woman’s body. How can I find faults in my body after I’ve given life? I will take my own time to let my body heal and get fit. I want to be fitter and healthier for myself and my babies, whose world revolves around me,” she signs off.

Title: Yukti Kapoor: I was tired of wearing saris and sindoor: Yukti Kapoor
Content: Television actress Yukti Kapoor , who rose to fame with the serial Agnifera, was in town to shoot for her next serial. Playing a cop in this serial, Yukti, says, “I had a wonderful experience in Agnifera. Through that show a lot of people in the television industry noticed me and I got more opportunities. It was great for me because I didn’t have to really wait to get another show after it, straight after Agnifera I was offered Namah wherein I played goddess Laxmi.” The actress said she consciously took up this role of a female cop in the serial Madam Sir. “I was tired of wearing those saris and sindoor and I had bawled my eyes out with glycerine. Now, I want to scare people, I want to yell my heart out,” she laughed. “On a serious note, I hope to inspire women and girls who are scared to speak their minds and be fearless. As far as female cops in India goes, I am quite afraid of them and I personally find them quite intimidating.Even though we have had iconic female cop characters on screen, Yukti further revealed that she was asked to watch male cops on screen instead of female cops. “I was asked to watch Amitabh Bachchan ’s Zanjeer to play a cop. I was told to copy his attitude as a cop instead of a female’s attitude from any film.”— With inputs from Yashi Agarwal

Title: Yukti Kapoor: I was tired of wearing saris and sindoor: Yukti Kapoor
Content:
Yukti Kapoor (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

Television actress Yukti Kapoor , who rose to fame with the serial Agnifera, was in town to shoot for her next serial. Playing a cop in this serial, Yukti, says, “I had a wonderful experience in Agnifera. Through that show a lot of people in the television industry noticed me and I got more opportunities. It was great for me because I didn’t have to really wait to get another show after it, straight after Agnifera I was offered Namah wherein I played goddess Laxmi.”

The actress said she consciously took up this role of a female cop in the serial Madam Sir. “I was tired of wearing those saris and sindoor and I had bawled my eyes out with glycerine. Now, I want to scare people, I want to yell my heart out,” she laughed. “On a serious note, I hope to inspire women and girls who are scared to speak their minds and be fearless. As far as female cops in India goes, I am quite afraid of them and I personally find them quite intimidating.

Even though we have had iconic female cop characters on screen, Yukti further revealed that she was asked to watch male cops on screen instead of female cops. “I was asked to watch Amitabh Bachchan ’s Zanjeer to play a cop. I was told to copy his attitude as a cop instead of a female’s attitude from any film.”

— With inputs from Yashi Agarwal

Title: ‘I had never thought that I would leave CRPF and become an actor’
Content: From the Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) to the small screen, it’s been a long journey for Rudra Kaushish . The actor, currently seen in the show, Dadi Amma Dadi Amma Maan Jaao !, was a sub-inspector in the police force for 12 years.So, why did he shift to acting? Rudra, who has been part of shows like Kullfi Kumarr Bajewala, Yeh Rishta Kya Kehlata Hai and Balika Vadhu , replies, “I had never thought about leaving CRPF and becoming an actor, but in 2007, I was forced to quit because of severe back pain. I then started looking for other employment opportunities, but was clear that I didn’t want a regular, nine-to-five job. While toying with the idea of starting a business venture, I came to Mumbai for some personal work. One day, a friend asked me to try acting and I started giving auditions. It happened suddenly.”Hailing from Jodhpur and with no connections in the industry, it wasn’t easy for Rudra to find a foothold. He recalls, “Initially, it was difficult to create a space for myself in the industry. For the first few years, I played small roles, which taught me the craft. However, after playing a negative cameo in Bhagyavidhaata , I started getting better offers. Now, I am enjoying my stint as an actor.”

Title: coronavirus: Coronavirus scare looms large over Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2 shooting in Lucknow
Content: With one confirmed positive case of Coronavirus in Lucknow, the scare of contracting the disease is looming large over everybody. And not immune to this scare is the team of the film Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2 which is shooting in Lucknow since last week. As a precautionary measure, director Anees Bazmee has made wearing face masks and using hand sanitizers mandatory for all on sets. Actor Govind Namdev , who is part of the film shares, “All precautionary measures are being taken during the shoot in the wake of the corona virus pandemic. We have been given masks and hand sanitizers while shooting and we all were wearing masks on the set.”A video posted by Kartik Aaryan on his social media account from the sets in Lucknow which shows him and the film crew wearing masks (BCCL/ @kartikaaryan)And while the crew and cast is taking all precautions, there are rumours that the film shooting may be postponed till further notice.The cast, which includes actors Tabu, Kartik Aaryan, Kiara Advani Rajpal Yadav and Rajesh Sharma took a day off from shoot on Friday after shooting throughout the night on Thursday at Mahmoodabad Palace in Sitapur district. Director Anees Bazmee, when asked if indeed the shooting will be cancelled, told us that the team was to discuss the matter on Friday evening. “We will all sit and have a meeting on what to do because we have a big unit and the schedule is also long. There are a lot of things involved, so we are yet to decide, which we will by today evening,” he said.Anees Bazmee at Mahmoodabad Palace (BCCL/ @aneesbazmee) Meanwhile, the local security people and the line producers have been put on guard. Talking to us a source from the unit said, “Till late Thursday night there was nothing that the shooting may be called off. But now even we are hearing that the producers and Anees sir are mulling over it. So let’s see.”

Title: Horses put their best foot forward for Army Commander’s Cup in Lucknow
Content:
An impressive band performance was put up by the army troops (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

The khukhri dance of the jawans had everyone in awe of them (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

(L) Lt Gen Iqroop Singh Ghuman (R) Maj Gen Pravesh Puri (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

(L) Ginny Ghuman and Heminder Puri (R) GP Singh and Samar Pundir (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

(L) Nayab and Abdullah Khan (R) Mukul Singhal (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

Padamini and Rita Pahwa (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

(L) Rajesh and Komal Singh (R) Rajneesh and Anjali Chopra (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

(L) Sabeen Farooq and Kavea Ghai (R) Sabiha and Naaz (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

(L) Swapna Nair and Lt Gen MU Nair (R) Vishal and Shaini (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

(L) Archna and Tarun Raj (R) Col Akshay and Naveena (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

The Army Commander’s Cup horse race was although a hurriedly put up affair but a mighty well managed one. With mostly people from the forces and their better halves present for the races, the Lucknow Race Course wasn’t lacking in any action. The sunny Sunday began with the band of the Gorkha Rifles putting up an impressive display followed by their troops showing off some dangerous moves with the khukhri dance.An impressive band performance was put up by the army troops (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)And while the ladies danced in between on the songs played by a civilian band, the horses got ready to gallop on the tracks. The first race was of the Indian bred horses which was easily won by Rani making the jockey Monu and owner Khwaja Atiq Ahmed proud.The khukhri dance of the jawans had everyone in awe of them (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)In the second race of the thoroughbreds, most were expecting the past two races winner Vijoy’s Joy to win this time too, but Dark Tiger proved to be the dark horse and easily cruised off ahead of the others much to the delight of owner Jaideep Narain Mathur .(L) Lt Gen Iqroop Singh Ghuman (R) Maj Gen Pravesh Puri (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)Apart from the winners collecting their trophies, a lot many other prizes were also doled out at the event by Lt Gen Iqroop Singh Ghuman and his wife Ginny and Lt Gen MU Nair and Swapna. While the Best Hat Male prize was clinched by Brig Bhargav, Hemi Puri walked away with the prize of the Best Hat Lady. Col Amit Dixit was adjudged the Best Dressed Gentleman while Priti Malaviya got the prize for being the Best Dressed Lady.(L) Ginny Ghuman and Heminder Puri (R) GP Singh and Samar Pundir (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)(L) Nayab and Abdullah Khan (R) Mukul Singhal (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)Padamini and Rita Pahwa (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)(L) Rajesh and Komal Singh (R) Rajneesh and Anjali Chopra (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)(L) Sabeen Farooq and Kavea Ghai (R) Sabiha and Naaz (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)(L) Swapna Nair and Lt Gen MU Nair (R) Vishal and Shaini (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)(L) Archna and Tarun Raj (R) Col Akshay and Naveena (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

Title: Dance your way to better mental health
Content: Think of the word "therapy" and you’re automatically picturing a room with a counsellor sitting on a couch in front of you, discussing mental health issues and solutions. While counselling sessions are important and helpful for those suffering from mental health problems, there are some who hesitate at the thought of opening up to someone verbally. Experts recommend alternative therapies for them and one that is slowly but gradually gaining popularity in India is Dance Movement Therapy (DMT).DMT is a type of therapy that uses the body, movement and dance as a way of expressing oneself and findings ways of exploring and addressing psychological problems or difficulties. Dance therapy gradually gained acceptance in the field of mental health.One of the pioneers of DMT in India and co-founder of Creative Movement Therapy Association of India (CMTAI), Tripura Kashyap recalls, "Though creative movement therapy started off as a form of treatment for war veterans and psychiatric patients, its scope and application gradually widened to embrace people with developmental, medical, social and physical impairments." She adds, "India has thousands of dance forms and it is worth exploring how these can be used to help people open up and express their mental health problems without the fear of being judged." DMT can also be the perfect outlet for many to deal with daily anger and frustration, say experts.Clients of any age can attend these therapy sessions to relieve their stress, improve their confidence & self-esteem, and to get over body image issues. "As a form of therapy it is not restricted to any specific clientele base. From neurotypicals to kids suffering from learning disorders and attention deficiency, DMT can help anyone," says Reetu Jain, co-founder of CMTAI. DMT can also leave a deep impact on people who have suffered from any kind of trauma and are not comfortable in opening up verbally."Attending a regular dance class is done with the intent to either learn, perform the art, improvise movements or to have a good time. But DMT uses the body and movement to foster communication and integrate physical, emotional functioning for clients/patients," explains Nishi Joshi, a licensed Dance Movement Psychotherapist. In DMT, each session looks unique depending on the clinician, clients, and setting.A typical DMT session is around 50-60 minutes long and has a definitive but loose structure. The first few minutes are spent checking verbally where the clients/patients interact with the facilitator and tell them how they are doing. Then begins the warm-up session followed by theme development, which is the most important part of the session. Theme development is the part where facilitator holds a safe space for the client to move and express theirselves. (The session varies from client to client.) The end of the session is dedicated to a verbal processing of the entire session where the clients are free to open up verbally.With talking about mental health still being considered a bit of a taboo subject across the globe, many people find opting for methods like DMT much easier. "Our first mode of expression, as we're born is through our body and without words. So movement is natural to us. Whereas it isn’t always easy to put words to how one is feeling, or thinking. That’s what makes DMT effective, where the client and therapist can have a dialogue without words and any taboo," explains Nishi Joshi, a licensed Dance Movement Therapist. As it might not be easy to express with words in a therapy session, movement therapy opens up the possibility of expressing through the body by holding a safe space for the client to move and create their own flow and rhythm."Workplace stress and anger issues are two things I am trying to fight. While DMT has helped me recognise some of it, my therapist believes that I have a long way to go. DMT has helped me more than speech therapy as I didn’t even know that I had a problem," says Muskan Kapoor, marketing professional from west Delhi."I like to go for DMT group sessions instead of getting one-on-one therapy. It makes me more comfortable. Getting to meet so many new people and rediscovering myself along with them is a very cathartic process and helps me connect with my inner self," says Jenika Agarwal, a corporate employee from Gurgaon.DMT is also being used as a co-curricular activity in educational settings nowadays and as adjunctive therapy in hospitals, special schools, halfway homes, and treatment centers. Some organisations in India provide diploma courses and hold workshops for the same.

The shutdown of Delhi theatres will have its effect in Noida and Gurgaon as well, as a huge section of moviegoers will now avoid going to cinema halls." Shaaminder Mallik, a distributor, adds, "We have information that other states are also planning to shut theatres. Most major films scheduled to release in April-May are likely to be postponed."S Bansal, a distributor in the Rajasthan-Delhi belt, says, "Other states like Haryana, Punjab and Rajasthan might also follow suit and shut down their theatres for a few weeks. It will take the business over a year to recover from that. Release dates will also get affected and the calendar will be disturbed in a big way and box office clashes might become inevitable."The spread of coronavirus and the resulting shutdown in Delhi will also affect the business of films that were released in the previous weeks. Yogesh Raizada of Wave Cinemas says, "Had the occupancy in cinema halls not dipped last week because of coronavirus scare, 'Baaghi 3' would have done even better."Ahmed Khan, director of 'Baaghi 3', says, "The safety of the audience is extremely important. We would never want their lives to be at risk. It’s unfortunate that the theatres in Delhi will be shut for a while now and that will affect the overall collections of my film, but some things are beyond our control. We must follow what the government bodies decide."Anubhav Sinha, whose directorial 'Thappad' is also still in cinemas, says, "Thappad has completed 80% of its run at the box office. Delhi contributes about 15% to the collections. That will be impacted but we have to live with it because logon ki jaan se badhkar kuch nahi hota. But we should not panic because that can just make the situation more difficult to handle. Apart from pulling down shutters of theatres in Delhi, governments across states and UTs need to educate people about this disease."— Inputs from Rachana Dubey

Title: coronavirus: Coronavirus scare looms large over Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2 shooting in Lucknow
Content:
A video posted by Kartik Aaryan on his social media account from the sets in Lucknow which shows him and the film crew wearing masks (BCCL/ @kartikaaryan)

Anees Bazmee at Mahmoodabad Palace (BCCL/ @aneesbazmee)

With one confirmed positive case of Coronavirus in Lucknow, the scare of contracting the disease is looming large over everybody. And not immune to this scare is the team of the film Bhool Bhulaiyaa 2 which is shooting in Lucknow since last week.As a precautionary measure, director Anees Bazmee has made wearing face masks and using hand sanitizers mandatory for all on sets. Actor Govind Namdev , who is part of the film shares, “All precautionary measures are being taken during the shoot in the wake of the corona virus pandemic. We have been given masks and hand sanitizers while shooting and we all were wearing masks on the set.”A video posted by Kartik Aaryan on his social media account from the sets in Lucknow which shows him and the film crew wearing masks (BCCL/ @kartikaaryan)And while the crew and cast is taking all precautions, there are rumours that the film shooting may be postponed till further notice.The cast, which includes actors Tabu, Kartik Aaryan, Kiara Advani Rajpal Yadav and Rajesh Sharma took a day off from shoot on Friday after shooting throughout the night on Thursday at Mahmoodabad Palace in Sitapur district. Director Anees Bazmee, when asked if indeed the shooting will be cancelled, told us that the team was to discuss the matter on Friday evening. “We will all sit and have a meeting on what to do because we have a big unit and the schedule is also long. There are a lot of things involved, so we are yet to decide, which we will by today evening,” he said.Anees Bazmee at Mahmoodabad Palace (BCCL/ @aneesbazmee)Meanwhile, the local security people and the line producers have been put on guard. Talking to us a source from the unit said, “Till late Thursday night there was nothing that the shooting may be called off. But now even we are hearing that the producers and Anees sir are mulling over it. So let’s see.”

Title: Coronavirus scare: Salman Khan and Hrithik Roshan postpone their International tours
Content: The World Health Organisation has declared Coronavirus as Pandemic. The virus is massively impacting the film industry. From ‘Sooryavanshi’ release being postponed to Salman Khan cancelling the international schedule of ‘Radhe’ – here’s how B-town is suffering from the Coronavirus outbreak.Now, according to the latest reports, Salman and Hrithik Roshan have cancelled their foreign tours. Reportedly, HR was supposed to have a meet and greet session with his fans in Chicago, Dallas, San Jose, New Jersey, Washington in the US from April 10 onwards. However, due to COVID-19 outbreak, the dates have been postponed and the new dates are not out yet.Even Salman who had planned for his annual concert in the US which was to be held from 3rd to 12 April, has cancelled the same.The report further stated that both the actors will announce the new dates once the outbreak gets contained.Coronavirus has brought the world to stand still. And all the industries are facing adverse effects of the same.Here in Maharashtra , the Chief Minister, Uddhav Thackeray announced the heath scare on Friday. A decision of keeping the cinema halls across Mumbai, Navi Mumbai, Thane, Nagpur, Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad closed until further notice was to tackle the COVID-19 outbreak, in which the state has seen over 15 positive cases.

Title: Coronavirus in Delhi: As screens go dark, cinema halls stare at loss of crores
Content: NEW DELHI: Roughly 150 cinema screens in Delhi have gone blank. The state government announced the closure of all cinema halls till March 31 in view of the risk posed by the novel coronavirus . The halls were already counting their losses with many movie releases being postponed and people wary of going to theatres. The two-week closure will affect not just the movie industry, but also cinema-associated industries such as retail and food and beverage outlets.Contrary to the belief that OTT, or streaming, platforms were weaning away cine-goers, theatre attendance was actually on the rise. An industry expert associated with a leading cinema chain estimates that around 2,000 people visit a multiplex on weekdays with the number touching 3,000-3,500 on a weekend if a popular movie is being screened. This translates, he explained, into roughly one lakh people seeing movies in the city’s multiplexes every day and spending on average Rs 500 per person for tickets and snacks. “Going to a movie also includes parking cost, fuel cost and taxes on movie tickets and food. Entertainment, especially movies, is a big revenue and economic contributor,” he said.Amit Sharma, MD of Miraj Cinemas, which as 128 screens across India, felt a shutdown in Delhi would mean a loss of up to Rs 20 crore per week for the industry. “There are new releases every week. There are movies that are in their second or third weeks and are having a good run alongside sought-after regional movies. All these earnings come to a standstill in case of a shutdown and impact the movie industry as a whole,” he said.Sharma though conceded that the situation created by the novel coronavirus was beyond anyone’s control and that he would not lay off any employee but bear their cost. “When the world enjoys movies on the weekends, our staff almost never have an off. This is the time to stand by them,” he asserted.Employees at other cinemas in the city are worried about their jobs as the communication from their employers hasn’t been as clear as Sharma’s. Most of them reported to work on Friday. Some who spoke to TOI on condition of anonymity complained that there had been no clear direction on whether to sit at home or report for work. “This is not a time when one can afford to lose a job loss because there aren’t other outlets hiring anyone for the next few weeks,” said a cinema employee.Most advance bookings for the closure period have been refunded, including those that were bought at the cinema counters, which are being refunded on site. Majority of the phone calls made to the cinemas on Friday related to refunds. Effort was made to explain that refunds were being processed at the earliest either by the cinemas or by the popular ticket booking platforms, a cinema worker revealed.PVR Cinemas, which has 68 screens in Delhi, stated that it believed this was a temporary crisis and remained optimistic about the film business in India. Sharma similarly said he expected things to pick up post Good Friday on April 10 and normalcy returning from May with the virus successfully contained across the globe by then.

Title: Coronavirus cases in India: Fewer cases, but India becomes 5th country to isolate coronavirus
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: India has become the fifth country to successfully isolate a strain of the novel coronavirus. China, Japan, Thailand and the US did it before.Simply put, it means that scientists have been able to obtain a pure sample of the virus that has been contained outside the human body.The scientific success is important because it will help in developing drugs, vaccines and rapid diagnostic test kits, the director general of Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), Dr Balram Bhargava, said.He added that the isolation of the novel coronavirus, the agent responsible for the ongoing outbreak of Covid-19, wasn't easy as India had fewer positive cases when they started the project."Total 21 throat swab and nasal swab samples were examined for this purpose. Of that, 11 tested positive and eight strains could be isolated from among them. They are 99.98% identical with the strain of the virus that led to outbreaks in Wuhan in China," said Dr R R Gangakhedkar, chief epidemiologist at ICMR. He added that now scientists can test whether a drug will work against the virus or not to develop rapid diagnostic kits.The isolation of this virus will also help in understanding the biology and evolution of the novel coronavirus, say ICMR experts. Till date, there is no cure for Covid-19. Also, there is no preventive vaccination.Anti-HIV drugs lopinavir and ritonavir have been tried on some Covid-19 patients, including the Italian national admitted at Sawai Man Singh hospital in Jaipur, with promising results. But the scientists said it is too early to conclude the efficacy.Most patients are only receiving symptomatic treatment, they added.Recently, in a draft report made public by the World Health Organisation (WHO), the experts claimed that Remdesivir, a drug developed for use against ebola, which caused major outbreaks in remote villages in Central Africa in 2014, is most promising for treating Covid-19.This is because the in-vitro (tests performed in test tube) and in-vivo (tests performed in living organism) data for the drug is available for coronaviruses. "Further, studies in mice using Remdesivir showed superior efficacy over Kaletra+IFNbeta," the draft report said.The report added that a clinical trial is being planned in China to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the drug in association with optimised standard of care, as the next step. Remdesivir slows the infection of healthy cells by blocking viral replication.The WHO expert also reviewed drugs used in HIV treatment - lopinavir and ritonavir - either alone or in combination with IFNbeta. It stated that among the repurposed drugs under consideration, this would be the suitable second option for rapid implementation in clinical trials.The use of convalescent sera-serum obtained from someone who has recovered from an infectious disease and considered to be especially rich in antibodies against the infectious agent of the disease could also be an option, said the expert group. However, the report added: "...but it remains to be defined if sufficient amounts of sera with high antibodies titres could be feasibly collected, using concentration and purification processes."

Title: UP govt brings ordinance to recover dues from protesters
Content: LUCKNOW: The UP government on Friday empowered itself to recover the cost of property damaged during protests, riots and rallies from the accused by promulgating the 'UP Recovery of Public and Private Property Ordinance'.The ordinance was cleared by the Yogi Adityanath cabinet even as a three-judge Supreme Court bench is slated to hear the state's special leave petition next week challenging the Allahabad high court order which asked the government to remove hoardings carrying names, pictures and addresses of 57 protesters accused of damaging properties during anti-CAA violence in Lucknow on December 19.After large-scale violence in December during the protests in which property worth crores was damaged, the government had served recovery notices on the accused, citing a 2009 order of the Supreme Court.State finance minister Suresh Khanna told newspersons after the cabinet meeting that the SC, in reference to writ petition 77/2007, had said in 2009 that a strict law was needed to recover costs if private or public property had been damaged during protests like political rallies, strikes and sit-ins."Following that order, we have cleared the ordinance. The next step is to draft the rules for this law which will also be cleared by the cabinet," Khanna said, adding that in the 2009 order, the SC had talked about constituting a recovery tribunal to recover losses to government and private properties in political and illegal agitations in the country.Although the rules for recovery of cost of damage to property are yet to be framed, a UP government source said that "posting of pictures and other details of accused in such cases" is likely to be included.As anti-CAA protests broke out across UP, Yogi had said that the government would recover the cost for the destruction of property from those who indulged in violence. The government served more than 500 notices on people across the state in the aftermath of the December violence. Out of these, 57 notices were issued just in Lucknow.After SC's 2009 order, the Allahabad high court also issued a similar order on December 2, 2010 which was followed by a government order (GO) on January 8, 2011 during the BSP regime. The 2011 GO said: "...the damage suffered to public property shall be assessed and the concerned department, local body, public corporation etc, i.e. the owner of the property, shall file a claim for realisation of such amount from the political parties/persons (who called for agitation/procession in which damage takes place)".It adds that if the person or persons against whom the claim is filed were responsible for the loss, "the amount assessed and awarded by such competent authority shall be realised, if not paid on its own by the person responsible within such time as directed, as arrears of land revenue".The Allahahad high court took suo motu cognizance of these 'name and shame' hoardings and directed the government to pull down the banners immediately. However, the government challenged the order in the Supreme Court.Referring to SC's 2009 order, government spokesperson Sidharth Nath Singh said: "The SC had asked for a law to be made and we are only respecting that. The CM's decision to challenge the HC order will ensure that such incidents of violent protests will not take place in the state again."

Title: Farooq freed after 7 months, hopes rise for Omar, Mufti
Content:
Former chief minister of J&K and Lok Sabha MP Farooq Abdullah along with his wife addressing media after his r... Read More

NEW DELHI/SRINAGAR: In the first release of a former Jammu and Kashmir chief minister, who has been kept in detention since the nullification of Article 370, National Conference patriarch and Srinagar MP Farooq Abdullah on Friday stepped out of his Gupkar Road home after seven months.

Abdullah, 82, was booked under the Public Safety Act, on grounds that he had made speeches that could inflame public sentiment. His release, official sources said, could set the stage for his son Omar Abdullah and PDP’s Mehbooba Mufti , both former CMs, also being freed — perhaps signalling a political thaw.

He parried questions from reporters on his future plans, saying he would “prefer silence till others detained under PSA are released”. With wife Molly by his side, he said, “I am free... Hope other political leaders will be released soon. I thank all parliamentarians who fought for my freedom. Will be able to take a decision on future only after other leaders are released.”

Asked if he would continue to speak out against nullification of Articles 370 and 35A of the Constitution to revoke J&K’s special status, Farooq said, “I will go to Parliament and raise my voice there.”

There had been reports of a political outreach to those held in detention at their homes with former RAW chief AS Dulat meeting Abdullah. There were indications that NC and PDP, the two main regional parties in the Valley, might consider participating in panchayat elections if their members were released. There was also a limit, in political terms, to the length of detention, particularly as the situation has been largely peaceful.

“The release of Farooq Abdullah and further plans to review detention orders of Mehbooba and Omar under J&K Public Safety Act (PSA) indicate the situation in J&K has returned to complete normalcy,” said a central government functionary. The detention order issued under PSA against Mehbooba and Omar in early February has a validity of three months.

Sources said political activity was already on with former PDP, NC and Congress MLAs floating Apni Party. “The release of top leaders of NC and PDP will now restore political activity in full and also ensure they are part of consultations on proposed delimitation of assembly and parliamentary seats,” the functionary said.

Abdullah’s release comes as there are indications that the Centre might consider scheduling panchayat polls that were put off recently. The emergence of Apni Party under former PDP member Altaf Bukhari, with the support of some 40 former legislators, has stirred the waters in the Valley and given NC and PDP something to think about.

Principal secretary (home) Shaleen Kabra’s order announcing the administration’s decision came after Abdullah completed six months of detention under a law which, ironically enough, was enacted in 1978 by his father Sheikh Abdullah.

Though the NC chairman had been under house arrest since August 5 last year, it wasn’t until September 15 that the administration invoked PSA to extend his custody by three months. The move came hours before the Supreme Court was to hear a petition filed by MDMK’s Vaiko, challenging Abdullah’s detention. On December 13, the administration issued a fresh order extending his detention by another three months.

TOI has learnt that the delimitation commission — constituted last week with former SC judge Justice Ranjana Prakash Desai as chairperson and election commissioner Sushil Chandra and state CEO as ex-officio members — is likely to begin its work towards the end of this month. Sources indicated that the panel, which will also be handling delimitation of seats in four other states — Assam, Manipur, Nagaland and Arunachal Pradesh — may take between six-eight months to complete its work.

Only after the delimitation award is notified can fresh assembly elections be held in the UT of J&K. Post-delimitation, the J&K assembly will have a total of 114 seats, up from 107 at present.

Title: Working at jet pace to check major coronavirus outbreak: Harsh Vardhan
Content:
Health minister

Harsh Vardhan

tells

TOI

the government has worked with ‘speed, scale and determination coupled with best practices’ to respond to the threat posed by Covid-19. Excerpts from an interview to

Sushmi Dey

:

What measures are being taken to prevent an outbreak of

?

Is there enough facility for treatment and to quarantine suspected cases?

How many additional beds have been set aside for Covid-19 patients?

What is being done to prevent shortage of critical preventive items like masks, sanitisers?

What is the status of availability of medicines in view of fears of a shortage of API supplies from China?

How are you ensuring awareness among people about coronavirus, particularly in rural areas?

How is the Centre coordinating with states on containing Covid-19?

Do we have enough testing facilities for disease?

Is there any plan to get on board the paramilitary and the Army to combat the spread of the virus?

More on Covid-19

We took a comprehensive and coordinated approach to engage the entire GoI machinery in containing the situation. With the PM setting out the approach, we have worked at jet pace and in mission mode as far as our preparedness levels are concerned. We are taking a number of measures to ensure the impact from imported cases is controlled and, at the same time, the localised spread is restricted.Firstly, we are focusing on comprehensive sanitisation at entry points like airports, seaports and border crossings. Since March 4, 2020, we have undertaken universal screening for all international passengers coming to India. Teams of specialist doctors have been stationed at all airports to ensure effective screening and arrangement for isolation in attached hospitals. Screening of passengers has also been initiated at 12 major sea ports and 65 non-major ports to identify passengers and crew coming from China and to isolate if found symptomatic.Government has initiated screening at all integrated check posts with bordering countries in collaboration with states of UP, Uttarakhand, West Bengal, Sikkim and Bihar as well as Sashastra Seema Bal and Land Port Authorities.We are using stringent 'contact surveillance' for cases having travel history from all major Covid-19 affected countries. Through the Integrated Disease Surveillance network, all such persons were tracked and as on March 13, 2020, a total of 42,000 individuals were brought under 'community surveillance' and state and district surveillance officers and rapid response teams are monitoring them daily.On receipt of requests from around 11 countries - Maldives, Myanmar, Bangladesh, China, South Africa, USA, Sri Lanka, Nepal, South Africa, Peru and Madagascar - we brought back 43 foreign nationals from Wuhan and five from Japan.We focused on identifying gaps and building capacity of our health response system. We have done a massive capacity building exercise in the last 55 days in epidemiology, surveillance, laboratory support, clinical management, non-pharmaceutical interventions, infection prevention and risk communication. We are countering misinformation campaigns and rumours on social media and other platforms. So far, around 25,000 calls (011-23978046) have been attended including around 981 international calls.States and central government hospitals have been advised for assessment of isolation and critical care facilities. Sufficient isolation beds and supplies have been made available in tertiary facilities across India. I have also held meetings with leading private hospitals and they have all assured all support. Nearly 14,000 quarantine beds have been identified so far and more are being identified.As on date, around 17,500 beds are available at various government facilities at central and state government level. Additional facilities will be made available as and when required.We have asked leading manufacturers of masks, personal equipment to share details of production capacities, stocks in hand. Details of all manufacturers have been shared with principal secretaries of all states and UTs to enable them to contact suppliers and undertake procurement. Sufficient supplies are available to handle any situation that might arise.We have stocks of medicines varying from four months to nine months depending on the medicine. We are given to understand that China has restarted its plants and started supply of medicines from second week of February 2020 from all their provinces except Hubei.We have sent 117.2 crore SMS's. Dos and Don'ts are being played on every mobile call. Ads have been issued in 156 newspapers. MyGov weekly mailers have been sent to 70 lakh users and push notifications have been sent to another 20 lakh users. We have also asked for display of dos and don'ts at post offices, railway stations, airports, other public places.In rural areas, we have adopted a two-pronged strategy. Eight central teams have been deputed to the rural areas adjoining our international borders in UP, Uttarakhand, West Bengal, Sikkim and Bihar to review activities at the border crossings, conduct gram sabhas and facilitate awareness and risk communication to the communities. Elsewhere we have sought support of the ministry of panchayati raj to facilitate awareness generation. We are also utilising the network of National Disaster Management Authority to spread awareness.We are regularly reviewing the emerging situation and preparedness with the states and UTs. Along with Union health secretary, I have been organising regular meetings with state/UT health ministers, health secretaries and other senior officials. On Holi (March 10) I had called up health ministers of coronavirus-affected states to get feedback about the condition of patients and problems being faced in availability of required supplies of personal protective equipment, masks and capacity building of health workers.NIV, Pune is the nodal laboratory. As part of Indian Council of Medical Research's preparedness for emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases, NIV has established capacity for molecular diagnosis of Covid-19. Next generation sequencing has also been established. The facility for collection and testing of clinical samples has been established in 52 labs. 57 labs have been identified as sample collection centres. The network is being further expanded.At the highest level, PM Modi is reviewing the situation on regular basis with representatives of all central ministries.

Title: Covid-19: PM urges Saarc nations to join forces; members welcome move, Pak mum
Content:
I would like to propose that the leadership of SAARC nations chalk out a strong strategy to fight Coronavirus. We… https://t.co/PwPT5K7G8c — Narendra Modi (@narendramodi) 1584085672000

Thank you for the great initiative Shri @narendramodi - #LKA is ready to join the discussion & share our learnings… https://t.co/XpVnPRvzbq — Gotabaya Rajapaksa (@GotabayaR) 1584091452000

haats

Thank you PM @narendramodi for taking the initiative on this important endeavor. Covid 19 requires collective effor… https://t.co/zMNjzLESuf — Ibrahim Mohamed Solih (@ibusolih) 1584092466000

More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: As the world battles the coronavirus pandemic, Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday launched a diplomatic initiative by inviting all SAARC nations to jointly combat the global health crisis.In a tweet that created a huge buzz through South Asia, Modi said, “I would like to propose that the leadership of SAARC nations chalk out a strong strategy to fight Coronavirus. We could discuss, via video conferencing, ways to keep our citizens healthy. Together, we can set an example to the world, and contribute to a healthier planet.”Sources said, the video conference, would be set up in the next few days.Modi’s invoking of SAARC was itself significant as in the past three years, the government has consistently overlooked SAARC, even promoting other regional arrangements like BIMSTEC. No SAARC summit has been held since November, 2014 in Kathmandu. India refused to participate in the 2016 summit in Islamabad after the Uri terror attack. No summit happened in 2018 either.The PM’s invitation was accepted by all SAARC nations, except Pakistan which had not responded till late Friday evening. Sri Lankan President Gotabaya Rajapaksa responded in a tweet: “Thank you for the great initiative Shri @narendramodi- #LKA is ready to join the discussion & share our learnings & best practices and to learn from other #SAARC members. Let’s unite in solidarity during these trying times and keep our citizens safe.”The reason for the Indian outreach is perhaps the extrenely porous borders which could undermine efforts of one country by flow of people and goods. Wagah and Attari borders with Pakistan are open as also borderwith Bangladesh in Meghalaya. So, it makes sense for all countries of the region to coordinate their actions and responses, as one official said, “contain and control” should be the mainstay during the crisis.President of the Maldives Ibrahim Mohamed “Ibu” Solih said, “Thank you PM @narendramodi for taking the initiative on this important endeavor. Covid 19 requires collective effort to defeat it. Maldives welcomes this proposal and would fully support such a regional effort.”Nepal’s Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli said,“I welcome the idea advanced by Prime Minister Modiji @narendramodi for chalking out a strong strategy by the leadership of the SAARC nations to fight Coronavirus. My government is ready to work closely with SAARC member-states to protect our citizens from this deadly disease.”In his response, Bhutan PM Lotay Tshering said, “This is what we call leadership. As members of this region, we must come together in such times. Smaller economies are hit harder, so we must coordinate. With your leadership, I have no doubt we will see immediate and impactful outcome. Looking forward to the video conference.”By evening, governments of Afghanistan and Bangladesh had also accepted the invitation. Bangladesh’s junior foreign minister Shahriar Alam tweeted, “HPM Sheikh Hasina welcomes the proposal and look forward to a constructive dialogue with @narendramodi @ibusolih @PM_Nepal @PMBhutan @GotabayaR n others HOSs/HOGs who already consented to discuss way forward at this testing times for the region and the world.”Modi’s new outreach raised hopes for revival of SAARC. However, sources said the potential collaboration would be under the regional rubric and this would not be extended to other areas. India has refused to be part of SAARC as long as Pakistan engages in cross-border terrorism.

Title: Edtech cos extend free online learning amid corona scare
Content: Chennai: With schools shutting down in some cities as a result of Coronavirus outbreak, ed tech companies in the K12 space are smelling an opportunity.Some are offering free live online classes, while few others are doing it at a subsidised rates. Schools in Delhi, Kerala and Bengaluru are shut amid increase in the number of Covid-19 cases.Online tutoring platform Vedantu is providing free live classes — which are usually paid — for all its courses, including IIT preparation modules. The live sessions are available at Rs 10 to Rs 900/ hour based on personalisation and class levels. The crash course for IIT can cost upto Rs 30,000.It is also in talks with schools to offer platform support so that teachers can ‘teach live’ for free. The educational institutions can either use the platform for their own teachers to take classes or access the platform’s existing content for free.“We are here to support by making our platform free during this crucial time. The students can study from the safety of their home,” said Vamsi Krishna, CEO, Vedantu. Toppr, an online learning app for classes 5-12, is providing free access to their live classes until May. Services worth up to Rs 20,000 are now being made free on the app. Byjus on the other hand is offering free access to its learning app until the end of April. “Considering the rigour of the exam season, access to the learning program will further assist students continue with their preparation for the year-end examinations,” a statement from Byjus said. Another platform Educational Initiatives (EI) is offering a 60-day free access to its Mindspark maths app for school children across various boards.In the competitive exam space, Unacademy and Gradeup, are also increasing their free lessons to those appearing for UPSC, banking and railway exams. While Gradeup is doubling the number of free videos, Unacademy is pooling in its educators to offer 20,000 free live classes.Gaurav Munjal, CEO, Unacademy said that this service will be available until the end of March and if the Covid-19 scare does not die down, the period will be extended to May.

Title: Amid corona fear, BJP MLA asks people not to wear masks
Content:
Gorakhpur: As coronavirus fear spreads, BJP MLA from Gorakhpur Radha Mohan Das Agarwal has urged people not to resort to panic buying of masks.

“Common people don’t need to wear expensive masks... Most of the people buy them due to lack of awareness and deceitful marketing of masks. Panic-stricken parents are buying exorbitant N-95 and surgical masks but they are not required,” Agarwal said.

“Only Covid-19 suspects or those suffering from coronavirus or medical or paramedical staff of hospitals should wear these masks,” said Agrawal, who is also a pediatrician.

In view of the rising positive cases in India and Uttar Pradesh not remaining unscathed by the global epidemic, hand sanitizers and face masks have vanished from chemist shops in the city due to panic buying. A large number of chemist shops have run out of stock and manufacturers are yet to replenish stock as demand saw a sudden spike in the past few days.

Most of the shops have displayed ‘no mask and no sanitizer’ boards.

Title: All 5 Rajya Sabha candidates from Bihar set to get elected unopposed
Content:
Nitish Kumar with Harivansh Narayan Singh (second from right), Ramnath Thakur (left) and Vivek Thakur (right) ... Read More

PATNA: All three NDA candidates for Rajya Sabha, including deputy chairman of the Upper House of Parliament Harivansh Narayan Singh, filed their nomination papers in the state assembly on Friday.

Senior NDA functionaries, including CM Nitish Kumar, deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi, JD(U) state president Bashishtha Narayan Singh and state BJP president Dr Sanjay Kumar Jaiswal, accompanied them in the chamber of the state assembly secretary Bateshwar Nath Pandey.

While Harivansh is the nominee of the JD(U), the two other NDA candidates are Ram Nath Thakur from the JD(U) and Vivek Thakur from the BJP. Several senior ministers, including Bijendra Prasad Yadav, Shrawan Kumar, Nand Kishore Yadav and Mangal Pandey were also present on the occasion.

With two RJD nominees Prem Chand Gupta and Amrendra Dhari Singh having already filed their nomination papers on Thursday, there are altogether five candidates to fill the equal number of seats that would fall vacant next month.
