Lalu actually believes in use and throw policy and people need to be cautious. Now, the people of Bihar will decide whether to caste vote in favour of such leaders or not?” Binu said. He further said his party will be contesting on all the 243 seats in the upcoming state assembly election.

Talking to an electronic media channel earlier, Sharad said he will be soon coming to Bihar and hold talks with his alliance partners and discuss the ‘sehat’ (health) of Mahagatbandhan.

Sharad had already said that he was not interested in state politics and will be doing politics from the Centre.

Title: Bihar Diwas celebrations postponed due to coronavirus scare
Content: PATNA: The state government on Friday postponed Bihar Diwas celebrations, which were to be organised from March 22 to 24, in view of coronavirus threat. Many departments of the state government, including Bihar State Tourism Development Corporation (BSTDC) and Bihar State Disaster Management Authority (BSDMA), had already initiated bidding process for preparing pavilions and stalls.Chief secretary Deepak Kumar said the annual event would not be celebrated from March 22 this year. “All mass events, including sports and other cultural programmes, have been postponed. The date for Bihar Diwas celebrations will be announced in the coming weeks,” he said.Sanjay Kumar Singh, state project officer of Bihar Education Project Council (BEPC) said, “It’s not possible to organise the three-day fest in the prevailing scenario. The situation is quite sensitive right now and holding events involving mass gatherings will only increase risk of spread of virus. As of now, we are waiting for situation to normalise. Thereafter, a date will be finalised by the state government for celebrating Bihar Diwas,” he said.Singh added that all government departments have been asked to call off the bidding process regarding activities and programmes for Bihar Diwas. “Installation of tents had started at Gandhi Maidan, where the main event was to be organised. All firms have been instructed to stop the preparations and dismantle the tents, main stage and barricading at the main venue and other places,” he said.

Title: Covid-19 scare: No biometric attendance at Patna University
Content: PATNA: The Patna University (PU) has postponed its examinations scheduled for Saturday, vice-chancellor Rash Bihari Prasad Singh said.The PU has also decided to suspend the system of biometric attendance for its teachers, officers and non-teaching staff till further orders in order to help prevent spread of deadly coronavirus on the campus. A notification issued by PU, however, states that the university people would continue to mark the manual attendance in their respective attendance registers.PU registrar Manoj Kumar Mishra said teachers, officers and employees of the university would report to their duties as usual. All seminars and conferences scheduled during the next fortnight have been postponed. The two-day state-level workshop on curriculum revision scheduled for March 16 and 17 has been postponed for an indefinite period, said the registrar.Meanwhile, with a view to safeguarding its students and faculty members from coronavirus, the National Institute of Technology-Patna has also suspended the practice of biometric attendance till March 31. All functions at NIT-P have been postponed. According to an advisory, if any student is suffering from cold, cough, fever or flu, he/she should stay at home.

Title: Coronavirus in West Bengal: Seats go empty, theatres may shut down for now
Content: KOLKATA: The lockdown on Delhi theatres till March 31 has made exhibitioners in Bengal wonder if a similar call needs to be taken here as well. The “sharp dip” in footfall after the global outbreak of coronavirus and paucity of big Hindi movie releases have forced many Bengal theatres to consider staying shut for a while. The final call is expected to be taken by Sunday.Ratan Saha, the chairman of the exhibitors’ section of the Eastern India Motion Pictures’ Association, has noticed a “50% dip” in sales. “As it is, single-screen theatres don’t do good business. And now, most people are not even going to the theatres. So, what’s the point in keeping the outlets open if there are no patrons? It is better to shut down and use this time for renovation,” Saha said.Navin Choukhani, owner of Navina, noticed a sharp drop in footfall since Thursday. “For the first-day show of ‘Angrezi Medium’, we had less than 50 viewers whereas the capacity is 800. As the news of the global outbreak spread, people stopped coming for movies. I feel that, irrespective of a notification, it is better to shut down,” Choukhani added. In his opinion, it makes sense to be safe than sorry. “We are monitoring the situation very closely and on Sunday we shall take a final call on whether to run the shows or suspend them till the situation improves,” he said.Suranjan Paul, owner of Minar, Bijoli and Chhabighar, said, “People are cautious about their health. At present, I have noticed a drop in sales.”The nCoV fear has also hit the release of movies. The release of the Akshay Kumar-starrer ‘Sooryavanshi’ has been postponed. In a statement, Rohit Shetty Picturez said the film, which was supposed to release on March 24, will be back when “the time is right”. The release of ‘Sir’ — a March 20 release starring Tillotama Shome — has also been postponed keeping “public health concerns and the advisory from the health ministry” in mind.Arijit Dutta, the owner of Priya Cinemas, said, “One can’t run a theatre while incurring heavy losses. There is a 30% dip in sales. Additionally, getting good content will be an issue since most of the movies have been postponed. Many single screens run on laser-thin margins. But if they shut down once, I wonder if they will be able to reopen.”Saha is equally worried about getting content. “We can’t run our theatres only on the basis of footfalls generated by screening Bengali movies. We need good content from Bollywood. Currently, I am in Tripura where the situation is equally bad,” Saha added.

Title: Covid-19 scare: Food delivery apps issue safety tips for staff, patrons
Content: KOLKATA: While ordering food on apps gets you your favourite dishes at your doorstep, it has also been ferrying the nCoV fear to foodies’ homes. To put customers at ease, delivery apps Swiggy and Zomato have issued a set of instructions for employees and customers, advising prevention measures, including an option for the latter to get food dropped off at their doorstep instead of having to receive it directly from the delivery partner.In an e-mail sent to customers, Swiggy has listed a series of steps taken by it to maintain a “safe and healthy environment”. It says that it has asked its delivery partners to self-quarantine in case they have symptoms and they will be provided free medical consultation and will receive financial support during the period of recovery.“Additionally, you may ask the delivery partner to leave the package by the door (in case of online payment) in case you are unwell or prefer so,” the e-mail said.Zomato, too, has been utilizing its partner app, as well as SMS services, to broadcast WHO’s best practices and important information such as Covid-19 testing laboratory locations as issued by the ministry of health. It has issued a similar guideline for stakeholders too. “We are using multiple channels of communication to sensitize our employees, users, restaurants, as well as delivery partners. We have advised all our employees to exercise their right and best judgement to work from home and have also created an internal emergency response team to reach out to for support,” said a Zomato spokesperson.She added that Zomato has always had an option on the app to add cooking instructions for the restaurants and delivery instructions for the partner, including having the packet dropped off at the doorstep. “In case you want to avoid contact with our delivery partner, you can request Zomato Valet to leave your package at the door via delivery instructions on our app. Please note that this will only work on orders paid online,” the Zomato e-mail said.The company is also sharing videos with its partners so that they can “focus on their well-being while ensuring the safe handling of food,” added the spokesperson.Both firms, however, said there has been no change in their volume of orders. “Our business has not been affected and we are confident that with the right practices and adequate social distancing, we can help curb the spread of Covid-19. We cannot emphasise enough on washing your hands properly before you eat any kind of food — whether cooked at home or ordered on Zomato,” said a Zomato spokesperson.

Title: NMC begins to demolish rooftop restros, structures
Content:
Nagpur: Finally, Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has started to demolish the unauthorized rooftop restaurants across the city. Rooftop restaurant on the terrace of Aangan Gajali Restaurant and Bar at Takli Sim, Hingna Road, was demolished on Friday along with Mi Marathi Hotel located on South Ambazari Road.

Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe has reportedly directed officials of enforcement department, town planning department and the ten zones to demolish remaining 21 rooftop restaurants declared fire-unsafe by the Fire and Emergency Services Department and other unauthorized constructions.

The team led by deputy commissioner Mahesh Moroney, assistant commissioner Raju Bhivgade and others demolished sheds, seating arrangements and kitchen constructed on terrace of G+2 storeyed Aangan Gajali Restaurant and Bar. After demolition, NMC slapped a penalty of Rs15,015 on the owner for expenditure incurred in demolition.

NMC Laxmi Nagar zone had served notices to the rooftop restaurant on November 24, 2016, and March 31, 2018, and declared it unauthorized. But further action was not taken.

During the ongoing budget session, MLC Jogendra Kawade had submitted a starred question following which the state’s urban development department (UDD) sought information from NMC. After getting the civic body’s reply that fire department has declared 22 rooftop restaurants as fire-unsafe, the UDD has on March 6 questioned NMC’s inaction and directed it to submit action taken report for building bylaws violations under Maharashtra Regional and Town Planning (MRTP) Act.

Mundhe, on March 6, reportedly directed officials to inspect and initiate action under MRTP Act immediately. Mundhe also slammed officials of these departments for neglecting action for so long.

After turning a blind eye for years, the fire department inspected and issued notices to 22 rooftop restaurants after Kamala Mills fire incident, which claimed 14 lives and injured several in Mumbai on December 29, 2017.

As per a press release issued by NMC, remaining 21 rooftop restaurants are at Hotel Pride on Airport Square, Tuli Imperial at Ramdaspeth, Amarjeet Resort at Somalwada, Rosseta Elite Club at Ajni, 39 Height Roof Tower at Manish Nagar, Seven Suites, Coriander Leaf, Villa at Abhyankar Nagar, Patiala House, Mocha Sky at Kannamwar Nagar, Roof 9 at Dharampeth, Chill and Green at Sitabuldi, Carnation Open Restaurant, Shijim Kitchen on Mount Road, Shri Vali 501 Open Restaurant at Dharampeth, Heaven Highlife, Warhadi That at Dhantoli, Hotel Shravan at Jhansi Rani square, Magic Food Court at Jaripatka, T3 on Amravati Road, and The Behinds The Bar on Hingna Road.

However, the civic body has continued to overlook residential bungalows turned into restaurants and lounges in various parts of the city. Also, NMC has not demolished over 2,000 structures despite serving notices in last five or more years.

IAN

* NMC used to serve notice for unauthorized constructions

* Many restaurants on terraces of hotels and commercial buildings across city overlooked for years

* Rules prohibit such use of rooftops

* Kamala Mills fire incident claimed 14 lives in December 2017

* Fire department inspected and served notices to 22 rooftop restaurants

* Following a case in HC, fire department declared all fire-unsafe last month

* UDD directed NMC to inspect building violations

* Civic chief ordered immediate inspection and action

* NMC demolished rooftop restaurant on terrace of Aangan Gajali Restaurant and Bar at Takli Sim, Hingna Road

* Also Mi Marathi Hotel on South Ambazari Road was demolished

* Mundhe also directed action against remaining 21 rooftop restaurants and unauthorized constructions

Title: Forest dept registers offence in murrum excavation case
Content:
Nagpur: The forest department finally registered preliminary offence report (POR) against Samruddhi Mahamarg contractor Afcons Infrastructure Limited for excavation of murrum from notified reserve forest land situated at mouza Kotumba, Selu tehsil, Wardha district. Chief conservator of forests P Kalyan Kumar also inspected the destroyed forest land on Friday.

Range forest officer AS Talhan told TOI that Hingni forest division has registered POR against Afcons. The forest department has registered POR under section 26 of The Indian Forest Act 1927 for destruction to forest land.

TOI had been reporting about excavation of murrum without any permission from various types of lands for construction of Nagpur-Mumbai Super Expressway since August last year.

Under RTI, Sandip Khedkar came to know that khasra no. 206 of mouza Kotumba was a forest land and social forestry department had planted 15,200 saplings on it and on khasra no 210 in 1989. TOI was the first to report on December 9, 2019 about murrum excavated from forest land with khasra no. 206 of mouza Kotumba. Khedkar had lodged complaints in this regard with forest department in December last year.

Citing a starred question in the state legislative council, Selu tehsildar Mahendra Sonone had written a letter to forest as well as social forestry departments. On Khedkar’s complaint, Selu police had also written to the forest department on February 20. Despite this, the forest department failed to take an action.

TOI on March 4 had reported that Wardha district administration omitted three pieces of lands, including forest land with khasra no. 206 of mouza Kotumba, for fine levied on Afcons. The administration assured to carry out survey on two lands owned by it — khasra no. 7 of mouza Itala reserved as zudpi jungle and khasra no. 65 of mouza Giroli which is a hillock. Also, the administration reportedly sent a letter to the forest department for inspection on the latter’s land with khasra no. 206.

The forest department then started survey of khasra no. 206 from March 6. Wardha deputy conservator of forest Sunil Sharma on March 12 had told TOI about murrum excavated from this piece of forest land.

The team of forest department continued the survey to know exact excavation in this land which is 4.68 hectares in total.

Khedkar had obtained documents from land records department on March 9 and came to know that khasra nos. 293/1 of 0.6 hectares and 293/2 of 50.71 hectares are also forest lands. The state government had handed over these two lands to forest on May 30, 1997. He had to say excavation also done on these two lands.

Afcons has been repeatedly denying its involvement in any sort of illegal excavation whatsoever. The company also alleged it is being unnecessarily targeted and harassed with a malafide intent to impede smooth execution of Samruddhi Mahamarg, which is a project of public interest.

It is the second case so far. On August 22 last year, Selu police had filed an offence against Anil Kumar, project officer of Afcons, and Ashish Daptary, owner of MP Constructions, for excavation of murrum without permission from Cozy Properties land.

Title: Reports of budget session being postponed fake: Speaker
Content:
Vidhan Sabha Speaker NP Prajapati leaves House

Bhopal: Amid political upheaval in Madhya Pradesh, Vidhan Sabha Speaker N P Prajapati rejected rumours of possible postponement of the budget session in the wake of fears around coronavirus.

Prajapati termed a message being circulated in his name as “fake”. In the evening, cybercrime branch, acting on complaint filed by J K Sharma, who is posted as director (security) at Vidhan Sabha, registered a case against unidentified persons on charges of cheating by personation under relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and IT Act.

DIG Irshad Wali said further investigations are on.

“I did not post any message on twitter or any other social media platform about the postponement of budget session of the state assembly. It’s fake,” said Prajapati on Friday.

Earlier, a fake tweet being circulated on social media networks purportedly posted on behalf of Speaker Prajapati, had claimed that the budget session of the House has been postponed till April in the wake of fears of coronavirus. Several leaders from both Congress and BJP had expressed surprise over the rumours of the session being postponed.

Title: Dy speaker’s son has BA degree from fake university: GU
Content:
Panaji: Goa University (GU) registrar Y V Reddy has informed North Goa additional collector Dashrath Redkar that the BA degree submitted by Raymond Fernandes, son of deputy speaker Isidore , for post of Awal Karkun (AK) has been issued by a fake university .

Reddy pointed out that the University Grants Commission, in a notification dated June 30, 2016, listed the Lucknow-based Bhartiya Shiksha Parishad, where Fernandes claims to have studied, as a fake university, “with a statement that the matter is subjudice before the district judge-Lucknow”.

Raymond was one of the 16 candidates selected in January by the North Goa collectorate for the post of Awal Karkun. Advocate Aires Rodrigues had filed a complaint with chief secretary Parimal Rai on February 25 seeking a probe into his selection, especially the authenticity of the degree and computer course certificates submitted by him.

The North Goa Collector had then asked GU to verify the same. Reddy has responded with a copy of the judgement of the Madras High Court and of the Calcutta High Court where Bhartiya Shiksha Parishad is stated to be a fake university. Reddy also informed Redkar that GU has not granted any equivalence to the computer courses completed by Raymond.

Meanwhile, demanding an investigation into Raymond’s selection, Goa Forward Party (GFP) has also demanded Isidore’s resignation on moral grounds. “There are many deserving candidates from Canacona, but Isidore got a bogus certificate for his son to ensure that he gets the job,” GFP vice-president Dilip Prabhudesai said.

Title: Tax dept expects collections to drop due to virus impact
Content:
Panaji: A spiralling economy triggered due to the Covid-19 scare, especially the slump in Goa’s tourism sector, will lead to lower income tax and corporate tax collections in Goa, chief I-T commissioner B V Gopinath said here on Friday.

Gopinath, who held an awareness programme on the Centre’s ‘Vivaad se Vishwas’ scheme, said the closure of mining operations had already led to a dip in I-T collections and if the tourism sector also suffered because of coronavirus, income in the hands of taxpayers would come down.

“It looks like there is an issue of foreign tourist arrivals because of coronavirus. I suppose it will have an impact on income and subsequently, tax collection,” Gopinath said.

The I-T officer said that year-on-year tax collection from Goa has shown marginal growth. “The mining closure has affected tax collections. They have dipped in comparison to the period when mining was on in the state,” Gopinath said.

Among the private sector, pharma companies are the highest taxpayers in Goa, followed by the hospitality industry.

The ‘Vivad Se Vishwas’ scheme for direct taxpayers was launched by the I-T department to end litigation and allows taxpayers to pay only their dues and get a waiver on interest. However, a number of grey areas remain.

Five Goa government agencies feature among the several tax disputes pending in the state. Gopinath said the I-T department has raised a demand for nearly Rs 2 crore in total from the five public sector undertakings.

“We met the chief secretary to tell him that the state government PSUs can avail of the scheme, too,” Gopinath said.

Title: IT firms told to make staff work from home
Content:
tnn

Mohali: The Software Technology Parks of India (STPI) centre in Mohali, on Friday, issued an advisory to 40,000 employees of 130 information technology (IT) units registered with it in Tricity to work from home till further orders.

The advisory has been issued as a precautionary measure to prevent spread of coronavirus, said Mohali STPI additional director Ajay P Shrivastava. “The directions are for the IT industries attached with STPI in Chandigarh, Mohali, Panchkula and parts of Haryana. The employees are allowed to work from home in safe and secure environment under the foreign trade policy,” he said.

Ajay Tewari, CEO of Smart Data Enterprises India (Limited) in Phase VIII, Industrial Area, Mohali, said, “We have already allowed all our 450 employees to work from home. Even some other companies have started the practice as a precautionary measure. Companies across sectors are asking their staff to work from home and adopt technologies like telepresence and video-conferencing to ensure business continuity.”

Title: Coronavirus in Chandigarh: PGI Red Cross sarai to be quarantine facility
Content: CHANDIGARH: The UT administration has identified Infosys Red Cross Sarai in PGI, with a provision of 262 beds, for quarantine of patients, especially asymptomatic ones travelling from coronavirus-affected countries.Besides, according to the Punjab Raj Bhawan, the upcoming engagements of Punjab governor-cum-UT administrator VP Singh Badnore have been restricted as a precautionary measure. The decision was taken at a meeting chaired by Badnore at Punjab Raj Bhawan on Friday.A senior UT officer said the UT administrator would not attend mass gatherings, but small events and crucial official meetings at the UT secretariat. The Chandigarh administration has approved the notification under the Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897, under sections 2, 3 and 4 to enforce preventive steps for control of COVID-19.UT home secretary Arun Kumar Gupta clarified that the UT administration has not declared COVID-19 as an epidemic. The notification was approved to enforce preventive steps only, he added. In the meeting, the preparedness of Punjab, Haryana and the UT was appreciated by the governor.The Chandigarh residents have been provided with a 24x7 helpline number 9779558282 for any type of queries related to COVID-19 and a dedicated ambulance is available round the clock for shifting and screening patients. Adequate arrangements have been made for isolation beds at all the three government hospitals of Chandigarh and space is made available to quarantine patients at all stages, a senior UT officer said.The Chandigarh administration is keeping a close watch on the suspects and till now none has tested positive. At present, 142 travellers are under home surveillance in Chandigarh.The UT administration appealed to residents not to panic and avoid mass gatherings. Use of masks was not required in case of healthy persons, it added.

Title: KL 13L 8527 — tale of an outcast dalit woman
Content:
Eramangalath Chitralekha

KANNUR: In 1893, dalit social reformer Ayyankali rode the villuvandi (bullock cart), which the dalits were not allowed to in the feudal Kerala, and created history in the social reformation. It’s been 127 years and Eramangalath Chitralekha , a dalit woman struggling hard to make both ends meet by plying an autorickshaw, is still an ‘outcast’ in her own native village, and had to leave that place to become a driver.

Incidentally, she was ‘outcast’ from the house of her friend and dalit leader Jignesh Mevani , she says in her biography set for release next month.

The book, ‘KL 13L 8527: Chithralekhayude Charithram’, written by her friend and activist Rupesh Kumar , is all about such struggles, fights and the discrimination she faced in a place that is said to be progressive.

“When you talk about the angst that the Muslim community is facing in India, against the backdrop of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, what I have to tell is that in a sense I am also fighting for my citizenship, and I am a displaced human being, which prompted me to tell my tale,” she said.

From her native Edat near Payyannur, she had to migrate to Thaliparamba, a few kilometers away, and again she returned to her native hoping that she could survive there. However, male autorickshaw drivers in the area did not allow her to ply the three-wheeler. It was attacked on many occasions. KL 13L 8527 was her first vehicle, which was set afire. Now, she plies an auto rickshaw in Kannur town.

Even though the previous UDF government sanctioned her a piece of land at Kattampally, where she had started constructing a house, the LDF government decided to take it back and the case is now in court.

When she decided to live in her ancestral house again, the electricity connection was cut as the bill was not paid for a month. When she went to pay the bill, she was asked to apply for a new connection, she said. Even though the house was damaged in the rain last time, the government was not ready to provide any help, as she is an eyesore for the local CPM activists, who are highly patriarchal, she said.

Ironically, she faced discrimination in the house of dalit leader Jignesh Mevani when she visited Gujarat to participate in a protest organised by Rashtriya Dalit Adhikar Manch (RDMM). When she visited Mevani’s house, she was not even allowed to use the toilet inside his house, she says in the book.

The biography is not just about her struggles, but also about how the mainstream political parties and even the feminist organizations ignored her fights, said Rupesh.

Title: Smart City: 3 UP cities in Top 10 hall of fame, Lucknow climbs up
Content: LUCKNOW: It’s three cheers for Uttar Pradesh in Smart City rankings. Not only has Agra topped the charts — a first-ever feat for any UP city — but Kanpur and Varanasi too have made it to the top 10 list. Lucknow has improved its position even if it did not figure among the elites.The pan-India rankings for 100 cities has been released by the ministry of housing and urban affairs based on the progress/completion rate of Smart City projects. While Kanpur ranks third and Varanasi seventh, Prayagraj is 12th, Lucknow 24th, Aligarh 55th, Saharanpur 68th, Jhansi 83rd, Bareilly 89th and Moradabad 97th.Following the Union ministry’s guidelines, civic authorities in the state had set for themselves steep completion targets. Their hard work seems to have paid off, especially with Agra beating Ahmedabad (Gujarat) to win the crown.Earlier, the evaluation was an annual exercise, but the ministry changed it to a half-yearly assessment from last year. Hence, the current rankings are based on work done by departments concerned under the Smart City project from October 1, 2019, to March 1, 2020.In the first round of rankings that was released by the ministry in October 2019, Agra had ranked 12th, Kanpur seventh and Varanasi 13th. Lucknow, which had ranked 41 last time, has made the most significant jump.

Title: Coronavirus in Chandigarh: Schools closed till March 31
Content: CHANDIGARH/MOHALI/PANCHKULA: As a precautionary measure against Covid-19, all schools in Tricity have been closed till March 31. The UT administration and the Punjab and Haryana governments issued the orders keeping in view the spread of the virus.The UT education department on Friday announced closure of all government and private (aided and unaided) schools till March 31. Students will attend schools only to appear in board examination, annual examination and assessment examination as per the previous schedule. However, all teaching and non-teaching staff members will attend schools as usual till further orders. Parents are advised to instruct their wards to avoid large gatherings and crowds during this period, it addedStudents have been asked to follow the school advisory and guidelines issued from time to time by the Union ministry of health and the local health department.Earlier in the day, the Chandigarh Parents’ Association had written to the UT home secretary to defer classes for the new academic session 2020-21. “Several state governments across the country have closed their educational institutions till March 31 in view of the rapid spread of coronavirus . However, in Chandigarh, some private schools had begun regular classes for the new academic session and many others were to begin classes as early as next week,” the parent association said in the representation.

Title: Vigilance official held for Rs 50k bribe
Content:
Hyderabad: A police constable of Regional Vigilance and Enforcement officer in Karimnagar was arrested by ACB sleuths for demanding and accepting Rs 50,000 bribe .

On February 26, the accused M Murali intercepted a truck at Dharmapuri which was transporting sand illegally. Murali threatened the truck owner Sk Layak, saying if he did not pay Rs 50,000 bribe, a fine of Rs 1.5 lakh will be imposed on him. Murali collected the bribe and let the truck go.

Layak lodged a complaint with vigilance officers on March 6. Officials seized the bribe amount and lodged a complaint with ACB. ACB official arrested Murali on Friday and sent him to judicial remand. TNN

Title: Chandigarh: Online fraud cheats Milkha Singh’s wife of Rs 1 lakh
Content: CHANDIGARH: Online fraudsters cheated the wife of Olympian Milkha Singh of Rs 1 lakh on Friday.Nirmal Kaur, a resident of Sector 8, said in her police complaint, “I had recently bought a foreign breed dog. As I wanted to get it registered, I asked my supervisor to find out the dog registration department contact number. The supervisor searched on Google and noted down a phone number from a website. When we called up on the number, a man informed us about the dog registration process.”The man took all details of her ATM card and asked her to do a transaction of Rs 10. “He then sent on my cellphone a One Time Password (OTP) and asked me to share it with him. As soon as I did so, Rs 99,900 were withdrawn from my Citibank account. He again sent an OTP on my cellphone. Saying that the money would be redeposited to my account, he asked me to share that too with him. But I did not.”Nirmal then asked the bank officials to block her account.After she lodged a complaint at SSP public window, it was forwarded to the cyber cell.A cyber cell cop said, “We are verifying the swindler’s phone number and the account in which money was transferred.”

Title: Delhi riots: Over Rs 10 crore compensation for 794 people
Content: NEW DELHI: An assistant sub-inspector in Delhi police , Sirpal Sharma, was on duty when his wife started calling him frantically on February 24. The atmosphere was quite tense outside and Sharma, who was posted at DCP Northeast office, thought family matters can wait. He initially ignored his wife’s calls. But when the calls didn’t stop, he finally picked up only to learn that the situation in Shiv Vihar, where he had been living for over 22 years, was grim.He immediately reached home to rescue his family comprising wife, son, daughter-in-law and granddaughter. The rioters later burnt his house.“I initially thought that things will settle down. Later I realised the situation was indeed grim. I immediately went back home and saw that the mob was approaching our area. They set the petrol pump on fire and burnt the fire engine too,” Sharma recalled.“Considering the situation, I had to flee with my family. When I came back, I saw that there was nothing left in my house. My house was completely damaged,” he added.Sharma’s house was among the 302 riot-affected households which were given a compensation of Rs 2.5 lakh each by Delhi government . Till March 14, the AAP government had released a total compensation of a little over Rs 10 crore to 794 people who either lost their loved ones in recent riots in northeast Delhi , were injured or their properties were burnt down.At least 53 people were killed and nearly 500 injured in communal violence in northeast Delhi in February.Sharma said he was living in a rented accommodation nearby and would now start rebuilding his house from the compensation amount.Kusumlata’s husband, Dinesh, was killed by a mob in the riots. A mother of two sons, including a 1.5-year-old, she now lives with her in-laws."I have a life full of struggle. I have to raise my children and give them good education. The Rs 10 lakh compensation that I have got from Delhi government will help me bring my life back on track," she said.Twenty-two years old Ashfaq, an electrician married for just 10 days, had gone to attend a complaint in Brijpuri area on February 25. But he never came back. He lived with his parents, brothers and their families in Gokulpuri.“His marriage was attended by all his Hindu and Muslim friends. They all came to support us after the incident. We are completely shattered, especially his young widow, but we have to stay strong,” said Agaz Hussain, his father. The government has given Rs 10 lakh compensation to the family. A government official said the compensation was a small amount to help the families get back on their feet."The recent riots have left a scar in the lives of many people. While some lost their near and dear ones, houses of many were burned down to ashes. Though we agree that the loss they incurred during the riots is irreparable, Delhi government is helping them in every possible way to bring their lives back on track,” said an official.Anish’s house in Shiv Vihar was burnt and valuables looted on February 25. He said that the Rs 2.5-lakh compensation from Delhi government had come as a huge relief. “It will help me fix my house,” he added.

Title: Better To Err On The Side Of Caution
Content: Goa may not have had any positive cases of Covid-19 yet, but there is no denying the fact that it is an extraordinary global crisis that requires desperate measures to keep it in check. India, by suspending most visas till April 15 to retard the spread of the virus, has taken the right step. But what is lacking here in Goa is seriousness from the state government in tackling the pandemic. State politicians, as is their wont, are incessantly suggesting to stay calm. While that may be a good idea, what is far more urgent and imperative is a radical change in behaviour. After much dithering, the state government has invoked the Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897, a half-hearted measure for a full-blown, exponentially spreading virus. Even the Unicef guidelines to the schools and educational institutions that have been issued only on Friday, have been diluted and there is no restriction on public gatherings, events or religious congregations, exposing thousands of people, especially children and senior citizens to a deadly communicable disease. Social distancing is the only way to stop the spread of the novel coronavirus. But the state government and its CM Pramod Sawant have ignored the most crucial fact and carried on with a false bravado of senseless hope that all is well in the sunshine state. India has already seen two deaths—a 76-year-old man in Karnataka and a 68-year-old woman in Delhi—and Goa’s vulnerability can be judged by the fact that it has the second largest proportion of people aged 60 years and above, constituting 11.2% of the state’s 14.5 lakh population. We don’t need an outbreak to act. Sawant, by his sluggish attitude, has shown a clear lack of leadership and foresight. Instead of downplaying the risks of coronavirus and hiding behind bureaucratic sloth, the state government must immediately ask people to stay away from public places, cancel big gatherings, bring religious congregations to a grinding halt and plan and prepare for any eventuality. Whether it is moving classes online, cancelling rallies and public meetings or even playing games in front of empty stadiums, the state should ensure every form of social distancing. As the elected head of the state, Sawant should take responsibility and set an example and not use potential panic and over-reaction as an excuse to put the public at risk.

Title: Sugar mill labourer raped, FIR registered against GM’s driver
Content:
Gorakhpur: A man was on Friday booked for allegedly raping a labourer of Dhadha New India Sugar Mill at Hata in Kushinagar district on Holi. Acting on the woman’s complaint, police have launched a hunt for the accused, who is the driver of the mill general manager.

According to the complaint, the survivor’s husband went out for shopping on Holi, when the accused Sadiq Ahmad forcefully entered her house and raped her.

When her husband returned, she narrated the entire ordeal and the couple went to mill authorities to complain against the driver and were assured action against Ahmad. However, when they went for a follow up the next day, they were held hostage inside the mill for two hours, the compalint said. The woman claimed that they were released after the intervention of corporator of ward number 13, Ranjeet.

On Friday, the couple went to Hata Kotwali police station and lodged an FIR against the driver. “On the basis of her complaint, an FIR under IPC section 376 has been lodged against the accused and manhunt has been launched to nab him,” SHO, Hata Kotwali, Harendra Mishra said.

Asked if action was initiated against the mill management for holding the accused and her husband captive to hush up the case, he said, “All allegations against the sugar mill management is a subject of investigation.”

However, mill GM Karan Singh denied the charges, saying, “The driver and the labourer had a clash over some issue which was later resolved. The allegation of rape is false and it is a conspiracy to defame the sugar mill.”

Title: Cuttack: 4 years on, CMC’s waste management plan put on backburner
Content:
Representative image

CUTTACK: The Cuttack Municipal Corporation (CMC)’s integrated solid waste management project-2016 is back to square one after four years.

The CMC’s plans to execute the project through a five-year contract with a private firm have to be reworked now.

The state government has ordered the cancellation of CMC’s tender process for the collection and disposal of solid waste from the city and asked the civic body to invite fresh bids with shortened scope of work to bring down expenditure.

CMC’s deputy commissioner (health and sanitation) Sanjibeeta Ray said “estimates have to be drawn all over again before inviting fresh tenders as we have been asked to cut down the scope of the work”.

“The civic body has been asked to involve self-help groups (SHGs) of women in sanitation operations and limit the scope of work to cleaning of roads and drains and cutting bushes while giving contracts to private firms through tender process,” Ray said.

The integrated solid waste management project 2016 was slated to be a blueprint for better disposal of garbage in the city. The execution of the project had become extremely vital as adhoc arrangements for nearly four years had resulted in unprecedented chaos in garbage collection and disposal in the city.

The delay in execution of the project is being seen as a typical case of failure of the civic administration. “It’s unfortunate that the civic administration has been unable to finalize a tender in a process proper enough to pass through scrutiny – be it legal or administrative even after more than three and half years,” Chittaranjan Mohanty , a city-based lawyer and social activist, said.

No headway has been made since 2016 despite three attempts to select a private firm by inviting bids for the execution of the much-awaited project that envisaged a crucial set of reforms by including GPRS tracking system, biometric attendance system, mechanized sweeping and a new set of regulations for better segregation and disposal of waste.

The CMC had first invited bids for the execution of the project in 2016. But the high court finally quashed the tender process in September 2017 after issuing a stay order.

Though there was a fresh dispute over the finalisation of tender in favour of a private party, the court gave a clean chit to it 2018. However, CMC had to cancel the tender process as the state government disapproved the tender finalised in favour of New Delhi-based Metro Waste Handling Pvt Limited

The CMC had invited bids for the execution of the project for the third time in December last. But the state government issued orders to cancel the tender process in February.

Title: ‘Avoid visiting courts, unless necessary’
Content: As a precautionary measure against Covid-19 , Bombay high court registrar general (RG) on Friday issued a circular to request people, litigants and lawyers to avoid visiting court complexes across the state , unless necessary. Health ministry guidelines should be adhered to, said RG S B Agrawal. Meanwhile, Acting Chief Justice B P Dharmadhikari, top two Justices A A Sayed and S S Shinde along with principal secretary Aniruddha Chandekar and Agrawal will hold a special meeting on Saturday to discuss other safety moves to adopt. tnn

Title: Combating Covid-19 vacation windfall: Make it blessing in disguise, say experts
Content: KOCHI: The early summer vacation for students up to class VII, in the wake of Covid-19 scare, has left parents and children in a quandary. With restrictions on travel and shutdown of movie halls, parks, summer camps, etc, there’s little else to keep them engaged. Many working parents are struggling to find babysitters and some are even taking leave as leaving kids alone at home is not an option.But psychiatrists and child specialists say that parents should view this situation as an opportunity to make children socially responsible and train them in homemaking and leading a healthy lifestyle. They suggest that parents should also use the opportunity to spend more time with children to help them develop social skills. Also, the vacation could be used to help kids develop good hobbies and nurture creativity.“It is true that Covid-19 has derailed the plans of many families but I think parents can turn this into an opportunity and mould their kids into responsible homemakers. Children, irrespective of gender, could be trained in helping parents with household activities like cleaning, cooking, gardening etc. Also, as it will be an extended vacation, children might lose touch with academics, especially when there were no final exams. So, it is ideal to make them revise what they have learned over the last one year till the official vacation begins,” said Dr Philip John , senior psychiatrist.Doctors said that children should be made aware of the health situation and trained to develop personal hygiene. “While younger kids need assistance in hygiene, elder kids need supervision. Parents should find time to make them aware of what Covid-19 is without scaring them and highlight the importance of hygiene. Coronavirus should not govern their personal hygiene, which should be made part of their daily routine,” said C J John, senior psychiatrist.Experts caution against children being allowed to spend more time in front of screens and advise parents to screen the content they watch. “Most kids would prefer playing computers games, on smartphones and watching TV. Parents should not allow them more than two hours a day. Watching movies on online streaming platforms is quite common today but parents can choose the content for kids and restrict their viewing time. Otherwise, there is good chance of addiction. Also, don’t allow them to sleep during daytime as it will make them night owls,” said Philip John.

Title: Aurangabad: Body-builders to flex muscles in Beed today
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: Despite the threat of coronavirus outbreak looming large in several parts of the country, a Beed outfit has decided to go ahead with the body-building contest it has scheduled for Saturday. Athletes from across the state are set to participate in the contest.

The Beed District and Marathwada Body Building and Physique Sports Association has decided to hold the event at the Sambhaji Maharaj ground at Shivaji Chowk in Beed despite chief minister Uddhav Thackeray announcing the closure of swimming pools, gyms, theatres, auditoriums in several cities across the state on Friday. A bike stunt show has also been lined up to attract more youngsters.

Sources in the body building association said that general secretary of the Indian Body Builders Federation , Chetan Pathare, had recently issued a communication to abstain from organizing tournaments.

Authorities in Beed police said that they could not stop people from organising such events unless the district administration imposed section 144 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

Meanwhile, as a precautionary measure, Beed district collector Rahul Rekhawar on Friday imposed the Disaster Management Act, 2005. With this act, departments like the police, civic body, food and drug administration and health have been put on alert for responding to any emergency as per the prescribed standard operating procedure prescribed in the law.

Title: Bhubaneshwar: After pact, Gajapati to get extra classrooms
Content:
Representative image

BERHAMPUR: The Gajapati district administration on Friday signed memorandum of agreement (MoA) with Rural Electrification Corporation (REC) Limited, a Navaratna company, for construction of additional classrooms and installation of reverse osmosis (RO) water systems in some of the government-run primary schools in the predominantly tribal district.

The MoA was signed between Gajapati collector Anupam Saha and Surendra Pradhan , general manager (finance), REC regional office, Bhubaneswar, in presence of senior officers of the district and the company.

According to the MoA, the public sector undertaking (PSU) will construct 53 additional classrooms in 32 government-run schools through REC Foundation, the corporate social responsibility (CSR) arm of the PSU. The Navaratna enterprise will spend Rs 3.32 crore under the CSR initiative for the purpose, a company source said. The construction of the new classrooms would be completed before reopening of schools after summer vacation, an official said. The additional classrooms would be constructed in government schools of Gosani (3) Rayagada (3), Mohana (10), Nuagada (5) Gumma (5) and R Udayagiri (6) blocks under the Aspirational District Scheme (ADS), the official added. Gajapati has been identified as one of the aspirational districts in the state by the Niti Aayog.

The finance assistance of the REC Limited to the district would boost primary school infrastructure in the district, said the collector. Besides, this would also facilitate quality education to the students, he said. Similarly, the REC will provide Rs 1.57 crore for supply of RO water systems to 94 government-run schools across the district. The amount was sanctioned under the CSR of the PSU last year. Utilising the funds, the district administration would also continue the Super 30 programme initiative to impart coaching to 30 brilliant students in the district to excel in the annual high school certificate (HSC) examination. District administration had launched the Super 30 programme last year.

Title: One held for showing porn to minor boy
Content:
Vasco: A native of Uttar Pradesh was arrested on Friday for showing a pornographic video to a minor boy at Dabolim airport.

Dabolim police said that a family from France who was travelling from Goa to Mumbai, stated that their minor son was shown a porn clip by a 24-year-old man working at a store at the Dabolim airport terminal. The family had lodged a complaint at the Mumbai airport police station around four days ago.

The man was arrested under provisions of the Pocso Act and Goa Children’s Act.

Title: Pune woman out to buy mask, burglars strike at home
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Burglars stole ornaments and cash totally worth Rs46,000 from a woman’s flat in a housing society in Hadapsar minutes after she had gone out to buy masks as guard against coronavirus on Thursday morning.

Sub-inspector Sachin Gadekar from the Hadapsar police said the woman had locked her flat at Indraprasth society in Pawar colony and went to a medical store near her house to buy the protective masks around 9am.

“The burglars gained access to her flat by breaking the locks of the door and stole gold ornaments and cash and decamped with the booty totally worth Rs46,000,” the officer said.

The burglary came to light after the woman reached home and found the door locks broken and the cash and ornaments missing from the cupboard, he said.

She subsequently lodged an FIR with the Hadapsar police against some unidentified persons.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Pune: Sinhagad Road corporators rope in Ganesh Mandals to spot the ‘ill’
Content: PUNE: Corporators from the Sinhagad Road are taking proactive measures to mitigate the spread of coronavirus as the number of positive cases recorded in the area has touched five.Multiple disinfection drives, sharing of Covid-19-related videos on social media platforms, monitoring of the areas by Ganesh Mandal workers, cancellation of public events and keeping an eye out for those arriving from outstation were among the several measures undertaken by the corporators in the past few days.The elected representatives said the measures were being taken, as the area has recorded the highest number of coronavirus cases in the city so far. Out of the 10 people in the Pune district who tested positive for the contagion till Friday, five are from the Sinhagad Road area.Local corporator Haridas Charvad said he has started circulating informative video clips in the social media groups to raise awareness about the highly contagious disease.“I am connected with over 50,000 people from the area through several social media platforms. We created a Covid-19 related video. The clip is now being circulated through my social media platforms to raise awareness,” Charvad said, adding that he was in constant touch with the Pune Municipal Corporation ’s (PMC) health department to provide better facilities to people in the area.Charvad said he has urged the PMC to intensify the disinfection drives at public places, markets and housing societies. “While several disinfection drives have been undertaken since the news of positive Covid-19 cases in Pune broke, I think there is a need to intensify it further,” the corporator said.Another corporator Rajabhau Laigude said he has roped in over 30 local Ganesh Mandals workers to keep a watch on people exhibiting flu-like symptoms. “We cancelled the Shivjayanti celebrations to mitigate the contagion’s spread. We have appealed to the people to avoid stepping out of their homes,” Laigude said.The corporator said the Sinhagad Road area has a significant floating population which could pose a challenge if the number of positive cases in the city rises. “We have avoided initiatives like distribution of masks as it could lead to unnecessary panic,” he said, adding that the citizens were continually being advised to contact the PMC-run hospitals in light of flu-like symptoms.

Title: ESZ monitoring panel clears HC parking project
Content:
Chandigarh: While the Punjab and Haryana high court has ordered demolition of all unauthorised structures in the Sukhna Lake catchment area, the monitoring committee for eco-sensitive zone for Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary has cleared a contentious project.

Sources said in a recent meeting attended by officers of the UT engineering department, urban planning department and UT’s forest and wildlife department, the project of three-level basement parking for the Punjab and Haryana high court was given clearance.

A senior UT officer, who attended the meeting, said the officials of the department concerned had submitted before the committee that the parking site does not fall under the catchment area as per Survey of India’s 2004 map. So, the committee cleared the project, the officer added.

The monitoring committee was recently re-constituted by the UT administration under the chairmanship of Debendra Dalai, UT chief conservator of forests who also holds the charge of chief wildlife warden.

Members of the monitoring committee included UT chief architect, UT chief engineer, MC chief engineer, UT director, rural development, and member secretary of the Chandigarh Pollution Control Committee. Deputy conservator of forests is member secretary of the committee, which was formed for a period of three years.

The UT engineering department has already sent a proposal to the UT environment department, seeking permission for the construction of proposed multilevel basement parking in the vicinity of the HC.

The Chandigarh Heritage Conservation Committee (CHCC) had in November last year given approval to the expansion plan of the HC, which included construction of three-level basement parking opposite the existing one in Sector 1.

As per the proposal drafted by UT engineering department, the multi-level parking will have three floors of basement to accommodate around 5,000 vehicles. The tentative size of the basement parking is 434ft x 810ft, with approximate covered area of one floor as 3,72,400 sqft and for three floors is 11,17,220 sqft.

‘Heritage status at risk’

The proposed underground parking project falls within the eco-sensitive zone around the Sukhna Wildlife Sanctuary that was notified in 2017. Also, the site is in the buffer zone of UNESCO World Heritage Site of Capitol Complex and many experts have warned that new construction in the complex may put its heritage status in jeopardy. The administration had recently decided to conduct an environmental impact assessment study of the proposed parking project. The study will include various aspects, including ambient air quality, vehicular traffic density, flora and fauna, water quality, socio-economic survey, among other factors.

Title: 6-month-old tiger cub killed in hit-and-run
Content:
Cub

Chandrapur: A six-month-old tiger cub was killed in a hit-and-run case near village Bamni Katwal under Kothari forest range on Friday. The injured cub was discovered by farmer Ashok Madavi in his farm on Friday morning, however, it succumbed to injuries before medical help could arrive.

Sources said that RFO Kothari Sandeep Langde rushed to the spot on getting information and simultaneously informed a veterinary doctor. By the time forest team reached the spot, there was quite a large crowd of villagers gathered around the tiger cub. Many of the onlookers were clicking pictures and selfies with the cub.

Forest team immediately cleared the crowd around the tiger cub, but it died before medical help could arrive. Officials claimed that the cub is a six-month-old female and belongs to a tigress having three cubs in the area. The dead body of the tiger cub was shifted to Jhari forest nursery for post mortem.

Initially, forest officials suspected that the cub might have suffered injuries while passing through a fence or in an attack by some other animal after straying away from the tigress. However, initial findings of post mortem revealed that at least six ribs on right side of the cub’s chest were fractured and it died of massive internal bleeding.

The farm of Ashok Madavi is adjacent to Kothari–Tohgaon road. Authorities suspect that the mother tigress might have been crossing the road with cubs when some speeding vehicle collided with one of the cubs that strayed behind. The injured cub crawled around 25 meter up to Madavi’s farm and lay there till it was discovered in the morning.

Title: Covid-19 scare in Chandigarh: Chhatbir zoo prohibits all animal, human interfaces
Content: MOHALI: The Covid-19 scare has also reached Mahendra Chaudhary Zoological Park in Chhatbir, where authorities have decided to prohibit the bird-human interface.People will not be allowed to visit the walk-in aviary, reptile enclosures and nocturnal houses. The footfall at the zoo has decreased by 40% in the past one week.Principal chief conservator of forests, Punjab, Kuldeep Kumar said, “We are taking major precautionary measures not only at Chhatbir, but at all the zoos of the state. At Chhatbir, we have decided to prohibit direct interface of humans with birds. We will be holding a meeting on Monday to take some more important decisions on the operations of zoos across the state.”Chhatbir zoo field director M Sudhagar said as a precautionary measure, all employees have been directed to wear masks, gloves and use sanitisers, which are provided to them at the entry gates. The employees at the gate have also been given thermometers to check suspects. They have been directed not to let in even those with mild fever and to inform the nearest health department, he added.He said, “The walk-in aviary, reptile house and nocturnal house, where chances of infection are very high, have been put on the prohibition list. Directions have also been issued to check foreigners at the gate. Probably, the entry of foreigners may be disallowed once directions are received from the Punjab government.”About the low footfall, he said, “On Saturday, we had just 2,000 visitors, while normally there are more than 4,000. On Sunday, Tuesday and Wednesday, the footfall did not cross the 4,000-mark, which otherwise on an average is above 6,000. Health teams have been given standing orders to act swiftly during an emergency or if a suspect is traced inside the zoo, shift him/her to the nearest dispensary and inform the Mohali civil surgeon.”

Title: 2 arrested for letting man die on road
Content:
Prayagraj: Two men were arrested on Friday for letting a critically injured truck cleaner die on the roadside near Shrinathpur village in Pratapgarh.

The accused were identified as Nanhe Sharma and Uma Shankar — all residents of Pratapgarh’s Kanhai area. Police said the deceased Sunil Kumar Sharma was found with his throat slit on Thursday.

SP (Pratapgarh) Abhishek Singh said the accused have been charged under sections 304 of the Indian Penal Code (whoever commits culpable homicide not amounting to murder) as they left a profusely bleeding man on the roadside and did not even inform the police.

On Thursday, one Neeraj Kumar Sharma — a resident of Sujatganj in Jaunpur — informed the police that his brother Sunil has been missing and was last seen while he was going to play Holi at his maternal uncle’s house in Gangpati area in Kanhai on Tuesday around 11am.

Sunil reportedly visited one Umashankar’s house in Shrinathpur village the next day. On Thursday, he was found dead with a slit throat on the outskirts of Shrinathpur village.

Police said the deceased worked as a truck cleaner with Nanhe Sharma and often used to visit the latter’s house. On Tuesday, an inebriated Sunil visited Nanhe’s in-laws in Shrinathpur village.

He allegedly got into a fight wiht Nanhe’s wife and Umashankar’s daughter Pushpa Devi. “After the tiff, he roamed around and local villagers heard him saying that he did not want live any more,” said police.

Local villagers didn’t pay any attention to him thinking that he was drunk. A few minutes later, Sunil went outside the village and allegedly slit his throat with a blade.

When Umashankar and Nanhe came to know about the incident, they first took a critically injured Sunil to his maternal uncle’s house. Sunil’s uncle asked them to take him to a hospital. However, the two left him bleeding on the roadside and went away. The accused did not even inform the police about his condition.

Title: LU UG admissions go online
Content:
Lucknow: The admission process for Luckow University’s undergraduate courses, from filing forms to counselling, will be online from the upcoming session. Application process will be online for postgraduate admissions, but candidates will have to visit the campus for counselling.

The submission of online forms for over 3,000 UG and 4,000 PG courses will begin from March 16.

“Last year, admissions to BA and BA(Hons) were done in offline mode, but this time we will have 100% online admissions,” said LU vice-chancellor AK Rai. He said all candidates will have the ease to apply, lock seats, gets documents verified and pay the fee online.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Despite opposition, Kerala budget session cut short
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Kerala legislative assembly has cut short its budget session in view of the rising concerns over Covid-19 outbreak and the health emergency the state is facing, despite an opposition from the UDF against applying guillotine to pass the remaining demands for grants without discussion or voting.As per the decision taken at the business advisory committee (BAC) meeting held before the start of the assembly session on Friday, all the outstanding demands for grants, besides the Kerala Appropriation Bill and Kerala finance bills were passed without discussion and the house was adjourned sine die.However, terming the decision as undemocratic and a bad precedent, the opposition UDF staged a walkout and alleged that the state government wanted to escape criticisms against its failures and was trying to cover up corruption with the Covid-19 scare. “This is a challenge on the House’s right to take part in the discussions and voting on demands for grants,” said opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala before staging the walkout.The budget session was scheduled to be held till April 8 and discussion and voting on demands for grants for various departments were to be held on March 16, 17, 18, 19, 23, 24 and 25, while presentation of Kerala Appropriation Bill was to be held on March 30.Presenting the BAC report, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan told the assembly that a demand for cutting short the budget session was raised from various quarters, including from opposition member and IUML leader KNA Khader. “This is not to create any precedence, or to escape any criticisms. Kerala has an assembly which is in session for the most number of days in the country,” he said.Earlier, opposition legislators, including M Ummer, K C Joseph, P T Thomas and Thiruvanchoor Radhakrishnan, opposed the BAC decision and asserted that it was an onslaught on democracy. “This will send a wrong message and create panic among people,” said Joseph.At the BAC meeting, opposition members had suggested that the house could be adjourned sine die after passing the vote on account and that discussions on demands for grants could be resumed after two months.

Title: Aurangabad: Complaint redressal system in Beed gets a digital upgrade
Content:
Representative image

Aurangabad: The Beed district police have launched a system enabling direct video conferencing of the victims with senior police officers, including superintendent of police, to address complaints of victims, especially women and children.

AURANGABAD:

Beed district, with an approximate population of three million, it takes close to five hours to travel from one end to another. The use of technology will give relief to the complainants hailing from distant places in the district.

Earlier, they had to reach out to the district police headquarters to get their complaints heard. Now, they will have to reach out to the nearest police station and inform the police station in-charge about their grievance. Depending on the gravity of the issue, the complainant would be put across to the senior cops.

The facility to interact with the top cops via video conferencing has been made available at all the police stations through open source softwares and applications available for the police department.

To begin with, the initiative is being used for tackling complainants made during the weekly complaint disposal day at the police stations in the Aurangabad range. Following the instructions of Aurangabad range IGP Ravinder Kumar Singal , all 87 police stations in the range hold a grievance disposal day every Saturday.

Beed superintendent of police Harssh Poddar told TOI, “Using this video conferencing technology, the senior officers can reach a much larger number of applicants. So, we are dovetailing this into weekly takrar nivaran.”

The officer informed that the hardware is already available at the police stations because of the digitization initiatives earlier, so nothing had to be purchased and the latest project is being implemented with zero cost.

However, Poddar clarified that the usual avenue of meeting senior officers will continue. “This is for applicants, who either don’t want or cannot afford to travel, across the district. At the moment 25 police stations, offices of the two additional superintendents of police and six SDPO offices are already connected with this service.”

Beed cyber police informed that considering the bandwidth as well as the quality of the available open source software, 25 video conferencing windows can be addressed at a single go, without facing any technical glitch.

Title: Pune citizens cancel or postpone routine check-ups amid coronavirus worries
Content: PUNE: Shruti Mundada was to visit her doctor for a post-surgery check-up recently, but she postponed the appointment on the advise of her family members, following the huge coronavirus scare.Like Mundada, many Puneites are reluctant to visit hospitals even for routine health check-ups for fear of contracting Covid-19. It is not just about hospitals, people are wary of visiting crowded places in the wake of the contagion spread, experts said.Wanowrie resident Rajesh Bhat said he was to take his mother for a follow-up at her diabetologist in a nearby hospital. “However, we called up the doctor and postponed the appointment to April to ensure that my mother is not exposed to the unhealthy atmosphere prevailing in the city,” Bhat said.Resultantly, healthcare facilities like Ruby Hall Clinic have reported a drop in visitors’ footfall.When asked about the fear and resultant drop in patient visits, Sanjay Patil, president of the Indian Medical Association, Pune, said, “There is definitely less footfall at hospitals and even in clinics. However, the rush is quite a bit when it comes to paediatricians, who are being visited by more people for consultation on seasonal viral fever.”He said this was happening due to the prevailing fear of Covid-19 among residents.“We have planned surgeries but even those are being postponed because of coronavirus fear. People wish to self-quarantine and not involve in group activities. They are also avoiding unnecessary travel even within the city,” Patil added.Chief executive officer of Ruby Hall Clinic Bomi Bhote said, “There is almost a 20% drop in footfall at our hospital in the wake of the coronavirus fears.”Senior surgeon at Deenanath Mangeshkar hospital Dhananjay Kelkar said, “We are full as always. There is no drop as of now and the same is in the OPD section.”

Title: Coronavirus Chennai News: Tamil Nadu CM Edappadi K Palaniswami chairs meet, but what was on the table?
Content: CHENNAI: When chief minister Eddapadi K Palanisami called for a review meeting with a battery of ministers and more than 35 IAS officials on Covid-19 at the secretariat, it looked like the government had finally woken up to the pandemic. But at the end of the meeting that lasted more than an hour, there were no announcements.The press meeting called by health minister C Vijayabaskar was cancelled and a press release that was awaited did not come until late in the night. Officials in the health department said senior officials were travelling to Adhiyanoothu in Dindigul where the chief minister would lay the foundation for a medical college. A stage was being erected in an open field with a seating capacity of more than 15,000 and parking arrangements were made for more than 2,000 cars.But the event could be a recipe for a disaster amid the pandemic. “This virus spreads by contact. We don’t know how many people in TN are carriers of the infection. In these circumstances, such large gatherings will provide a fertile field for an epidemic. No responsible government would do that,” said George Thomas, former editor of the Indian Journal of Medical Ethics.During the review meeting, officials discussed the need to invoke provisions of the Tamil Nadu Public Health Act, 1938, Epidemic Act, 1897, and the Disaster Management Act, 2005. For the first time in eight weeks, the state decided it would invoke provisions under Disaster Management Act so they can get funds for contingency measures. The chief minister, who is the chairman of the State Disaster Management Authority, also agreed to release funds.On the ground, senior officials from schooleducation, municipal administration and transport departments said they did not have funds to buy disinfectants, soap and sanitizers. Disinfecting surfaces, using soap solutions and hand sanitizers would push back the virus. “But where is the money” asked a senior official. “Till date, we have not been given any money to buy disinfectants,” he said. The state health department needs funds to augment quarantine facilities and beds.Later, the commisionerate of school education announced that pre-KG, LKG and UKG classes in all schools across the state will remain shut from March 16 to 31. In border districts of Kanyakumari, Tirunelveli, Tenkasi, Theni, Coimbatore, Tirupur and the Nilgiris, Classes I to V will remain suspended.“Even that is too little. When two neighbours Kerala and Karnataka have reported cases, why should we restrict prevention measures to just borders?” said former city health officer P Kuganandam. “Children are vulnerable to infection. We should ask children up to Class VIII to stay at home.”

Title: Gujarat: 65 quarantined for their contact with 7 coronavirus positive cases
Content:
Two more testing labs by weekend

Govt trying to trace those possibly affected

AHMEDABAD: Health department officials said that a total of 65 persons, who were in close contact with the seven positive cases, have been quarantined and their samples have been taken.Jayanti Ravi, principal secretary (health & family welfare), told reporters on Friday that the majority of the persons are young and none of them are on ventilator. “They are under constant monitoring and their health is stable,” she said.Health department officials said that those breaching the home quarantine should be reported immediately on 104 helpline or to the district health officer or collector office.“Those flouting rules will be shifted to government quarantine. We are aware of apprehensions in members of society, but we are taking all precautions to ensure that quarantined persons are observed closely and we are also doing community-based survey to identify persons who have foreign travel history, apart from arrival at Ahmedabad and Surat international airports,” said Ravi.Jayanti Ravi said that apart from the COVID-19 labs at Ahmedabad and Jamnagar, two more will come up at Surat and Bhavnagar before Sunday. “We had applied for four more labs at Bhavnagar, Surat, SVP Hospital in Ahmedabad and Vadodara. On Thursday, we have got in-principle nod for the two labs from ICMR whereas we are hopeful of getting the permission for two more by next week,” she said.Health department officials said that efforts are on to identify possible affected cases after the first positive cases reported from Gujarat The challenges are huge. “For example, a person from Rajkot who had returned from UAE had taken the international flight to Mumbai after which he had taken a train to Rajkot along with his family. Thus, the number of persons with whom he had come into contact is quite high,” said an official.

Title: Schools Closed in Bhopal: All schools, colleges and cinema halls shut in state
Content:
Bhopal: The Madhya Pradesh government has ordered closure of all schools and colleges and cinema halls till further orders in wake of Coronavirus spread and prevention. The orders were issued on the directives of the chief minister Kamal Nath after a review meeting on Friday.

As per the order of the school education department only the board exams for classes 10 and 12 and state-level exam for classes 5 and 8 will be held as per schedule, while all other activities by schools will stand either cancelled or postponed.

“We have not decided how long the schools will remain closed as we do not know if the situation will get better or worse with time. So, only when the situation is under control, we will order reopening of schools as there is nothing more important than the health of the students”, said principal secretary, school education department, Rashmi Shami.

An order by Rajya Shikha Kendra stated that all annual exams going on in government schools for classes 1 to 4, 6 and 7 in government schools and all the annual exams in private schools will be postponed until further orders

However, all the external exams for board classes will be held as per schedule.

“As per the orders, only the board exams of classes 10 and 12 for all boards, CBSE, ICSE, MP Board will be held as per the pre-decided time table. State level exams for classes 5 and 8 will also be held as per schedule. The schools however will have to postpone the annual exams for other classes”, added Shami.

Likewise, all colleges and cinema halls will also be closed while large public gatherings would be restricted.

The chief minister said that the responsible citizens of all communities and religious gurus of different religions should also be urged to create awareness and not to organize such events in which people gather at one place. He said that our preparations should be such that the disease does not spread before the virus is detected

Nath also asked to screen people coming from the border states of Madhya Pradesh, especially Rajasthan, Chhattisgarh, Maharashtra and Uttar Pradesh. He said that the preparations made for disease prevention by these states should also be studied and sought the information about the preparations made so far by the health and medical education department.

Meanwhile, the mid-term exams have been postponed to March 23.

Title: Schools’ solution: Exams at home, virtual classes amid coronavirus scare
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

KOCHI: Though final exams have been disrupted with holidays for students up to class VII being advanced, a few city schools are giving them a chance to write the exams at home. The institutions are sending question papers online to students and asking them to write the exam within the prescribed time and self-evaluate the answer sheets in order to keep them engaged till the official summer vacation begins.

A few schools are also providing bridging classes, which are the sessions provided to present Class IX and XI students to familiarise them with Class X and Class XII syllabus, through online platforms. Also, some schools are giving vacation assignments to students to conduct internal evaluations till March-end.

Coronavirus outbreak live updates

“Most parents and students are unhappy having to miss the final exams despite having prepared for them. Theatres are closed, the malls cannot be visited, all gatherings have been stopped, so we felt it imperative that we as educators help and partner with parents to keep the students engaged. We will share their term-end question papers with parents. Parents can encourage the child to attempt the assignments at home. The papers will be sent as per the scheduled exam timetable. This is not an exam but more of students’ self-assessment of their own strengths. This will not be counted toward the overall grades,” said Sreekumar Kartha , principal of Global Public School .

Bhavan’s Vidya Mandir, Girinagar, is working on syllabus-based assignments for students. “Although we had to unexpectedly suspend classes earlier this week, we are keen on engaging with our pupils in a meaningful manner. Class coordinators are planning the assignments,” said principal Girija T S.

Global Public School is also offering online bridge sessions for class IX and XI students. “We have been using Google Classroom for the last four to five years for our students. On March 11, we launched virtual classes in chemistry and business studies for our senior students on a trial basis. Students can interact with teachers using software like Google Meet and Google Classroom. We will be conducting online classes as per a new schedule,” said school vice-principal Susanna Sunil.

Toc H Public School, Vyttila , is also planning similar online classes. “Students are already in vacation-mood but we advise parents to make sure that students don’t miss classes,” said principal Juby Paul.
