For, early on, the 28-year-old architect and industrial designer, who hails from Vadapalani, had made the decision to stay and ride out the crisis rather than head back home, and risk spreading the virus.

“By travelling, I would be putting myself at a higher risk. Worse, I wouldn’t want to be someone responsible that brought the virus into another country with a lower number of cases,” says Mithun, who moved to Milan in 2016 to pursue his masters’ at the Politecnico di Milano. “I am young and may survive it, but without my knowledge what if I do contract it and transmit it to someone who may not survive? That was something I questioned and decided not to do. It seemed a bit selfish. Instead I keep my family informed about what is happening here every day,” says Mitun, whose job-hunting plans have been put on hold for now.

“Even if I do get back to India, how does one decide when to return? I understand this virus may not be eradicated entirely in a few months,” he says, adding that the government is doing all it can to ensure the general public is well taken care of.

“All the workplaces whose employees can work from home do so, others are required to take mandatory precautions. For example, at the pharmacies the queues have lines marked on the floor with one metre spacing and everyone is requested to maintain that gap,” says Mithun. In small stores, there are signs that specify how many people can enter the store at a time. “The calculation is based on the size of the store. A small bakery near my home, which is about 3m long and 3m wide, has calculated that only three people can stand in line at a time. And people respect queues.” The police force also ensures people do not crowd public places.

“Until last Saturday, before Milan and Lombardy was declared to be a red zone, restaurants and pubs were open provided they had only table service and all the tables were 1m away from each other,” says Mithun. “But now many establishments have closed until further notice, which ensures even the ones who do not want to respect the quarantine have less options if they step out.”

The lockdown has had a psychological impact as well. “Initially, there was panic. Staying informed is key. Technology really helps -- at the very least one gets to stay in touch with people they care about to keep oneself warm virtually,” he says, adding that you need to use the time imposed on one positively. “I spend it reading more than I ever did in the recent past,” he says.

In Albignano d’Adda, province of Milan, industrial designer Girish Gopalakrishnan, 27, has also decided to stay put as the project he is working on requires his physical presence. “I am not so worried about COVID-19 as I take all necessary precautions to protect myself,” says Girish, who originally hails from Ramapuram and moved to Italy two years ago.

“Life has become sober here. COVID-19 has really brought Milan down to its knees. No football matches (heart and soul of every Italian), no bars, no shopping. I don’t eat out as much, or meet friends, use self-billing counters when I go to supermarkets and don’t leave home until there is an exigency,” he says. “There is a severe shortage of sanitary masks and gloves but no shortage of any other supplies.”

Since it is also the season of common influenza, the symptoms of which are similar to COVID-19, all precautions are taken. “I was down with fever for two weeks. The doctors just put me on antibiotics and home quarantined me.”

Girish is only worried about family and friends in India. “They blindly follow what is shown on TV irrespective of what the real situation is here. And I don’t know how calm them down,” he says.

Title: Volunteers flood health min’s FB page
Content: Kochi: The Facebook page of health minister K K Shailaja is witnessing a flood of comments by people who express their desire to work as volunteers to fight Covid-19 . But sources close to the health minister said currently there is no requirement of volunteers.“Dear teacher, my name is Kavya and I am a lab technician. I am ready to join any initiative to eradicate the disease. Bird flu has been detected in Parappanangady where I am based. I am also ready to join activities to prevent the disease,” wrote Kavya Shiju under a post by the health minister.Manju Jinesh, who identified herself as a trained BSc nurse, said she is ready to volunteer as a health worker in Kannur or nearby areas. “I am ready to work without remuneration,” her post said.An FB user, Mary Neethu, said she is ready to offer support as a counsellor. “I’m a counsellor and I’m ready for any psychological intervention in this emergency situation,” she wrote, adding that she isn’t afraid of meeting Covid-19 patients. Some who are not connected to medical field also wanted to offer a helping hand. “I am from Neyyattinkara. Though I have no connection with medical field, I know driving and I’m ready to work in any situation without payment,” wrote an FB user who identified as Socratese.“We are documenting all the responses but the situation is not similar to that of the floods and currently we don’t need volunteers,” said health minister’s private secretary P Santhosh. The state, however, wants people to register with ‘Sannadham’, an initiative under Kerala state disaster management authority (KSDMA). An exclusive portal Sannadham.Kerala.gov.in has been launched for the purpose where volunteers can register by filling a web form. Interested persons can also give a missed call on 9400198198 to join. The aim is to create an army of volunteers - one for every 100 citizens - who can assist state government machinery in the time of disasters.

Title: Relief to hospitality sector: Ashok Gehlot government slashes bar licence fee by 10%
Content: JAIPUR: In a move to provide relief to the hospitality sector and reduce the impact of coronavirus , chief minister Ashok Gehlot announced a 10 per cent cut in bar licence fee for hotels and restaurants in the state assembly on Friday.He made the announcement while replying to the Appropriation Bill 2020 in the assembly. The hospitality sector the desert state has been on the receiving end, incurring losses following a decline in both domestic and foreign travellers.Gehlot also made a slew of new announcements in his 40-minute speech, followed by a voice vote. As in the previous budget, he announced opening of 31 new colleges in the upcoming academic session. This is the second highest in the number of colleges being announced in an academic year in the history of the state. “Last year, we announced 50 new colleges, aiming to make the state an education hub in the country. This year, we will continue to open new colleges to make the state a hub,” said Gehlot. All these colleges will come up in blocks and tehsils which either does not have a government college or have high gross enrolment ratio in higher education.Fulfilling the long pending demand by the minorities department, the government will now include children enrolled in government registered ‘madrasas’ in the insurance scheme for students. The scheme will benefit close to two lakh students studying in 3,500 religious seminaries. He also increased the remuneration of ‘shiksha karmi’, para teachers and ‘madrasa’ para teachers by 15 per cent.Replying to the demand of Opposition for a package for farmers hit by the recent hailstorms, Gehlot said, “Our government is with the farmers. We are ready to extend all kind of help to farmers in distress. The government is carrying out a special crop damage assessment which will be completed by March 20. Grants will be released to affected farmers,” he assured. He also informed that the assembly that the government has released Rs 1,410 crore for citizens, including farmers who suffered due to various natural disasters, till March.He also accused the central government for not releasing Rs 3,553 crore for relief work despite repeated reminders. Charging the previous government of putting the state in a financial mess, Gehlot said that the state had revenue deficit during the five years of BJP rule.

Title: Aurangabad: HC orders probe against SP for crossing jurisdiction
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: The Aurangabad bench of the Bombay high court directed the state government, the home department to institute an inquiry against the Osmanabad superintendent of police for directing a police team to raid a premises in adjoining Latur district in 2019 without giving any intimation to the Latur police.

The bench also directed that an inquiry be made into the circumstances due to which the intimation was not given to the Latur SP before taking any action. The bench also ordered inquiry against the then special IG Police, “who had allegedly passed oral instructions to the Osmanabad SP for taking such action.” The inquiry report has to be submitted in the court in four months.

The Osmanabad SP had ordered a sub-inspector attached to the anti-dacoity squad to conduct a raid in neighbouring Latur district in January 2019. The police had arrested 36 people under sections 4 and 5 of Maharashtra Prevention of Gambling Act, 1887. The area falls under the jurisdiction of Latur MIDC police station.

The suspects, Balaji Arjunrao Zunjure and 35 others, approached the court through lawyer P P More seeking inquiry and appropriate action against the cops, who crossed their jurisdiction.

While disposing of the petition, the bench comprising Justices T V Nalawade and M G Sewlikar on March 6 observed “inquiry needs to be made as to what were the circumstances due to which such intimation was not given to the Latur SP before taking any action.”

It also observed that “if the superiors had no trust in Latur SP and wanted to take action against the inaction on his part, they should have taken action against him after the raid. Admittedly, such action was not taken by the officers superior to the SP Latur. This circumstance cannot be ignored and this circumstance creates a probability that there was some mischief and something was fishy.”

The bench also said the enquiry is to be made against the then special IG police, who had allegedly passed oral instructions to the Osmanabad SP for taking such action and that “during enquiry, the contentions of the sub-inspector that he had written instructions from the Osmanabad SP need to be kept in mind.”

The bench further observed though “it is true that there is material to show that illegal activity was going on in that building, when there are allegations of aforesaid nature against police of demand of ransom and when there is no written instruction on record, thorough enquiry needs to be made by the department. If that is not done, the similar-minded police officers will start thinking that they can do anything even by going to the other district and nothing can happen to them.’’

Incidentally, the Osmanabad district falls under the Aurangabad Range, while Latur comes under Nanded Range Special IGP. The additional public prosecutor Mahendra Nerlikar said on Friday that the affidavit filed in this petition by the then DGP, S K Jaiswal, didn’t clarify which of the two- Aurangabad or Nanded range IGPs -had issued oral orders to Osmanabad police for taking action in Latur.

Title: Coronavirus scare in West Bengal: Port starts isolation wards in Kolkata, Haldia
Content: KOLKATA: The Kolkata port has stopped shore leave for all crew members, irrespective of their nationality or last port of call. This decision was taken a fortnight ago following instructions from the Centre, said Vinit Kumar, chairman of Syama Prasad Mookerjee Port Trust.Shipping agents have been instructed to adopt all protective measures when boarding ships in Kolkata, Haldia, Budge Budge and smaller jetties. Screening of all crew continued and information was being shared with all agencies, Kumar said.“Since January 29, we have screened 8,145 crew members of 470 ships. At smaller jetties, screening is being conducted by Inland Waterways Transport. We have set up an eight-bed isolation ward at the port hospital in Taratala and a four-bed ward in Haldia. An SOP has been evolved to shift any Covid-19 suspect from a ship or any port premises to isolation wards. If need be, we can increase the number of beds in Kolkata to 30,” Kumar said.Masters of vessels are sending details of crew —nationality, last port of call and health condition— to SPMPT. Only after the port health officer clears the details are the ships being allowed to berth in Kolkata, Haldia and Budge Budge. Even then, medical teams screen the crew.

Title: Coronavirus in Lucknow: City’s no to maids, weddings & ATMs
Content: LUCKNOW: City residents are making urgent changes in lifestyle to combat the colossal public health challenge posed by the novel coronavirus , as the global toll crosses the 5,000 mark.From sending domestic helps to indefinite leave and working from home to avoiding weddings and even ATMs — citizens are pulling out all the stops to curb a pandemic that already has 1.4 lakh confirmed patients worldwide. Kamal Bhasin, a businesswoman in LDA Colony , said her whole neighbourhood had asked maids to stay home. “Juggling household chores with office work is a challenge, but obviously not as big,” she said.Charbagh resident Mukesh Mishra and his wife were supposed to attend a family wedding in Chandigarh in March-end. “But, we decided to cancel the trip. Many of our relatives who live abroad will be there at the function. We cannot risk an infection at our age,” said the man who is pushing 70. If eating out on weekends is no longer an option for homemaker Rimjhim Sharma and her family, Nalini Singh of Gomtinagar is ignoring food delivery options. People are even not using ATMs. “Digital wallets are safer. Who knows if an infected person has used machine,” said student Rahul Pathak.

Title: 7 centres to collect samples from suspected cases
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: Even before the district reported three cases of Covid-19 for the first time by Friday evening, the district administration was geared up to face the pandemic.In a meeting with representatives of local bodies, district collector K Gopalakrishnan said that district was 100% prepared to face the situation. The collector said that all persons with fever or cough need not crowd at the Medical College Hospital for testing.“We have arranged basic screening facilities in other government hospitals in the district. In addition to Medical College Hospital, facilities are ready to collect samples at General Hospital, Peroorkada District Hospital, Nedumangad District Hospital, Fort Taluk Hospital, ESI Hospital and Neyyatinkara General Hospital,” he said.People with symptoms and who have primary, secondary or tertiary contacts with suspected cases can contact any of these hospitals for screening.The district administration has also arranged over 100 ambulances to bring persons under quarantine to isolation wards.Two ambulances are parked near airport to bring suspected cases to hospital. The ambulances will be sanitised after each use.“There is no need to worry over the isolation wards. The district has enough number of beds and more are getting ready. In addition to rooms available at Medical College Hospital and General Hospital, we have also decided to open defunct hospital buildings as isolation wards. The closed SR Medical College Hospital at Varkala and unused beds of SUT Royal will be utilized as isolation wards. With this, around 1,200 beds will be ready for isolation process,” the collector said.In addition to the testing facility which started functioning at Medical College Hospital on Thursday, the Rajiv Gandhi Centre for Biotechnology (RGCB) is also equipped to conduct testing for Covid-19. “We are waiting for consent from Indian Council for Medical Research to start the testing facility at RGCB. The consent is expected in a day or two,” the collector said.The disaster management cell of district administration is ready to clear doubts of people regarding Covid-19.The toll free number ‘1077’, which had around three lines, has been upgraded with nine lines.Collector said that 30 PG students of Sree Gokulam Medical College are handling the calls after proper training.“The lines will be available 24x7 and the students have been given training to clear doubts and concerns with accurate information,” the collector said.The Medical College Hospital has a clinic, 49 isolation rooms and ICUs for treating Covid-19 patients. The Covid clinic was started to avoid mingling of patients with others.The OP of Covid-19 clinic is located at the ground floor of Kerala Health Research and Welfare Society (KHRWS) deluxe pay ward. Specially trained doctors and patients are available at this place.In General Hospital, KHRWS pay wards have been readied for Covid-19 patients. Twenty four rooms are ready for patents under isolation at General Hospital, which also opened a clinic which functions round the clock.

Title: Events get cancelled over Covid-19, hotels rue losses
Content:
aa

Prayagraj: Hotels and restaurants in Prayagraj are busy counting losses as the recent novel coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak is forcing organisers to cancel events and parties.

Hoteliers claim that several conferences and meetings scheduled to be held at their hotels have been cancelled due to travel restrictions imposed by several countries and the recent advisory urging residents to avoid gatherings and crowded places.

Hotel owners said that occupancy of rooms has come down by 30-40% within the past 10 days due to the fear of an outbreak.

A city-based hotelier said that the occupancy rates are likely to go down further over the next few days. He said that most of his clients are considering postponing conferences\seminars and parties in the wake of the health crisis.

UP State Tourism Development Corporation (UPSTDC) senior manager DP Singh said the occupancy in two hotels of the corporation has gone down to 20 -30% in past 10 days. “Our clients started cancelling reservations within a week after coronavirus cases were reported in the country.”

Many travellers have also cancelled their vacations, especially those who had planned to visit coronavirus-affected destinations.

“The virus outbreak has dealt a huge blow to the hotel industry in the city. Our international clients have almost stopped visiting the city and there is a drastic fall in our domestic business as well,” said another hotelier in the city.

Meanwhile, president of Prayagraj Hotel Association Sardar Joginder Singh said, “Occupancy in most hotels has decreased by 30-40% due to coronavirus. Worried travellers are either cancelling their bookings or postponing their plans. We have also restricted bookings by travellers from Asian countries like China, Hongkong, Japan and Macau.”

Title: Water supply restored to Miramar, Caranzalem
Content:
Panaji: Water supply to Miramar and Caranzalem was restored within hours on Friday morning as PWD officials worked through the night to identify the damage to a pipeline that burst in St Inez around 6.15pm on Thursday.

“The Natural Gas Agency damaged a 350mm diameter DI pipeline near Caculo Mall, St Inez. The breakdown was attended to and water supply has been restored,” PWD executive engineer Nivruti Parsekar, said.

The pipeline, which burst during drilling activity, carries water to Caranzalem and Miramar. It was repaired by 7am on Friday.

Title: MP demands separate Marathwada railway corporation
Content:
File photo of Mumbai railway station

AURANGABAD: Aurangabad MP Imtiaz Jaleel has demanded the formation of an independent Marathwada railway corporation on the lines of Konkan railway corporation .

He voiced this demand during the ongoing parliament session for entire Marathwada region. The MP demanded the construction of railway pitline, thus connecting Marathwada to several other industrial and tourist destinations across the country through long-route trains.

He said, “Entire Marathwada region, especially Aurangabad should be attached to Central Railways , instead of the current South Central Railway .”

While raising the demand of doubling the tracks and electrification for Parbhani – Manmad, Jaleel said, “SCR general manager has replied to us in written that preliminary engineering, traffic survey was completed and the report was submitted to the board with a cost of Rs 2,199 and the rate of return (ROR) at 2.12% in December 2017.”

He demanded laying of pitline with an investment of Rs 18 crores, having a capacity to cater trains with of 26 coaches. “Whenever we demand improved connectivity of the trains to Marathwada, our demands are turned down due to non-availability of coach facility at Aurangabad.”

He also demanded funds for the construction of railway under bridge (RUB) at Shivajinagar area. PWD has estimated the cost of bridge construction at Rs 38 crore while the railways have estimated the construction of this bridge with the cost of about Rs 6 crores.

Title: Aurangabad: State, civic chief told to file affidavit on formation of biodiversity panels
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: The Aurangabad bench of the Bombay high court on Thursday asked the state government to file its say on constitution of biodiversity committees in each district of Maharashtra.

The court has also asked the Aurangabad municipal commissioner to file an affidavit by March 18 on what steps the civic body has taken as per the resolution passed in the meeting of biodiversity management committee held on September 22, 2015.

The court has also instructed the municipal commissioner will have to remain present in court if the addidavit is not filed in the given time.

The matter came up for hearing before Justices Z A Haq and S M Gavhane on Thursday. Mahesh Bharaswadkar , the lawyer representing the petitioner Salim Ali Lake Conservation Forum, pointed out in the court that no steps have yet been taken by the state government to constitute biodiversity committees across the districts.

He also pointed out that no action has been taken by the AMC on implementation on expert committee report with respect to declaring Salim Ali Lake a biodiversity heritage site.

The forum, a non-government organization, through its coordinator Arvind Keshav Pujari , had in 2013 approached the high court seeking direction to the AMC to declare Salim Ali Lake in Aurangabad as a biodiversity heritage site. The petition pointed out that the forum members noticed that civic body was carrying out beautification and development activity in and around Salim Ali Lake and made a representation to the municipal corporation expressing the need to preserve the biodiversity at the site.

When the matter came up for hearing, Bharaswadkar said “No steps are taken as per the resolution passed in the meeting held on September 22, 2015. Even the affidavit sworn by the Aurangabad municipal commissioner on February 7, 2019, is silent on the point...’’

While placing the next date of hearing for March 23, the bench directed the state government to “file affidavit pointing out whether the grievance of the petitioner in this regard is proper or not. The affidavit shall be filed till March 18, 2020.”

Title: A walking talking map
Content:
On Thursday, during a question and answer session held post the screening of Sindhustan at the Bangalore International Centre, celebrity stylist and filmmaker Sapna Bhavnani was asked a slightly unexpected question. The logic behind the question held ground though. “Why haven’t Sindhis who migrated from Pakistan fought for a state of their own in India?” “That is because we are true Sufis!” joked Bhavnani adding that till date her community had tried and failed in getting a Doordarshan channel in Sindhi, never mind a state. Deliberating on the question a whole day later, Bhavnani said, “I am quite amazed that we have not got anything. In India, states are based on languages spoken, and because the Sindhi language is dying, we don’t have a basis to fight for a state. We needed to have at least fought for a DD channel, at least then people would have had access to the language and a lot more could have been done,” Bhavnani said.

While she may not look it, since the launch of her documentary Sindhustan, Bhavnani has inadvertently become the flag bearer of Sindhi culture. “Google Sindhi and chances are my name will pop right on top!” she jokes. A documentary with a duration of a little over an hour, Sindhustan is unique because it brings together many threads of the Sindhi culture and then, like a jigsaw that finally falls into place, ties it up gloriously with tattoos Bhavnani got inked on her legs: tattoos which document the tales of Sindhi survivors of the partition in Ajrakh and Madhubani art. As the film’s concept note explains, ‘Sindhustan’ is the story of the largest migration of a culture in history told through ink (tattoos).’ “When I sat down to work on the story, I knew that I wanted to focus on memories that were personal, memories that wouldn’t be readily available on Google,” Bhavnani said. Which is why starting from a kitchen where her aunt is seen preparing for Sindhi kadhi, the film takes the viewer on an immersive journey, one that flows along through the stories the partition survivors – mostly in their late 70s and 80s –narrate. “Because we don’t have a language of our own, a lot of the stories of Sindhis migrating to India during partition have been forgotten,” says Bhavnani about why she chose to get the speakers to share personal tales. While the elders shared generously, it wasn’t enough for Bhavnani to just focus on the stories. She wanted to make the entire experience even more personal. That’s when a tale her grandmother narrated, “about older times when people tattooed themselves to identify their tribes struck her”. Bhavnani decided to ink the stories the elders shared. Today, she is a human map, with names of places like Karachi, Shikarpur, and Sindh etched on her legs.

For Bhavnani, the film has given her a sense of finally having found her roots. “I was lost for a long time, till I discovered the history of my community,” she said but there’s one unfulfilled dream. “I was so desperate to get to Sindh. Once, my open tweet to Imran Khan asking him to grant me permission went viral with Sindhis across the border sharing it. I have for now made peace with the fact that I may not be able to go there with things being the way they are,” Bhavnani rued.

NO PAIN, NO GAIN

The process of getting the tattoos is another aspect Sindhustan shows. Lack of budget and time meant that Bhavnani had to go under the needle for 10 days in Goa. “A process that would have taken five years was done in 10 days,” she says. “I took (medicinal) injection for the first six days and I sat for 30 hours, but after that, my body couldn’t take it, so I spent the last four days getting inked in a hospital’s operation theatre. I couldn’t walk for a month and a half after that,” Bhavnani recalled. While the tattoos, done by Yogesh Pawar, have inspired viewers around the world, for Bhavnani, the greatest gratification came from the reactions by her interviewees. “They were blown that I had tattooed their stories,” she said. As a walking history of the survivor tales of Sindhis, Bhavnani has plans to insure her legs. There’s more. “When I die, I actually want my legs to be taxidermied because they contain the history of an entire community,” she said.

Title: Local body members to trace contacts
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: Understanding that a ward member or ASHA worker in a locality will have better information about individuals returning from Covid-19 affected countries, the state government has given the task of tracing contacts to the local body members and health workers. The first district-level meeting of members of three-tier local bodies was held here on Friday.Health minister K K Shailaja, who attended the meeting held at the district panchayat office, said that the local body members should keep their eyes and ears open. “Ward members and ASHA workers can help the department in tracing contacts of the infected persons. All members should function as per the protocol of the health department. District collector will co-ordinate activities in each district,” she said.Shailaja said that it was important to ensure that people who are on self-quarantine gets enough support. “They are not enemies. They are on self-quarantine so that we don’t get the disease. We should ensure that they have enough food and other necessary items. The members should ensure social distancing and wash hands frequently. Cases were reported where such persons with symptoms faced social stigma. Local body members could make effective interventions to avoid such cases,” she said.The minister said that local bodies must convene meetings to give awareness to all members to take necessary measures to prevent spread of the disease. “If members come across any case of people returning from affected countries, they should ensure that they are quarantined,” she said.Devaswom minister Kadakampally Surendran said that local body members should abstain from attending marriages, funerals and festivals. “The local body members should ensure that such events are held with minimum participation,” he said. Minister said that minimum two calls should be made to persons under self-quarantine to ensure that have necessary materials at home.MLAs in the district, district panchayat president V K Madhu, district collector K Gopalakrishnan, DMO Dr P P Preetha, among others attended the meeting. Similar meetings will be held in other districts in the coming days.

Title: Covid-19: More than the virus, they are scared of mindless criticism
Content: KOTTAYAM: The Covid-19 patient admitted to the isolation ward of the Medical College Hospital (MCH) here is fed up with the criticism he and his family have been facing on social media . “Once we overcome the disease, I won’t stay here for long. I will go abroad,” he said.The 34-year-old man along with his wife aged 28 and four-year-old daughter is confined to a small room in the isolation ward. While the husband and wife are diagnosed with Covid-19, the girl has tested negative. “Her first sample was negative. They have again taken her sample on Friday,” said the father over phone.Meanwhile, the family is very happy with the care they are getting at the isolation ward. The only difficulty is passing the time. The small room with an attached toilet does not have a television. They solely depend on their mobile phones for passing time. “We watch news on our mobile phone and go through social media. Though we don’t usually give the phone to our child, now we are forced to give her. She is bored with the stay here,” the father added.One day he opened the window of the room which was facing a compound. Some men who were working in the compound noticed it and shouted to close it as they were scared. “I have never opened it after that,” he said.The trio had gone to pick up the family from Ranni, who arrived at Kochi airport from Italy. The family from Italy has been facing the brunt of the criticism for travelling and meeting people without reporting to the medical department. The 34-year-old man, who is the son-in-law of the couple from Italy, said that he has made up his mind to remain in the isolation ward to ensure that others won’t get infected.“I know several people in my locality are being home quarantined just because of me. But I am helpless. I never knew such a thing will happen,” he added.His in-laws and brother-in-law have been working in Italy since 2000. The brother-in-law is a radiologist and an employee of the Italian government. “They were supposed to come next month only. But my father-in-law’s father, who is 92, wanted to see his son at the earliest. He told his son that he was not sure whether he will be alive by the time he arrives in April. So, the family advanced the trip,” he said.The 92-year-old man and his wife, both Covid-19-infected, are also admitted to the isolation ward of MCH. “I wanted to meet them. Though I requested the doctors, they did not allow me. However, they showed me a video clip in which they were seen talking to each other,” he added.

Title: Temple heist caught on cam, man steals Rs 12L
Content:
Bhopal: In a daring robbery in TT Nagar area on Friday, a masked man stole Rs 12 lakh from the donation box of a temple in Banganga after rendering the temple priest’s son unconscious.

The thief reached the temple early in the morning and gave prasad to the priest’s son, for offering it to the deity. When the priest’s son went to offer the prasad, the thief smothered his face with sedative-laced cloth and stole the cash.

The entire incident lasted for about seven minutes and was caught on CCTV camera in which the accused was seen revering a holy book and committing the theft calmly. The victim boy had to appear in class 12 exam. He was so terrified after the incident that the family members had to accompany him till the exam centre.

Temple priest (Mahant) Kuldeep Bairagi, told TOI that the temple at Banganga in TT Nagar is under construction and he stays in the back side of the temple.

Bairagi told TOI that around 8.15 am, he found Ritik in panic. When he asked, Ritik told him that a man gave him prasad for the goddess.

“While he was offering the prasad, the accused gtabbed him from behind and smothered his face with some sedative laced cloth, and he fell unconscious. The accused then stole cash Rs 12 lakh kept in donation box and fled the spot.

Bairagi said that when he checked CCTV camera fitted at the temple, he found that the accused attacked Ritik from back and when he fell unconscious, he committed the theft calmly within seven minutes. He said that the accused revered a holy book kept above the donation box and kept it aside. Subsequently he reported the matter to TT Nagar police. Bairagi said that the cash was collected as donation for construction work of temple.

Investigation officer ASI Narayan Thakur said that police investigated the crime scene with help of FSL team and registered a theft complaint. Sections of poisoning have been added to case. Search was on to nab the accused who had covered his face with a mask and was also wearing a goggle.

Title: Lawyers oppose move to bring them under CPA
Content:
Kanpur: The advocates of the city on Friday while strongly opposing the proposal of the government to bring them under the ambit of the Consumer Protection Act ( CPA ) handed over a memorandum to the additional district magistrate (city. The protest was held under the banner of Adhivakta Kalyan Sangharsh Samiti.

Convener of the samiti, Ravindra Sharma, said the advocates are officials of courts and play a significant role in the judicial process.

He said the advocate fraternity would never accept the proposal. He has demanded immediate withdrawal of the proposed amendment in the Act.

Later, members of the Adhivakta Kalyan Samiti handed over a memorandum to ADM (city) Vivek Kumar.

The ADM city assured the advocates that their memorandum would be sent to the minister.

Title: P&W to finish A320 upgrades by May-end
Content: Hyderabad: Engine maker Pratt & Whitney expects to complete retrofitting all of its GTF (geared turbofan) engines currently on Airbus A320neo ahead of the May 31, 2020 deadline set up Indian aviation regulator DCGA, an official of the company said on Friday on the sidelines of Wings India 2020. While IndiGo has 100 A320neos, GoAir has 50. “We have already retrofitted 230 engines out of 300 on the 150 A320neos in India and expect to complete it before time,” Ashmita Sethi, MD, P&W India said. TNN

Title: Agri varsity cancels its 4th convocation
Content: Hyderabad: Professor Jayashankar Telangana State Agricultural University has postponed its fourth convocation ceremony scheduled to be held on March 18 due to Covid-19 spread. Registrar Prof S Krishna, in an official release, said that the new date will be announced after situation comes to normal. Candidates can get further information on the university website (www.pjtsau.edu.in).

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: DMRC drive focuses on touch points and high-footfall stations
Content: NEW DELHI: Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC) has intensified cleaning of its trains and 264 stations in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak . Delhi government, which is supervising the disinfection of metro trains and buses, has also started sanitising buses arriving from other states to the three inter-state bus terminals of the city.A DMRC spokesperson said that while all the metro trains are cleaned thoroughly every day before the start of services and at terminal stations after every trip, the practice has been intensified with more rigorous cleaning of stations. Special emphasis is on locations like hand railings, train doors, token vending machines, passenger emergency alarms, elevators and escalators among other places where hands come in direct contact.“Mechanised cleaning of metro stations is being carried out 24X7, which includes scrubbing and wet cleaning of floor, concourse, platform, passages, stairs, station control rooms, ancillary building areas, doors, window frames, shutters, etc.,” the spokesperson said.Weekly, fortnightly and monthly activities are also being planned for mechanised cleaning, he added.“To provide better service to metro commuters, the floors and seats of metro trains are cleaned during revenue hours. For this, specially trained additional housekeeping staff are deployed in two shifts at terminal metro stations of all the lines,” he said.He stressed that special cleaning drives are carried out at the busy stations. DMRC is also focusing on cleaning of surrounding areas, removal of unauthorised posters, cleaning of parking areas, proper disposal of garbage and plastic wastes and cleaning of security frisking area and toilets. “Parking areas are cleaned regularly. Weekly intensive cleaning is carried out every Saturday night,” the spokesperson said.DMRC said that eco-friendly chemicals and high standard equipment are being used for cleaning of stations and trains. “Cold water high pressure jet, battery operated walk-behind automatic scrubber dryer, automated vacuum cleaner, steam cleaner and automatic escalator cleaners are being used.”“Delhi Metro staff have also been sensitised and guidelines have been circulated regarding dos and dont’s to prevent the spread of coronavirus. Dos and dont’s in both English and Hindi are also being displayed on digital screens at major stations like Rajiv Chowk, Kashmere Gate, Central Secretariat, Chandni Chowk, New Delhi, etc.,” the spokesperson said.“The civic bodies have also been requested to help in keeping the areas outside the metro stations clean,” he added.

Title: Kanpur: Girl commits ‘suicide’, cops detain parents
Content:
Representative image

KANPUR: After receiving information that a girl, who had died under mysterious circumstances, was cremated quietly, police on Friday, detained her parents and one of their relatives. The incident had occurred in Balai Buzurg village under Derapur police station of Kanpur Dehat .

After the 20-year-old girl’s death on Wednesday, her family initially had claimed that she had ended her life by hanging herself from the ceiling of her room after being scolded by her father over some issue. Police got suspicious when the family, without informing anyone, had conducted her last rites by immersing her body in Sengur river. According to police, the family tried to pass off the girl’s death as suicide. After the police received a tip that her body was being quietly immersed in Sengur river by her family, they went to the girl’s house for investigation.

“We have launched a search in Sengur river but the girl’s body has not been fished out so far. When our team asked them how she died, her father said that she had committed suicide by hanging. Suspecting something amiss, the police have detained her father and mother and one of their relatives. Their questioning is underway,” said inspector Neeraj Singh .

Title: IIST suspends classes till April 13
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: After the initial resistance to comply with the state government directive to suspend classes owing to Covid-19 outbreak, Indian Institute of Space Science and Technology (IIST) campus at Valiyamala near here on Friday suspended regular classes till April 13.The institute asked all students to vacate the hotels by March 16 and leave for their homes. Students were also asked to take necessary precautions as per the UGC guidelines over Covid-19. Despite the state government directives, the institution had been continuing academic activities till Friday with the argument that the institution had been assessing the situation and would take appropriate action at the right time.“All the students are advised to visit IIST website for further instructions that may be issued from time to time. All the faculty members, officers (and), staff have to attend the institute as usual. In case any one has to travel abroad during this period they are required to seek special permission from the appropriate authority,” a notification issued by the centre director V K Dadhwal said.“All are advised to follow the advisories issued by health ministry from time to time to stay healthy. These are special circumstances requiring stringent measures to contain the situation. Further necessary instruction will be issued by the deans of the institute concerned,” the notification said.

Title: Seven hours of suspense and drama at airport over rebel Congress MLAs’ return
Content:
Scindia supporters protest at Airport on Friday. ----- pics rajeev sarathe

Bhopal: The MP political drama may have more twists and turns ahead. Bhopal’s Raja Bhoj airport was the stage for one such scene in the power play on Friday when Congress and BJP workers confronted each other amid suspense over the arrival of the rebel Congress MLAs of the Jyotiraditya Scindia faction from Bengaluru.

After seven hours of yes and no, it finally became evident that the 22 MLAs won’t be arriving. They had reportedly gone back from Bengaluru airport to the resort where they have been holed up since March 9. But by then, BJP and Congress workers had nearly come to blows at the airport, forcing police to clamp section 144, deploy STF and remove both groups from the premises.

In the morning, word suddenly got around that 22 Congress MLAs would be arriving from Bengaluru at 11am. Senior Congress leader Digvijaya Singh remarked that if they arrive, all of them should be tested for coronavirus.

Mediapersons scrambled to the airport and found two buses duly parked there, with a couple of state BJP leaders flitting in and out. One of them said he had come to pick up some relatives. “A busload of them?” reporters asked. Another said he had come to pick up teerth yatris.

Soon, a group of around 50 BJP workers arrived, followed by a Congress crowd that outnumbered the saffron brigade three to one. They went eyeball to eyeball. Slogans were raised, and the two sides came uncomfortably close to each other multiple times.

Police had a hard time keeping the two sides at bay. DIG Irshad Wali then took charge and separated the rival groups. The administration imposed section 144 to ban large gatherings. The two sides dispersed, but the buses stood there. So did journalists.

The MLAs had to appear before assembly Speaker Narmada Prasad Prajapati to get their resignations accepted after Scindia joined BJP. The Speaker wanted them to tell him personally that they haven’t resigned under duress.

They were expected to arrive on three 10-seater charter planes from Bangalore. Since Scindia was in Bhopal during the day, it was expected that his loyalist MLAs would arrive here and he would meet them, possibly at the airport lounge, before leaving for Delhi in the evening. The airport witnessed heavy deployment of police and STF, apart from CISF.

Scores of Bharatiya Janata Yuva Morcha workers, led by its state president Abhilash Pandey, thronged the airport. Two buses were brought by BJP leaders, fuelling speculation that the MLAs’ arrival from Bengaluru was imminent.

Soon enough, Congress workers arrived in strength, led by Guddu Chouhan.

A slogan-shouting match began. The two groups repeatedly came close to each other. Police acted as buffer and kept the two sides at bay. Security personnel locked the main exit of the airport from inside at 3.10pm, and at 3.45pm, police announced section 144 at the airport. Congress workers were taken in a police bus from airport.

Around 4.15pm, the two buses went off, empty.

It later came to light that the Congress MLAs had gone to Bengaluru airport, but did not board the planes and returned to the resort

State Congress media in-charge Shobha Oza went to the airport to ‘receive’ the six former ministers who were supposed to come from Bengaluru. “BJP has kidnapped our MLAs. Why aren’t they bringing them back?” she asked. Oza left an hour before Scindia arrived.

During the daylong drama at the airport, PWD minister Sajjan Singh Verma returned Bhopal from Jaipur, where Congress MLAs are lodged. “Congress MLAs are free and their phones are also with them, unlike BJP, which has forcefully kept Congress MLAs in Bengaluru,” he said. Verma returned to Jaipur in the evening.

Police deployment continued at the airport. BJP leaders voiced security concerns for the 22 MLAs when they return from Bengaluru.

Title: Tadipatri tense as tempers flare during filing of nominations
Content:
Tadipatri remained tense on Friday after YSRC and TDP workers came close to exchanging blows.

On hearing that YSRC workers were preventing TDP candidates from filing nominations for the municipal polls at Tadipatri in Anantapur district, former minister JC Diwakar Reddy arrived at the local municipal office along with his followers.

But local police prevented Reddy from entering the office saying MLA Kethireddy Pedda Reddy’s son Harshavardhan Reddy was inside and that they would allow him in once Harshavardhan came out.

The former minister’s supporters objected to the suggestion and a minor altercation followed.

The TDP men and YSRC workers at the spot hurled abuses at each other.

Police, however, managed to thwart a clash by dispersing both groups from the spot.

Title: These nurses are fighting stigma too
Content: KOTTAYAM: The four Covid-19 patients in the isolation ward of the Medical College Hospital ( MCH ), Kottayam , find relief in talking to the nursing staff who attend to them. However, the three male nurses who voluntarily opted to do this duty, which most of their colleagues have avoided, are not just battling a pandemic but also social stigma.On Thursday, they were politely told by their landlord to vacate the place they had rented out as the family turned apprehensive of their presence at the house. Though the trio, all in their early 30s, got a temporary accommodation in the hospital, they doubt whether anybody will provide them a place to stay in the future.“Our house owner’s wife told us on Thursday morning that their relatives and neighbours have raised concerns about her husband’s health as we were staying there,” said one of them.“She said that there was no medicine for Covid-19. We have been staying there since the deluge of 2018 and maintained a good relationship with them. So, considering their fear, we decided to move out ,” said the 31-year-old Pathanamthitta native.After moving out, they apprised the MCH authorities of the situation. They alleged that the Medical College principal initially said that he could not arrange any accommodation for them. They then had to run after the authorities to find a temporary place to sleep. Later, they were allotted two rooms in the same floor where the isolation ward functions. They then met MCH superintendent Dr T K Jayakumar , who promised them a staff quarters for two weeks. The quarters, which is in a dilapidated condition, is expected be readied soon.“This is a difficult situation. We have voluntarily taken up this duty. We are extending all support to the state government in its fight against the disease. But when in need, we are left on our own. By now, everyone in the locality has identified us. Who will give us accommodation after two weeks?,” said the youth who has been a staff nurse at the MCH for the last eight years.Meanwhile, the house owner’s wife said she had never asked them to vacate. “I just shared the concern raised by my daughter, who is a nurse in London, and another close relative, who is a nurse in Italy. They raised apprehensions about the health of my husband, who had undergone a bypass surgery four months ago. They told us that Covid-19 is dangerous for old and sick persons,” said the 54-year-old woman.Her husband, who is around 60, is a retired Navy officer. “We can’t ask them (nurses) to move out all of a sudden. They have been staying here for over one-and-a half years,” she added.Meanwhile, Indira P G, nursing officer, MCH, said that the nursing staff are under constant stress and they not only need the support of their families but also the society. “The society should realise what would be the world like if none of the nurses wanted to work in such situations,” she said.District collector P K Sudheer Babu said necessary action has been taken to mitigate the plight of the nurses. “The MCH authorities have arranged a temporary stay for them,” he said. He also said that he has directed the MCH superintendent to check the possibility of providing them accommodation on the hospital premises itself.

Title: Police rescue three ‘cattle thieves’ from being lynched in Kanpur
Content:
Representative image

KANPUR: Police on Friday morning rescued three men from being lynched by a mob in Ratepur village under Saandh police station of the district. The mob assaulted them suspecting them cattle thieves.

According to villagers, the men were trying to escape with three buffaloes belonging to Buddhi Lal Yadav and his neighbour.

Station House officer Devendra Rawat said the police personnel rescued the three men from the mob.

The police identified the three men as Niyamat, his two sons, Salim and Riyaz. They were allegedly trying to escape with three buffaloes belonging to Buddhi Lal Yadav and his neighbour in a loader during the early hours of Friday.

On coming across commotion, Buddhi Lal raised alarm to alert the villagers following which the mob chased the trio and nabbed them. Soon, the angry mob started assaulting them, the police official said.

“On being informed, a police team managed to reach in time, rescued the the three men and took them into its custody. We have impounded their vehicles, including a loader for investigation,” the SHO said and added, "The three men, residents of Machariya area of Naubasta, had allegedly come on couple of two-wheelers and a loader to steal buffaloes. Medical aid was provided to them for injuries caused to them during the attack. An FIR has been lodged on the basis of a complaint and further investigations are being conducted n this regard.”

Title: Covid-19 scare in Telangana: OU, KU stop biometric attendance in colleges
Content: HYDERABAD: Osmania and Kakatiya universities have stopped recording attendance through Aadhaar-based biometric system in its affiliated colleges as a precautionary measure against coronavirus (Covid-19).Both the state universities have issued circulars to all affiliated colleges as directed by the University Grants Commission (UGC) to exempt employees from marking their attendance on the biometric system due to concerns that chances of virus spread through touch may increase.“As a preventive measure to curb spread of Covid-19, the principals of campus/constituent and all affiliated colleges under the jurisdiction of Osmania University are hereby informed to withhold recording of the attendance of staff and students of their colleges through Aadhaar-based biometric system until further orders and maintain attendance registers as it was done earlier,” read the circular issued by OU on Thursday. Similar orders were issued in KU on March 7 with staff and students asked to maintain manual attendance until further instructions are issued.The OU directive comes nearly a month after it made Covid-19 tests mandatory for Chinese students returning from vacation or seeking admissions for the 2020-21 academic year. Even other state universities such as Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University, Telangana University, and Satvahana University are likely to issue similar directives soon.The UGC has also issued detailed guidelines to all higher educational institutions on ways to contain Covid-19 spread. The commission has directed all institutions to avoid large gatherings, disinfect frequently-used surfaces such as door knobs, switches, desktops, and railings within the campus as well as provide alcohol-based sanitisers in colleges and hostels.The UGC has also asked teachers to be alert and look out for students with cold, cough, fever and difficulty in breathing and have them tested immediately.

Title: High court pulls up election commission
Content:
Vijayawada: The high court on Friday pulled up the state election commission for not taking action on the complaints about malpractices and violation of the model code of conduct during local body elections .

Kovelamudi Ravindra, a TDP functionary, moved the high court alleging that the SEC was not taking any action even after they submitted video evidence.

Arguing on behalf of Ravindra, senior counsel P Veera Reddy told the court that the ruling party members were influencing the voters by distributing sarees at Tadipatri in Anantapur district.

In Chittoor district, village volunteers are involved in the election campaign. Though complaints were lodged in both the incidents along with photos and videos on March 8 and 9, no action was initiated, he said.

The counsel for the SEC told the court that the commission has asked for reports from district collectors to initiate necessary action. Expressing displeasure over the reply, the high court asked why the has the election commission failed to get report from the collectors without delay.

The high court observed that the conducting elections in a free and fair manner was the primary duty of the election commission and it has failed to act accordingly even after the high court issued orders recently in other matter.

The HC asked why the elections were being conducted in very short span of time whereas earlier it was told to the court that 40 days were required to complete the process.

As the counsel for the SEC told the court that the fixing the schedule was in the ambit of the state government, Veera Reddy said that the state government was conducting elections in a hurry without giving ample time. While five days should be given to file nominations, only three was given this time, he said.

The HC asked the election commission to file the action taken report by Monday when the next hearing would take place.

The high court also directed the high court registrar to send the copy of the order issued in the matter of removing party colours on government buildings to the central election commission so as to monitor the functioning of the state election commission.

Title: Hyderabad Corona Update: After cancellations, flyers scamper around for refunds in Hyderabad
Content: HYDERABAD: Despite assurances from airline operators, scores of flyers from the city were seen scampering around for refunds, on Friday, after cancelling their tickets in the wake of the Coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak. Passengers complained that the carriers were either not responding to their requests or forcibly withholding their payments, for future bookings. Worse, in some cases they are even levying a cancellation charge, flyers added.“Our ticket is on March 13, which is between 12th and 31st March. We have cancelled the ticket before flight departure and for our and other passengers’ safety. Please do fair business and issue us a refund (sic),” wrote a passenger on social media, as the airline insisted on charging a cancellation fee.Along with the international sector, travel agents say, 70% to 80% of domestic bookings too have been called off, over the last few days. And while the cancellations were limited to March, so far, passengers have now started rescheduling or scrapping their April plans too. In fact, IndiGo stated that its daily bookings in recent days has seen a 15% to 20% drop and that it expects its “quarterly earnings to be materially impacted” because of this.Meanwhile, the lack of clarity over refunds has left several passengers fuming. “@goairlinesindia @GoAirFlights @makemytrip @makemytripcare very disappointed with your service. My flight from Kolkata to Bangalore via Hyderabad which was one stop was cancelled while I was waiting at Kolkata airport. kindly help me out to get refund,” wrote another passenger, adding, “Because of your service I have to suffer the whole night at Hyderabad airport and Goair ground staff were like I can’t help you out. You can book bus or take any medium to travel. This is so horrible. (sic)”Another international flyer posted: “@AirAsia following directions from GOI I have to reschedule my flight from Sydney to Hyderabad. However, I am being charged $150 for date change. Messages to Air Asia support remain unanswered.”“There is a serious concern with refunds. Not all airlines are offering it. Instead, some are asking passengers to use it on their next booking,” said Abdul Majid Faheem, chairman, Travel Agents Federation of India (Andhra Pradesh and Telangana).

Title: We will win 80% of seats, says Avanthi
Content:
Visakhapatnam: State tourism minister and senior YSRC leader, M Srinivasa Rao said that his party will win 80 per cent of seats in the upcoming local bodies’ elections, including in the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation (GVMC).

Speaking to TOI, in an exclusive interview, the minister exuded confidence that YSRC will win a thumping majority in all 39 mandals in ZPTC (zilla parishad territorial constituency) and MPTC (mandal parishad territorial constituency) elections. “There are half a dozen aspirants for the mayor’s post and chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy will decide on it,” he added.

The YSRC leader further said that the services of sincere party workers will be recognised. “Urban voters are now attracted to YSRC. It’s natural that there will be a rebel issue. There will be more aspirants for YSRC,” he said.

Discussing the administration of GVMC, Srinivasa Rao said that decentralisation of the GVMC administration will take place soon.

Talking about the operationalisation of the new railway zone, the tourism minister said that both YSRC national general secretary Vijayasai Reddy and MP MVV Satyanarayana have written to the railway minister.

Title: Coronavirus scare: IIT-Hyderabad extends mid-semester break
Content: HYDERABAD: The Indian Institute of Technology, Hyderabad (IIT-H) has extended its mid-semester break till March 29 in their effort to stem the spread of coronavirus (Covid-19). An e-mail was sent to all students by the dean of students welfare on Friday evening announcing changes in the academic calendar.“Due to the situation prevailing because of Covid-19, the institute has decided to extend the mid-semester break till March 29, 2020. Classes will start on March 30, 2020 (Monday),” read the e-mail.“The institute had decided to revise the academic calendar for the period of April-May 2020 to compensate for the extension of the mid-semester break, which will be circulated shortly,” the e-mail stated.The dean of students welfare has further advised students who have gone home not to return to the campus till further notice. The management has also advised students within the premises not to travel out during this period.The decision by IIT-H comes after several other institutions such as IIT-Delhi, IIT-Kharagpur, IIT-Kanpur decided to suspend classes amid Covid-19 scare.

Title: CM’s strictures ignored, Avanthi fields daughter
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Tourism minister Avanti Srinivasa Rao ’s daughter Dr. Lakshmi Priyanka has entered the fray for local bodies elections.

She is the YSRC candidate from ward 6 (PM Palem area) in Bheemili constituency. Lakshmi Priyanka is involved in the administration of Avanti Educational Institutions.

It is learnt that the party high command has not given the green signal as of now to Priyanka’s candidature but it is expected that party general secretary Vijayasai Reddy is likely to convince chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy.

Priyanka has been involved in social service for the last few years. She campaigned for her father during the Lok Sabha election in 2014 in Anakapalle. She was also involved in the campaign when he fought assembly polls from Bheemili in 2019.

Party sources said the minister’s personal assistant Chandra Rao was pitching to get the seat for his wife. Sources said Priyanka is in for a stiff fight.

The YSRC president had sent a circular instructing MLAs and in-charges of constituencies not to field their kin in the election. A week ago a few MLAs had objected to relatives entering the fray for ZPTC and MPTC elections.

The second list of candidates released by YSRC on Friday included the names of Gajuwaka MLA Tippala Nagireddy’s son Vamsi, Anakapalli MLA Amar’s relative in Mindi village, Visakha East constituency in-charge Akkaramani Vijaya Nirmala’s relative in ward 2.

Many in YSRC said the party high command was showing favouritism by allowing family members of various leaders to contest the local body elections.

Title: Police put people-friendly programmes on hold in city
Content:
A file photo of police commissioner P S Harsha undertaking the My Beat My Pride initiative where officers of t... Read More

Mangaluru: On August 9, 2019, when city police commissioner P S Harsha took charge, he backed the Mangaluru city police to be receptive to the people’s policing needs and to be people-friendly. Cut to the December 19 anti-CAA/NRC protest violence that left two dead in alleged police firing, and the city police has perceivably dragged itself into a deep hole and has gone into a shell .

This is evident from the fact that the Friday phone- in programme, where the public get an opportunity to raise their grievances with the top cop, has been put on hold for the time being.

The last phone-in programme was held on November 29, 2019. Former city police commissioner M Chandra Sekhar, along with the then DCP (crime and traffic) Dr Sanjeev M Patil had launched this programme so that people could directly interact with the cops.

Former police chief T R Suresh was part of the 100th Mangaluru city police phone-in programme.

The hour-long programme used to register an average of 15 calls that used to be answered in the presence of senior officers including traffic police personnel.

“Among issues raised by the public, civic issues used to outnumber policing ones. However, there were callers who would reach out to the department, and we have been able to solve several issues related to traffic. The programme has been put on hold for the time being,” a senior officer said.

Another major initiative launched by city police commissioner Harsha was ‘MyBeat, My Pride’, an upgraded beat system. Through this system, the commissioner would literally walk the beat with the designated beat constable to get a first-hand feel of people’s problems. As part of this, several WhatsApp groups were created. However, after the December 19 violence, several members have exited from the group and most groups have not been active. Not much information is being sent out by the police on the groups.

An officer said, “The department is busy with court and other related work. The commissioner appeared before the magistrate on Thursday, for the inquiry into the firing. Similarly, the top cop has to appear before the high court and national and state human rights commission.” The city police commissioner submitted a nearly 21-page written statement, with 936 supportive documents and evidence.

Title: IISER scientists bag Rs 11cr govt funding for research on quantum computing
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: Researchers from the Indian Institute of Science Education and Research (IISER), Thiruvananthapuram, led by Dr Madhu Thalakulam and Dr Anil Shaji have jointly been awarded a research grant of Rs 11.38 crore under the Quantum Enabled Science and Technology (QuEST) programme.

QuEST is an initiative of the department of science and technology, government of India.

The grant is for developing a quantum computer and associated technologies as part of the overall mission of QuEST to jump-start research and development activities in quantum technologies in India.

The group led by Dr Madhu Thalakulam will focus on the design and realization of a quantum information processor based on electron-spins in silicon quantum dots.

Dr Anil Shaji’s group will focus on the theoretical aspects related this project.

“The computers we see today utilize principles of classical physics which is entirely based on the deterministic nature of the physical systems & macroscopic world. Quantum computers are radically different units altogether. The working principles are quantum superposition, particle-wave dual nature of physical systems. The basic units in a classical computer is a BIT. Information, written in the binary language, can be stored and manipulated on arrays of billions of BITS in a modern microprocessor. In quantum computing, the analogous basic unit is a Qubit (quantum-BIT) which can exist not only in the ON and the OFF state but in an infinity of states ‘in-between’ where it is both ON and OFF at the same time due to quantum superposition. Computers made with these Qubits come with enormous powers for various jobs. In a recent experiment in the quantum computer that Google built with 53 Qubits, a computational problem that is estimated to take 10,000 years to solve if it is run on the fastest supercomputer on earth, was solved within a matter of minutes,” Madhu said.

Quantum computing and quantum technologies can bring ground breaking changes in fields starting from everyday banking business to sensitive technologies in the health and medical fields and defence applications.

“For example, photosynthesis, the process by which plants prepare food from carbon dioxide and water using sunlight, is an intricate quantum mechanical process involving quantum entanglement and superimposition between the states of the light and the molecules involved in the process. Extraction of this ‘recipe’ is an unsolvable problem with today’s best computers. Quantum computers come with the potential to understand this process and this may lead to eliminate hunger in the world,” said Anil Shaji.

Until now as a country India has no notable footprint in the field of quantum technologies and lag by many years behind most of the developed countries.

Recently the Union government has identified this gap and declared the development of quantum-enabled technologies and quantum information processing machines as a priority area of research and the groups at IISER has been identified as one among the few groups in the country to carry out this research.

Title: Cops seize Rs 18L in cash
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Visakhapatnam rural police seized Rs 18.3 lakh in cash and a car during a routine vehicle check in view of the local body elections at Hukumpeta in the district on Friday.

Two people—L Ramu and B Srinivasa—were on their way to Hukumpeta from Paderu in the car.

When the police questioned the cash, they did not give a proper reply following which the police suspected that they might have committed a cognizable offence.

The police found one brown bag which had Rs 18.3 lakh cash.

Title: Coronavirus in Kerala: Lino tests negative, visits father’s grave
Content: KOTTAYAM: Finally, there’s some relief for Lino Abel , who was confined to the isolation room in the medical college hospital and was unable to attend the funeral of his father . The test result of his sample for Covid-19 came as negative and he was discharged from hospital on Saturday.The 29-year-old youth had to go through the ordeal of watching the body of his father being carried away in an ambulance from the window of his isolation room.“I got the results on Saturday morning and was discharged by noon,” said Abel. The youngster went straight to St Mary’s Church in Kalayanthani, where his father Abel Ouseph was laid to rest.Abel, who reached Kerala from Qatar to meet his father who was critically ill, chose to get admitted after he had some doubts about his health.Meanwhile, governor Arif Mohammad Khan saaid in a tweet, “Heard about Lino Abel, who couldn’t attend the funeral of his dear father Abel Ouseph, as he chose to stay in isolation ward for suspected Covid-19 infection. I share Lino’s grief and appreciate his sacrifice for the people of Kerala”. On Friday, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan had praised the youth for his social responsibility.After getting the results, Abel wrote on his FB page: “I don’t know whether I am happy or sad. I have been staying in the isolation ward for six days. Here, I was looked after very well. Even the woman who comes to clean the room used to speak in a very positive way.” He also wrote that he won’t forget the Room No 205 where he stayed. He also thanked the doctors, nurses who treated him like a brother and a son.

Title: Blood donation camps to resume
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: A day after blood banks in the city faced serious shortage of blood, things are slowly picking up.On Friday, the Kerala State AIDS Control Society (KSACS) issued a circular clarifying that voluntary blood donation camps, both outreach and in-house, will be organized in the coming days.TOI had on Friday reported that the scare over spread of Covid-19 and closure of educational institutions to check the disease had resulted in a major dip in the number of blood donors in the city. The issue turned worse following cancellation of some scheduled camps this week.More donors turned up at institutions such as Sree Chitra Tirunal Institute for Medical Sciences and Technology on Friday for voluntary donations.Regional Cancer Centre too received several calls after messages of blood shortage went viral. Dr K Vijayalekshmi, who is in charge of the blood bank at RCC, said that they haven’t faced shortage, but are not sure about the coming days as people are distancing themselves from hospitals.“Some volunteers who help us in arranging donors have informed us about the difficulty in arranging donors due to the spread of Covid-19. As the message spread, more people have called us and expressed interest to donate,” she said.Refuting the claims that it has cancelled outdoor camps due to the restriction imposed by the state government due to the spread of Covid-19, KSACS project director R Ramesh said that no circular was issued to cancel camps. Later, the KSACS issued a circular clarifying that the camps would continue. The circular stated that there was shortage in blood donation due to Covid-19 outbreak.

Title: Patient displayed high levels of awareness
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: “I will recover, I am feeling better with each passing day. Nobody has to be scared,” said the 32-year-old coronavirus patient who returned from Italy and is under isolation at Medical College Hospital. While a Pathanamthitta family triggered a statewide scare by skipping screening, this man showed high levels of awareness right from the time of arrival, setting an example for all those returning from foreign countries.

“I had slight cough when I arrived. I was willing to go into isolation. The medical team told me to go on 14 days’ home isolation and asked me to report in case of any signs of infection,’’ he said, speaking to TOI by phone.

He had voluntarily reported at the screening centre and demanded that he be isolated. He then took a taxi to his house at Vellanadu after being directed for home isolation. Even before his arrival, he had asked his wife, his daughter and son to shift to their house in Idukki. He didn’t even get into direct contact with his father who stays in the house nearby. His father passed food through the window.

When he felt some discomfort, he rang up the Disha helpline, got in touch with the local ward member and proceeded to MCH alone in an ambulance. After giving samples, he again expressed willingness to be placed in isolation. From MCH, he minimized risk of public contact and didn’t take a bus. Instead took an auto rickshaw to his house, which is more than 20km away.

On the way he stopped at a wayside shop and bought a bottle of juice and made sure that he didn’t drink anything from the shop. He even made sure that he made his father give the fare to the auto driver to avoid any kind of contact with the driver.

“I was fully aware of steps to stay out of public contact and tried my best to comply with measures,’’ he said. According to him, the cough persists, though temperature is now normal and there is no fatigue. He is having trouble getting sleep at night and is on complete bed rest throughout the day.

Collector K Gopalakrishnan was all praise for the patient. “We would like to thank him, he showed extreme caution and distanced himself from all possible contacts. That is exemplary behaviour,” said Gopalakrishnan.

Vellanadu panchayat committee said that his responsible behaviour saved a village and many people from unnecessary scare. “He rang me up at 4am and told me about the need to be isolated. That was really commendable of him. We are able to do away with fear factor because of his caution,” says Vellanad Sreekandan, chairman, health standing committee, Vellanadu panchayat.

He has been settled on the border of Germany-Austria-Italy for the past nine years. “I am getting good care here, doctors and nurses check on me twice a day. I talk to my family over phone. I have asked for something to read and they said they will make it available soon,’’ he said. His brother, who returned from Italy, has been isolated at MCH.

Title: IIT-Madras scholar’s coronavirus prank sends passengers and officials into a tizzy
Content: CHENNAI: An IIT-M research scholar playing ‘truth or dare’ with her friends created a scare on board a Chennai-Coimbatore bus saying she was a Covid-19 patient, sending her co-passengers into panic and the state public health workers into a tizzy on Friday. Later traced to her campus and taken to the directorate of public health, she was let off with a ‘stern’ warning.The woman, Sujitha, later told TOI, “I was just playing with my friends. I did not realise the ramifications. Please don’t take this seriously.” She told officials that her friends, who were in a car tailing the bus, dared her to say she was Covid-positive and stop the bus.On Friday afternoon, the state nodal officer and joint director of public health received a call from a man saying his co-passengers on a bus had announced that she tested positive for Covid-19 three days ago. When she coughed, some passengers screamed, some called the state helpline and a few others called the state police control room. “As soon as we got the call we asked the bus driver and conductor to wait on the road,” said Dr Sampath P, joint director of public health (epidemic control). “He halted the bus near Melmaruvathur.”Eyewitnesses told police that Sujitha was on phone with her friends throughout the journey, and when the bus crossed Perungalathur, she asked the driver to stop the vehicle. When he refused, her friends, who were following the bus, challenged her to play the prank. “That’s when she announced that she was infected. During inquiry she told us that the bus ride and the lie were all part of the game they were playing. She was asked to dare,” the official said.A team of health department officials, including the deputy director of public health from Chengalpet and a medical team from Acharapakkam primary health centre, rushed to the spot. By then Sujitha had got into her friend’s car and left. The officials disinfected the bus, offered passengers hand sanitisers and counselled them.Later, police and state health officials took the address and contact details she had given to the transport company while booking the ticket. “We asked her to come to the DMS office for inquiry. When she refused, we told her we would have to initiate criminal action against her,” said another senior health official.Meanwhile, a team of officials were at the IIT because they received a call that one of the visiting professors staying on campus had symptoms of Covid-19. “We went there but realised it was not true,” a senior official said. By around 5pm, Sujitha appeared before the directorate and tendered an unconditional apology. She was let off by the health department with a ‘stern’ warning.

Title: ‘Finish cabling, sewer work for Kumbh by June’
Content:
Haridwar: Urban development minister Madan Kaushik on Friday held a review meeting with officials of various departments involved in Kumbh development works, including Gas Authority of India Ltd. (GAIL), Haridwar Natural Gas, Integrated Power Development System (IPDS), Amrit Yojana and Jal Sansthan, apart from PWD and Nagar Nigam. The minister stressed on timely completion of all works, adding that facilities like underground cabling, natural gas pipeline, water supply and sewer lines must be completed by June, so that there is adequate time for reconstruction of roads damaged in the process.

“Wherever the roads are damaged, an estimate of repair or fresh construction work should be prepared. The amount of repairs should be charged from the agency concerned. If the agency fails to do the repair works, it will be made to pay another agency to do it,” the minister said, adding that “locals should not be made to suffer because of uneven roads.”

IPDS executive engineer (EE) Pawan Singh said that underground cable work in the city will be finished by June, ahead of the November deadline.

“The completion of cable laying is scheduled for November but 80 per cent work has already been done. The service connection process, 20 per cent of which has been completed too, is also going steady,” Singh said. According to Amrit Yojna EE Sanjai Singh, 27 km of laying sewer lines has been completed. “The work largely involves replacement of old lines and laying a few new ones,” Singh said. “We have to change 40-km-long PVC water supply lines into ductile iron (DI) pipelines. 85 per cent work has been done. The project, which was to be completed in March 2021, will be completed by June this year,” he added.

Jal Nigam executive engineer Mohammed Misam said that the Jal Nigam has to dig four infiltration wells, which will be done by August.

Title: 3L students switched to govt schools
Content:
Gandhinagar: The state government has said that about 3 lakh children have switched to government schools from private schools in the state.

Education minister Bhupendrasinh Chudasama said that he had been getting reports of waiting lists for admission in government colleges. The minister has claimed that apart from improving the quality of education in government schools, the government has been organizing employment camps and in 2019-20, there were 20,084 students who got placements in these camps. The highest annual salary package was of Rs 9 lakh and the lowest salary of Rs 96,000.Chudasama said that for mathematics and science subjects in Class VI to VII, ‘energized textbooks’ (ETBs) were introduced.
