These books have QR codes with which 427 e-materials have been added,

The minister said that by scanning these QR codes with smartphones an audio or a video or an animation of the related topic is played, and it has helped students to a great extent to understand topics. He further said that so far, these QR codes have been scanned for more than 15 lakh times. Now, energized textbooks will be introduced in Class III-VIII in all textbooks of Gujarati medium.

Title: Kerala man sent back by MCH doctors tests positive for coronavirus
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Even while the government was refuting the opposition’s allegation on lapses in dealing with Covid-19 , officials concerned at the medical college hospital here seems to have acted in an unprofessional manner while handling a suspected case on Thursday. A man sent back home by the doctors after collecting swab samples for testing was later tested positive for Covid-19.This person had come to the medical college hospital from the outskirts of the city in an ambulance since he had fever and throat pain. But after taking the samples, the MCH authorities informed him that ambulance was not available to take him back and was asked to return on his own. It is learned that he had informed the hospital authorities of his willingness to undergo isolation but the hospital staff did not accept that.He returned in an autorikshaw to his house, which is around 20km from the hospital, and en route he visited a medical shop too. Now, the autorickshaw driver and the medical store staff have been quarantined.The man reached Thiruvananthapuram airport on Wednesday morning by QR503 flight of Qatar Airways from Doha. He had mentioned at the airport that he was coming from Italy and went to Munich before catching the flight from Doha.As the man had no symptoms, he was asked to go for home quarantine. But he developed fever symptoms the very next day (Thursday) and immediately contacted the health helpline. The emergency wing sent an ambulance to shift him to the hospital. At MCH, the doctors sent him back after collecting the swab samples.“It is true that he was sent back. He was not given an ambulance since it was not readily available there. Since he himself had taken enough precautions, he did not had any direct contacts with many people. He had direct contact with only five people after reaching Thiruvananthapuram,” said district collector K Gopalakrishnan However, the district administration is facing the uphill task of tracing those who had travelled with him in the Qatar airways flight. There were 92 passengers, of which 31 are learned to have been traced. They have been asked to undergo home quarantine.Interestingly, there were 20 foreigners in the flight, who according to the district collector, are still in the state capital itself. The collector said they will also be asked to get quarantined at their places of stay.

Title: MP Kateel raises cancelled trains issue in Parliament
Content:
Mangaluru: A move by Indian Railways to cancel the Bengaluru City-Karwar express (4 days in a week, 16513/14 via Kunigal-Hassan route) and Bengaluru-Karwar tri-weekly express (16523/24 via Mysuru-Hassan route) echoed in the Lok Sabha on Friday. Raising this issue was Dakshina Kannada MP Nalin Kumar Kateel , who was participating in a debate on demands for grants for the ministry of railways for 2020-21.

Nalin expressed his profound gratitude to the ministry for introducing a new train service between Yeshwantpur and Karwar (train 16595/16596).

This new train service will help people of coastal Karnataka immensely, as its departure and arrival timings are convenient for them. At the same time, Nalin drew the attention of the ministry, through the speaker, about the public demand in wake of cancellation of above-mentioned trains.

“The railway administration, while introducing the above mentioned train, had cancelled the existing two trains,” Nalin said.

These train services between Karwar, Mangaluru and Bengaluru were highly patronised since their inception.

Besides, this train was serving as a convenient commuter train between Karwar and Mangaluru, helping the working class, students and traders of the region. It was also serving as the connecting train for many outgoing trains at Mangaluru Central.

Cancelled trains were used by people since 8 yrs

“The cancelled trains were catering to the needs of the public of the region since the last 8 years. Withdrawing this popular train’s service at this juncture is not at all reasonable, especially when large numbers of passengers were using the train service. This decision has deprived the public of convenient connectivity between Karwar and Mangaluru in the morning and evening,” the MP said in his written submission in the debate.

He exhorted the ministry to review the decision of cancellation of the above two trains, and restore service of the same, duly maintaining connectivity via Mangaluru Central, in the interest of the people of the region.

Activists had alleged that the ministry took the decision by bypassing its own cancellation policy at the behest of KRCL, which maintained that the new train will affect goods traffic and result in revenue loss, while putting forth its case seeking cancellation of existing trains.

Title: Coronavirus in Kerala: You just can’t walk in and demand a test
Content: KOCHI: The state government has already advised people with mild symptoms of Covid-19 not to come to hospitals for testing and treatment. But there are many who are thronging the government hospitals and insist on testing.Government doctors said that around 25% of the visitors who approach the OP at the isolation wards in government hospitals are those who haven’t travelled abroad or those who aren’t primary or secondary contacts of Covid-19 patients. When doctors on duty try to explain the government guidelines on testing, they insist that it is their right to get tested.“Ordinary people are swarming hospitals claiming that they have corona. Just like walking into a lab for diabetes test, they walk into the isolation ward’s OP demanding Covid-19 test. They don’t need to rush to the hospital on suspicion but they can call the Disha helpline and take guidance,” said Dr Amar Fettle, state nodal officer (public emergency), currently in charge of anti-Covid-19 effort in the state.He said that people needn’t go to the hospital if they have common cold. Only those who have returned from abroad or are primary or secondary contacts of Covid-19 patients should go to the hospital. “If too many people come, there are chances of skipping genuine coronavirus cases. Too much of unwanted rush would also result in lapses despite the best efforts of the doctors. This is also essential to minimise community spread,” said Dr Fettle.The state government had revised guidelines for testing, quarantine, hospital admission and discharge for Covid-19 on March 12 and said, “Testing is not going to change either the clinical course or management of the patient with mild symptoms”.“Despite our best efforts, every day we have five to six ‘normal’ persons walking in to each hospital claiming that they suspect to have Covid-19. While some insist on testing, some leave once they are counselled on the government’s guidelines,” said Dr Joseph Chacko, president, Kerala Government Medical Officers’ Association.

Title: Politics infected by coronavirus: Madhya Pradesh CM
Content:
Nath to Guv: The very edifice of democracy is in danger

BHOPAL: Chief minister Kamal Nath met Governor Lalji Tandon on Friday morning and demanded that Congress MLAs “imprisoned in Bengaluru” be freed. Accusing BJP of plotting an “unethical and illegal” conspiracy, Nath told reporters later that politics “has been infected by coronavirus”.At 11am on Friday, the CM’s convoy rolled into the Raj Bhavan compound, with him waving the victory sign to waiting mediapersons. During the hour-long meeting, Nath informed Tandon of the ongoing political upheaval in the state and submitted a memorandum, alleging “horse-trading of MLAs by BJP”.After leaving Raj Bhavan, CM Nath stepped out of his car to speak to mediapersons. Looking confident, he said: “I have met the Governor and greeted him on Holi. I gave him a letter on how Congress MLAs have been imprisoned, and demanded that all the legislators held captive in Bengaluru be freed and brought back to the state. The entire country has seen how Congress MLAs are being held hostage.” Asked about a possible floor test in the assembly, the CM said, “Floor test can be done after Governor’s address and budget. But that is only possible when MLAs are independent. You hold 22 MLAs captive and then ask for floor test, that is wrong. Let these MLAs come before the media and talk.”Replying to a question on spread of Coronavirus, CM Nath said, “Coronavirus is right now in the political situation here. politics “has been infected by Coronavirus.”In his letter to the Governor, the CM writes, “Our commitment to democratic process is unwavering. As a responsible leader of Indian National Congress, I invite and would welcome a floor test of my government in the forthcoming session of Madhya Pradesh assembly, already notified from 16th March 2020, on a date fixed by the Speaker. This is the minimum a Constitutional authority can offer to address the ongoing turmoil.”The CM leveled serious allegations at BJP. “I’m constrained to point out the immoral, unethical and illegal acts of BJP in Madhya Pradesh. In the first attempt, on 3rd/4th March 2020, the midnight drama leading to whisking away MLAs to Bangaluru is in public domain. Congress leaders foiled BJP’s attempt to keep in captivity the MLAs by using both allurement and force,” he wrote.“After the failure of the first attempt, BJP on 8th March 2020 arranged three chartered aircrafts to whisk away 19 MLAs of Congress to Bengaluru. Since then, these 19 MLAs, six of whom are cabinet ministers, are incommunicado in a resort arranged by BJP. Nobody is allowed access and /or any sort of communication with the 19 captive MLAs,” he has alleged.The CM expressed shock that senior leaders of BJP went to the Speaker’s residence and submitted resignations of the 19 MLAs. “This demonstrates the complicity of BJP leaders in the entire conspiracy and illegal action. It raises questions of Constitutional propriety and legislative procedure and transparency,” Nath points out.The CM also mentioned Thursday’s incident in Bengaluru when cabinet ministers Jitu Patwari and Lakhan Singh Yadav and Narayan Choudhary, father of an MLA Manoj Choudhary, were “manhandled” and arrested by police. Congress says Manoj wanted to return to Bhopal. “In these disturbing circumstances, the very edifice of democracy is in danger. Trust of a transparent democratic process seems lost. It merits full investigation and inquiry, so that persons responsible for de-railing the democratic institutional process are exposed and punished,” the letter said.

Title: Gold prices fall by Rs 1,400, settle at Rs 43,100
Content:
Ahmedabad: Gold prices which touched a record-high last week breaching the Rs 46,000 mark, over the spike in COVID-19 cases, have now witnessed a steep fall.

The price of yellow metal stood at Rs 43,100 per 10 gram on Friday in the Ahmedabad market, showing a sharp fall of Rs 1,400 in just a day. Gold prices plunged against Thursday’s Rs 44,500 per 10 gram due to heavy profit-booking, said analysts

“Many investors have begun selling gold, in lieu of better returns. Moreover, heavy profit-booking of gold led to a significant fall in international price of gold which settled at $1,550 per ounce. As a result, the price in local markets fell,” said Haresh Acharya, director, India Bullion and Jewellers’ Association (IBJA).

Gold prices remained high during the initial part of the week, as international gold prices soared. According to analysts, concerns over impact of COVID-19 outbreak in various parts of the world on global trade and economy, caused gold prices to increase significantly in the international market.

This coupled with the Indian rupee slumping against the US dollar past the Rs 73 mark caused gold prices to go up in Indian market.

Title: Death of Unnao rape survivor’s dad: Sengar gets 10-yr term
Content:
NEW DELHI: Expelled BJP legislator Kuldeep Singh Sengar and six others were on Friday sentenced to 10 years in prison on the charge of culpable homicide not amounting to murder of the father of the Unnao rape survivor.

District judge Dharmesh Sharma compensated the deceased’s family with an award of Rs 10 lakh, to be paid by Sengar and his brother Atul, who is a co-convict in the case.

The court also directed the UP government to initiate disciplinary action against the doctors whose “gross negligence” that led to the death of the father. “The deceased was the sole bread winner of his family, comprising his wife, four daughters — two of whom are minors and a minor son. They have been uprooted from their native place and it would be difficult for them to go back,” the court said.

Sengar and his brother were consequently directed to pay Rs 10 lakh compensation to the wife and children of the deceased.

Apart from these two, the court sentenced Makhi police station in-charge Ashok Singh Bhadauria, sub-inspector K P Singh, and Vineet Mishra, Birendra Singh and Shashi Pratap Singh to 10 years in jail.

The 10-year jail term awarded under Section 304 (culpable homicide) Part (ii) (if act is done with knowledge that it is likely to cause death, but without any intention to cause death, etc.), is the maximum among all punishments for the offences the convicts had committed. The CBI had argued for a maximum punishment for the convict a day ago.

In its conviction order, the court highlighted that the convicts demonstrated their “political and muscle power” in order to criminally intimidate the deceased and his family and deter them from pursuing the sexual assault case against 0Sengar.

While framing charges in August last year, the court had viewed the death as a “part of a larger conspiracy to deter, silence and prevent the father from pursuing the complaint” in the rape case of his daughter in 2017.

The convicted policemen in the culpable homicide case were stated to be “seasoned police officials”, who provided “protective police cover” to the convicts. “They disobeyed the direction of law to protect the life and liberty of the victim,” the court said. Four persons, including a UP police constable, were acquitted for want of evidence.

Among the various IPC charges, the accused will face punishment under Sections 304 (culpable homicide not amounting to murder) and Section 120B (criminal conspiracy).

“Bhadauria and K P Singh fabricated false evidence against the victim... causing him grievous hurt,” the court said. It came on record that the father was brutally assaulted and at the same charges of assault, criminal intimidation and possession of fire arms were slapped against him owing to a conspiracy on the part of the convicts. Four others — Shailendra Singh, Ram Sharan Sinigh, Sharadveer Singh and UP police constable Amir Khan — were given benefit of doubt and acquitted of all charges.

In December, 2019, Sengar was sentenced to life imprisonment till the remainder of his natural life and slapped Rs 25 lakh fine for raping a minor from Unnao in 2017. While awarding the jail term, the court observed that the survivor and her family had been “uprooted from their native village” and couldn’t even “dream of returning to their native place and live peacefully ever after”.

Title: Govt to disburse salaries of teachers
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: The government has decided to disburse the salaries for the teachers of single-teacher schools in the state that has been pending for months now.

The decision was taken at the discussion between the Alternative School Teachers’ Association (ASTA) and education minister C Raveendranath in the presence of former chief minister Oommen Chandy.

The issue was taken up by ASTA after teachers of single-teacher schools launched a relay protest after their salaries stood pending without disbursal for months.

On the basis of the discussion, the minister entrusted secretary (general education) A Shajahan to prepare the proceedings for disbursal of their salaries and forward it to the concerned education department offices.

Finance minister T M Thomas Isaac also agreed to consider providing wages to such teachers every month without fail.

The education minister also assured them that no teacher will lose his/her job and the government will consider taking the multi-grade learning centres as a cluster for administrative convenience.

It was also assured that the issues of teachers above 50 years of age will be leniently considered while preparing the report on taking decision about the issues of the teachers of single-teacher schools.

TOI had earlier reported about the plight of K R Ushakumari, the only teacher of a tribal school in Amboori in the hilly areas of the capital district. She was part of the protest being undertaken by the teachers of single-teacher schools.

Talking to TOI, she had explained how their wages were not given by the government for the last five months, and their demand for permanent posting as teacher was not considered by the government, despite putting in more than 20 years of service. After she launched an indefinite protest, two other teachers of such schools – Ajitha of Sholayur and Tinu of Marayur- also had launched similar protests.

Title: 3 of a family found dead in house
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: A three-member family was found dead in their rented house at Kulathoor near Kazhakootam on Friday afternoon under suspicious circumstances. The deceased include a man, his wife and their son. Police suspect that the man might have murdered the wife and son and then committed suicide .

Kazhakkoottam police have registered a case and launched a probe. Suresh, 35, of Kanyakulangara near Vembayam, his wife Sindhu, 30, of Kulathoor and their son, Sharon, 9, are the deceased. They were living in a rented house located next to Sindhu’s ancestral home near Sri Narayana Library at Kulathoor.

Santhosh was an expatriate who had been working in a Gulf country for the past several years. It was only 20 days ago he returned home. Sindhu was working in a private firm at Muttada in the city for the past three months. Before that she used to work as a nursing assistant at a private clinic at Kulathoor.

Police suspect that Suresh strangulated the wife and son on Thursday night and then committed suicide by hanging on Friday morning. Sindhu’s body was lying in the kitchen while Sharon’s body was lying on the bed in the bedroom. Suresh was found hanging from the ceiling in the same room.

“We suspect that he committed both murders in the previous night and waited till morning to hang himself,” said Kazhakkoottam sub-inspector A Santhosh Kumar. If the bodies of Sindhu and Sharon were cold when found, Suresh’s body was still warm.

It appeared that Sindhu was strangulated from behind while she was doing the dishes in the kitchen sink. There were leftovers of previous night’s dinner on the kitchen floor and as a result, her body was infested with ants. It is also suspected that Suresh might have strangulated Sharon in his sleep.

The bodies were found by Sindhu’s mother on Friday afternoon.

According to police, Suresh had sent a WhatsApp message to his brother-in-law (Sindhu’s elder sister’s husband) requesting him to visit him at his house at 8am as he wanted to discuss something serious. But the brother-in-law, who lives at Kanyakulangara, saw the message only after 8am. Since then he tried to reach Suresh and Sindhu on phone several times but in vain. Following this, he called Sindhu’s mother and asked her to go and check the family. It was then the bodies were found.

The bodies were shifted to the mortuary after inquest. During the inquest, police found strangulation marks around the necks of Sindhu and Sharon. The postmortem will be conducted on Saturday.

Title: Amid coronavirus war, viral holiday rumour in Gujarat
Content: AHMEDABAD/GANDHINAGAR: Deputy chief minister Nitin Patel on Friday advised against organizing large gatherings as the world continues to battle with the Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19). Patel told reporters in Gandhinagar that Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s scheduled visit to Gujarat on March 21 and 22 has been postponed.A supposed office memorandum made the rounds on Friday on social media in which Maharashtra, Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh, and Sikkim were ‘advised that mass gatherings may be avoided or possibly be postponed till the disease spread is contained.’The memo even declared a holiday from March 14 to 21 terming it “mandatory for all schools, colleges, educational institutes, workplaces having more than 10 employees, and all statutory and local bodies of the state.” The memo said that those not adhering to the rule would be fined Rs 5,000 daily.Jayanti Ravi, principal secretary (health and family welfare), said that the communiqué was fake. A clarification from the Press Information Bureau on Friday evening also called the letter fake.However, before the clarifications were issued, the letter had been circulated widely on social media platforms as citizens were happy about the possible week-long break. Scores of people contacted state government officials, health officials, and media to check whether the message was factual.As for Modi’s visit, Patel said: “The Prime Minister’s office has informed us that following the Government of India’s recent advisory, the PM’s Gujarat visit for a series of events has been postponed. New dates will be finalized later,” He went on to say: “Because of the current coronavirus situation and the recent central government advisory, we advise citizens to avoid organizing large gatherings.”Patel said that the state government is taking all necessary steps to avoid the spread of the virus as positive cases are reported from across India, including the neigbhouring Maharashtra.When questioned whether Gujarat will follow Delhi and Maharashtra in restricting the functioning of schools and theatres and in regulating crowds, Patel said that no such step has been taken because not a single positive case has been registered in Gujarat. “There is no need for such drastic steps yet. We are strictly following the Government of India’s directives to control the spread of the virus,” he said.Modi was to visit the Statue of Unity to inaugurate a clutch of new tourist attractions and also visit Ahmedabad to inaugurate the 800-bed UN Mehta Institute of Cardiology and Research Centre on the Civil Hospital campus.

Title: Man held for raping US tourist in Rishikesh
Content:
Haridwar: Police have arrested a man working in a yoga centre on charges of raping a 33-year-old foreign tourist who had come to Rishikesh from the United States to learn yoga a month ago.

The accused has been identified as Geetansh ,28, a resident of Rishikesh, and a case has been registered in the matter.

Police said that the incident took place during a birthday party that was organised in a yoga centre located in Tapovan under the jurisdiction of Muni-ki-Reti police station on March 10. “The accused became friends with the woman during her training session and he allegedly forced her to drink alcohol at the party, following which he raped her. The woman approached us on March 12 and we registered a case under section 376 (punishment of rape) of IPC and arrested the accused on Friday. Medical examination of the victim has also been done,” said an official.The accused was produced before court on Friday and was remanded in 14-day judicial custody.

This is the second such incident reported from the area in just two weeks. A similar incident was reported from Rishikesh a few days ago when a 25-year-old Japanese tourist was sexually assaulted by a seer of an ashram.

Title: Coronavirus in Gujarat: Demand for branded hand-sanitizers spikes 10-fold
Content: AHMEDABAD: Following the advisory issued by the Union ministry of health and family welfare to curb and prevent the COVID-19 outbreak, the demand for hand-sanitizers has risen 10-fold. Consequently, there’s a shortage of branded sanitizers and alcohol-based hand rubs on the shelves.According to estimates by Federation of Gujarat State Chemists and Druggists Association (FGSCDA) against 10,000 units sold on a daily basis across Gujarat, the current demand is as high as 1 lakh units a day.When TOI independently checked with four chemists in different parts of Ahmedabad, none had branded hand-sanitizers available. “We just have a single brand of sanitizers. We used to keep other brands, but supplies are low as the stock is limited,” said the manager of a chain of medical stores near Panjrapole Crossroads.Yet another medical store owner in Prahladnagar claimed he had run out of stock completely. “People are asking for alcohol-based hand-rubs that have 60% or more alcohol content and those are not easily available. We have completely exhausted stocks and have placed order for sanitizers, but are not sure when they will be available,” said Manish Patel, a chemist.Industry sources also said that amid short supply and high demand, hand sanitizers are being sold in the black maret at high rates.“We have issued an advisory to all our members to not hoard stocks of hand sanitizers and masks which are currently in high demand, just to sell them at a higher price,” said Alpesh Patel, president, FGSCDA.A similar advisory was also issued by Gujarat Food and Drug Control Administration (FDCA).

Title: Quid pro quo case filed at behest of TDP, Congress: Andhra Pradesh CM
Content: HYDERABAD: Andhra Pradesh chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy on Friday told the CBI court in Hyderabad that the quid pro quo case filed against him could be described as the sum total of the heartburn of TDP and Congress on one side and the ignorance of CBI investigators on the other.Putting forward Jagan’s case for the first time ever since the case was filed in 2011, senior counsel S Niranjan Reddy briefed the court that Jagan did no wrong in the case. “In fact, the quid pro quo case itself was filed at the behest of TDP and Congress which jointly went to the high court,” he said, terming the charges politically motivated.The Congress joined the TDP to suppress Jagan ever since he came out of Congress after his father YS Rajasekhara Reddy’s demise, the senior counsel said, while urging the court to intervene in the matter and discharge Jagan from the case, which he said will not stand any test and parameters laid down by the Supreme Court even with respect to framing of charges.Niranjan presented his arguments on the chargesheet filed against Jagathi publications, the publisher of Sakshi, a Telugu daily. He said that the CBI’s chargesheet is devoid of merit and is full of contradictions. “While the CBI claims that the projections made by Jagan to the investors about the future prospects of Jagathi were unrealistic, all projections on circulation figures were achieved by Sakshi on the first day of its launch,” he said, adding that the advertising rates were market-based and the CBI does not say that it is incorrect. Citing the case of the Jio experiment, he explained that the competitors feared Sakshi’s entry and slashed their prices, and hence, Sakshi could not achieve the estimated profits.Speaking about the allegations of the CBI that share premium paid by investors were nothing but bribes paid by investors to Jagan for the benefits they reaped from the state headed by his father, Niranjan said that the allegations were unfounded. Of the total Rs 1,246 crore invested in Jagathi, over Rs 844 crore (more than 2/3rd) were invested six months after the demise of YSR. Shares were purchased due to the record circulation figures achieved by Sakshi newspaper in a short span of time, he explained.The CBI failed to consider the fact that Jagan had been into various businesses even before his father was elected chief minister and the investments were made considering the potential of the businesses headed by him, the senior counsel said. Other allegations made by the CBI on Jagathi shares were made on account of fundamental misconceptions the probe agency has about the company law, he said, adding that they were contrary to the provisions of Companies Act, 1956.“The allegation that Jagan invited outsiders to invest in Jagathi in contravention of Section 3(1) (iii)(c) of Companies Act, 1956 and that this amounts to public offer is legally incorrect. The chargesheet betrays a total lack of knowledge of company law by the investigating officer,” Niranjan said. All the investors had, in fact, gained on account of their investment in Jagathi, he said, and added that investments, even in large companies, would become beneficial only after longer gaps. “Allegations that issuance of shares was contrary to Articles of Association (AoA) are in fact contrary to the actual facts and were issued without reading the articles. It anyways does not amount to a commission of offence since such a contravention only amounts to breach of contract (having only a civil remedy) since AoA is merely a contract between the company and its investors,” Jagan’s counsel said.Ridiculing the suggestion made by CBI that Jagathi should have bought back shares to make good the loss caused to the investors, he said the suggestion is contrary to Companies Act since the Act prohibits buying back of allotted shares by a company. The chargesheet is entirely based on the statements of 3 witnesses-cum-investors and these statements do not make a strong argument for the case, he said. “Since none of them had lodged any complaint despite claiming to have been victims of the alleged crime, no reliance could be placed on them,” he said.Niranjan said that the CBI does not claim that the projections of Deloitte report, alleged to have been relied upon by the witnesses before making investments, are incorrect.“The CBI, without method considered by Deloitte, makes vague assertions that the valuation figures of Deloitte are exaggerated,” he said, urging the court to discharge Jagan.

Title: With eye on polls, SCB members push works
Content:
Sewer trunks being laid beside Ramannakunta

Secunderabad: To ensure reelection in the ensuing Cantonment Board elections, the SCB ward members have swung into action for completing the pending key projects. The ward members have six months for the work after the extension given by ministry of defence.

Construction has started on projects, including laying sewer trunk beside the century-old Ramannakunta Lake at Bowenpally, which was getting delayed for three years. The trunk is being laid to prevent sewage from entering the lake. The project had earlier seen hurdles like delay in persmission from defence authorities, fund crunch and the state government sanctioning the funds late.

“Completion of Ramannakunta project is my dream. I have faced numerous hurdles to get financial support and work has finally started on ground. Once the main sewer trunk has been laid, as many as six residential colonies abutting the lake would get rid of the stink and mosquito menace permanently,” ward no-VI member Pandu Yadav told TOI.

In ward no-VIII, there are two major projects including providing the Bollarum General Hospital with adequate services and reviving a major community hall.

“Though the general hospital was upgraded with 30 beds, patients are not coming here due to lack of medical services. In fact, the state government had earlier given assurance to provide enough medical staff and ensure better medical services, but the promise could not be materialised,” said Loknatham.

The revivial of the community hall will start soon and completed within six months, said Lokanatham.

A key project at Ward No-VII is shifting of a dump yard from premises of Mahatma Gandhi Community Hall at Trimulgherry.

“Though I have raised the concern several times during board meetings, the SCB officials have failed to shift the dump yard. However, the issue came to light recently when the DG, defence estates, Delhi, Deepa Bajwa visited SCB. She gave assurance to shift the dumping yard to some other defence land,” said Bhagya Shree.

Title: State to get more masks, sanitizers soon
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: With fresh Covid-19 being reported in the state, the prisons department has joined the fight against the disease and is aiding the containment measures taken by the state government.The prisoners of textile units in Thiruvananthapuram, Viyyur and Kannur central prisons have stopped all other activities and begun producing face masks. The production of masks began in all three units on Friday. “When the suggestion for mask production came up, the prisoners willingly came forward. The production has begun,” said DIG (prisons) Santhosh Kumar.The suggestion was originally put forward by social justice department and after consulting the health department for suggestions and specifications of the mask, the prisons launched the initiative. “The sample mask was made available from SAT hospital and then we procured raw material for production,” he said.The masks are being manufactured using cotton cloth which can be re-used after washing them. On the first day alone, in three to four hours, as many as 2,000 masks were produced by the inmates of the Poojappura central prison. The prisons department is thinking of distributing the masks through government’s Karunya pharmacy or its own sales outlets. “Though the price has not been fixed, we have decided that a mask will not be priced more than Rs 15 or Rs 20,” he said. It has been estimated that at least 10,000 masks can be produced per day from the three units.Meanwhile, Kerala Drugs and Pharmaceuticals Limited has begun the production of hand sanitizers. KSDP is producing sanitizers as per WHO formula. Industries minister EP Jayarajan said the production of sanitizers was launched to address shortage in the market. He said that by Saturday, as many as 2,000 bottles will be produced and in 10 days, one lakh bottles will be produced.Action against 16 shopsThe legal metrology department has initiated action against 16 shops for selling face masks, hand sanitizers and cleaning materials by levying more price than the printed maximum retail price (MRP). The raid was conducted in 121 shops in Ernakulam, Thrissur, Idukki and Pathanamthitta on Thursday. Health minister KK Shailaja and CM Pinarayi Vijayan have warned traders against hoarding and overpricing materials like face masks during the crisis.Deputy controller J C Jeemson said shops which breached the conditions of Packaged Commodities Act were penalized during the raid. He said strong action would be initiated by invoking the clauses concerned in the law against offenders. Apart from medical shops, raids also covered supermarkets and surgical shops. Sources said similar raids will be conducted in other districts soon.

Title: HC notice to Patanjali Ayurvigyan for not following order
Content:
Nainital: The Uttarakhand high court (HC) on Friday issued show cause notice to the principal of yoga guru Ramdev’s Patanjali Ayurvigyan Evam Anusandhan Sansthan for failing to comply with its order.

The single bench of Justice Manoj Kumar Tiwari had on January 8 given the institute eight weeks to refund the money that they had charged from its students of Bachelor of Ayurvedic Medical Sciences (BAMS) after a Government Order (GO) increased the fee from Rs 80,000 to Rs 2.15 lakh.

However, on Friday the court was informed that the institute is yet to refund the money. Speaking to TOI, Vinod Tiwari, the lawyer appearing for petitioner said that the court has given the principal, DN Sharma, time till March 24 to show cause why contempt proceedings should not be initiated against him. “We informed the court that despite the court’s order of refunding the money within eight weeks, the students are yet to receive even a penny. The court has now issued a show cause notice to the principal and if he fails to respond, charges will be framed against him,” Tiwari said.

SK Tijarawala, a spokesman for Patanjali, told TOI that they will go through the HC order and take a decision on it accordingly. “We are yet to receive the order. However, we respect the court and as soon as we get the order we will go through it and file our response accordingly,” he said.

Title: Quadruple rail line made operational
Content:
Secunderabad: In a major boost to the pending MMTS Phase-II work, the quadruple railway line between Moula Ali-Ghatkesar has been made operational. Moula Ali - Ghatkesar section connects Secunderabad, Kazipet, Nadikudi (Guntur) and Sanath Nagar with heavy congestion.

South Central Railway (SCR) officials say, to ease the congestion and also to operate suburban trains in this section this railway line has been quadrupled by adding two more newlines.

As part of quadrupling,, two additional platforms each have been constructed at Cherlapalli and Ghatkesar stations. In addition, new station buildings have been erected at Moula-Ali C cabin, Charlapalli and Ghatkesar, according to an official release from SCR.

"Completion of the entire project will provide direct rail connectivity to residents of eastern parts of twin cities to reach Hitech city, Lingampalli, Patancheru, Falaknuma and other suburban areas at an economical price," said chief public relations officer of SCR Ch Rakesh.

Senior railway officials of Rail Vikas Nigam Limited (RVNL) have however informed that delay in getting approval for track work in a 4-km stretch near Suchitra Junction, which is under the Local Military Authorities (LMAs) has led to slow down in work.

Meanwhile, tracks are also being doubled between Falaknuma-Umdanagar.

Title: Telehealth services bridge critical gap in medical sector
Content:
Hyderabad: Telehealth— the technology to deliver virtual healthcare services to patients outside clinics and hospitals and in remote locations — has the potential to transform the future of healthcare.

Recently, through telehealth facilities, a Hyderabad-based doctor helped diagnose a 27-year-old man living in a village in AP with thyroid cancer. The absence of adequate checking in remote areas has led to several players offering telehealth services.

Ramulu (name changed) reported to an Apollo primary healthcare centre, complaining of pain in the neck with a small mass on the right side. At the telemedicine-enabled primary healthcare centre, the medical officer recommended tests, but was also in touch with specialists. In doing so, a diagnosis was arrived at early and the patient was treated.

City-based Pooja Singh, 54, has also reaped the benefits of telemedicine. “Being a diabetic, I need to monitor my blood sugar and electrolyte levels on a weekly basis. It used to be tough for me to go to hospitals every week. But that has changed now. I go to Tattvan’s e-clinic opened in Ramky Discovery City,” she said. The e-clinic seeks to provide comprehensive healthcare solutions to residents of the community.

Speaking about the need for expansion of telehealth facilities, Vikram Thaploo, CEO, Apollo TeleHealth, said, “A major problem with Indian healthcare system is its inability to diagnose serious diseases on time. Telehealth can fill the accessibility gap.” Tattvan’s CEO Ayush Mishra said, “Many physicians don’t practice in Hyderabad but can treat residents through our e-clinic.”

Within the telehealth space is CallHealth Services, which provides virtual e-consultations with doctors through audio and video mediums. “Our web and app platforms integrate all constituents within the ecosystem,” said Sony Agarwal, who works with the firm.

Title: Kolhapur airport sees drop in international travellers amid Covid-19 scare
Content:
Representative image

KOLHAPUR: Kolhapur airport which is connected to four international airports — Mumbai, Hyderabad, Bengaluru, and Tirupati — has witnessed a drop in international travellers , said airport director Kamal Kumar Kataria amid the ongoing coronavirus situation.

He said that the number of travellers coming to Kolhapur from the said cities has dropped tremendously. “We are keeping a record of travellers who have foreign travel history and so far only two people have been named in the database,” he said.

“The creation of database is in accordance with the instructions from higher authorities so as to trace the travellers in case the need arises,” he said.

According to Kataria, the number of domestic passengers too is dwindling, but the impact is much lesser as compared to international travel.

On the safety front, the Kolhapur airport is equipped with hand sanitizers and frequent cleaning is on agenda, he added.

“Hand sanitizers are available in ample quantity in the frequently visited places,” he said.

From Kolhapur airport, flights to the Bengaluru, Mumbai, Hyderabad, and Tirupati are operated almost every day by Air Alliance, Indigo, and TruJet.

Besides, a lot of developmental works, including the work of the air traffic control tower, runway extension, and new terminal building, among several others, is being carried out at the airport.

The airport is located in the Ujalaiwadi neighbourhood, around 9 km from the main city.

Title: TRS RS candidates file nominations
Content:
Hyderabad: On the last day of filing nominations for Rajya Sabha polls on Friday, K Keshava Rao and KR Suresh Reddy filed their papers after paying tributes at the Telangana martyrs memorial near the assembly building.

Municipal administration minister KT Rama Rao, MP J Santosh Kumar and former Nizamabad MP Kalvakuntla Kavitha accompained them.

Two others also filed nominations, which are likely to be rejected since there were no proposers for their nominations. Returning officer is likely to announce Keshava Rao and Suresh’s unanimous election on March 18 on the last date of withdrawal of nominations. tnn

Title: Arrest drunk drivers, Madras high court tells Tamil Nadu government
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: Arrest drunk drivers, seize their vehicles and cancel their driving licences — this is the Madras high court’s prescription to tackle the menace in Tamil Nadu. The court has also directed the authorities to disqualify such offenders from holding a driving licence.

Categorically blaming the government’s retail liquor vending policy for drunk driving and deaths/injuries caused by it, a division bench of Justice N Kirubakaran and Justice Abdul Quddhose said, “Easy accessibility and availability of alcohol made by government is the main reason for increase in crimes in society. Many precious lives are lost, and many people are injured and crippled due to drunken driving.”

Heinous crimes are committed while drunk. Health of citizens consuming liquor is gradually affected violating fundamental right guaranteed under Article 21 of the Constitution making it a dangerous social problem. Women and children are worst sufferers when men become drunkards, the high court bench added.

Pointing out that about 70 lakh of the 6.8 core population in Tamil Nadu consume alcohol daily, the court said 6,500 Tasmac shops catered to consumers, earning 35% of state’s income.

“Mostly the consumers are labourers, farmers, lower middle and lower strata people. Most of the daily wagers are stated to be spending 50% or more of their earnings on liquor, driving their families to abject poverty,” the judges said. The bench then directed the authorities to arrest drunk drivers under Section 202 of the Motor Vehicles Act and subject them to breathalyser test under Section 203 for alcohol detection as per Section 185.

This apart, the court also directed the authorities to invoke Section 279 (rash driving) of the IPC for the offence of drunken driving in addition to Section 185 of Motor Vehicles Act. For rash driving, a person can be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.

As a preventive measure, the court has directed the central government to consider directing automobile manufacturers to install ‘Alcohol Sensing Ignition Interlocking’ in vehicles. Such device would enable a person to start a vehicle only if they breath clean.

Title: 25 CCTV cameras installed in Ooty ahead of tourist season
Content:
Udhagamandalam: Ahead of tourist season, the Nilgiri police have installed 25 CCTV cameras across G1 police station limit in the town. All the footage from the cameras would be transmitted to the station.

Inaugurating the launch of the 25 CCTV cameras, Nilgiris SP V Sasi Mohan said, “It is to regulate the movement of vehicles from Rohini Theatre junction to Kandal area.”

Rohini Theatre junction is the portal for vehicles coming from Kerala and Karnataka via Gudalur road.

“We are planning to install CCTV cameras in other major roads such as Garden Road, Etienne’s Road and Commercial Road in the town, besides prominent tourist places”, the SP said.

Police have appealed to the traders’ association to sponsor some CCTV cameras so that important places and roads would be brought under surveillance.

“Our road safety fund is not enough to get the required number of CCTV cameras. Next, we will concentrate in Kotagiri, Coonoor and Gudalur,” Sasi Mohan said.

Even the traders who have their own CCTV cameras have been asked to form groups to get suggestions from police on the location of cameras to benefit the public.

Title: Prominent boarding schools in Doon decide to keep students in campus
Content:
Dehradun: A day after the state government announced that all schools will remain closed till March 31 due to the Covid-19 threat, prominent boarding schools in Dehradun said they have decided to take strict measures to make sure that the virus doesn’t spread on their campuses. The schools said that they are making sure that high standards of hygiene are maintained and students are not allowed to leave the campus.

Piyush Malviya, director of public affairs at The Doon School, said, “In boarding schools, it’s best that we quarantine ourselves. So we have made a ‘No-Entry and No-Exit’ rule. Within the campus, we have placed sanitizers throughout the place. We have been talking to the students and staff and everybody is being apprised of the situation from time to time. They are also being informed about the various preventive measures against the virus. We have also cancelled all kinds of outings and students can’t leave the campus. We are not asking the parents to come here and take their children as the situation is well under control.”

The Welham Boys’ School has also decided not to allow any visitors and make sure that the students are not leaving the campus. M Kandpal, vice-principal of the school, said, “Board exams are going on and as per the government directive, we will continue with them. We are yet to take a call on students of the classes that are not appearing for board exams. The students who are appearing for their boards can’t leave the campus until exams are over.”

Meanwhile, authorities of many schools have appealed to the education department to let them conduct home examinations (exams of non-board classes such as classes VIII, IX and XI). They claim that most of the home exams will conclude by next week.

Prem Kashyap, president of Principal Progressive Schools Association of Uttarakhand, said, “The government has allowed the Kendriya Vidyalayas to conduct home examinations. So why can’t a similar arrangement be made available for other schools as well? We have written to the education director requesting him to allow us to conduct home examinations. However, we are yet to receive a confirmation from them.”

Meanwhile, an education department source told TOI that it is highly unlikely that the department will allow the schools to continue with home examinations and schools will have to postpone them. In another related development, the regional office of the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) in Dehradun on Friday issued a directive asking the authorities at the board centres and the students to take preventive interventions and ensure that proper hygiene is maintained.

Meanwhile, over 100 students and teachers of a private college in Dehradun that had gone on a study tour to Dubai were advised to stay at home for 14 days by the college administration as a precautionary measure.
