Title: Gujarat high court takes step to guard court premises against Covid-19
Content: AHMEDABAD: A day after India witnessed its first Covid-19 death in Karnataka, the Gujarat high court on Friday swung into action to safeguard court premises against coronavirus spread. The HC directed government authorities to strictly follow the precautionary measures recommended in the advisory issued by the Union ministry of health and family welfare to curb spread of the pandemic.To formalize the move the HC filed a PIL suo motu and issued directions to the government as well as bar associations and court administrators.The bench of Gujarat Chief Justice Vikram Nath and Justice A J Shastri directed lawyers across the state to “discourage litigants from attending courts”. Those who appear in court as party-in-person may remain absent and the courts will not pass adverse order in their cases, the bench said.Clarifying that its directions are to “strengthen hands of the governments”, the HC issued notice to the state government, health department and legal department asking them to file affidavits within a week stating what action they took on the HC instructions and what is the situation and how equipped the administration is to deal with the pandemic.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Soon, pay EB bill through PoS machines at doorstep
Content:
An announcement in this regard was made by state power minister P Thangamani in the assembly on Friday after t... Read More

CHENNAI: Soon, Tangedco consumers can pay bi-monthly power bills at their doorsteps. The discom plans to send assessors with a point-of-sale machine to consumers who are not able to pay through other sources.

An announcement in this regard was made by state power minister P Thangamani in the assembly on Friday after the debate on demand for grants on the energy department.

The discom has allocated Rs 1.75 crore to purchase point of sale machines. Now, there are several sources through which a consumer can pay the bills. “There are multiple channels of collection of current consumption charges. Consumers pay through net banking, debit/credit cards, mobile banking, mobile app, post office collection, bank counter collection, ATM collection, e-seva centres, Bharat bill payment system. Along with all this point of sale machines will be added,” said an official.

Of the total consumers, 34% use the above facilities to avoid standing in queue at collection centres. A total of Rs 1,626 crore has been collected from consumers through sale of power through these sources, said the official.

The government is also planning to use solar power at all traffic signals in the city as well as in all surveillance cameras installed across the city. “A total of Rs 7.4 lakh has been allocated to provide solar power to traffic signals as well as surveillance cameras in the city. But this is only a start and in phases more money will be allocated to provide solar power to these two,” said the official.

There are around 500 traffic signals in the city and at present all these draw power from the grid. Thus, if there is a power shutdown, signals will not work leading to traffic snarls. On several occasions, the Nandanam signal has gone on the blink due to power cuts. “Solar power panels above the traffic signals will have a battery so that power saved during the day can be used in the evening,” said the official. The project will be implemented by Tangedco along with the transport department.

Title: AAP launches membership drive in state
Content:
Dehradun: A day after announcing Uttarakhand in-charge, the Aam Aadmi Party ( AAP ) on Friday launched a membership drive and inched a little closer to gaining a foothold in the hill state.

The party has appealed to people of the hill state to gain its membership by giving a missed call at the party number.

The Delhi-based party aims to increase its foothold in the state and is going to focus on issues pertaining to the people of the state, especially in the health and education sectors.

State party in-charge Dinesh Mohaniya said, “We appeal to everybody to join the party by giving a missed call at 9871010101. If we are elected in 2022 assembly elections, then we will replicate the ‘Delhi Model’ in Uttarakhand too. Our party has tremendously improved in the health, education and infrastructure sectors in the national capital and the same kind of work is required in the state of Uttarakhand. We want to get votes on the basis of our work and not on the basis of divisive politics.”

Title: Uttarakhand to formulate indicators to give financial value to ecology
Content:
Dehradun: In a first, Uttarakhand is going to formulate indicators for analysing the 'economic value of ecology', or Gross Environment Product (GEP). The components that will be given economic value will primarily include water, air, forest and soil. The move is aimed at giving financial value to ecology so that it can be equated with GDP, said Doon-based environmentalist Padma Bhushan Dr Anil Joshi, who is spearheading the initiative.

"It will help the (central) government in understanding real time picture of its ecology and draw plans and give funds to each state based on its initiatives to safeguard the ecology. A committee of scientists, environmentalists and activists has also been formed in this regard recently under the aegis of K Vijay Raghavan, principal scientific adviser (PSA) to the PM," Joshi said.

The PSA suggested that a concept note on GEP measurement for Uttarakhand should be developed by Madhu Verma, chief economist at World Resources Institute (WRI), New Delhi, in consultation with the department of planning of Uttarakhand, said Joshi.

The concept note should incorporate suggestions of expert organizations, lay down relevant goals, responsibilities and timelines, said the PSA.

An 'operations committee' was proposed to be created for Uttarakhand that will be chaired by the principal secretary (forest department) Anand Vardhan. Additional secretary of the forest department Subhash Chandra will be the co-chair for the committee. The heads of state institutions will be part of this committee, with the department of planning being in the lead for GEP calculations.

Experts at a meeting held on March 5 at the Wildlife Institute of India (WII), Dehradun , however, expressed concern regarding the lack of coordination between various agencies and, hence, said there might problems in getting data on a single platform.

Speaking at that conference, Raghvan had stressed the importance of having a pool of real-time data “and its analysis, which would help in policy formulation, followed by decision-making and final implementation. This requires continuous evaluation of data and identification of gaps for refining future policies.”

The committee will hand over the proposal to the principal secretary of forest by March 31, who will then take it up with the PSA.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Kolhapur: Sample of CPR doctor tests negative
Content:
Representative image

KOLHAPUR: A swab sample of the Chhatrapati Pramila Raje Rugnalaya ( CPR ) doctor has tested negative after the medical practitioner started showing coronavirus like symptoms on Thursday.

According to CPR officials, the swab samples were sent to NIV , Pune as a precautionary measure as it was a protocol of the state health department.

They are monitoring the situation of the other medical practitioners in the civil hospital as well, so as to avoid any kind of infection. “We have taken a few swab samples in recent past and fortunately nothing so far has been reported positive. The administration and the hospital staff is ready to tackle any kind of situation, which has grappled the global community and has been called a pandemic by the World Health Organization,” said the official.

Meanwhile, Pune divisional commissioner has asked the district administration to take the precautionary measure and prepare the blueprint of the safety measures to be taken on a war-footing.

He has asked the concerned officials to prepare awareness campaigns across the villages and city areas, which can include video clips, hoardings, posters, and handbills.

Meanwhile, the medical experts have said that while no specific antiviral treatment is available for the ailment, precautionary steps are advised to follow. Steps like good personal hygiene, hand wash with soap for at least 20 seconds, avoid touching eyes, nose, and mouth, avoid close contact with people who are sick and consumption of raw or undercooked animal products.

Title: Constable held for raping, threatening woman in Kolhapur
Content:
Representative image

KOLHAPUR: Constable Rahul Deepak Parit (28) of Chandgad police in Kolhapur district was arrested late on Thursday night for allegedly raping a woman . He has been remanded in police custody for four days.

The woman in her complaint has told the police that she got acquainted with Parit through social media. They met on a couple of occasions and became friends. Parit allegedly then promised to marry her. When the woman came to know that Parit is already married, she approached the police.

The woman has complained that Parit forcibly took signatures from her on a few documents. She alleged that Parit gave her cold drink, that was allegedly laced with sedatives. He then raped her when she was under the influence of the drink.

Parit then allegedly took photographs of the woman on his cellphone. He later allegedly threatened the woman that he would circulate the photos if she did not give in to his demands. She approached the Ichalkaranji police on January 31 and a case of rape and threatening with dire consequences was registered against Parit.

Parit was absconding after the complaint was filed and he moved the local court to get anticipatory bail. The application was rejected. Later, he also went Bombay high court seeking the anticipatory bail, but it was also rejected. He surrendered before police late on Thursday night and was arrested.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: US return IIT-R student show Coronavirus-like symptoms, kept under observation
Content: Roorkee: A doctorate student of IIT-Roorkee, who recently returned from America, has reportedly been kept under observation at a separate ward in the institute’s hospital after he showed symptoms similar to novel coronavirus. As a precautionary measure, the institute has also suspended classes till March 22. Sources told TOI that the student had returned from the US to the campus a few days ago. On Thursday, he was kept under observation for coronavirus after he complained of cold and flu.“The student in question has been kept under observation by IIT’s hospital in view of the coronavirus pandemic. He is told to be in good health,” Namami Bansal, joint magistrate of Roorkee, told TOI. The institute has also cancelled a two-day-long international conference to be held from March 14 and other public events in view of Covid-19 threat.Meanwhile, IIT-R professor Absar Kazmi, his wife, and their three children , who were on a foreign trip, got stranded in Qatar for four days due to cancellation of flights to India due to coronavirus scare. "Now, I will be coming to India on March 14 in an Oman Air flight," Kazmi told TOI over phone.

Title: Commercial units pollute storm drain on Vayalur road
Content:
Trichy: Even though Vayalur road under K Abishekapuram zone has underground drainage (UGD) connection, a section of commercial establishments on this road are discharging solid waste into the storm water drainage, clogging it often.

The storm water drainage running along Vayalur road is for discharging rainwater into Kathiri Vaaikal from EVR road, Puthur and Bharathi Nagar. “The civic body should penalise the commercial units discharging waste water into the storm water drainage,” said S Pushpavanam, secretary of Tamil Nadu Consumer Protection Council.

Soon after Trichy was upgraded to corporation, ward 52, which includes Vayalur road, was facilitated with UGD and a pumping station was also established near the Bishop Heber College. Over the years, the residential locality witnessed robust growth attracting a lot of commercial units including hotels.

Though the commercial complexes were provided with UGD connections, locals lamented that the storm water drainage was being used by them to discharge waste water. Residents said that such practice is prevalent in other parts of the city including Cantonment.

Sanitary workers face routine hardships to clear the drains clogged with plastic waste and used flour from hotels. “When the drainage gets clogged, rather than placing a complaint with the corporation regarding it, commercial establishments request locals to register complaints so that their wrondoing is not exposed,” a source said.

The cleaning process also impacts the movement of pedestrians as the platforms covering the storm water drainages are frequently opened. When contacted, city health officer A Jaganathan said that action will be taken against erring commercial establishments.

Title: Court to hear Revanth’s pleas on March 17
Content:
Hyderabad: Justice G Sri Devi of the Telangana high court on Saturday admitted three pleas filed by Congress MP A Revanth Reddy, who urged the court to quash the drone case filed against him by the state police. The court would hear them on March 17.

Senior counsel Salman Khurshid argued that the drone case would not award him more than a month’s jail even if he is convicted. He had already spent nine days in jail, he said.

Public prosecutor Pratap Reddy opposed relief to Revanth, contending that at his behest, some persons used drone at the house of a VIP. “This is unlawful and some anti-social elements too may resort to similar methods,” he said. It was Revanth who went to police station and wanted police to arrest him, he said, terming Revanth’s action politically motivated. tnn

Title: Kolhapur: Worker killed at Sangli Road
Content:
Representative image

KOLHAPUR: The Ichalkaranji police registered a case against unidentified individuals for murdering a construction worker at Sangli Road on Thursday.

The deceased has been identified as Kishor Suresh Netke (28), who is a resident of Sangli Road in Ichalkaranji.

According to Ichalkaranji police, Kishor was attacked by four or more people, when he was on his bike going towards Sangli Road. “His body was lying on the road, creating an impression that he met with an accident . Residents took him to the hospital when doctors found serious injuries on his neck, head, and chest,” said an officer attached with Ichalkaranji police.

Police suspect that Kishor was attacked near the bridge, which is supposedly a dark area. They are further checking the CCTV footage from nearby houses and shops to trace the attackers. They are also exploring angles if Kishor had any previous enmity with any attackers.

Police suspect that attackers might have run over Kishore’s body after attacking him with sharp weapons. The crime site also provides some clues indicating that Kishor was chased by the attackers by a car.

Police are recording statements of Kishor’s family members and friends. His family members told police that Kishor was constantly getting threatening calls from the past few days.

Title: Tiger, gaur safaris at Chennai zoo soon
Content:
Two safari parks will come up close to the existing lion safari enclosure, chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswa... Read More

CHENNAI: You can soon experience a wild experience at the Vandalur zoo, watching tigers and Indian gaur in the open.

The two safari parks will come up close to the existing lion safari enclosure, chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami announced in the state assembly on Friday under Rule 110.

The proposal to set up the two parks at an estimated Rs 11.50 crore, as part of a safari world project, is aimed at drawing more visitors to the zoo, already the city’s top tourist spot, a senior wildlife department official said, adding that the it will be thrown open to the public in about five months.

The lion safari park, where visitors in vans can see seven big cats roaming in the open, will be the basis of the proposed safari parks, said the official.

Fifteen hectares have been set up for the Indian gaur facility and kept vacant. Clearing of undergrowth and laying of roads are to be taken up soon. A successful breeding programme has ensured that the zoo now has more than 25 of the animals including a few calves. Space for the tiger park is yet to be finalised along with the number of animals to be released in the open and the number of vehicles to take visitors inside.

No zoo in South India has a tiger safari and the one proposed at Vandalur could even be a first of its kind in the country, the official said.

The zoo, which sprawls over 6.03 sq km, is larger than most facilities in the country including in north India, he added.

Title: HC disposes of govt plea to bring accused from MP
Content:
Ahmedabad: The Gujarat high court has disposed of the state government plea seeking directions to Madhya Pradesh government to send 10 accused in the 2008 serial blasts from MP jail to Sabarmati jail, after the government did not press its demand on Thursday.

The state government told the HC that it was seeking the presence of the accused including main suspect Safdar Nagori before the special judge in Ahmedabad so that the court can record their further statements under provisions of Section 313 of the CrPC. However, the court has already started recording statements of these accused persons through video-conferencing and therefore there is no need for directions to bring those accused to Ahmedabad prison.

The 10 accused were transferred to MP jail a couple of years ago after they were convicted in a terrorism related case in the neighbouring state.

The HC was also moved by the state government following the complication that arose after the MP government did not send these 10 accused to Gujarat on directions issued by the trial court last year.

The MP government did not send the accused to Gujarat citing Section 268 of CrPC, the provision restricting a prisoner’s movement outside the jail, as well as availability of video-conferencing for the trial in Ahmedabad.

When the MP government did not send the accused to Gujarat, the trial court threatened to initiate contempt of court proceedings against MP officials, including the jail authorities, for disobeying its orders. The MP government approached the high court, which stayed the trial court from issuing contempt proceedings. The HC had termed the trial court’s order as general and vague.

Title: 308 govt medical college teachers to be hired on fixed pay
Content:
Ahmedabad: After introducing fixed-pay system in various departments, the state government on Friday announced filling up of 308 positions of professors, associate professors and assistant professors in medical colleges. The recruitment process will take place from March 16 to 26.

The government has introduced two categories of practising and non-practising faculty members with different pay scales, causing furore among the candidates. The fixed-pay appointments would be for 11 months.

According to the notification, the recruitment will be for the Gujarat Medical Education & Research Society (GMERS) colleges at Sola, Gotri, Gandhinagar, Valsad, Junagadh, Patan, Himmatnagar and Vadnagar.

“The professors who wish to practice medicine or surgery along with the job will be paid Rs 50,000 and those who will teach full time will get Rs 1 lakh. For associate professors, the figures are Rs 40,000 and Rs 65,000 and for assistant professors Rs 30,000 and Rs 55,000. Currently, about 400 posts are vacant in the state medical colleges,” said a government medical college official.

It’s likely that the model will also be followed for government colleges with non-clinical positions filled by contract system. “Whenever there is Medical Council of India (MCI) inspection, 250-plus professors, associate professors and assistant professors are transferred across the state. While the medical fraternity was waiting for the recruitment process, the fixed-pay system has discouraged many,” said the official.

Title: Thiruverkadu offers discount coupons for segregating waste
Content:
Residents with coupons

CHENNAI: Thiruverkadu municipality on the outskirts of Chennai is offering discount coupons that can be redeemed at 15 commercial establishments to people segregating waste. The one lakh residents of the municipality generate 23 tonnes of solid waste daily.

“We have identified 1,000 individuals in Thiruverkadu municipality who segregate household waste. We are giving them free coupons, ” said municipal commissioner S Senthilkumaran.

The civic body has struck deals with three hotels, two bakeries, two vegetable shops, two supermarkets, a gym, a saloon, a water can agency, a textile shop, a medical shop, and a tea and juice shop in the town to offer discounts of 2% to 10% on the coupons. Municipality officials said they were in talks with more showrooms and shops to accept the coupons and offer discounts.

Tiruvallur collector Mageswari Ravikumar launched the pilot project on Thursday at the municipality office under ‘Clean India – Not too far’ scheme.

Commissioner Senthilkumaran said, “At least 75% of residents segregate dry and wet waste. Wet waste is sent to a micro-composting centre where workers further separate it into saleable and non-saleable waste.” He said the civic body conducted regular meetings with conservancy workers who are also monitored using the GPS fitted to their vehicles.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Chinese lockdown hits artificial gem cutters in Trichy
Content: TRICHY: The scare over the novel coronavirus has created an unusual victim in Trichy , the artificial gem cutting industry which depends solely on China for raw materials and machinery. Ever since the virus outbreak was reported from China, the movement of both has ceased. The lockdown has put aspiring entrepreneurs in the artificial gem cutting industry in a fix too.Trichy was once considered the capital of artificial hand-made gems or artificial diamonds supplied to jewelleries. These were used in the value-addition process of gold and imitation jewels. However, the rise of Chinese artificial gem cutting machines in the past decade had paved the way for the downfall of hand-made artificial diamonds in Trichy. Gradually, jewellers imported artificial diamonds from China while a few entrepreneurs imported the machinery itself to produce artificial gems here.Except for the few local gem makers, jewellers were importing artificial diamonds from China and other countries. Things were smooth until Covid-19 outbreak started to wreak havoc in the local artificial gem making industry. “We still depend on China for the cutting and polishing tools. We usually import on a monthly basis to cut the artificial diamonds. The clampdown on goods movement has kept our workshop closed,” T Rajasekar , leading artificial diamond maker from Karumandapam, said.Rajasekar is one of the few artificial gem producers with imported Chinese gem cutting machine worth Rs 30 lakh to produce 30,000 artificial diamonds a day. On seeing his success story, a bunch of conventional gem cutters mobilised fund and subsidies and were to follow suit. They are in a fix now as they could not launch production after the lockdown in China. “I mobilised Rs 25 lakh to procure Chinese gem cutting machines and was about to visit China. But Covid-19 scare has derailed our plans,” M Kalyani, a conventional artificial gem maker said. Kalyani is not alone as at least five such conventional gem makers who mobilised funds to purchase the machines are in trouble. Citing visa restrictions till April 15, the entrepreneurs said they have to wait for two more months to resume their business.

Title: KMC to allow parking in private spaces, hike fees at pay & park facilities
Content:
Representative image

KOLHAPUR: The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation ( KMC ) is going to draft a policy to allow parking of vehicles on privately-owned spaces to avoid traffic congestion in the city, Sachin Jadhav, chief estate officer of the civic body said.

The municipal corporation is also going to hike parking fees for two-wheelers and four-wheelers at its sites. While four-wheelers will be charged Rs 40 per hour, two-wheelers will have to pay Rs 20 per hour once the proposal is approved by the general body.

In addition, parking of heavy vehicles will be banned on the KMC-owned parking sites .

For the sites managed by the Kolhapur Municipal Transport (KMT), parking charges for two-wheelers will be increased to Rs 10 per hour and Rs 30 for four-wheelers.

Sachin Jadhav, chief estate officer of the KMC, said, “Considering the increase in expenses to manage the parking sites, we have decided to hike the parking fees. The standing committee has submitted the proposal in the general body where the final decision will be taken. Currently, KMC has two parking sites whereas KMT has eight. Of these eight sites, four are currently operational while the rest are yet to be started.”

In total, six pay and parking sites are currently operational in the city. Recently, district guardian minister Satej Patil suggested developing parking sites in private spaces. Jadhav said that a draft policy regarding the same will be ready in a couple of weeks.

“Considering the limited staff and delays in getting private contractors on board, we have decided to ask the owners to allow parking of vehicles in their unused spaces. The charges for parking vehicles in private spaces will be fixed by us. The owners have to formally apply for a license and the town planning officials will be consulted to ensure that no other developmental work is being planned at that particular site. The vehicles parked on roads often cause traffic congestion. Allowing people to park their vehicles in private spaces will not only be beneficial for commuters but also for owners of these private spaces,” added Jadhav.

Title: Gujarat: PSU bank staff to go on strike on March 27
Content: AHMEDABAD: Just ahead of the financial year-end, at least 30,000 employees of public sector banks are expected to go on strike on March 27. This means banks will remain closed for three consecutive days, March 28-29 consist the fourth-Saturday weekend, and therefore, banks will be closed on these days. Bankers will go on strike to protest privatization of nationalized banks.“Privatization and unwarranted merger of banks is taking place, despite our vehement protests. Besides, the issue of recovery of corporate bad loans is being ignored and concessions are being given to the corporates while service charges are increased for the common people,” said a statement issued by the bank employees’ association.Estimates by Maha Gujarat Bank Employees’ Association (MGBEA) suggest that transactions worth Rs 15,000 crore are likely to be affected with banks remaining closed for a day. Banking transactions such as cash withdrawals, cheque deposits in addition to issuing drafts, letters of credit, among others are likely to be hit. The decision to go on strike has irked trade associations and industry bodies, because closure of banks around the financial year-end will hit business activities hard. Bankers are protesting for wage revision and against privatization of nationalized banks.“March-end is a time when the entire year’s books of accounts are to be cleared, audits are taking place, payments are to be issued and all of this involves extensive financial transactions. Banks not functioning for three days at a stretch will only add to the woes of customers,” said Jayendra Tanna, president, Gujarat Trader Federation (GTF).In fact, the GTF along with several other trade associations, has already filed a petition in the Gujarat high court, over frequent strikes by bank employees which is hampering business activity.

Title: I-T firms offer jobs to kin of CRPF martyrs
Content:
Hyderabad: I-T companies, security companies and other firms in the city are offering jobs to the family members of CRPF martyrs. These family members have not received jobs from state or central government.

CRPF IG, MR Naik, told TOI, “Around 2,200 CRPF personnel were martyred in the country, but only few of the family members got jobs in the government sector. In Telugu states, 63 CRPF personnel lost their lives and only nine of the family members got jobs in state and central government on compassionate grounds. For the first time, we are able to arrange jobs for around 20 family members based on their educational qualification.”

CRPF DG AP Maheshwari will hand over the appointment letters to the family members of CRPF martyrs on Friday. Companies like Wipro, Tech Mahindra, Kaston, GAR Corporation and others have offered jobs for positions of software engineers, security supervisors, housekeeping staff, etc.

Maheshwari will also inaugurate 77 New Family Quarters in Hyderabad.

Title: Pilgrim turnout at Purnagiri dips due to coronavirus scare, bad weather, ongoing board exams
Content: Tanakpur (Champawat): The turnout of pilgrims at the ongoing Purnagiri temple fair in Tanakpur received a hit due to the combined effect of coronavirus scare, bad weather conditions, and state board examinations.Office-bearers of the revered shrine say that the pilgrim footfall has decreased in comparison to previous years. The district officials and organisers of the fair, meanwhile, are hoping that pilgrim footfall would increase after the weather gets clear and state board exams get over.“We are hoping that the footfall would increase once a special train for the fair, like every year, is started. All preparations have been made for the pilgrims who visit the fair,” Dayanand Saraswati, fair magistrate and sub-divisional magistrate, Tanakpur, told TOI. He added that the administration has made special arrangements to deal with the coronavirus threat and regular check-ups have been arranged. “Teams of doctors have been deployed on both the routes of Indo-Nepal border. Every person coming in from those routes is being screened. Doctors have also been stationed at all the parking lots of the fair complex. Hoardings have been put up to make people aware of coronavirus and mike announcements are also being made,” added Saraswati.

Title: Tourists from 5 nations to be allowed inside CTR only after they test negative for Covid-19
Content: Nainital: Officials of Corbett Tiger Reserve (CTR), on Friday, announced that tourists from five nations — China, Japan, South Korea, Iran and Italy — will only be allowed inside the reserves after they test negative for Coronavirus. The certification will be given by a medical team designated by the Chief Medical Officer (CMO).This means that the tourists who come to visit CTR will have to wait until their medical report proves that they do not have coronavirus. “The testing of samples usually takes three-four days, so till that time tourists can stay the night at the hotels they have booked,” CTR director Rahul said, adding that this is for tourists from nations where Coronavirus cases have crossed alarming numbers. “Teams have been stationed at each gate of the tiger reserve and they will conduct blood test, nasal secretion tests, and thermal screenings of all tourists before granting them entry to CTR,” he said. These five countries are worst hit by Coronavirus and the number of cases in these nations runs into thousands.Rahul said that even the tourists who come from places other than these priority nations will have to go through a thermal inspection before being allowed entry into the CTR. Indian tourists will also have to undergo these screenings.The CTR officials say that face masks have been distributed to all its employees and they have been directed to wear them throughout their duty hours. "We have also procured sanitisers and disinfectants to maintain hygienic conditions. All of our employees have been distributed masks and they have been advised to wear them at all times," Rahul said.Even though the tests are only for the tourists entering CTR, the administration has also asked the hotel and resort owners to keep an eye on tourists who show Coronavirus-like symptoms.Hari Mann, president of Ramnagar Hotel Association, said that they have also procured sanitisers and disinfectants and are continuously checking on the tourists as well.

Title: Woman thrashed, eyes gouged out, dies
Content:
Bareilly: A 26-year-old married woman was thrashed and her eyes gouged out in her house at a village in Nigohi area of Shahjahanpur on Thursday night. She was taken to hospital where she succumbed to injuries on Friday morning.

The woman’s husband alleged that his wife was killed by their neighbour while the neighbour claimed that the woman’s husband killed her after he came to know about their extramarital affair.

Police have filed an FIR against her paramour, Krishan Kumar, and two of his brothers under IPC sections 342 (wrongful confinement), 452 (house trespass with intent to hurt) and 302 (murder) at Nigohi police station on the complaint of woman’s parents.

Dr Ajay Nagar, a member of autopsy team, told TOI, “The woman’s body bore nearly 40 injuries. She was hit repeatedly on the face with a blunt object and later, strangled to death. It is likely that she was tortured before being killed.”

People on the side of the husband claimed that the victim and her sister-in-law were alone at home when their neighbour, Krishan Kumar, who was inebriated, barged into their house and locked himself with the victim in a room. Those supporting the neighbor, alleged that when woman’s husband came to know about her affair, he and his family members thrashed her in a fit of rage.

SHO Indrajeet Bhadauria told TOI, “We have registered an FIR against Krishan and his two brothers but we are also investigating the other aspects of the case. None of the neighbours saw the accused entering the victim’s house and someone told us that there was an argument between the couple over her affair.”

Title: ‘Make the machines here, revive industry’
Content:
Trichy: With no possibility of sourcing their tools from China, artificial gem cutters are now seeking the help of domestic fabrication industries to produce them. MSMEs said if fabrication units here can manufacture low-cost gem cutting and polishing machines as replacement for Chinese machinery, it will help revive the artificial gem cutting industry.

“Trichy’s MSMEs are known for skilled replication of machinery and components. Domestic production of gem cutting machines will also bring down the machine’s cost compared to the imported one,” N Kanagasabapathy, past president, Trichy District Tiny and Small Scale Industries Association (Tiditssia) said. Presently, artificial gem cutters purchase the machines for Rs 25-30 lakh. If domestically produced, the cost of the machine can be limited to Rs 10-15 lakh, MSME sources said. Due to the lockdown in China and unavailability of spare parts, artificial gem cutters have approached industries in Hosur to produce gem polishing tools. However, the quality of the tool produced locally has to be refined further to be on par with the Chinese tools. “We can check one imported gem cutting machine and consider it as a prototype to be emulated. Some of the fabrication units are already producing semi-automatic gem cutting machines here,” R Ilango, president, Tiditssia said.

Since the huge cost of importing machines deters artificial gem cutters, entrepreneurs said that local production of low-cost gem cutting machines will revive the dormant domestic industry. Artificial gem cutters said they are paying 18% GST for importing the gem cutting machines. Local production if encouraged will defeat the Chinese monopoly, they added. TNN

Title: 21 travellers under surveillance for Covid-19 in Meerut
Content:
Meerut: Amid coronavirus scare in the country with two dead and 81 cases being confirmed, the health department here has kept 21 travellers under surveillance.

The health authorities have made it mandatory for travellers from seven countries – France, Spain, Italy, South Korea, Japan, Iran and Germany -- to get themselves tested if they arrive in Meerut.

The 21 travellers identified had visited one or more of these countries and China over the past few weeks.

So far, not a single case has been left unattended to. Meerut has sent samples of nine people so far for testing, out of which eight have tested negative and the report of one case is pending, said health officials.

The Union government has suspended visas for visitors from all other countries for at least a month in response to the coronavirus pandemic. The suspension came into effect on Friday.

“As many as 21 people who have travelled from other countries to India are under surveillance for coronavirus. Not just this, it is mandatory to get the travellers from seven countries -- France, Spain, Italy, South Korea, Japan, Iran and Germany – tested for the disease,” said Dr Rachna Tandon, Meerut district epidemiologist.

Meanwhile, as many as three new swine flu cases were reported in Meerut on Friday, taking the total number of patients to 101.

“Testing of samples for coronavirus is absolutely free for those with suspected symptoms and travel history. We, in fact, send a team of health officials to take samples of all the suspected patients and sent them to Delhi for further testing,” said Dr Tandon.

“There is nothing to panic about. City residents should take care of their hygiene and cleanliness to ensure that they do not get infected. Only people whose immunity is compromised are at risk, while others shall focus on improving their immunity and hygiene,” said Dr Raj Kumar, Meerut chief medical officer.

Title: Corporation seals shop for not clearing rent worth Rs 37 lakh
Content:
Trichy: Revenue department officials with Ponmalai zone of the Trichy Corporation on Friday locked and sealed a shop for non-payment of rent totalling Rs 37.42 lakh.

The shop, located on the Madurai Road near Trichy Railway Junction, belongs to the corporation. The shopkeeper, Thangabalam Arumainayaagm, had not been paying the monthly rent of Rs 19,000 plus taxes for the past few years, officials said. As notices sent by the civic body directing the shopkeeper to pay the rent had not yielded any result, the officials on Friday locked and sealed the shop.

Corporation sources said that the shopkeeper would be permitted to retrieve the belongings in the shop outlet only after settling the outstanding rent.

The civic body said that it is considering similar lock and seal drive for collecting pending rent from other buildings in the city. “Few shops are still defaulting on paying outstanding monthly rent to the tune of Rs 5 lakh. They were insisted to pay the amount or face similar action,” an official source said.

Title: Inter student commits suicide
Content: Warangal: An Intermediate first year student committed suicide by hanging herself from the ceiling at her house in Padmakshi Colony in Hanamkonda on Friday. According to Hanamkonda police, Saraswathi (17), a student of Pingle Women’s College, was depressed over her poor performance in English exam. Hanamkonda police registered a case and shifted the body to MGM Hospital for postmortem. tnn

Title: Uttar Pradesh: After Shaheen Bagh, another infant dies after falling ill at anti-CAA protest site
Content:
MUZAFFARNAGAR: A 42 days old baby girl died allegedly after being exposed to cold weather conditions at an anti-CAA protest site in UP’s Deoband, where her mother was bringing her for the last 15 days to “make the child strong”. According to the protest organiser, Amna Roshi, the woman was bringing the child to the sit-in despite being warned against it.

“I had warned Noshaba several times. I had told her not to carry the child to the protest site as it was cold due to the rains. Even we had sent her back once as she was carrying the child. But she used to say that the baby girl was getting stronger,” Roshi said.

It comes against the backdrop of the death of a four-month-old infant at Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh. The child had died due to exposure to cold weather on the night of January 29.

A similar protest is going on in Deoband’s Eidgah ground for the last 47 days, and scores of women are taking part in the relay strike against the Constitutional (Amendment) Act. Noshaba was also among the participants, who started to bring her newborn about 15 days ago.

According to sources, the child fell ill a few days ago. “On Thursday evening, the girl slept and didn’t wake up,” a source close to the family said, adding that she was rushed to a hospital where doctors declared her brought dead.

On Friday, a large number of protesters, including Roshi, went to Noshaba’s home and paid condolence. A special prayer was also organized at the protest site later.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Pregnant woman found hanging, kin allege murder
Content:
Representative Image

BIJNOR: A seven-month-old pregnant woman was found hanging at her in-laws’ house in Bijnor's Faizipur village on Friday. Family members of the deceased woman alleged that her in-laws hanged her for dowry. They have filed a complaint against four members on her in-laws’ side. A case has been registered against her husband, his father-in-law, brother-in-law and sister-in-law under relevant sections of the IPC.

The deceased woman was identified as Kaushal (25). Her husband, Sompal Singh, and brother-in-law-Manoj Kumar have been detained for questioning.

Family members of the deceased alleged that Kaushal was hanged to death by her in laws for failing to bring Rs 50,000 and a bike as dowry. They kept on harassing for dowry even after five years of her marriage, they alleged.

When Himpur police rushed to the spot and tried to take charge of the body, the deceased’s family members opposed it, demanding strict action against the accused.

Later, the deceased’s family members staged a protest at Himpur police station, demanding that a complaint be filed against Sompal Singh, Manoj Kumar and father-in-law Kailash Saini and sister-in-law Vimala.

Police have registered a case against the accused under various IPC sections, including 306 (abetment of suicide) and 498a (husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty), said Himpur SHO Vinod Kumar Tyagi.

Title: More isolation wards set up in Kolhapur, Sangli districts
Content:
Representative image

KOLHAPUR: Kolhapur and Sangli district administrations have set up more isolation wards for potential coronavirus cases in their respective jurisdictions. So far, no case has been reported from these regions.

“The isolation wards are necessary for treatment of Covid-19 suspects. So far, we have set up a 48-bed facility in five different locations across Kolhapur district. We have scouted a few more private hospitals in the city and the number of beds will increase by 50. A total of 98 beds will be available in isolation wards in Kolhapur,” said B C Kempi Patil, district civil surgeon, Kolhapur.

He said that apart from that they have identified locations for quarantine facility for the suspects in the city. The suspects can be accommodated in the quarantine facility set up in an animal husbandry hall behind the circuit house. “So far, no suspects have been identified and only travelers who had foreign travel history were home monitored,” he said.

“Since March 2, the swab samples of around four individuals have been sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune, of which, three have been tested negative while one is awaited,” Patil said.

In Sangli, a 48-bed isolation ward will be set up in Wanless hospital, said district collector Abhijeet Chaudhary.

“There was a small hiccup while we were scouting the location for setting up of an isolation ward facility as few locals in the concerned locality showed opposition to it. We have now ticked off the said location and changed it to Wanless hospital where the 48-bed facility is available,” he said.

Chaudhary has also issued a circular stating that yatras and annual fair be called off to avoid mass gatherings.

“This is the need of the hour and we have to act accordingly. Weekend holidays for the concerned department officials too have been called off,” he said.

Shekhar Singh, district collector, Satara, in his media brief, said that there will be strict monitoring of lodges, restaurants, and dhabas on national highways. If any hotelier is found maintaining unhygienic conditions, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has been given a free hand to seal such establishments.
