Police did not find poison or any other substance in the room. “Also, he did not froth at the mouth,” the SI said and added they can confirm the cause of death only after receiving the post-mortem report.

Dr Subhash had been working as an assistant cardiologist in the hospital for more than a year.

His suicide was third such instance by a doctor in Hyderabad in recent times. Last week, MD of a multi-speciality hospital Dr Ravindra Kumar shot himself with his licensed pistol in his Dammaiguda home . On February 4, MD of Vaishnavi Hospital Dr K Ajay Kumar ended his life in his hospital cabin in LB Nagar. The doctor reportedly left a note naming seven persons, including a former sarpanch, responsible for his suicide.

Meanwhile, some doctors have voiced concerns over work pressure and long working hours. “We worked together for 18 hours a day, most of the time in the ICU. His suicide has left us all in a shock,” said a woman doctor.

Recalling his association with Dr Subhash, president of resident doctors’ association, NIMS, Dr G Srinivas urged the corporate hospitals and the government to introspect on the spurt in suicides by medical professionals.

“Since doctors in corporate hospitals put in longer hours of work, stress levels are very high. If they have personal problems, it gets worse,” he said.

Title: B’luru based Star Air to connect Hyd to Jamnagar in May
Content:
Hyderabad: Bengaluru-based commercial airline Star Air is all set to connect Hyderabad to Jamnagar in Gujarat, which is home to some of the world’s largest oil refineries, this May, Star Air CEO Simran Singh Tiwana said here on Friday.

“It will be an interesting route as the entire western Gujarat area has not been connected to south India yet. So, we will be connecting Jamnagar to Bengaluru and thereafter Jamnagar to Hyderabad in May,” he added.

The year-old airline has three aircraft connecting nine centres, including Tirupati, Hubli, Indore, Kalaburagi, Ajmer and Raipur, among others. The airline is also set to connect Indore to Ajmer next week, he said.

Speaking about the aircraft acquisition plans on the sidelines of Wings India 2020, Tiwana said, “We fly about 18 hours a day. We are inducting two more aircraft by the end of April and thereafter we are looking at two more aircraft, Embraer 145s.”

Title: Covid 19 scare in Vizag: No pharmacy in Visakhapatnam airport for travellers looking to buy mask
Content: VISAKHAPATNAM: Even as health authorities take emergency measures to contain the spread of novel coronavirus, the lack of a pharmacy in Visakhapatnam International Airport has become a matter of concern for travellers.Although prescribed norms for international passengers are being followed at the airport, members of the airport advisory committee of Visakhapatnam airport suggested that precautionary measures be taken for domestic passengers as well.At Visakhapatnam airport, a frequent flyer, Kumar, said, “Since I needed to carry a sanitizer along with me while I was travelling, I went to search for one on the airport premises. I was disappointed after I learnt that there are no sanitizers available in the airport and later I found out that there is no pharmacy to cater to the medical needs of passengers.”The advisory committee has submitted a representation to the ministry of civil aviation on the need for preventive measures at Visakhapatnam airport.In the representation, committee members O Naresh Kumar and DS Varma said sanitizers should be provided at points where hand contact is unavoidable, such as the check-in process, and sanitizers and masks should be sold at MRP in the airport.The letter also recommends that passengers pass through a thermal scanner, ensure that no passenger COVID-19 symptoms is allowed to travel and have a doctor and supporting staff round-the-clock in the airport.All airport staff, the letter states, should be screened daily and given masks and gloves and buses, trolleys and washrooms be cleaned and fumigated more frequently.Speaking to TOI, Visakhapatnam airport director, M Raja Kishore said, “We are following all guidelines issued by the ministry of health and family welfare. Until now, we have not got any notification regarding screening of domestic passengers. Due to scarcity of availability of masks, we are providing mask for a passenger only if the need arises. However, it is not available for everyone.”Adding that cleaning of surfaces is being done with diluted solutions, Kishore said, “We have provided seriline hand rubbing liquid for the passengers.”Kishore added, “Although tenders for setting up a pharmacy were initiated several times, there was no response. We will initiate a fresh tender again. The matter will also be escalated to higher officials.”

Title: Student, 2 others commit suicide
Content:
Hyderabad: Three persons, including a degree student, ended their lives in the last 24 hours in the city.

Veluri Vandana (19), a first year degree student, hanged herself in her Almasguda house in the late hours of Thursday. According to police, Vandana was vexed with frequent tiffs with her husband Naveen Kumar. The couple got married in December last year. Police said Vandana found out about Naveen’s affair with her mother. She confronted her mother, who threatened her. A case of abetment to suicide was registered.

In the second incident, K Tirupathi Reddy (38) hanged himself inside his Errum Manzil office. Police said Reddy, a resident of Film Nagar, took the extreme step owing to work pressure. Reddy was working with a construction firm in Errum Manzil.

On Thursday morning, he left home at 10 am and did not come back home. “He might have taken the extreme step inside his office on Thursday night. When staff members reached the office at around 10 am, they found him hanging from the ceiling and alerted cops and his wife,” said Panjagutta SI Shiva Krishna.

In a suicide note, which cops found, Reddy wrote he took his life because of work pressure. He is survived by wife and a daughter. Police, however, are yet to receive a complaint from the family.

In another incident, a 28-year-old driver, M Ramesh hanged himself to a tree in his agriculture land at Kandukur. Ramesh left home saying he was going to attend the marriage function of his friend on Thursday night.

On Friday morning, his father found him hanging in the agriculture land. Police are yet to find out the reasons for his suicide.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Man poses as woman, dupes people of Rs 20 lakh
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 25-year-old man was nabbed by cybercrime police for impersonating a woman on a dating application and collecting money from various people under the pretext of a video chat. According to police, he cheated people to the tune of nearly Rs 20 lakh in the last one year.

The accused hails from Vizianagaram district in Andhra Pradesh. In February, a woman approached police stating that an unidentified person has created a fake Tinder profile in her name.

The accused was communicating with people and collecting money promising sex video chat.

During the investigation, it was found that the offender was creating fake profiles on social media platform, especially on dating apps, by using pictures of women which he downloaded from social media accounts.

Title: SpiceJet, GMR sign pact to develop a free trade zone at RGI airport
Content:
Hyderabad: GMR Hyderabad Aviation SEZ (GHASL), a 100% subsidiary of GMR Hyderabad International Airport (GHIAL), said it has signed an agreement to lease with SpiceJet, as part of which GHASL will be constructing a facility for SpiceJet to carry out warehousing, distribution and trading activity within the free trade warehousing zone of GMR Aerospace & Industrial Park, its multi-product SEZ housed in Hyderabad airport city.

The agreement will see the development of what is being touted as India’s first and only airport-based free trade zone (FTZ) on around 1.6 acres within the SEZ area of the GMR Aerospace & Industrial Park. The facility will be spread over 33,000 sq ft initially, with a potential to expand to 1 lakh sq ft, based on demand, GMR said.

Commenting on the development, SpiceJet chairman and managing director Ajay Singh said the move will boost the cargo industry in India.

“As we expand our cargo arm SpiceXpress, this first-of-its-kind initiative by an airline in India will enhance and facilitate cargo industry in the country. The FTZ and the end-to-end service provided by SpiceXpress will boost businesses, saving valuable time for our partner companies,” Singh said in a statement.

GMR Airport Land Development CEO Aman Kapoor said, “SpiceJet Limited’s addition to the FTZ at GMR Aerospace & Industrial SEZ is a testimony to the growing warehousing business at Hyderabad airport. Most of the tenants including those in pharma, aerospace & defence, electronics, automotive & FMCG, will benefit from the availability of high quality warehousing catering to the export and import of goods from RGIA .”

The park offers ready-to-use industrial infrastructure with the flexibility of choosing land within SEZ for businesses focusing on foreign markets and land in domestic tariff area for businesses catering to Indian market.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Taste for seafood dips amidst coronavirus fears
Content: VISAKHAPATNAM: The rise in number of coronavirus cases has led to a drastic fall in the sale of marine fish in Andhra Pradesh. According to an estimate by fishermen’s associations in the state, sales have decreased by at least 30 per cent in the last couple of months.“Just like chicken there’s a lot of misconception over consumption of fish. People are apprehensive they might get affected if they consume fish. Sale of fish has reduced drastically,” said Arijili Dasu, executive director of Fisherfolk Foundation, a community-based fishermen’s association in the city.Every year, Andhra Pradesh exports in bulk a portion of its marine catch to Odisha, Chhattisgarh and Karnataka, and even parts of Tamil Nadu, Kerala and Maharashtra.Since January, wholesalers supplying fish to neighbouring states have been reluctant to place bulk orders. At local markets across the state, wholesalers have reduced the number of orders.“Our estimate suggests that sale of marine fishes has dipped by at least 30 per cent and soon it will have an immense impact on the livelihood of the fishermen,” added Dasu.Andhra Pradesh has around 3,55,000 fishermen, of which around 75,000 are deep sea fishermen.Amidst fears surrounding the consumption of fish, fishermen added that the lack of storage facilities is compounding their problems. Apart from the fishing harbour in Visakhapatnam, no other fishing centre in the state has storage facilities.“If we cannot sell fish in bulk it becomes very difficult for us to keep the fish fresh. Many of us have stopped venturing out into the sea. Even if we are going to the sea our catch is lower than our usual catch,” said S Buliya, a fisherman.Fishermen’s associations who were planning to organise awareness camps for wholesalers and customers have now had to postpone their plans in view of the upcoming elections to local bodies in the state.“This is not the right time to organise such awareness programmes. People are busy with the election. We would wait till the dates of poll results and considering the situation then we would decide on the awareness camps,” said Dasu.

Title: AAI plans to raise $300m via ECB
Content:
Hyderabad: The Airports Authority of India (AAI), which has lined up a capex of Rs 25,000 crore for the next five years, is planning to raises about $300 million via the external commercial borrowing (ECB) route next fiscal to fund its capex plans, AAI chairman Arvind Singh said here on Friday.

“We are a profit-making company and are earning revenues from private airports which we have leased out. We have large amount of cash surplus. Apart from that we are also thinking of going for ECB at lower rates to fund our plans. We will be going for ECBs next financial year. Plus, we get funds from the Government of India (GOI) under UDAN scheme. They have allotted Rs 4,500 crore for building airports under the scheme,” Singh said on the sidelines of Wings India 2020. He added that the board has approved the ECB proposal a month ago.

He said there are 110 airports in the country, of which AAI operates over 90. Talking about the utilisation of the Rs 25,000 crore capex over the next five years, he said the funds will be utilised to upgrade some of its existing airports, build new terminals at some airports and converting some underserved and unserved airports under the UDAN scheme.

Title: CSIR, HAL sign defence aircraft MOU
Content:
Hyderabad: State-owned aerospace giant HAL and CSIR-NAL (National Aero Space Laboratories) on Friday inked a pact for design, development, production and maintenance of SARAS MK II aircraft, which is intended to be sold to Indian defence services, civil aviation sector and export customers.

The indigenously designed and developed 19-seater aircraft will also cater to the needs of regional connectivity in tier-2 and 3 cities, as well.

The MOU was signed by HAL director (operations) MS Velpari and NAL director Jitendra J Jadhav in the presence of senior officials of both the institutions.

Title: Rag-picker killed in Ameerpet after petty quarrel
Content:
Hyderabad: A rag-picker was murdered by a footpath dweller in Ameerpet during an argument over a petty issue on Thursday. Mohsin (35) had an argument with Abu alias Ghori, also a rag-picker, about a petty matter. The latter suddenly took out a blade and slit his throat, Panjagutta ACP Thirupatanna said.

“Mohsin and his wife were sleeping on a footpath in front of a garments showroom on Thursday night. At around 11.30pm, Mohsin’s wife went out. It was at this time they engaged in an argument and Mohsin was killed,” Thirupatanna said. Police registered a murder case under Section 302 of the IPC. The accused is on the run. TNN

Title: 11 caught drunk from MLA’s party plot
Content:
They were held on Thursday night

VADODARA/ ANAND: Sleuths of local crime branch of Anand busted a liquor party at a party plot from where nabbed 11 persons were nabbed in an inebriated state in Petlad town of Anand district on Thursday night.

The party plot is owned by Petlad’s Congress MLA Niranjan Patel. Sources said that two sons of the Congress MLA were also present at the party plot during the time of the raid, but they were not found to be be drunk. “The party plot belongs to the MLA but was hired for a function by the accused, most of whom are locals,” said police inspector H B Chouhan.

Chouhan confirmed that MLA’s sons were present at the party plot.

“Since, they are the owners of the party plot, they might have come for some work,” he said.

Those arrested include residents of Petlad, Karamsad, Kasbara, Mogri, Bakrol, Sojitra and Valasan areas of Anand district apart from one resident of Subhanpura area of Vadodara. The cops have also seized one liquor bottle from the premises.

Title: Thermal scanners set up in temple city
Content:
TTD has initiated measures to contain the spread of novel coronavirus in Tirumala . Nearly 60,000 devotees visit the temple town, on average, everyday.

As a first step towards isolating patients with symptoms of coronavirus, coronavirus awareness and counselling centres were set up at three different places including vehicle check point and pedestrian route at Alipiri and the Srivari mettu pedestrian route.

“Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy and K Jawahar Reddy, special chief secretary, medical and health department, government of Andhra Pradesh have already held reviews on the steps to be taken at Tirumala to contain the spread of COVID-19. Accordingly, coronavirus prevention camps have been set up with thermal scanning equipment, at Alipiri check-point, Alipiri pedestrian route and the Srivari mettu pedestrian routes,” EO Anil Kumar Singhal said.

“Our doctors and paramedic staff will monitor the situation round the clock and try to isolate pilgrims exhibiting symptoms. Such pilgrims will be referred to the isolation ward at the SVRR government general hospital in Tirupati for further treatment. The district administration has also requested TTD to allocate Sri Padmavathi Nilayam at Tiruchanoor to create additional isolation wards if necessary and we have agreed,” EO Anil Kumar Singhal added.

The EO said special focus has been given to sanitation . The EO added that TTD is broadcasting precautionary steps for creating awareness among pilgrims. “As a precautionary measure, TTD will allow only 250 devotees in each compartment of the Vaikuntham queue complex as against the usual 450-500 people,” the EO said.

Title: Sanskarinagri’s MSU sees ugly scenes again
Content:
Cap

Vadodara: M S University head office witnessed a clash for the second consecutive day on Friday over the delay in declaration of results of exams of commerce and other faculties of the university.

After Thursday’s scuffle between students and vigilance staff, a group of students led by general secretary (GS) of MSU Students Union (MSUSU) Rakesh Panjabi on Friday had again reached university head office to resolve the long pending issues related to declaration of result.

But when the students group started raising slogans, members of the vigilance staff entered into heated arguments with them and allegedly started pushing the students which aggravated the situation.

Two syndicate members – Mayank Patel and Dinesh Yadav – who had reached the head office to resolve the problems faced by the students were also annoyed with the aggressive behaviour of some of the vigilance staff members who kept on pushing the students group in the presence of MSU’s officiating registrar K M Chudasama.

“In the melee, one of our students was even slapped multiple times by a personnel of a private security agency,” alleged Panjabi.

Both Patel and Yadav too issued a stern warning to vigilance staff members asking them to handle such situations with utmost care, especially when students come to make genuine representations before the university officials.

Later, the syndicate members took a couple of students representatives for a meeting with MSU vice-chancellor (VC) professor Parimal Vyas, who assured them of all the co-operation.

Vyas has decided to constitute an exam reforms committee with representation of MSUSU GS and vice-president.

The students have been demanding declaration of results of the semester end results that ended on December 9. “It has been agreed that the results will be declared latest by March 24. Also, after declaration of results, students will get enough time before the next exam session begins,” said Panjabi.

“We are resolving whatever issues have cropped up and we will have a committee to find a fruitful solution,” said Chudasama.

Title: 52 sovereigns gold stolen from house
Content:
Coimbatore: Burglars decamped with 52 sovereigns of gold jewellery from a house in Pollachi.

The burglary came to light on Friday morning when the residents, who were away, returned. In addition to the gold jewellery, police said silver ornaments worth Rs 15,000 were also stolen from the house.

According to police, houseowner K Dharmalingam, a resident of Suleswaranpatti, had left the place along with his family on Wednesday to Sathankulam in Tirunelveli district to attend a family function. They returned on Friday morning to find the door broken open and the valuables kept in a wooden bureau missing.

Fingerprint experts Ajithkumar and Ranjith visited the spot and lifted three fingerprints suspected to be that of the burglars. Police said that there were no CCTV cameras installed in the vicinity of the house. Efforts are on to identify the suspects. tnn

Title: Pune: RTO not to register BS-IV vehicles after March 31
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The Regional Transport office ( RTO ) on Friday said it would not register any new vehicle of the Bharat Stage IV (BS-IV) emission standard make after March 31, 2020, in accordance with the Supreme Court’s order.

“This is in line with the Supreme Court order. So, people should exercise caution,” a senior RTO official said.

Addressing a news conference on Friday, Pune regional transport officer Ajit Shinde said people buying new BS-IV vehicles should complete their purchases a week before March 31, 2020, to ensure timely completion of the registration.

“Unlike, what happened during the migration in March 2017, people cannot buy BS-IV vehicles till the last date and register later. The process of registration has to be completed by March 31, 2020,” Shinde said.

In March 2017 (see box), vehicle sales had increased by about 4-6 times compared to usual office days on the count of unprecedented discounts. “The new BS-IV vehicles not registered by March 31, 2020, will directly go for scrapping,” he said.

BS-VI standard vehicles and renewal registrations of all old vehicles will continue as per the usual process. On an average, about a 700-1,000 two-wheelers and about 200-300 four-wheelers get registered at the Pune RTO every day. A majority of manufacturers have already migrated their fleet to BS-VI.

However, in the prevailing slow market, dealers have been left with a sizable BS-IV stock, which might prompt the dealers to resort to deep discounts to sell the BS-IV vehicles. “People should check with the dealer on assurance of registration before March end. Only then should they make their purchase,” Shinde said.

Title: New IIIT-H gizmo for personalised AC temp
Content:
Hyderabad: People at workplaces will no longer have to deal with a uniform air-conditioning temperature as researchers at the International Institute of Information Technology, Hyderabad (IIIT-H) have invented a method that will enable co-workers to have personalized temperature as per their comfort.

In a bid to provide user control, Prof Vishal Garg and his student Sam Babu Godithi from the IIIT-H invented the mechanism iSPACE (Intelligent System for Personal Ambient Control and Energy Efficiency), which was recently patented in the US.

Funded by the Department of Science and Technology (DST) under the US-India Joint Center for Building Energy Research and Development (CBERD) project, the mechanism consists of a SmartHub and a smart power strip that enables networking of all personal environment devices, providing a unified interface to the user with the building level control systems.

For example, a person having a workstation facing a window may have higher sunlight versus some sitting away. This means that a uniform air conditioning temperature set for the floor will not provide the same level of comfort to the window-facing occupant (who would need a lower setting) and the occupant sitting further away.

The mechanism invented by the IIIT-H researchers will optimize the load of devices such as table lamps, air-conditioner, table fans etc. “We are letting users have a say in the manner in which loads can be optimized while exercising a choice on their comfort parameters at the work stations,” said Prof Garg.

The mechanism is currently being evaluated for two scenarios. In the first scenario, the building publishes the electricity price without any constraint on the load whereas in the other every individual gets a load limit within which she has to operate. The research team at Lawrence Berkeley National Lab and IIITH are exploring how the technology can be commercialized.

Title: Haj tour operators ask GST relief
Content:
Hyderabad: A delegation of tour operators met state finance minister T Harish Rao on Friday and requested him to present their plea for GST exemption at the council meeting on Saturday.

In a representation, the association requested GST exemption for all pilgrims visiting Saudi Arabia for Haj and Umrah. The association has requested exemption under the negative list clause which says ‘any service provided by way of conducting religious ceremony’ may be exempted from GST. Omer bin Taher

Title: Woman moves Pune civil court against D S Kulkarni & his wife
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A 53-year-old woman from Wanowrie has filed a suit in a city civil court against D S Kulkarni Developers Limited and its jailed top bosses D S Kulkarni (DSK) and his wife, Hemanti, for the recovery of Rs40 lakh she had invested in 2016 with the firm keeping in view her daughter’s future education and marriage.

The woman (name withheld) had received the money from a family court in Mumbai as a permanent alimony in a divorce proceeding against her estranged husband. Post-divorce, she shifted from Mumbai to Pune and was looking for an apt avenue to invest the money. She came across an investment scheme offered by the D S Kulkarni Developers Limited with interest at 18% per annum and opted for making the investment.

Her lawyer, Milind Pawar , told TOI, “We have preferred moving the civil suit to stake our claim on priority over any recovery made by the government from DSK and others. The ongoing proceeding before a designated sessions court under the MPID Act regarding the multi-crore rupees economic fraud by the developer and other accused is more of a criminal proceeding. There is no clarity yet as to when money will be recovered and distributed among the affected depositors.”

In her plaint, the woman stated that she invested Rs15 lakh with the developer’s company on May 5, 2016, and another Rs25 lakh on June 9, 2016, both as loans to the firm for receiving 18% per annum interest every quarterly term. As per a mutual agreement between her and the defendants (DSK, Hemanti and their firm), the quarterly interest was to be paid in advance, the plaint stated.

She stated that the defendants paid timely interest till February 2017 and kept assuring thereafter that her money was safe and, that, she would continue to receive quarterly interest on time. However, the defendants stopped paying interest and she started visiting DSK’s office for a refund of her deposit.

After several requests, the defendants issued her two payment vouchers as well as cheques of Rs15 lakh on April 5, 2018, and Rs25lakh on May 9, 2018, both drawn on the Bajirao Road branch of the Bank of Maharashtra , the plaint stated. When she deposited the cheques with her bank, the latter returned them as dishonoured on July 16, 2018, and August 8, 2018, with a remark “Refer to Drawer”.

Later, the woman sent a legal notice to defendants raising a demand for her money, but the latter did not comply with the notice and did not furnish any reply, the plaint added.

Title: Series of events at MSU rescheduled
Content:
Vadodara: COVID-19 has impacted activities at M S University campus. Several events or programmes that were scheduled this weekend are either being cancelled or postponed as part of precautionary measure.

On Friday, the university’s women’s grievance prevention, counselling and redressal cell (WGRC) had organised a programme on ‘sensitisation on prevention of sexual harassment at workplace’ which was cancelled at the last moment.

The programme was scheduled on Friday morning at the Pandit Deen Dayal Upadhayaya Auditorium located in the premises of Faculty of Management Studies.

Sources said that earlier the plan was to convene the programme with precautionary measures like providing masks to the participants but later as the logistics did not work out the programme was cancelled.

The university has taken the policy decision of cancelling major seminars, conferences and workshop at least till March 31 as a measure to safeguard against the spread of the 2019 novel coronavirus.

“For almost all the programmes, we have sent an advisory that we have received from the University Grants Commission (UGC) and the Ministry of Human Resources Development (MHRD),” said MSU’s officiating registrar K M Chudasama.

“We will continue with the routine things like classroom teaching with sufficient precautionary measures. But wherever mass gathering is expected such programmes or events should be avoided,” he said.

“This will be applicable till we get further orders from the UGC or MHRD and till the time there is improvement. Once, there is an improvement, things will be relaxed,” he said, adding that for smaller events, the decision has been left on the discretion of head of departments and deans of faculties.

Title: Pune: Minor falls from pickup truck, dies
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A 12-year-old boy was killed after he accidentally fell from a pickup truck while returning from Shivneri fort on Thursday afternoon on Junnar-Bankar Phata Road, around 110km from the city.

The boy — Pratik U Shingote of Khamundi village in Junnar — had gone to the fort with a group from his village to celebrate Shivjayanti. The group members took Pratik to a hospital in Otur, where he died, an officer from the Junnar police said.

“The entire group had gone to the fort in a pickup truck. They were returning to Khamundi after the celebrations. Pratik was sitting on the edge of the vehicle,” the officer said.

When the pickup truck crossed a pothole on Junnar-Kamshet Phata Road, Pratik lost his balance and fell off the truck. “He suffered severe head injuries,” the officer said. The group members rushed him to the hospital in Otur. “Pratik succumbed to injuries during treatment,” the officer said.

Pratik was a Standard VI student of a private school in Yedgaon in Junanr taluka, the officer said.

On February 19, a trekker (20) from Thane, Siddhi Kamate, died after she fell off the Hadsar fort, around 13km from Shivneri fort.

Kamate had gone to the fort to conduct a cleanliness drive to mark the birth anniversary of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj .

Title: Dwarka may get Delhi’s second BRT for smooth travel to airport
Content: NEW DELHI: To ease the traffic congestion in Dwarka, Delhi Development Authority (DDA) is mulling creating Delhi’s second Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) corridor connecting Dwarka to Indira Gandhi International Airport (IGIA).Delhi’s first and much maligned Ambedkar Nagar to Moolchand (5.8km) BRT corridor came up in 2008 during the Congress regime, which was criticised for causing major traffic snarls on the stretch. The corridor was eventually dismantled by the AAP government.A DDA official said the authority would ensure the ‘mistakes’ of the first corridor were not repeated in Dwarka. “The School of Planning and Architecture had been studying the traffic situation in the sub-city, and based on its interim report, the idea of BRT corridors and a proposal for Light Rail Transit (LRT) came up. We will ensure the width of the road is sufficient to avoid congestion,” the official said.A BRT corridor is of no benefit if it’s a standalone corridor that does not connect two major areas, he said, adding that, “If you do a half corridor, it will not work for any public transport project.”A source said DDA was likely to work on the Dwarka-IGIA BRT corridor, which would then be linked to Delhi Metro network for seamless integration. The second corridor connecting Dwarka to Bijwasan is also being planned, but no concrete steps have yet been taken.The official added that currently, the availability of buses in Dwarka was insufficient and more buses were required to ensure adequate frequency on the proposed corridors. “The bus frequency needs to be 2-5 minutes during peak hours. The bus routes also need to be changed and rationalised for better availability on key routes,” the official said, adding that better frequency will ensure last-mile connectivity from metro stations and bring down use of private vehicles.DDA is also planning to improve the connectivity between Dwarka and Gurgaon, but is not clear if it will be done through a BRT or an LRT corridor. “Any project to connect these two areas will require collaboration with the Haryana government. It is not going to be a simple project, but we are trying to come up with a plan,” he said, adding that the overall plan involves remodelling of road intersections, improving parking facilities, better accessibility in all areas, etc.As per the directions of lieutenant governor Anil Baijal, an inter-disciplinary sub-group under chairmanship of principal commissioner (land disposal), DDA was constituted to prepare a strategic plan dovetailing all projects optimising available land and building on the latest policy framework to develop complete ecosystem for Dwarka. The plan was presented to him on February 18. It focusses on issues related to regional connectivity of Dwarka, among others, and recommended exploring BRT or LRT corridors in the sub-city.

Title: Pune: Truck mows down man on Katraj-Dehu Road bypass
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A speeding truck mowed down a 23-year-old man while he was crossing the Katraj-Dehu Road bypass opposite High Energy Materials Research Laboratory (HEMRL) at Bavdhan on Thursday evening.

The Hinjewadi police said the man, Suresh Chavan , was a resident of Mhaske Vasti in Ravet. The truck driver left the vehicle at the accident spot and fled.

Assistant inspector Anand Pagare of the Hinjewadi police said Chavan was a tractor driver. “He was on his way to Katraj to drive a tractor for a Shivjayanti procession when the accident occurred,” he said.

A friend of Chavan had dropped him opposite HEMRL along the carriageway of the bypass towards Chandni Chowk around 6.30pm.

“Chavan had crossed half the carriageway and was in the first lane nearest to the divider, when the truck knocked him down. He died on the spot,” Pagare said.

“The truck was carrying watermelons. We have seized the vehicle and will soon arrest its driver,” Pagare said.

Chavan’s elder brother, Dhauji, has lodged an FIR with the police.

Title: Five horses with glanders in Santrampur to be euthanized
Content:
The horses were taken to the area in a goods carrier

VADODARA: Officials of the animal husbandry department in Santrampur found themselves in a sticky situation with locals of an area where they had taken five horses to be euthanized and buried after they tested positive with the dreaded glanders disease. The test results of one more horse is awaited as officials were asked to conduct the tests again.

The disease was diagnosed among horses owned by one Abdulsattar Pathan, a resident of Santrampura in Mahisagar district. One of his horses took ill earlier this month and was initially taken to the Santrampur veterinary hospital and then to Anand for treatment.

In wake of the horse showing symptoms of glanders, a test was conducted on the horse along with other horses in the same stable. It came to light that five of the horses were suffering from the disease. Officials told media persons that the test reports arrived on Thursday following which the decision to put them down was taken after necessary clearances from top officials of the animal husbandry department.

Officials identified an isolated place to euthanize the horses and bury them there. The horses were taken to the site in a goods carrier by the officials. However, a group of people staying in the area gathered at the site and objected to the horses being buried there.

The villagers even roughed up a couple of officials of the department who had to be taken to the Santrampur referral hospital for treatment. “The procedure to be followed in case of the disease is clearly laid out. Some misinformation spread regarding the disposal of the dead horses. We are trying to convince the people,” said Mahisagar district development officer Neha Kumari. She added that the option of choosing an alternative site was also being examined.

Meanwhile, the officials were also ordered to repeat the test for the sixth horse. A decision regarding this horse will be taken at a later stage. The veterinarians will also be conducting tests on donkeys, horses and mules in the area to rule out spread of the disease.

Title: HM man, auto driver booked for ruckus
Content:
Coimbatore: The city police have registered a case against Hindu Munnani executive committee member Guna for attacking an autorickshaw driver.

The incident happened on March 2. Members of Hindu outfits including Hindu Munnani were conducting a pro-CAA event in front of Hotel Tamil Nadu at Gandhipuram. The victim, N Shahul Hameed of the North Housing Unit at Selvapuram, had dropped some passengers in front of the hotel. Noticing a cellphone accidentally dropped by three men on a motorcycle, he picked it up and returned it to the bike-borne men, Hameed said. Meanwhile, Guna, who was accompanied by some other people, came there and abused him. They threatened him with dire consequences and also rebuked Hameed’s elder brother Kamardeen, he said.

Based on Hameed’s complaint, police registered a case under Section 75 (1) (c) of the Tamil Nadu District Police Act, 1859 and Section 323 (voluntarily causing hurt) and 506 (i) (criminal intimidation) of the Indian Penal Code.

Meanwhile, Guna filed a complaint with the Kattoor police stating that Hameed was recording the pro-CAA event using his mobile phone. When he questioned him, Hameed abused him, Guna said. Some people came there in 10 autorickshaws and threatened him with dire consequences, he told police.

Based on Guna’s complaint, police have registered a case against some people including Hameed. They were booked under Section 75 (1) (c) of TNCP act and 506 (i) (criminal intimidation) of the Indian Penal Code.

Title: Turbid water raises a stink again
Content:
Localities have been receiving brackish and yellow water

Vadodara: The old city seems to be mired in the menace of contaminated water supply. Residents here have been receiving dirty, stinking water for more than a week now which often flows out of taps as discoloured fluid.

Various localities of the city had been receiving brackish and yellow coloured water throughout the year. While the major issue of supply of turbid water from Nimeta filtration plants was taken care of by the aithrities during June-July 2019, other parts of the city continued to receive contaminated water due to local problems.

Sewage contamination remains a major issue in the old city as most drainage as well as water supply pipelines are old crying for replacement. Some of these areas have been facing the problem on and off for several years now with Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) having no permanent solution to nip their woes.

Both elected representatives from the affected areas as well as citizens have been taking up the issue with the civic body, but to no avail. Corporator from ward 13 Balasaheb Surve said, “I have been raising the issue repeatedly which only gets solved temporarily. Presently Rajratna Society, Goyagate Society, Shraddha Society, Vijay Society, Jawahar Society, Upla Falia and other areas are getting contaminated water.”

Hemangini Kolekar, corporator from ward 16, said, “The VMC clears drains and manholes in my locality to ensure sewage does not mix with drinking water, but the problem does not get solved. Sewage is flowing even in storm water drains in the area. There is some major fault that the officials are unable to take care of.”

VMC standing committee chairman Satish Patel said that he had ordered officials to take care of the contamination issue at the earliest. He said that the civic body had already sought aid from the state government to change the water supply network in the old city.

Title: Over 300 isolation beds at MLA hostel for Covid-19 patients
Content: Nagpur: In view of growing threats arising out from coronavirus, the district administration has readied over 300 isolation beds at MLA Hostel in Civil Lines. All the patients arriving at Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Airport from seven countries like China and South Korea, where Covid-19 cases are high, would be kept there under isolation for 14 days.However, the residents of Priyadarshini Nagar at Damodar Colony which is behind the MLA hostel, have protested the district administration’s move to set up a temporary hospital in the locality. They met collector Ravindra Thakare and handed over a representation to him opposing any such move.“As the city has found more cases of coronavirus, we the residents are obviously in the grip of fear. After coming to know about setting up of isolation wards, we’re more worried as the virus could be transmitted from the patients to nearby areas. We request the administration to shift the beds to other locations like Mayo hospital, Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) or outside the city, as some staff working in MLA hostel is staying in our colony,” the residents said in the representation, which was also forwarded to divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar and mayor Sandip Joshi.The delegation, led by corporator Pragati Patil, have Pavan More, Randhir Nashine, Amar Zanke, Sumit Chandekar Suchitra Nashine and others.Earlier, while speaking to media, Thakre, stated that the residential buildings were at a distance from the hostel where temporary beds were set up. “This virus didn’t spread by air and all precautions would be taken to prevent patients from getting into contact with outsiders. There is no need to panic for the residents,” he said.“We had already taken the permission from secretary of state’s legislature to use the hostel, as it comes under their jurisdiction. They immediately consented for it considering the situation,” he said.Endorsing him, divisional commissioner Kumar told TOI that it would be mandatory for all flyers from seven identified countries to undergo isolation of 14 days at the temporary facility erected at the MLA hostel. “All flyers would be directly taken here after they landed at the airport,” he said.Accompanied by divisional deputy director of health services Sanjay Jaiswal, the collector added that they were searching for all travellers from seven countries who descended in the city since February 15. “We’ve so far screened over 774 flyers from these countries, who arrived from Doha (daily) and Sharjah (twice a week) to the city. We plan to keep all these suspects and also those flying in city from these international destinations in newly created isolation wards in MLA Hostel,” he said.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: Coronavirus scare causes TTD to limit devotees at fest
Content: In view of the rising number of cases of novel coronavirus in the country and as a precautionary measure, the Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams (TTD) is likely to restrict the audience for the Sri Ramanavami Utsavams slated to begin on April 4 at the Sri Kodanda Rama Swamy temple at Vontimitta in Kadapa district.Addressing the media in Tirupati, TTD executive officer (EO) Anil Kumar Singhal said the Utsavam at Vontimitta is celebrated annually as a state festival and religious importance is attached to the Sitarama Kalyanam that is a part of the festival.“Like every year, we anticipate more than one lakh devotees to take part in the Sitarama Kalyanam scheduled for April 7 this year. TTD has already made elaborate arrangements for the conduct of the annual fete. As it is a customary practice, chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy is also scheduled to present ‘pattu vastrams’ to the presiding deities. But owing to the central and state government’s coronavirus-related advisories to avoid large congregations, we have now consulted the AP state government for advice on whether to go ahead with the festival celebrations as planned,” said the EO.The EO added, “We have brought the issue to the notice of the special chief secretary, medical and health department, government of Andhra Pradesh and sought the government’s advice. Once we get the instructions, there are chances of organising the religious events connected to the festival without having a large congregation.”Meanwhile, the EO along with additional EO AV Dharma Reddy presented ‘pattu vastrams’ to the presiding deity of Bhaktavatsala Perumal at Tirunindravur in Tamil Nadu on Friday.

Title: Jaipur: Parking woes continue at Johari Bazaar, traders cry foul
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: The Walled City ’s parking problems do not seem to be ending anywhere soon. The Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC) in a meeting in January had agreed to the demands of Johari Bazaar Vyapaar Mandal to find a solution for the problems within a month. However, no concrete step has been taken by the JMC till now.

In the meeting it was decided that JMC will create sideways parking area along with automatic receipt through machines. Traders of the market specifically asked for proper implementation of rules in the market.

Kailash Mittal, general secretary of Johari Bazaar Market Association , said that parking has become their worst problem. “Most of the businessmen working in the market keep their vehicles parked in the market throughout the day. As per rules no one can park vehicles for more than two hours. After two hours extra charge should be paid but the corruption is such that anyone can park a vehicle with monthly payment to the contractor illegally. This is taking a toll on our business as customers do not get space for parking,” said Mittal.

Traders also demanded that the contractor’s workers should be in uniform so that they can be easily identified. In addition to this the traders should be allotted space for vehicles. All the demands were supposed to be fulfilled within a month, however, nothing concrete has been done so far. The traders say that now the JMC officials do not respond to their calls. TOI also tried to contact the officials, but no one was available for comment.

There are many wide lanes in the Walled City but illegal parking has made driving through the roads impossible. Haldiyon Ka Rasta, Gopalji Ka Rasta, Nahargarh Road, Baba Harish Chand Marg and Khazane Walon Ka Rasta are a few such examples. Residents of the area claim that due to parking issues many people are moving out of the area.

Title: Jaipur: Tribunal setback for Gayatri Devi’s grandkids
Content:
Representative image

Jaipur: National Company Law Appellate Tribunal (NCLAT) , New Delhi has set aside the order of the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) order giving majority stake in the iconic Jai Mahal Palace Hotel on Ajmer Raod to Gayatri Devi’s grandchildren Rajkumar Dev Raj and Rajkumari Lalitya on August 1, 2018.

The order followed Jai Mahal Hotels Pvt Ltd appealed against the National Company Law Tribunal order.

“Maharani Gayatri Devi on the death of Maharaj Jagat Singh on February 5, 1997 became his sole legatee by ‘Will’ on June 23, 1996. Therefore, Rajkumar Dev Raj and Rajkumari Lalitya cannot claim inheritance on original 5050 shares to be legal heirs of Late Maharaj Jagat Singh on his death on February 5, 1997,” said the appellate order.

It added, “Once the claim of Rajkumar Dev Raj and Rajkumari Lalitya on the total original 5050 shares of Late Maharaj Jagat Singh are determined by high court and Supreme Court based on ‘Will’ in favour of Maharani Gayatri Devi and giving legatee herself bequeathed her rights in favour of Rajkumar Dev Raj and Rajkumari Lalitya, they cannot claim their right on such shares by way of inheritance on the death of Maharaj Jagat Singh.”

The Tribunal failed to consider the above said aspects and wrongly held that Rajkumar Devraj and Rajkumari Lalitya inherited the shares of Late Maharaj Jagat Singh on his death. Earlier, tribunal has "restored the position ante immediately upon the death of late Maharaja Jagat Singh" in terms of strength and directors of the board of Jai Mahal Hotel Ltd.

National Company Law Tribunal in its order had said that Maharani Gayatri Devi grandchildren’s majority shareholding in the hotel have been converted in to a minority by the overt and covert acts of Jai Mahal Hotel management including Gayatri Devi’s step son Maharaja Prithvi Raj and his son Vijit Singh.

Title: Jaipur: Banasthali Vidyapith gets NAAC’s A++ grade
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Banasthali Vidyapith, residential university for women has become Rajasthan’s first varsity to be accorded A++ grade by National Assessment and Accreditation Council (NAAC). NAAC assessment is done on basis of seven criteria and Banasthali scored 90% and above in each of these, reflecting its overall excellence.

Title: Restore peace, CPM leader urges top cop
Content:
Coimbatore: CPM state secretary K Balakrishnan on Friday requested police commissioner Sumit Sharan to restore communal harmony in the city.

He requested the commissioner to form a peace committee consisting of representatives of all political parties, businessmen, people’s representatives and members of social and religious organisations, Balakrishnan told reporters. “Police should not allow communal organisations conduct rallies in the city. They should take strict action against those who conduct rallies without prior permission.”

Hindu Munnani, RSS and other Hindu outfits have been planning to spur violence in the city for the last 10 years, the CPM leader said. “Police should take action against RSS and Hindu Munnani for their involvement in violence,” he said.

Muslims are fighting against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019 as they are afraid that it would destroy their livelihood, Balakrishnan said. “But Hindu Munnani is trying to stir up religious hatred. So, police should not treat the two protests in the same manner. While police have allotted places to conduct protest, Hindu Munnani, RSS and BJP men conducted protests in places that were barred for protests. But police are silent on this.”

Speaking about the recent shutter-down protest in the district, the Left leader said that traders had closed their shops out of fear. “But the outfits that had called the protest think that they have the support of the shopkeepers.”

Title: Hit hard by coronavirus, travel industry in Coimbatore faces its worst crisis in three decades
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: This is that time of the year when travel company offices in the city gets flooded with summer vacation enquiries and bookings. The picture is altogether different this year. Most of the travel firms are empty, except for a few trying to work out cancellations.

Travel agents in the city say the industry is facing its worst crisis in three decades, much worse than the lull after the first H1N1 outbreak. According to them, domestic tourism has also been hit as almost every state in the country, including neighbouring Kerala and Karnataka and other popular destinations such as Jaipur and New Delhi, has begun recording coronavirus (Covid-19) cases.

While schools have declared holidays for children in lower classes from this week till April first week, the kids are forced to stay indoors. Sushmita Khanna, a resident of R S Puram, says, “My daughter has been pestering me to go to my mother’s place in Mumbai. But I can’t promise her anything, because of the virus outbreak. Maharashtra has four cases and we have been advised to stay away from airports, especially since I also have a four-year-old son.”

As on Friday morning, the country has reported 76 cases of Covid-19. While stockbrokers and investors watched glumly the bearish run of the stock market, travel agents were busy marking the destinations hit by the virus to exclude them from their offerings.

R Krishnaraj, president, Travel Agents’ Association in Coimbatore, says, “The city residents usually travel to hill stations in South India and North India. However, with all the popular holiday destinations such as Jammu and Kashmir, Kerala, Maharashtra and Karnataka recording Covid-19 cases, no one is coming in or calling up for enquiries.”

Expressing a similar view, Nirupa of city-based Ashok Travels, said people were scared to travel. “They are not only completely avoiding flights unless necessary, like business or medical reasons, but also afraid to travel by road. This includes even bold honeymooners, because their families advise against it. Holiday planners are almost nil.”

Indian luxury resorts are, however, yet to slash their rates, with top players sticking to their peak season rates in April and May. “While we are seeing some cancellations by foreigners, we are getting new bookings from foreigners who are forced to extend their stay due to Covid-19 outbreak. We are hopeful that the business would pick up by April-end,” said a manager of a star hotel on Avinashi Road.

Title: Vadodara stands ninth in Smart City rankings
Content:
Representative image

VADODARA: The city jumped two ranks finishing amongst the top 10 in the country in the Smart City rankings announced on Friday.

Vadodara was amongst the 100 cities that were picked up from across the country for implementation of the Smart City projects. The union ministry for urban development announces rankings of Smart Cities periodically.

In the last rankings, VMC had finished on the eleventh ranking. In the latest ranking, Vadodara improved its position and finished on the ninth spot. It got 53.81 points in the overall tally announced on Friday.

Title: Covid-19: More Mumbai schools suspend ops, move classes online
Content: MUMBAI: Though the state government has not yet called for closure of educational institutions in the city as a preventive measure to stave off Covid-19 , at least 10 more top schools decided to suspend classes from Friday and continue education online.Nikhat Azam, principal, Billabong High International School, Santacruz, said, “The attendance in our school has been optimum in spite of the outbreak. All precautionary measures have been taken to contain the spread of the virus. But keeping in mind children’s safety, our management has decided to keep the schools closed from March 14 to 31. The online education system would be adopted to ensure that learning continues within the safe environment of home. Worksheets and learning resources would be shared with the parents through the online portal to keep the students fruitfully engaged.”At VIBGYOR Group of Schools, parents received a message saying they would continue to function until a formal directive for closure is received from the state. By the end of the day, though, the school decided to close operations for all students from Monday until further notice. “All internal examinations have been cancelled for now. However, board examinations will continue as per schedule and there are no changes to the same,” read a message.Among other schools that have given students a break are Lilavatibai Podar School, Santacruz, HVB Global Academy, Marine Drive, Campion School, Fort, Bai Avabai F Petit Girls’ High School, Bandra, New Horizons Scholars School, Thane, and Sunitidevi Singhania School, Thane. “Even though students will not be physically present in school, we will continue with some academic activity where teachers will share videos and links, for simple topics, through the flipped classroom technique for students of the primary and secondary sections,” said a mail to parents from Bai Avabai F Petit Girls’ High School principal Daina Marfatia. Pre-schools such as Podar Jumbo Kids called for closure too. Aided schools affiliated to the state board continue to wait. “Nearly 30% students aren’t coming in but we can’t suspend classes,” said Uday Nare, teacher, Hansraj Morarji Public School, Andheri.

Title: 1 held for attacking HM secy, 2 HM men arrested for attacking SDPI secy
Content:
Coimbatore: The city police have arrested one more person for attacking Hindu Munnani district secretary M Anand on March 4.

The arrested person was identified as A Azharuddin, 30, of Karumbukadai, an auto driver and member of a Muslim outfit’s trade union. He was booked under sections 294 (b) (sings, recites or utters any obscene song, ballad or words in or near any public place) 307 (attempt to murder), 341 (wrongful restraint) and 506 (ii) (criminal intimidation) of the Indian Penal Code and remanded in judicial custody on Friday.

Anand was on the way home after attending a pro-CAA event at Gandhipuram on his motorcycle when two men, who followed him on a motorcycle, attacked him using iron rods. The Podanur police registered a case and formed three special teams to nab the attackers.

Police had arrested S Noor Mohammed, a resident of Kurichi, a few days ago for attacking Anand.

The Kattoor police arrested two Hindu Munnani cadres on Friday for attacking Social Democratic Party of India (SDPI) district secretary Mohammed Iqbal at Ram Nagar here on Tuesday.

The arrested men were identified as K Sathish Kannan, 23, of Kattoor, an autorickshaw driver and R Rahul, 23, of Patel Road in Ram Nagar, an electrician.

Police are grilling Mathiyazhagan and Vinesh, who were detained in connection with the case.

A seven -member gang had attacked Iqbal while he was on the way to a bakery on foot on Tuesday around 3.30pm. He suffered an injury on his head and is undergoing treatment in a private hospital at Saibaba Colony. TNN

Title: Covid-19: Salem railway division disinfects all stn premises
Content:
Salem: The Salem railway division is on a drive to disinfect all the railway stations, passenger amenity areas and train coaches to contain the spread of coronavirus (Covid-19). It has also deployed exclusive medical teams at all major stations to help the passengers, if required.

Divisional railway manager U Subba Rao said the drive would be continued till the virus outbreak is fully contained. “Disinfectants are used liberally. We will regularly disinfect door handles, windows, handrails of escalators, staircases and lifts, enquiry and ticket counter areas, armrest of chairs, water taps, sanitary fittings and door latches, among others.”

He said they have also been creating awareness on Covid-19 by handing out pamphlets that detail more about the virus and preventive measures to the passengers at railway stations and on trains.

“We have also put up posters with instructions and dos and don’ts in Tamil, English and Hindi at prominent locations in and around the station. We are also playing video clips on the preventive measures at all the railway platforms round the clock, besides making announcements on the same. We are also keeping the railway station premises neat and tidy,” Subba Rao said.

The divisional railway manager said he has instructed station officials to check the availability of water in all the taps round the clock to help passengers wash their hands.

Title: PFI condemns arrest of leaders in Delhi
Content:
Coimbatore: Popular Front of India (PFI) cadres conducted a protest at Athupalam on Friday evening to condemn the arrest of PFI leaders in New Delhi.

State representative of PFI A Fayaz Ahamed, who addressed the cadres, said that PFI had no hand in the Delhi violence. “But the Delhi police, which are functioning under the Union government, arrested PFI leaders and members in connection with the violence. Sangh Parivar and Delhi police are behind the fake cases and arrest of PFI cadres and leaders. The Union government has been working to defame PFI. It is targeting the organisations that are fighting against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019, national population register (NPR) and national register of citizens (NRC). We request all those who believe in democracy and civil rights to oppose the Union government for targeting Muslims in Delhi.”

General secretary of Thanthai Periyar Dravidar Kazhagam Ku Ramakrishnan said that the state government put NPR on hold after Muslims organisations intensified the protest against CAA and NPR. “Hindu Munnani was planning to attack some shops during the one day shutter-down protest. However, Muslim organisations also announced a protest on the same day. So, no violence was reported in the city. More than 95% of shops were closed. The shopkeepers closed the shops as they were afraid of the Hindu outfits. But the Hindu outfits thought that the shopkeepers were supporting the protest,” he said.

More than 150 police personnel were deployed to prevent any untoward incidents.

Title: Two suspects in isolation at Chanda civil hospital
Content:
Chandrapur: The public health administration in Chandrapur is on high alert after two suspected Covid-19 patients reported to the civil hospital on Friday.

The swab samples of the suspects, a couple who returned from a vacation in Dubai on February 28, have been sent to Indira Gandhi Government Medical College and Hospital (IGGMCH) in Nagpur, said civil surgeon Dr ND Rathod.

Dr Rathod claimed that the suspects are from Chandrapur city. “They did not report to the administration about their travel, but are claiming that they were in self isolation after return. But after developing symptoms of coronavirus infection even before completion of the incubation period, the couple approached a private doctor on Friday, who immediately referred them to us,” Dr Rathod said.

He informed that both the husband and wife are in their 40s. “They have developed fever and cough. They have been examined and kept in the isolation ward here for primary treatment,” the civil surgeon said.

Dr Rathod maintained that both the patients are stable. He claimed that administration would track people with whom they have come in contact after their return from Dubai.

Title: Telugu New Year spurs jaggery biz in Salem, Namakkal districts
Content:
Salem/Namakkal: The jaggery manufacturers and merchants in Salem and Namakkal are working round the clock to add sweetness to the Telugu New Year festival in Andhra Pradesh and Telangana. Expecting a good business, more than 1,000 cottage units that are involved in jaggery manufacturing in these two districts have upped the production volume. Presently, they are producing more than eight tonnes jaggery a day.

According to industry sources, there are more than 800 jaggery cottage units in Paramathi-Velur taluk in Namakkal district alone. They usually produce up to 2,000kg jaggery a day in non-peak season and 8,000kg during peak season such as Pongal.

K S Srinivasan, a jaggery manufacturer from Paramathi, said, “After the Pongal festival, there was no remarkable sale across the state. After a lull, the jaggery production has picked up pace now as we have started getting orders from Andhra Pradesh and Telangana ahead of the Telugu New Year, which falls on March 25.”

The increase in jaggery production has helped the sugarcane farmers in Erode and Dharmapuri districts as well, from where these manufacturers are procuring the raw material.

K Shanmugam, a merchant in Salem, said, they were doing a brisk business. Pointing out that the jaggery from the Namakkal units would first reach Salem, which is the main market, he said, “From here, we will transport them to Andhra Pradesh and Telangana through trucks. We are presently sending nearly 50 tonnes jaggery to the neighbouring states daily.”

The jaggery price has also shot up in tandem with the increase in demand. While a pack of 30kg jaggery was priced at Rs 900 after the Pongal, the same now costs Rs 1,230. “1kg jaggery will be sold at Rs 45 in retail shops in Andhra Pradesh and Telangana,” Shanmugam said.

Title: U’khand govt postpones 3rd anniversary celebrations in view of coronavirus threat
Content: Dehradun: The state government on Friday announced that it is postponing the state-wide celebrations that it had planned for March 18 when the Trivendra Rawat government would be completing three years in office. A letter in this context, written by chief secretary Utpal Kumar Singh, was forwarded to all the district magistrates on late Friday evening. Although no fresh date was announced, sources said that the celebrations may now take place sometime in April.The ruling Bharatiya Janata Party had chalked out a detailed programme for the celebrations — ‘Vikas ke teen saal: Baatien kam kaam zyada — encompassing all the 13 districts of the state. Publlic meetings in 70 constituencies either by the elected party MLA or a senior leader, and direct telecast of chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat’s speech in all the constituencies were to be a part of the celebrations. However, in wake of the coronavirus scare, all this has now been put on hold.Speaking to TOI, BJP chief spokesperson Munna Singh Chauhan said, “The entire country is united in its efforts against coronavirus and keeping the fact in mind, the government has decided to avoid having large public gatherings. Therefore, the celebrations have been postponed for some time.”Earlier, the state government had postponed its adventure summit which was to be held at Ramnagar from March 20 and a welllness summit, which was to be held in early part of April.Meanwhile, addressing mediapersons in Dehradun on Friday, CM Trivendra Rawat said that “special monitoring is being done at the border areas of the state and if required, the borders can also be sealed.” Elaborating further, he said that there were eight India-Nepal border posts — at Banbasa and Tanakpur in Champawat district, Dharchula, Baluakot, Jauljibi, Jhulaghat and Dyura in Pithoragarh district, and Khatima in Udham Singh Nagar district. “The screening of 22,968 people have been done at these eight border posts and not a single case of coronavirus has been detected. At each check point, we have put in place medical teams who are equipped with infrared thermometers for scanning,” he added.‘526 quarantined in state, no Covid-19 positive case so far’The screening of over 60,000 people has been done in the state so far, of which 41,405 people have been screened at airports of Dehradun, Pantnagar and Pithoragarh and no coronavirus positive case was found, CM Rawat said on Friday. He added that 526 people have been quarantined for showing some symptoms of the disease, out of which 351 people have completed a 28 day period of being under observation. “Of the remaining 175, 174 were under observation at home and one was under observation in hospital. Till date, the samples of 17 people — who have been kept under observation in isolation wards — have been collected. Of these, 12 have tested negative while the reports of the rest five are awaited,” the CM added.

Title: Delhi may soon have 25,000 mohalla marshals
Content:
Rajendra Pal Gautam

NEW DELHI: Delhi may soon see deployment of over 25,000 civil defence volunteers and ex-servicemen as ‘mohalla marshals’ who will act as a security layer between the police and the citizens to help women and senior citizens feel safer.

Delhi government had asked its revenue department to make a plan for deployment of these marshals, which was among the 10 promises the chief minister had made in his guarantee card released in the run up to the Delhi assembly polls.

Since the plan was conceived to make the city safer for women, the government had initially tasked women and child development (WCD) department to prepare an action plan. WCD minister Rajendra Pal Gautam had even convened a couple of meetings to roll out the scheme where it estimated that a force of about 25,000 people would be required to man the city in shifts. But because monitoring a team of thousands of civil defence staff and ex-servicemen was a huge task which WCD was ill-equipped to handle, the government handed over the responsibility to the revenue department.

A revenue department official, however, said the scheme was currently at a nascent stage.

Title: ‘Regular screening only way to guard against glaucoma’
Content:
Madurai: As ‘World Glaucoma Awareness Week’ comes to an end on Saturday, doctors from the ophthalmology department at the Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) stressed that regular screening is the only way to prevent loss of vision due to glaucoma.

Glaucoma is an eye disorder caused by an increase in the eye pressure, which causes damage to the optic nerve. “The condition leads to defective field of vision and blindness if not treated on time. As there are no alarming symptoms like eye pain, redness or irritation, most patients delay in approaching an ophthalmologist. Screening is the only way to detect glaucoma,” said Dr U Vijaya Shanmugam, HOD, Department of Ophthalmology at GRH.

The disease is diagnosed by simple, non-invasive investigations like intra ocular pressure measurement, Optic nerve head analysis, Field test and Eye scan test. “Regular screening is recommended for risk populations, with gaps varying from once in two months to once in two years. There needs to be more awareness,” said Dr R Saravanan, associate professor, glaucoma Unit at GRH.

Risk populations include those who are above 40 years of age, frequently change glasses, have family history of Glaucoma, have diabetes or hypertension.

Treatment involves eye drops, laser treatment or surgical management, aimed at lowering the intraocular pressure. At GRH, last year, the glaucoma unit at the Department of Ophthalmology has treated 847 patients with eye drops alone and performed surgery for 324 patients.

For ‘World Glaucoma Awareness Week’, GRH has conducted an awareness rally, a CME program, free drug distribution, and various awareness programs addressing public during the course of the week. “We are also trying to hold mass screening for Glaucoma for all our employees. We are screening around 25 people a day and hope to first cover screening all our staff during the course of the next week,” Dr Saravanan said.

Title: HC asks cops to amend report on release of Sri Lankans
Content:
Madurai: Madras high court has directed the police to amend the final report in a case where five people were arrested for helping two Sri Lankan nationals with bad antecedents escape back to the island nation after the duo were inadvertently released from prison though the court had directed to deport them.

On Friday, a division bench of justice P N Prakash and justice B Pugalendhi gave the direction to the police officials to amend the report by including IPC section 109 for abetment of crime.

During the previous hearing, the court directed the state government to complete disciplinary proceedings against the erring officials and further directed to complete the investigation into the case registered by the Pamban police within three months.

Sanga Sirantha and Mohammaed Saffras, who were involved in murder, rape and gang war in Sri Lanka, had come to India in 2019 to escape punishment. The Kenikarai police in Ramanathapuram district arrested and got them remanded in judicial custody as they had entered the country without valid documents.

When the duo filed a habeas corpus petition seeking to deport them back to Sri Lanka, the court sought a status report from the Ramanathapuram judicial magistrate II regarding the case and subsequently directed to deport the duo to Sri Lanka.

Since the Kenikarai police filed a withdrawal petition, the Ramanathapuram JM II discharged the duo from the case. When the order was communicated, the SP of the Puzhal Central Prison misconstrued the said order as if the two Sri Lankan nationals had been released on bail and accordingly released them from prison on August 18, 2019.

The court took serious view of the inadvertent release of the duo. The central and state governments informed the court that the duo had surrendered before a court in Colombo.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Woman kills hubby over illicit affair
Content:
Representative image

NAMAKKAL: A 40-year-old woman, along with her 19-year-old daughter and mother, set her husband ablaze while he was asleep outside the house at Jeevanagar in Pudansandhai here in the early hours of Thursday after she came to know that he was having an extramarital affair. The three were arrested on Friday morning.

Senthamangalam police inspector (incharge) Pon Selvaraj identified the deceased as P Kandasamy, 45, a building contractor.

The officer said the incident took place while he was sleeping outside the house after his 40-year-old wife Angammal, along with daughter Shanthi, had gone to visit her 65-year-old mother Ellammal at her house in the same village on Wednesday night.

“Around 4am on Thursday, Kandasamy woke up in flames, crying for help. Neighbours immediately rushed to the spot and extinguished the fire by pouring water on him. They then took him to the government hospital in Namakkal town,” the officer said.

When alerted, district superintendent of police (SP) R Arularasu, deputy superintendent of police Gandhi and Selvaraj met the victim at the hospital. “In his dying declaration, Kandasamy told us that some unidentified people had doused him with petrol and set him ablaze. Based on this, we started our inquiry,” the inspector said.

During inquiry, the victim’s wife, daughter and mother-in-law confessed to the crime. In her confessional statement, Angammal said her husband was in a relationship with a woman in Salem city . “He had decided to live with her after April. And Kandsamy and Angammal have been fighting over this issue for the past three months,” the officer said quoting Angammal’s statement.

Infuriated, Angammal hatched a plan to finish off her husband and sought the help of her mother and daughter, who backed her. “Angammal purchased five litres of petrol, which she used to douse her husband, from a petrol bunk. She, along with her daughter, left the house to create the impression that the incident took place when he was alone at home. After setting him on fire, the trio left the place immediately,” the officer said.

Based on their confessional statement, the trio were arrested on Friday morning and lodged in the Salem Central Prison under judicial custody.

Title: Woman gored to death by Indian bison
Content:
UDHAGAMANDALAM: A woman was gored to death by a gaur near Jakkanarai village in Kotagiri taluk on Friday.

The victim R Parvathi, 70, was returning home after work at Keelkeri near Jakkanarai village when the Indian gaur suddenly attacked her from the back. The animal punctured her stomach, according to assistant conservator of forests Saravana Kumar . The locals informed the forest officials who rushed to the spot. “Parvathi died on the spot,” an official said.

Title: Ban on generator sets in Delhi lifted after five months
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

NEW DELHI: Delhi Pollution Control Committee has lifted the ban on use of generator sets, which was in place since October 15.

DPCC clarified in a notice, a copy of which is with TOI, that the ban on generator sets, which is a part of Graded Response Action Plan (GRAP), was scheduled to continue till March 15, 2020. The only exception was essential services like in medicine (hospitals or nursing homes or healthcare facilities), elevators and escalators, railway services and stations, DMRC services, airport and interstate bus terminals.

However, looking at the prevailing air quality after the Supreme Court-mandated Environment Pollution (Prevention and Control) Authority (EPCA) recommendations, the ban had been lifted with effect from March 11, the notice stated.

Due to a western disturbance (WD), which led to windy days and good rainfall over northwest India, Delhi recorded three satisfactory air quality days and one of the cleanest spells yet this year during March 5-7. The last time the city witnessed satisfactory air was on March 1, with an AQI of 90, due a spell of rain and windy conditions. Last year, Delhi recorded a lone ‘good’ air day on August 18 as the average AQI touched 49.

“On the recommendation of the task force constituted for GRAP and improving the air quality, EPCA has decided to lift the ban on operation of diesel generator sets in Delhi. In view of the above, the earlier direction issued by DPCC dated October 11, 2019 banning operation of DG sets is withdrawn with immediate effect,” it stated.

The generator set ban had also included those that run on diesel, petrol and kerosene. “While diesel gensets are the most common, the ban had included any fuel-based generator set,” said a DPCC official.

Earlier, before last winter, EPCA at a meeting with Delhi government officials and other agencies announced that a ban on generator sets would come into effect from October 15. It had clarified that weddings would not be allowed exemption, stating that temporary connections could be provided just like last year. For housing societies, however, the generator sets could only be used for services like lifts.

Title: Four from Yavatmal, 1 from Gondia test negative
Content:
Nagpur: The swab samples of nine suspects from Yavatmal, who had a history of travelling with the Covid-19 positive Pune couple, were tested in the lab facility at the IGMMCH on Friday. By late night, four of them were found negative.

The results of 5 samples need to be tested again on Saturday as results are inconclusive. A sample sent from Gondia GMCH has also tested negative.

Officials said that the two suspects admitted at Mayo hospital, who were not related to the confirmed positive patients, were also found negative. These patients had a travel history to Italy and Dubai.

Out of the four patients who were admitted in the GMCH, two tested negative late on Friday night. Results of the others are awaited.

Red alert in Yavatmal: Yavatmal district collector MD Singh has issued a red alert in the district. In a review meeting held in his office on Friday, he urged the officials to take utmost care to prevent the Covid-19 virus from entering the district. He has issued circular to the health service officials not to grant any leave to their employees and also recall those on leave till further notification.

According to the dean of GMCH, Yavatmal Dr Milind Kamble, all the nine suspects are kept in the isolation ward and are under doctor’s supervision. The Dean said that the present isolation ward is of 12 beds which can be increased to 20 if the emergency arises.

Since the first ever Covid-19 reported from Yavatmal on March 1, there is no new patient reported for the last 13 days from anywhere in the district.

Title: 2 HM men arrested for attacking SDPI man
Content:
Coimbatore: The Kattoor police arrested two Hindu Munnani cadres on Friday for attacking Social Democratic Party of India (SDPI) district secretary Mohammed Iqbal at Ram Nagar here on Tuesday.

The arrested men were identified as K Sathish Kannan, 23, of Kattoor, an autorickshaw driver and R Rahul, 23, of Patel Road in Ram Nagar, an electrician.

Police are grilling Mathiyazhagan and Vinesh, who were detained in connection with the case.

A seven -member gang had attacked Iqbal while he was on the way to a bakery on foot on Tuesday around 3.30pm. He suffered an injury on his head and is undergoing treatment in a private hospital at Saibaba Colony.

Title: Petitioner fined Rs 50K for false allegation
Content:
Madurai: Madras high court has imposed a cost of Rs 50,000 on a petitioner for making false allegation before the court that his mother, an AIADMK ward member, was abducted by rival party members in an attempt to prevent her from contesting in the indirect election conducted for the post of chairperson of Chinnamanur panchayat union in Theni district. The court gave the direction after the state government informed that the woman was at her relative’s house and was not abducted.

The petitioner, R Vimaleswaran, stated that his mother R Shanthi was elected as ward councillor of Chinnamanur panchayat union. She filed her nomination for contesting in the election for the post of chairperson of the union. Due to the ruckus created by rival party candidates, the indirect election for the post of chairperson and vice-chairperson was postponed twice and election was scheduled on March 4.

He stated that his mother, who went to her relative’s house went missing on March 3. Since her mother went missing before the day of election, he suspected that she might have been abducted by the rival party members to prevent her from participating in the election.
