During the previous hearing, the court had granted interim injunction restraining the functioning of chairperson and vice-chairperson of the panchayat and further directed to trace the petitioner’s mother.

When the case was taken up for hearing on Friday, the state informed the court of the woman’s presence at her relative’s house. Taking note of it, a division bench of justice P N Prakash and justice B Pugalendhi vacated the interim injunction as the allegation made by the petitioner turned out to be false. The judges also directed the petitioner to pay Rs 25,000 each to the chairperson and vice-chairperson of Chinnamanur panchayat union.

Title: Left MP to address lake encroachers
Content:
Coimbatore: Hundreds of people staying along the Muthanan Kulam illegally will attend a public meeting called by communist parties today evening to decide the future course of protest. Member of Parliament P R Natarajan will address them.

The encroachers are demanding land and patta for those being removed, instead of accommodation in the multi-storied apartments built by the Tamil Nadu slum clearance board (TNSCB) at Keeranatham.

Several encroachers, who agreed to move to Keeranatham a few months ago, have returned to the banks of the lake as the tenements are unlivable, Velmurugan of CPM said. “The buildings have developed cracks and may collapse during rain and earthquake. Coimbatore has been marked an earthquake-prone zone,” he said.

Authorities had promised that the area will have government schools, colleges and work opportunities, Velmurugan said. “There are no schools, colleges or work opportunities for the hundreds of women working as domestic maids and men who work as masons, and sanitary workers,” he added.

Title: School where patient’s wife worked shuts down till March 21
Content:
The woman works as a training coordinator at a montessori school and was present in school on March 7, a day a... Read More

Nagpur: The pre-primary school where wife of Nagpur’s first coronavirus patient worked, has been shut till March 21 by its owners as a precautionary step. She is the first woman patient in Nagpur to test positive for coronavirus.

The woman is working as a training coordinator at a montessori school and was present on March 7, a day after coming in contact with her husband upon his return from the US.

TOI got in touch with the school’s director who, to her credit, responded clearly to all queries in detail without being evasive. “We also came to know about her being positive on Friday only. Government officials got in touch with us and asked if any of our staff or students showed any symptoms, to which the answer was negative,” she said.

“If one looks at the timeline, it is very unlikely that anybody from our school would have got infected. In fact, I am very convinced that she too was not infected while in school,” she said.

Explaining the sequence of events from her point of view, the director said, “The woman’s husband returned on March 6 and the next day she was at our training centre. On March 7 she showed no signs of infection and after that day she has not been in school at all most probably to take care of her husband. So there seems to be no chance of any other staff member getting infected.”

On March 7, there was an exhibition at the school premises which was attended by teachers from around a dozen schools. “Authorities have not asked us for names and details of the participants, but I am assuming that will happen soon. Regardless, we will try to inform them by collating contact data,” the director said. She has not ruled out keeping the school closed beyond March 21, but is confident that it would not be needed.

Title: Nainital zoo to get snow leopard from Kashmir
Content:
Administration also plans to conduct mating of tigers

Nainital: The Nainital zoo administration is in talks with the authorities of Kashmir to bring a snow leopard to the zoo.

The Nainital zoo, also is known as GB Pant High Altitude Zoo, is one of the very few places in the country with optimum temperature required for snow leopards to survive. Earlier, the zoo had a snow leopard but it died a few years ago.

Speaking to TOI, Biju Lal, director of the zoo and divisional forest officer (DFO), Nainital, said that the final decision on bringing the snow leopard will be taken in the annual general body meeting (AGM). “We have talked to the authorities in Kashmir and a final decision on the process will be taken at the AGM which is expected to be held next month. As soon as the AGM approves the proposal we will initiate the process,” he said.

Meanwhile, the zoo authorities are also planning to conduct mating of animal species at the zoo. “We are planning to conduct mating of several animals inside the zoo. However, our focus will be on tigers. Though it was tried once before as well but the project didn’t succeed. If everything goes as planned, we aim to initiate the process in the next mating season. If the project succeeds, it will be a big achievement for us,” Lal said.

At present, there are three tigers at the Nainital zoo, including the recently brought Vikram. Vikram was shifted to Nainital zoo from Corbett Tiger Reserve after it turned a maneater.

These initiatives are part of the 10-year master plan, which was recently certified by the Central Zoo Authority, of the Nainital zoo.

Apart from bringing the snow leopard and initiating the mating process among animals, the zoo will also host research programmes that will focus on exploring the facts behind increased man-animal conflicts in the state. “The programmes will start at the zoo in the next financial year. Our aim is to bring in researchers to find reasons behind man-animal conflict and to also propose solutions for this,” the DFO said.

Title: Sales down, poultry farmers to cut down on production
Content:
Namakkal: The spread of coronavirus and outbreak of bird flu in Kerala have impacted chicken production in poultry farms in the district.

Poultry farmers have decided to reduce the chicken production due to crash in prices.

“The price of 1kg of chicken has come down to Rs 27 from Rs 72,” executive member of National Egg Coordination Committee ‘Vangili’ Subramaniam said.

He said the impact has been felt in retail markets as well with 1kg of chicken being sold for Rs 60.

Worse, fake messages doing rounds on social media that coronavirus spreads through chicken and eggs have also compounded poultry farmers’ problems.

“When the poultry industry has been grappling with problems arising out of coronavirus, the bird flu outbreak worsened the situation further,” Subramaniam said. People are showing reluctance to eat chicken for these two reasons. Following this, the committee has decided to reduce the chicken production in the district, he said. “We will take a concrete decision on this after convening a meeting with other poultry farmers,” he added.

Namakkal district is the major hub for chicken and egg production in the state. The district produces 4 crore eggs and 20 lakh chickens daily for sales. “Of them, 40 lakh eggs and 10 lakh chickens will be sent to Kerala daily,” Dr P V Senthil, secretary of Livestock and Agri Farmers Trade Association (LIFT) said.

The district has nearly 988 poultry farms and all the major farms were following bio-security system. “Though there is no avian flu outbreak in Tamil Nadu, poultry farmers across the district have taken precautionary measures,” Senthil said, adding that they have ensured chicks are vaccinated without fail. “In the wake of the bird flu outbreak in Kerala, we have tightened biosecurity in all farms,” he said.

Title: Special centres to educate rescued child labourers a big success
Content:
COIMBATORE: Over 300 rescued child labourers are studying in the 17 special centres that were opened recently in Coimbatore and Tirupur districts to educate them under the National Child Labour Project (NCLP).

“While 13 new centres were opened in Tirupur, four were opened in Coimbatore. With this, there are 21 such centres in the region. As many as 374 children aged between nine and 14 years are studying there,” NCLP project director D V Vijayakumar said.

The centres were set up based on a survey conducted by NCLP members, school education department and volunteers last June, the official said. “The survey identified 317 child labourers – 179 boys and 138 girls. Most of them are children of labourers from states including Bihar , Odisha, West Bengal , Uttar Pradesh and Assam.”

“The children will be shifted to mainstream schools after spending six months to two years at the centres, which is required to make them adapt to the school environment. We had shifted students of 17 special centres to mainstream schools last year,” Vijayakumar said. “The number of child labourers, especially those from Tamil Nadu, has come down drastically in the last few years. Surveys conducted in the previous years used to find over 1,000 child labourers, half of whom used to be from Tamil Nadu. But this year, only 46 of them were from the State.”

Rehabilitating children of migrant labourers is a difficult task, Vijayakumar said. “The labourers keep shifting often. We had to close three centres – two in Valparai and one in Dharapuram – where close to 50 children were studying until a month ago, after their parents migrated.”

NCLP rescued five children after conducting awareness sessions at 599 industries and other commercial establishments in February, the official added.

Title: District administration forms task force to check child marriages
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: The district administration has formed District Task Force (DTF), a 16-member committee, to check child marriages.

The initiative is a part of the adolescent empowerment programme launched with the support of the United Nations International Children’s Emergency Fund (UNICEF) in the district.

DTF consists of the collector, superintendent of police, chief medical officer, district social welfare officer, chief educational officer and a member of NGO Child Rights and You (CRY).

As per the National Family Health Survey (NFHS) – 4, the district has 19.9% of women who were married before 18 years.

A senior official with the district social welfare department said that they are preparing a strategy work plan for the committee. “As many as 62 child marriages reported in the district since January 2019 were stopped by the department. People came forwarded to report them to authorities as they are aware that child marriage is an offence,” the official said.

“In most cases, children living with guardians or single parents and those who are in a relationship, are married off before the legal age. But we interfere as soon as the issue is reported,” she said. “Even though child marriages are taking place in rural as well as urban areas in equal numbers, we have been concentrating in areas in and around Karamadai, Madukkarai and slum areas in the corporation limit.”

An official with the district administration said that they have been working along with officials in panchayat unions and had taken a resolution to stop child marriages during gram sabha meetings.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Father throws baby into well, arrested
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: A 26-year-old man was arrested for killing his 10-month-old daughter by throwing her into a well in Theni district on Thursday.

Panneerselvam from Bodi Zamin Thoppu, married to Azhagumeena, has two children -a son and a daughter. After an argument between the two, Azhagumeena left to stay with her mother, police said.

On Thursday, the accused went to Azhagumeena's house and had an argument during which he snatched the baby and said that he will kill her. As he escaped, Azhagumeena rushed to complain with the Palanichettipatti police station.

In the meanwhile, Panneerselvam took the baby and threw her in a well at Kodangipatti. On finding out that his wife had gone to the police, Panneerselvam fled.

The Palanichettipatti police immediately filed a case and started a search. Panneerselvam was subsequently arrested for murder on Friday.

Title: Woman to deliver fifth child after HC suggests counselling
Content:
Madurai: A woman who sought pregnancy termination after a failed family planning surgery, agreed to deliver her fifth child after the Madras high court suggested counselling to her. The court also directed the Madurai district collector to examine the possibility of disbursing financial support to the woman and providing temporary government job to her husband.

The petitioner, a 35-year-old woman who was married in 2007 had three daughters and a son. On April 14, 2014, she underwent family planning surgery at a primary health centre in Virudhunagar district. Recently, when the petitioner underwent medical examination, she learnt that she was pregnant.

The petitioner moved the high court Madurai bench seeking compensation for medical negligence and also sought termination of pregnancy. Hearing the plea, Justice C V Karthikeyan suggested counselling to the woman.

Pursuant to the counselling, the doctor submitted a report stating that the petitioner had agreed to have her fifth child.

Taking note of the report, the judge observed that the court shall take up the responsibility of her family since the family planning surgery which she underwent voluntarily ended in failure. Since the woman’s family is presently residing in Madurai district, the judge gave the direction to the Madurai collector.

The case was adjourned to March 30 for further hearing.

Title: Kolkata: Tidal traffic on Lockgate flyover from today
Content:
Kolkata Police to allow tidal traffic on Lockgate flyover

KOLKATA: From Saturday, Kolkata Police will introduce tidal traffic movement along Lockgate flyover , parallel to Tallah Bridge that is under demolition, to facilitate faster movement of directional traffic during peak hours. The move will help Higher Secondary examinees to reach their exam centres without much hassle.

From 6am to 1pm, the peak directional traffic on Lockgate flyover will be south-bound while it will be north-bound after 1pm. This will ease traffic congestion to a great extent, a senior traffic police officer said.

While the flyover is meant for the peak directional traffic, its parallel level crossing will serve the traffic moving in opposite direction (off-peak directional traffic). That means north-bound vehicles will ply through the level crossing from 6am to 1pm. The vehicles coming from Central Avenue-Girish Avenue will run via Prankrishna Mukherjee Road, Jagannatha Ghat Road and Khagen Chatterjee Road to reach BT Road at Chiria More. From 1pm to midnight, the level crossing will be used by the south-bound traffic. However, traffic will move both ways on Cossipore Bridge.

From Thursday afternoon till Friday evening, Kolkata Police ran a trial of the tidal traffic movement and the result showed a considerable ease in the traffic movement, according to the police.

Kolkata traffic police have been experimenting with traffic flow in this zone ever since the demolition work of Tallah Bridge began.

Initially, the Lockgate flyover was used for north-bound throughout the day, while the south-bound traffic took a long detour along the Northern Avenue, Belgachia Road and R K Kar Road to reach Shyambazar.

Title: Four more from patient’s co report for tests
Content:
As a safety measure, the entire office of the company is being fumigated by professional agencies

Nagpur: After an associate of the same company in which the first Covid-19 positive patient works was detected as second positive case in city, the administration and the IT company have started taking steps to ensure testing of all the employees who came into contact of the duo.

On Friday, four more suspects reported themselves to the Government Medical College Hospital (GMCH). All of them are employees of the same company.

“One of the two positive cases found on Friday include our associate, while the other is wife of the associate who tested positive on Wednesday. The first covid-19 positive case had been to Atlanta, GA and Washington DC. He returned via Doha. The associate who tested positive on Friday had also been to Atlanta, and also returned via Doha in the same flight with him. There was another associate (third one) with them on the same flight, he tested negative on Thursday,” reads an official statement by the company.

The company has also clarified that the one who has tested positive on Friday had attended office for three days earlier. As a safety measure, the entire office of this company is being fumigated by professional agencies.

There were four associates who were experiencing symptoms on Friday. So, they were admitted in GMCH and have taken a test the same day. Their results are awaited.

“We are in constant touch with the government agencies and are cooperating with them. We are diligently adhering to each and every instruction provided by them,” the statement concludes.

A senior official of the company said that many of them are working from home while those who are coming to office are practicing isolation in their cabins and working mostly online and on phones.

Title: Schools under NMRDA to be closed till March 25 only
Content:
Nagpur: While schools and colleges under Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) limit and rural area will remain closed till March 31, but the schools that come under Nagpur Metropolitan Region Development Authority (NMRDA) will be closed only till March 25 only. The decision to this effect was taken after a meeting of district collector, education officials and ZP CEO, creating a lot of confusion among several schools.

NMRDA covers everything under the 25km radius area which starts right after city limits. So in a simplified explanation, it is the area between Nagpur city and rural areas. Koradi, Hingna, Kamptee, Khapri etc are some examples of the places that come under NMRDA.

The entire confusion started with the state government circular which said that areas under corporation, council and panchayat will be shut down till March 31. This circular missed mentioning the areas under NMRDA which is why the local authorities were in a fix. They raised the issue with higher-ups and were informed that it can be sorted out at local level.

Speaking to TOI, resident deputy collector Ravindra Khajanchi said, “The collector held meeting with Zilla Parishad CEO in this regard today. Then, he took decision for restrictions in the NMRDA area only up to March 25 as of now. It is because there are no cases from the NMRDA area. Further decision to extend the closure will be taken well before March 25 after a formal review of the situation.”

A principal, whom TOI spoke to, said the decision does not make sense to them. “Maximum schools of CBSE are in rural areas because they are located just outside the city. But majority of students there come from Nagpur. So, in any case, maximum students have to come to their schools or colleges from Nagpur, which is under lockdown. There is no point in such decisions,” he said.

Another principal said it is tough for them to explain this to parents. “On Saturday and Sunday morning, we sent SMS to parents announcing closure of schools till March 31. Now, this decision will change everything and put us in a fix. Parents will also be livid with us when the next date goes out,” she said.

Title: ‘BJP trying to sabotage democracy in country’
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: AICC general secretary incharge of organisation K C Venugopal alleged that BJP is trying to sabotage democracy in the country.

After filing his nomination for a Rajya Sabha seat from Rajasthan, Venugopal told reporters, “BJP is trying to sabotage the entire democratic system in the county. Horse-trading is going on in Madhya Pradesh, but we are confident that the Congress is dealing with the challenge and will succeed.”

The two Congress nominees for the Rajya Sabha seats from Rajasthan, AICC general secretary K C Venugopal and Pradesh Congress Committee (PCC) general secretary Neeraj Dangi, filed their nominations on Friday.

The biennial elections for Rajya Sabha will be held on three seats in the state on March 26.

Venugopal, who reached here on Thursday night, said he is thankful to party president Sonia Gandhi and former party president Rahul Gandhi for giving him an opportunity to serve as a Rajya Sabha member from Rajasthan.

On the issue of BJP fielding a second candidate, AICC general secretary incharge, Avinash Pande said, “We are confident of victory of the two candidates with a comfortable majority.”

Scrutiny of nominations will be held on March 16 and nominations can be withdrawn on March 18. Polling will take place from 9am to 4pm on March 26.

Rajasthan has a total of 10 Rajya Sabha seats and at present nine are held by BJP, including three whose tenure ends this month.

The Congress’ only Rajya Sabha MP from Rajasthan is former Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, who was elected unopposed in the Rajya Sabha bypolls held last year after the seat fell vacant following the demise of BJP’s Madan Lal Saini, who was also the party’s state president.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Indian students abroad hunt flats as universities clear dorms
Content: MUMBAI: The hunt for a couch intensifies as Indian students on campuses across the world are being directed to vacate university dorms.Most are looking for apartments near campuses as they wait for the Covid-19 pandemic to end. Meanwhile, the consulate general of India, New York, it is believed, has asked students to request their friends to host them. While some are moving in with relatives or requesting locals to accommodate them, many others are toying with the option of flying back home.A directive from the consulate received by students suggests they stay back as flying back home to India would mean staying under quarantine for 14 days. Moreover, flying via certain countries may affect the student’s entry into India and the USA. The office of the consular general has asked students to request their universities if they can still be accommodated.Karan Gupta, a counsellor who works with students wishing to study abroad, said, “As the spread of the virus intensifies, students will have to pair up with friends and look for rental accommodation near their campus.”Several American universities have asked candidates to not return after the spring break. Universities are running classes via the virtual mode. “If the universities are not accepting applications or have not approved applications for continued housing, ask friends if they will be able to host for the period for which the university has shut down,” the advisory said.Students have been advised to check with their respective university about how to avail of health services, international student services and any other essential services which are impacted in case on-campus services are suspended.

Title: TN: Two in isolation wards test negative for coronavirus
Content: MADURAI: Two men, who were under observation in the isolation wards for Covid-19 in the Tirunelveli and Kanyakumari government hospitals respectively, were discharged on Thursday night and Friday evening, after they tested negative for coronavirus. The two had recently returned from the Gulf.The man admitted in the Government Tirunelveli Medical College and Hospital (TVMCH) was identified as a 27-year-old from Chokkampatti village near Kadayanallur in Tenkasi district. He returned from Dubai on March 7 and was asymptomatic when he was checked in the airport on arrival. He later developed fever and cold and was admitted in the isolation ward at TVMCH on Monday.He tested negative for malaria and typhoid, following which his blood samples were sent to Chennai for analysis two days ago. “We got the result on Thursday night and he tested negative. He was discharged the same night,” dean M Ravichandran said and added that the youth had fever only for a day.At present, a 40-year-old Malaysian national is admitted in the TVMCH isolation ward for fever and uncontrolled diabetes. While the fever is settled, his diabetes is also getting under control, due to which there was no need to collect his samples for COVID-19 testing, the dean said. “He is likely to be discharged on Saturday,” Ravichandran added.In Kanyakumari district , a 26-year-old man with recent travel history to Oman got himself admitted in the Kanyakumari Government Medical College and Hospital on Thursday afternoon fearing symptoms of Covid-19. “We collected swab samples from him and sent it to Chennai for testing. We got the result on Friday morning and he tested negative. So, he was discharged on Friday evening,” dean R Suganthy said.

Title: Private college students protest fine on semester fee defaulters
Content:
Coimbatore: More than 50 students of a private arts and science college in Perur staged a sit-in in front of the district collector’s office on Friday after the college management had sought up to Rs 10,000 as penalty for delaying to pay semester fee and pending fees from the students. The protesters alleged that they were not allowed to attend the practical examination.

A student on condition of anonymity said, “The last date for paying the semester fee was December 13 and we were told that penalty would not be slapped against us even if we pay half of the fees. I had paid half of the amount before the deadline and the remaining amount a few days after it. About a week ago, the college management had informed me that I had to pay Rs 2,750 as penalty for the delay in paying the fee and other pending fee. My semester fee itself is Rs 5,000.”

Another student said penalty up to Rs 10,000 was slapped on most of the students in BBA, BCom (CA) and BCom (IT) and how could they pay such a huge amount in such a short period. About a week ago, 17 students were suspended from the college without any reason and when a reason was sought, the management remained tip-lipped, he added.

Seeking the intervention of the district administration, the students had submitted a petition at the office of the district collector and officials had assured to investigate it.

Title: Govt taking several steps to develop sports in state: Min
Content:
Madurai: Tamil Nadu is taking many steps to develop sports and Rs 218.60 crore has been allocated this year for the purpose, minister for school education, youth welfare and sports development K A Sengottaiyan has said.

He was speaking after inaugurating the Chief Minister’s Trophy for the state-level kabbadi tournament for 2019-2020 at the open air auditorium in Tamukkam, which is going to be the last official event to be held in this historical site before it is closed for developmental activities. The minister said that steps were being taken to enhance job opportunities for sportspersons both in the public and private sectors. In a recent conference of the CII in Chennai, Sengottaiyan said that he urged industrialists to sponsor sportspersons who won gold medals at the national level in tournaments.

It was under the AIADMK rule that sportspersons were being awarded high cash prizes. Those participating in this tournament stand to win Rs 12 lakh collectively, he said.

Concerns were raised by some public against the large gatherings at the venue during the weekend, amidst Covid-19 fears. Participants also said that they were not supplied with any precautionary measures yet, though some of them had brought their own hand sanitizers. Sarathi, who had come to witness the event, said the government should ensure screening for spectators and players.

Minister for co-operatives Sellur K Raju and minister for revenue, disaster management and IT R B Udaykumar, said that chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami was taking many steps to develop sports in the state. Fund allocations were being made and playgrounds established in all panchayats across the state, they said. tnn

Title: Attendance at Delhi government schools to go digital soon
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: From April 1, Delhi government schools will have zero paperwork as even attendance will be marked through tablets and the whole process will be digitised. Education minister Manish Sisodia has also announced that the schools will have video-conference facilities so that meetings can be held easily.

In a meeting with the deputy directors of education (DDE) on Thursday, Sisodia said the gounment would “digitise the process of exam result tabulation and attendance records. All teachers will be given tablets”.

Referring to the assembly elections, the deputy chief minister said, “This is the first time in the history of India that education has become a significant electoral issue. We have have to work really hard in the next five years.”

Everyone associated with education “should not have any arrogance”, Sisodia said, adding that other states and countries were reaching out to learn the way Delhi had changed its education model. “We should not be swelled up with arrogance while sharing our educational practices and model with them.”

He asked DDEs to ensure every teach in all zones had a tablet. “I want zero paper work. Section-wise attendance should be marked by teachers. We are aiming to build a robust software for the attendance system so that every DDE gets a notification by 9am every day about students’ attendance in each section of each school within their zones.” Examination results also have to be uploaded and maintained online on tablets, Sisodia suggested.

He also asked DDEs to keep a track on the installation of CCTV cameras on the premises. “Each DDE should know whether CCTVs are functional and if password has been provided to the parents to access them,” he said.

Video-conference facilities will ensure easy access at the zonal and directorate levels, the minister said. Meetings of the heads of school with DDEs and their senior officials can also be conducted online. “This will save time consumed in commuting.” The deputy CM also asked DDEs to work on improving the aesthetics of the school buildings, boundary walls, gates and nameplates within their zones. They should also take step to keep the premises clean.

Title: Drop move to merge ICMR: Su Venkatesan
Content:
Madurai: Su Venkatesan, MP, has urged the Union health minister to drop the move to merge the Madurai Centre of Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) with the one in Jipmer, Puducherry.

In a letter to the council’s director-general, he said that a recent report in the leading medical research journal Lancet titled “health and climate change’’ has stated that climate change will nullify the progress achieved in the field of public health so far. It also states that children will be the most affected by vector-borne diseases.

Opening more laboratories to expand research in the field of such diseases and microorganisms has become very important in the wake of the spread of diseases like Ebola, Saars and now Covid-19.

The success of the ICMR centre in Madurai is evident from the fact that it was the nodal centre dealing with diseases such as Japanese encephalitis, which was prevalent in the districts of Thiruvannamalai and Villupuram. The spread of these diseases was controlled and eliminated to a great extent by the ICMR centre in Madurai. Shifting the unit and merging it with the one in Puducherry would affect this work greatly.

Administratively also, Puducherry and Tamil Nadu are two different administrative units and state-level coordination for study, control and management would be difficult. It would affect the management of vector borne diseases.

Hence, the move to merge the centre in Madurai with the one in Puducherry should be dropped and more funds allocated for its functioning in Madurai, he said.

Title: Devotees protest entry fee to Siriyur temple
Content:
Udhagamandalam: Ahead of the Siriyur temple festival , local residents have approached the forest department with a request to do away with the entry fee at the forest check post to enter the temple that is located within the buffer zone of Mudumalai Tiger Reserve (MTR).

Earlier this year, the forest department had for the first time announced its plans to collect an entry fee of Rs 30 per person and Rs 50 per vehicle during the festival that is scheduled to take place on March 15 and 16.

B Kumaran, vice-chairman, Tea Board of India, said, “It is one of the important festivals of the Badaga community in the Nilgiris. The annual festival of Siriyur Amman is decades old tradition. We were taken aback by the decision to impose entry fee during the two-day festival.” A native of the Nilgiris, he has made a representation to the field director of MTR on Friday to scrap the entry fee. “This will cause long queues at the check post, hindering the smooth flow of the festival. Also, devotees are upset over the introduction of the entry fee to the temple.”

Meanwhile, Nakkubetta Farmers’ Association and other forums in the Nilgiris have written to the forest minister and chief minister to cancel the entry fee system.

When contacted, a senior forest official said the devotees would be allowed as usual without any entry fee.

Title: Delhi high court refuses to interfere in religious conversion issue
Content:
Delhi high court (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Religion is a personal belief and to convert to a different faith or not is an individual’s choice, Delhi high court remarked on Friday, declining to entertain a plea for stopping or regulating religious conversions .

A bench of Chief Justice D N Patel and Justice C Hari Shankar asked the petitioner — lawyer and BJP member Ashwini Kumar Upadhyay — to withdraw the petition as it did not want to reject it. Subsequently, Upadhyay withdrew the matter.

When the petition came up for hearing, the court said professing a religion was a matter of personal belief and whether to convert to a different religion was an individual’s choice. “Tell us how can we regulate it? What will we regulate? If someone is threatening someone or intimidating someone, it is an offence under the Indian Penal Code,” the bench said and added there was no reason for an individual to succumb to threats, intimidation or allurement to convert to a different faith.

Upadhyay, in his plea, had contended that many individuals, NGOs and institutions are converting downtrodden persons, particularly of the Scheduled Caste/Scheduled Tribe community, by “intimidating, threatening, luring by monetary benefits and by other acts, including miracle healing, black magic and more.”

The petition further claimed that “Many individuals/organisations have started conversions of SC/STs in rural areas and the situation is very alarming. The mass religious conversion of the economically downtrodden men, women and children, and, in particular of the scheduled caste and scheduled tribe community, is on the rise in the last 20 years.”

It had also claimed that as per the 2011 census, Hindus constitute 79 per cent of the population down from 86 per cent in 2001 and if no action is taken “Hindus will become minority in India”. Upadhyay had suggested enacting of a law to prevent conversions by force or deceit and to award jail term for any violation.

Title: Fewer cases, but India becomes 5th country to isolate corona virus
Content: New Delhi: India has become the fifth country to successfully isolate a strain of the novel coronavirus . China, Japan, Thailand and the US did it before.Simply put, it means that scientists have been able to obtain a pure sample of the virus that has been contained outside the human body.The scientific success is important because it will help in developing drugs, vaccines and rapid diagnostic test kits, the director general of Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), Dr Balram Bhargava, said.He added that the isolation of the novel coronavirus, the agent responsible for the ongoing outbreak of Covid-19, wasn’t easy as India had fewer positive cases when they started the project.“Total 21 throat swab and nasal swab samples were examined for this purpose. Of that, 11 tested positive and eight strains could be isolated from among them. They are 99.98% identical with the strain of the virus that led to outbreaks in Wuhan in China,” said Dr R R Gangakhedkar, chief epidemiologist at ICMR. He added that now scientists can test whether a drug will work against the virus or not to develop rapid diagnostic kits.The isolation of this virus will also help in understanding the biology and evolution of the novel coronavirus, say ICMR experts. Till date, there is no cure for Covid-19. Also, there is no preventive vaccination.Anti-HIV drugs lopinavir and ritonavir have been tried on some Covid-19 patients, including the Italian national admitted at Sawai Man Singh hospital in Jaipur, with promising results. But the scientists said it is too early to conclude the efficacy.Most patients are only receiving symptomatic treatment, they added.Recently, in a draft report made public by the World Health Organisation (WHO), the experts claimed that Remdesivir, a drug developed for use against ebola, which caused major outbreaks in remote villages in Central Africa in 2014, is most promising for treating Covid-19.This is because the in-vitro (tests performed in test tube) and in-vivo (tests performed in living organism) data for the drug is available for coronaviruses. “Further, studies in mice using Remdesivir showed superior efficacy over Kaletra+IFNbeta,” the draft report said.The report added that a clinical trial is being planned in China to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the drug in association with optimised standard of care, as the next step. Remdesivir slows the infection of healthy cells by blocking viral replication.The WHO expert also reviewed drugs used in HIV treatment — lopinavir and ritonavir — either alone or in combination with IFNbeta. It stated that among the repurposed drugs under consideration, this would be the suitable second option for rapid implementation in clinical trials.The use of convalescent sera-serum obtained from someone who has recovered from an infectious disease and considered to be especially rich in antibodies against the infectious agent of the disease could also be an option, said the expert group. However, the report added: “...but it remains to be defined if sufficient amounts of sera with high antibodies titres could be feasibly collected, using concentration and purification processes.”
