Title: Kolkata: Fitness test for 15 Salt Lake tanks
Content:
A water tank at CK Block in Salt Lake which will undergo fitness test

KOLKATA: Bidhannagar Municipal Corporation has planned to conduct structural health and fitness tests of 15 overhead water tanks located across Salt Lake . The move comes a day after the collapse of a 33,000 gallon capacity overhead water tank inside the Post and Telegraph housing quarters in Salt Lake’s CC Block on Thursday morning.

From these 15 overhead water tanks, filtered water is supplied twice a day to about 26,000 households in the township with a population of about 2.16 lakh.

“We have decided to get a fitness test of the overhead water tanks conducted across Salt Lake by the structural engineers of Jadavpur University . It is not possible to know the condition of the tanks by looking at them from outside. We have already held talks with the JU experts and we will show them all the 15 tanks that will undergo the fitness test. We will take further steps following their recommendations,” said Bidhannagar mayor Krishna Chakraborty on Friday.

The civic authorities have already conducted tests on three tanks like 3, 7 and 10 as they had some doubts over their conditions. “We will work as per the suggestions of the JU experts. Our civic engineers are keeping in touch with them,” said the mayor. The civic officials said that in the Rajarhat area, there are two overhead water tanks, which are relatively new and in good condition.

Chakraborty said that the civic body is sending water tankers to Post and Telegraph housing quarters where the overhead tank had collapsed on Thursday. “We will supply water to the housing complex as long as it is required. The buildings are in terrible condition. We have already talked with the authorities of the complex in this regard,” the mayor added.

However, when the postal and telecommunications officials inspected the collapse of the water tank, residents of the complex protested against the lack of maintenance of their buildings in the past 15 years. The civic authorities are already taking steps to store surface water from the New Town water treatment plant. Two new overhead tanks and two new underground water reservoirs are coming up near tanks No. 5 and 13.

Title: Sanitizers, masks in short supply; rates shoot up
Content:
Nagpur: The corona scare has cleaned up sanitizers from the market, literally. There has been a sudden rise in demand for chlorhexidine and ethyl alcohol based hand sanitisers after the outbreak of Covid-19 infections throughout the country.

Taking advantage of the situation, manufacturers and stockists have nearly doubled their margins, allege retailers who cannot sell the product above the MRP.

So far, the product was largely procured by hospitals only. The demand from hospitals has now gone up after the coronavirus outbreak. Stockist say they are giving priority to hospitals first, after which retail sellers are being supplied.

According to manufacturers, earlier there was hardly any demand for the product from the retailers but now it has gone up by as much as 10 times. They are hardly able to meet the demand, the manufactures said.

TOI scanned nearly 10 medical shops in different parts of the city and found a bottle of sanitisers only in one. There is a similar shortage of masks too and their rates too have gone up.

There are 4 to 5 manufacturers of sanitisers in the city apart from some of the multinationals also supplying the product. “Our monthly sale in the city, including that to some major hospitals in neighbouring Wardha, came to 3,000 litres during normal times. This has gone up to 5,000 litres in less than a month now,” said a representative of multinational company having a manufacturing facility in Pune.

The situation has led to problems in procuring raw material and items like containers and dispensers, say manufacturers. “Normally, the total demand was not more than 4,000 litres a month, but in a week there is a demand for as much as 50,000 litres. The manufacturers have a limited capacity,” said Deepak Kukreja whose firm makes the Adroit brand of sanitisers.

Ethyl alcohol, one of the basic ingredients that goes into making sanitisers, is available on a fixed quota basis to each manufacturer, due to which even the production cannot go beyond a certain level, he said.

Deepak Jinturkar of M/s Deepti Pharmaceutical that makes sanitisers using isopropyl alcohol said that raw material suppliers have increase the chemical’s cost to Rs150 a litre from Rs100 earlier. This is reflected in the end-price of the product too, he said.

“The retail demand cannot be met also because of an acute shortage of plastic containers. The retail market is supplied in smaller plastic bottles which are almost out of supply,” he said.

“It is expected that the supplies will normalize in a couple of days. However, it must be understood that there is no need of panic buying as well,” said Mohan Abhyankar, the Vidarbha zone president of Maharashtra Chemists and Druggists Association.

Rates of masks have gone up from Rs10 to Rs15 to as much as Rs30 to 40 a piece. The standard N-95 masks are being sold in the range of Rs230 to 250 a piece. Many retailers are hardly finding any margin in the product and have stopped procuring masks, said a source.

Title: T aims to boost air connectivity with 3 new airports, revival of 3 others
Content:
Hyderabad: In a bid to boost air connectivity in the state, the Telangana government is planning to re-activate old airports and set up greenfield airports along with establishing a chain of heliports to connect the remotest parts of the state, Telangana IT and Industries minister KT Rama Rao said on Friday.

“We have proposed three greenfield airports and revival of three brownfield airports in Telangana. The greenfield airports at Bhadradri-Kothagudem, Jakranpally in Nizamabad district and Gudibanda village at Mahabubnagar district. The brownfield airports are at Mamnoor village in Warangal Urban district, Basanthnagar at Peddapally district and at Adilabad,” he said while delivering the inaugural address at Wings India 2020.

He said the state government has appointed Airports Authority of India (AAI) as consultant for preparing techno-feasibility studies for the existing airstrips as well as the greenfield ones.

The minister said the state government is betting big on the maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) sector to attract big-ticket investments in the state. “We are in active discussion with various OEMs and operators and are told that our ecosystem offers the best infrastructure and skill base for MROs in India,” he said, adding that Telangana currently has two MROs operated by GMR and Air India.

He also added that the decision to slash VAT on ATF from 16% to 1% during Wings India 2018, has resulted in leading operators such as Spice jet and Indigo expanding their operational base in Hyderabad.

He also added that Telangana is the first state to come up with its own drone policy and it is actively working with startups and industry partners to pilot drone use cases in diverse sectors such as healthcare, agriculture, mining and law enforcement, among others.

Title: Ajmer: Video of police beating naked man goes viral, probe on
Content:
AJMER: Police on Friday initiated a probe into a video which went viral in the city in which policemen are seen beating a naked man on road with sticks.

The authenticity and origin of the video is yet to be ascertained. The video has been sent for examination and investigators are yet to identify the policemen involved and the place where this incident occurred.

Police officials refused to comment on the issue but said they will investigate the matter. The video shows the victim roaming naked on road. When police ask him to go away, he denies and starts arguing. Later, two policemen start beating the man. Bystanders are hard asking the policemen police not to beat the man as he might be ‘mentally ill’.

After the video went viral, some groups demand police officials to act against the policemen in the video. They said police cannot take law in their hands.

According to sources, it has been found in the preliminary investigation that the man is a drug addict and was creating nuisance. Police had to use force to control him.

Title: Rs 5 lakh seized from office of sub-registrar
Content:
Namakkal: Sleuths attached to the Directorate of Vigilance and Anti-Corruption (DVAC) conducted a surprise raid in Tiruchengode sub-registrar office in the district on Thursday night and seized Rs 4.86 lakh unaccounted cash.

The search ended around 11am on Friday. The DVAC acted based on a tip-off that employees in the sub-registrar office were demanding bribe for registration related works.

The DVAC also received information that officials were sharing the bribery amount among themselves after office hours.

“We have initiated inquiry with the officials including sub-registrar and cases will be registered if they found guilty after inquiry,” the officials added.

Title: Covid-19 wards set up in two more GHs
Content:
Coimbatore: Though the district is yet to record its first case of Covid-19 and the state itself has recorded only one positive case, the spreading of the virus in neighboring Kerala and Karnataka seems to have made the state government increase its preparation to handle the virus. In Coimbatore, the public health department has set up two more exclusive isolation wards for Covid-19 suspected and confirmed patients.

On Wednesday, the department set up two more exclusive Covid-19 treatment wards—one at the Coimbatore Medical College Hospital and the other at Pollachi Government Hospital. This is in addition to the first such ward set up at ESI Hospital. While the ESI Hospital ward has around 20 beds, the Coimbatore Medical College Hospital ward has around eight beds and Pollachi GH too has another eight. “Our Covid-19 ward is like an intensive care unit set up, equipped with centralized oxygen supply, ventilators, mobile X-ray units along with face masks, gloves and a set of fever treatment equipment that will not be used in any other ward,” dean Dr B Ashokan said. “Our ward is specifically for Covid-19 positive patients,” he added.

Comparatively, the 20-bedded coronavirus ward at ESI Hospital is meant for quarantining. “That ward actually requires only television and access to food and books for patients to relax and wait it out. So, we plan to send suspected patients to ESIC Hospital and keep only positive and treatment requiring patients here,” added the dean.

Besides this, the medical services department has asked every GH to keep a small ward aside to be ready to be converted into a Covid-19 quarantine ward. In Mettupalayam GH, they have set up a 10-bed isolation ward. This has centralized oxygen supply, beds, screen between beds, giving quarantine patients privacy, and a toilet. “We want people not to be afraid of quarantine, but to volunteer and come forward. We can only do that with presentable quarantine wards like that of private hospitals,” a health department official said.

Meanwhile, the 60-year-old woman who returned from Umrah with a cold, tested negative for the virus on Friday. She is the fifth person in the district to be tested for the virus and turned out negative.

Title: Kolkata: Cracks on slum structures on East-West Metro route, 45 shifted
Content:
Slum dwellers of 3,Gour De Lane in a central Kolkata hotel

KOLKATA: Forty-five slum dwellers were shifted to hotels on Wednesday evening after cracks surfaced in the walls of their homes at 3, Gour De Lane.

Kolkata Metro Rail Corporation ( KMRC ), the implementing agency of East-West Metro, has started extensive repairs of the rooms located opposite 5/2 Gour De Lane, from where 36 residents had been evacuated the previous midnight as the fissures on the structure started expanding. The building was constructed with steel beams and extensive grouting is being done to strengthen it.

On Thursday morning, the slum dwellers living on the opposite side of the narrow bylane called in the engineers of KMRC and ITD ITD-Cementation, contracted to build the last 2.45km of underground tunnels between Esplanade and Sealdah. They showed them the gaping cracks and demanded to be relocated. The Metro authorities shifted them to two central Kolkata hotels around 9pm.

Prasanta Jana, 48, said, “Around 8.30pm, I and my son were told to pack our bags. Cracks developed in our room. We have been told that we can return after our home is repaired.”

Title: Low attendance in school & college of patient’s kids
Content:
Officials work at a Coronavirus control room set up at Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) office in Civil Line... Read More

Nagpur: As expected, attendance at the school and college of daughter and son of Nagpur’s first coronavirus patient remained low on Friday. At the son’s engineering college, a holiday had been declared on Friday specifically for the first year batch in which he studies and the building was disinfected.

At daughter’s CBSE school, attendance had dipped sharply with parents preferring to play it safe before the weekend. Both the children have tested negative for the virus, which came as a big relief to teachers and their classmates.

The college’s principal told TOI that attendance was on the lower side but he would not call it a sharp fall. “I actually though that it would be much lower, but that was not the case. The first year batch anyway had a holiday on Friday while the other batches had a slightly lower attendance. We are taking all precautions regarding coronavirus,” said the principal.

The CBSE school’s director said the latest medical report has come as a relief. “It is good to know that the girl is medically fit and not infected with the virus. This is also good news for all others who were in contact with her and were worried,” said the director.

The low attendance can also be attributed to results of coronavirus test not released till late night, thus not giving parents time to make up their mind about sending kids to school.

One parent whose child studies in the same school as the patient’s daughter said, “We just thought there was no point in attending school on Friday with the weekend coming. My son is in primary section so it really was not a big deal. I do believe the government should close down all schools for a week.”

Title: Collector isn’t corona patient, to take police action over news
Content:
Ravindra Thakare

Nagpur: Perturbed after receiving numerous calls and messages from his near and dear ones after he was mistakenly declared as coronavirus patient, district collector Ravindra Thakare on Friday said he will take police action against the media company that published the misinformation.

“On Thursday, I hadn’t thought of taking cognisance but when I started receiving calls from across the country, I thought of correcting the blunder. Some news portal had wrongly displayed my name as coronavirus patient. Media shouldn’t carry any news without verification, as it can lead to harassment of the person concerned. This is very irresponsible journalism. I have already told police to inquire into the source of this news,” he said.

Thakare said that he couldn’t focus on his work after receiving several calls. Slamming social media users who spread such fake news, the collector said it often leads to unnecessary panic. “They should resist from forwarding such news without verifying its source. Media shouldn’t believe in such rumours,” he said.

Title: JMC polls: Candidates focus on door-to-door campaigning
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: With the announcement of the urban local bodies’ elections, people aspiring to become councillor have started making strategy for poll campaigning. Most of the candidates are planning to focus on door-to-door election campaigns, due to the small size of the wards.

After the new delimitation of Jaipur city was completed, Jaipur has now been divided into Jaipur Municipal Corporation – Greater and Jaipur Municipal Corporation – Heritage . There will be total 250 wards. More wards means smaller geographical area and population. Unlike last year, when wards used to have 30,000 people in their area, now the population has gone down to 8,000 people. The number of voters will be less than that. Hence, this year, votes will be given on the basis of the reach of the candidates amongst the people.

A former Congress councillor anonymously said that they have planned to reach out to as many people as possible. “We have to go and meet each voter. Last time, we had organised road shows and had banners of party symbol on it. This year it won’t work. Your liaison will work in your favour,” he said.

BJP has already begun a survey in every ward to shortlist the people who are influential and financially sound and can be given tickets. Workers of the party have been asked to figure out the Congress vote bank in the wards and to chalk out strategies to break their vote bank. A voters’ list will be prepared for the number of people residing outside the district or ward.

In the outskirts of the city like in Kho Nagoriyan, the rural population is higher. People who are eyeing for the seat of a councillor are trying to keep good terms with the elders of the family.

“In rural settings, the heads of the family are always taken seriously. WhatsApp groups are being formed where we are trying to connect with the people directly. The elections will be fought on local issues and allegiance to any party will not matter a lot,” said former BJP councillor anonymously. As per the new delimitation, Hawa Mahal constituency with 16,199 people is the most populated ward in Walled City and ward 75 in Kishanpole constituency is the least populated with 8,800 people. Both the wards fall under Jaipur Heritage Municipal Corporation (JHMC) jurisdiction.

Title: Calcutta high court seeks West Bengal government report on Saradha damages fund
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: Calcutta high court on Friday directed the state government to file a report within four weeks on steps taken to spend a sum of over Rs 138 crore — out of Rs 500 crore — given to the Shyamal Sen Commission to compensate the Saradha scam victims. The commission was appointed in August 2013 and empowered to dispose of assets belonging to the Sharadha Group .

The commission had paid compensation to 4,98,673 victims from the sum allotted to it by the state government. After its tenure ended in 2014, the remaining money was handed back to the government.

On February 7, 2019, a division bench of Justice Joymalya Bagchi and Justice Shekhar B Saraf had asked the state government to file an affidavit stating its decision on utilisation of the sum made available to the commission. On Friday, the division bench of justices Joymalya Bagchi and Suvra Ghosh considered the state’s affidavit and directed the government to file a report on Rs 138 crore which had been returned by the commission.

Title: Coronavirus: Coaching institutes in Nagpur to shut down
Content: NAGPUR: Following government’s directives to shut down all schools and colleges in Maharashtra till March 31, the Association of Coaching Institutes (ACI) has announced that its members will abide with the decision with immediate effect.The shutdown had been proposed earlier in the day by the health department to prevent spread of coronavirus infection. The education department endorsed the proposal and issued notification late in the evening on Saturday.Speaking to TOI, ACI’s office-bearer Sameer Phale said, “In the interest of the students and as directed by the state government, all of our member institutes will shut down.”ACI is a Nagpur-based body which has been providing a platform to coaching institutes to address concerns over proposed regulatory moves. ACI has also moved on to peer interaction and training programmes for its members.Shortly before the state government announced its decision to shut all educational institutes, ACI had issued a media statement saying they have requested Indian Medical Association (Nagpur) members to visit their classes and create awareness about coronavirus.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Delhi: Tihar Jail quarantines new inmates for three days before allotting cells
Content: NEW DELHI: Tihar Jail authorities are scanning new entrants for traces of the novel coronavirus before allotting them a cell on the premises. The inmates are kept in a quarantine facility created in a separate cell for three days before transferring them to their wards.Foreign inmates, too, were being shifted to a special ward after they expressed concerns about infection. A jail source said during the screening, if any of the inmates were found with symptoms of the infection, they were shifted to an isolated section in the jail hospital.The source added that apart from this, the existing inmates had been informed about the symptoms and any inmate showing signs were asked to immediately inform the jail wardens. The jail officials informed that no cases of Covid-19 have been reported so far from the jail premises.The jail hospital has been asked to keep adequate stock of saline and paracetamol.The inmates meanwhile, have been directed to wash their hands and use hand sanitisers after stepping out or entering their cells. They have also been advised to avoid physical contact with others during community activities or working at the jail factories.A special sanitisation drive was conducted at all the 16 jails, including the two women ones, where officials had cleaned the premises with sanitisers and disinfectants.A jail source said about 70% of the prisoners were from Delhi, while about 20% from other states, the rest were either foreign citizens or NRIs. At least 60 prisoners are lodged in Tihar Jail daily for various offences.

Title: Student back from US gets infection; 10 coronavirus cases in Pune district
Content: PUNE: A 21-year-old student, a resident of Mangaldas Road in Pune, has tested positive for the novel coronavirus infection (Covid-19) on March 13. His close contacts are now being traced.The case tally of Covid-19 cases has gone up to 10 in Pune district . Of these, seven are in isolation care at Naidu Hospital and three positive patients have been quarantined at YCM Hospital in Pimpri-Chinchwad."The new patient returned to Mumbai from Seattle in the US via Frankfurt in Germany on a Lufthansa flight on March 10. He was at the airport for about 40 minutes,” a civic health official said. Seattle is being considered as the epicentre of the outbreak in the US .The man dined with two friends at a restaurant just opposite the airport and took a cab to Pune arranged for by his father.“On arrival, he was with his parents for two hours before he self-reported to Naidu Hospital when he had throat irritation. He was quarantined the same day and his throat swab sent to National Institute of Virology tested positive for the contagion on Friday afternoon,” official said.Health officials have begun tracking the man's two friends with whom he dined in Mumbai. “We will isolate and test the cabby and his parents to rule out Covid-19 infection," they added.Earlier, four members of a group that had visited Dubai tested positive for the contagion on March 9 and 10. A couple, their 23-year-old daughter and another man are residents of Sinhagad Road.A private cab driver, who had ferried the couple and their daughter from Mumbai to Pune on their return on March 1, also tested positive for the contagion on Tuesday. Thereafter, another 27 year old co-traveller who was also part of the group tested positive for the contagion.Three residents of the Pimpri Chinchwad who were part of the same group were also found infected with the contagion on Wednesday. They are stable and will remain at the YCM Hospital.On Thursday, another resident of a housing society on Sinhagad Road, who had returned from the US, tested positive for the infection.In Nagpur, two persons who were in close contact of the man who tested positive soon after returning from US also tested positive for the contagion on Friday. The total tally of the Covid-19 infected persons has gone up to 19 in Maharashtra between March 9 and March 13. A person in Mumbai and another in Ahmednagar tested positive on Friday.“Except the cab driver in Pune and two close contacts in Nagpur, the remaining 14 people who tested positive for the contagion in Maharashtra had a history of international travel. This shows that there is no community spread so far in the state. Every effort is being made to trace, isolate and test those who have come in close contact with the travellers to contain the virus from spreading,” state surveillance officer Pradip Awate said.41 swab samples fromPCMC areas with NIVTwo citizens from Pimpri Chinchwad, with a recent history of travel abroad , were admitted to YCM Hospital on Thursday. They were allowed to go home on Saturday after their swab samples tested negative on Friday.The PCMC said swabs of 41 citizens have been sent to NIV and the results are awaited. Also, the test results of 34 people, who interacted with the three positive patients from Pimpri Chinchwad, are awaited. They are home quarantined.

Title: 1 more held in Rs 5cr theft case
Content:
Vijayawada: Nellore Rural police, on Friday, arrested another accused who was involved in the inter-state robbery, in which a container carrying a consignment of Xiaomi mobile phones from Sri City worth Rs 4.8 crore was hijacked in February 2019. The police have already arrested six persons in connection with this case.

On Friday, the police seized Rs 25 lakh from the accused Jitendra Gupta alias Jeethu Gupta. Nellor SP Bhaskar Bhushan said the container with mobile phones was heading towards Kolkata from the manufacturing unit of the company when the gang intercepted the vehicle. TNN

Title: Jaipur: Minor’s body found in well, kin allege murder
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR/ALWAR: A 14-year-old girl’s body was found in a well in Bharatpur’s Nagar police station area on Friday morning. The teenager was missing since Wednesday. Her family has now lodged a case of abduction and murder against unidentified accused.

The deceased was identified as Sanju Jangid. “The teenager went missing on March 11 morning and her family started looking for her. On Friday morning, they received information that a body matching the description of the missing child was floating in the well. They rushed to the spot and with the help of the locals took out the body,” said an official of Nagar police station. Following this, the cops were informed who reached the spot and took the body to the mortuary.

Elaborating further, the official said, “The family did not inform the police and kept searching for the girl on their own. They claimed that on Wednesday morning Sanju left home without informing anyone. At present we do not know if this is a case of murder or suicide.”

Police are also looking at the call details of the victim’s mobile phone. The victim’s family has alleged that she was kidnapped and murdered. A case under relevant IPC sections has been registered on the basis of the complaint. TNN

Title: RBU panel to probe Basanta Utsav row
Content:
Kolkata: The executive council of Rabindra Bharati University ( RBU ) on Friday has set up a four-member committee to look into the role of any insider in the untoward incident during Basanta Utsav celebrations.

The committee will be led by dean faculty of Arts while three others are EC members and heads of Rabindra Sangeet, Sanskrit and Applied Arts departments.

The report will have to be submitted within one month to vice-chancellor Sabyasachi Basu Roy Choudhury. Based on the report the EC will decide on the future action.

Sources said that there is no scope of any inquiry to be conducted by an outside agency as the police have been investigating the incident where some outsiders were found to be involved. TNN

Title: Seven more arrested in three Delhi riot cases
Content:
Communal riots shook parts of northeast Delhi in the last week of February

NEW DELHI: Delhi Police has arrested seven more people in connection with the northeast Delhi riots . The accused have been booked on charges of murder, attempted murder and rioting.

Police have also identified six women who were involved in the mayhem at Chand Bagh in which a cop was killed and two others were critically injured. Raids are on to nab them. They were identified through mobile videos and CCTV footage, said an officer.

In the first case, the SIT arrested three men, identified as Mohammed Firoze, Chand Mohammed and Rayees Khan in connection with the murder of a youth named Shahid. Shahid was killed on February 24 near his house in Dayalpur area. All the accused belong to Chand Bagh.

Shahid was standing atop a house in the area when he was hit by a bullet fired by rioters. During investigation, police analysed several videos obtained from public and social media, and identified the trio who were firing shots at Shahid. They were tracked down and arrested on Thursday. A manhunt has been launched for their associates.

Two men, Shoib and Imran, were arrested on charges of murdering a man named Mehroom. The incident was reported from Subhash Mohalla in Bhajanpura on February 24. The cops identified the accused from the video footage shot on mobile phones by the locals. The accused are being interrogated about the identity of the other rioters.

In the third case, which was lodged for rioting and murder, police arrested two men named Gulfam and Tanveer. The incident pertains to rioting in Dayalpur. The two accused men were identified from a mobile video.

One of the victims, Ajay, stated in his complaint that he was returning home from his uncle’s house on February 25 when he was shot at on his arm. Ajay fell down and sought help from the locals who told him to run away as the two goons were firing indiscriminately at people in lane number 5 and 6. When he looked back, he allegedly saw heavy firing and stone pelting happening from the terrace of AAP councillor, Tahir Hussain.

Ajay was rushed to a nearby hospital from where he was referred to Hindu Rao Hospital for treatment. He later gave his statement to the cops.

Title: No shutting of schools, colleges: Dist admin
Content:
Nagpur: The district administration led by divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar and collector Ravindra Thakare on Friday ruled out immediate closure of academic institutions. However, public places like theatres, malls, gyms etc will be closed as per state government orders.

While advising citizens against spreading panic, the duo reassured them that the situation was in complete control and the administration was ready to tackle any emergency.

Thakare, however, advised citizens to avoid visiting public places like theatres, malls and others, or attend events with mass gatherings. “Those arriving from abroad should strictly avoid going outside home, and should keep themselves under self-isolation for two weeks. If any of them is infected, there’s every chance that the disease would spread to others, as it’s highly contagious.”

On parents demanding closure of schools and colleges, the collector clarified that the administration didn’t want to spread panic and the situation wasn’t that bad. “The government would ultimately take a decision in this regard if the situation worsens, but we wouldn’t be shutting any academic institution from our side, as of now,” he reiterated.

When informed about a slew of socio-cultural events taking place over the weekend, Thakare said those at risk should avoid visiting there. He also ruled out screening of railway passengers, stating that only places where international tourists would be arriving like airport would have such facility.

“We’re searching only two international flights that arrive in the city. International passengers arriving from Delhi, Mumbai and other cities have already undergone screening at airports there. We will work as per the advisory issued by the government,” he said.

Action against officials revealing patient’s name

The collector, who was earlier reluctant to take action against senior officials from the health department who revealed the coronavirus patient’s name, assured action against them. “We will inquire and act against them. It was wrong on the part of officials to disclose name of first coronavirus patient. We assure you that such mistakes wouldn’t be repeated in future,” he said.

After the name of the patient was revealed by a section of media, his family faced troubled times. The school on Katol Road where his daughter was studying, was thronged by parents wanting to take their wards back home due to panic. Even the engineering college his son studies in had declared one-day holiday for first-year students on Friday.

Title: Covid-19 scare in Delhi: Corporations to disinfect open gyms, parks, zonal offices
Content: NEW DELHI: Municipal corporation teams have started mass disinfection drives at common places like open gyms, toilets, parks, zonal offices and community centres among others. In the midst of the coronavirus scare , awareness banners and announcements via loudspeakers are being used to spread awareness among Delhiites.On Friday, a training programme was held by the north corporation for sanitation supervisory staff. A senior south corporation public health department official said that sodium hypochlorite is being procured in bulk for future use.“Senior officers explained in detail the precautions and steps to be taken to check the transmission of the virus. The staff were asked to regularly disinfect the public places using a solution of sodium hypochlorite,” a senior north municipal corporation official added. “Stickers on the ways to wash hands will be soon displayed in the public toilets.”The staff were also asked to wear masks and hand gloves for their own protection. “The zonal office buildings, citizen bureuas and other office buildings which see more footfall will be sanitised,” said the director of the sanitation department.East corporation, too, has started its own training and awareness programmes. “Two deputy health officers of the public health department and couple of doctors from the hospital administration had undergone training of trainers on March 9. Subsequently, training was imparted to supervisory staff and healthcare personnel,” the spokesperson said.Municipal bodies have also been instructed to identify properties that can be used to create isolation wards.Meanwhile, north corporation mayor, Avtar Singh, visited Hindu Rao Hospital to check preparations of the 50-bed isolation facility. He also reviewed the preparedness at MVID hospital. The nursing home of Hindu Rao Hospital has been converted into a ward for coronavirus patients, while the newly constructed boys’ hostel of Hindu Rao Medical College has been converted into a ward for suspected cases.

Title: Jodhpur municipal elections: Aspirants make a beeline for forms at Congress, BJP offices
Content:
Representative image

JODHPUR: Large crowds of party workers converged at the BJP and Congress offices on Friday to collect the applications forms for contesting the municipal election scheduled for April 5.

Distribution of forms started Friday and will continue till March 18.

According to the divisional spokesperson of Congress Ajay Trivedi, a total of 397 candidates willing to contest the election obtained application forms on the first day on Friday from the party office.

He said the last date of submission of application forms is March 18, after which no forms will be accepted.

Similarly, the BJP workers also obtained forms from the party office on Friday. But the party has also given forms to the mandal presidents in order to avoid rush at the party office.

“We have given 50 forms each to 12 mandal presidents and have advised them to arrive at a consensus on potential candidates with senior leaders on every booth,” said party spokesperson Jagdish Dhanadia .

Meanwhile, with the declaration of the date for election to six municipal corporations in three districts, parties have swung into action for fielding candidates and campaigning.

The BJP has appointed Union cabinet minister Arjun Meghwal as the election convener for both the North and South municipal corporations of Jodhpur city , while Jaitaran MLA Avinash Gehlot has been roped in as coordinator for North and Jalore MLA Jogeshwar Garg will be the coordinator for South.

The party has begun Holi meetings in all the 12 mandals of the city, wherein all the party workers will bring meals from their respective houses and dine together while discussing the election planning with focus on their respective wards.

Similarly, Congress has also begun preparation for the election, but not as aggressively as the BJP. A committee has been constituted by the party’s city unit for election management, but it will remain restricted to the party office just to look after the form distribution.

Jodhpur has been divided into North and South zones, bifurcating hitherto one municipal corporation with 80 wards each in North and South municipal corporations. The city earlier had only 65 wards, which has, post delimitation, shot up to 160 wards.

Title: Stop campaigns against protesters: Eminent citizens
Content:
The statement by all-women signatories says Muslim women led the anti-CAA protests, in the best tradition of t... Read More

NEW DELHI: A group of eminent economists , lawyers, political and social activists , academics, health professionals and women’s organisations issued a statement on Friday calling on governments to do justice in the aftermath of the riots and attacks in northeast Delhi . Trouble in the neighbourhoods started on February 23, stretched to February 26 and sporadic incidents were reported even after. The statement also counters the misinformation campaign designed to malign the women-led anti-CAA protests .

The over 100 all-women signatories include Devika Jain, Uma Chakravarti, Tanika Sarkar, Jayati Ghosh, Kamla Bhasin, Annie Raja, Farah Naqvi and Amrita Johri.

The statement said, “Delhi struggles to recover from the terrible violence… which hit some of the poorest people — tailors, scrap dealers, carpenters, and daily wagers... Both (Hindu and Muslim) communities bear the sorrow of lives and livelihoods lost in this senseless violence.”

It rebuts the campaign to “criminalise” protesters and demands governments do justice. “We need governments to give us justice, reassurance and relief.”

Talking of the ground reality of the anti-CAA protests, the statement said, “Muslim women led these protests, in the best tradition of our freedom struggle… and proud we joined this struggle with them, in full measure as Indians — as students, women’s rights activists and queer groups, people’s movements, farmers and workers collectives, and as ordinary citizens; to fight for justice, harmony and peace for all. Clearly, something resonated… which is why in over 300 places, women sat and many still sit… to be heard, be visible as democratic citizens.”

As Delhi assembly met for a special session on NPR, the women’s statement called on it to “delink the NPR from the Census”. It sought expedition of the “time-bound relief and compensation to families of all who lost lives in the Delhi violence, and full rehabilitation to those displaced.”

It condemned threats to the protests. “The rainbow that is India is being targeted. There is intimidation, FIRs based on falsehoods, threat of arrest against protesters and those who stood with the protests. This politics of intimidation threatens all women, it threatens each citizen, and it must end. Now. This vicious campaign against citizens… must stop immediately.”

The statement added: “We say, across identities of religion, caste, class, gender, sexuality and ability that we oppose the proposed NPR, CAA and NRC. We stand by the protestors and the right to protest.” The statement emphasised continuity of the “struggle to preserve constitutional values, against NPR-CAA-NRC, and protection of the people’s rights to live, speak, believe, work, protest without fear.”

Title: Cops get new guidelines for missing person cases
Content:
Vijayawada: Days after the AP high court pulled up state police in a habeas corpus case, the state government has issued new guidelines to deal with such cases.

The government on Friday issued an order to follow the standard operating procedure (SOP) (Unified Procedure) for taking appropriate action in case of missing persons and issued guidelines to the police to follow judgments of the Supreme Court and the advisory on minor children issued by the ministry of home affairs.

As per the guidelines, all information in respect of missing persons shall be recorded in the General Diary. Police have to register FIR in all missing of person (Adult male women and Children) complaints, may be Zero First Information Report Under Section 154 Criminal Procedure Code, 1973. Cases shall be endorsed by the officer-in-charge of the police station to sub-Inspector for investigation. The investigation shall continue till the missing person is located. The photographs of the missing persons should be published in newspapers and telecast in electronic media. The photographs of the missing shall be given wide publicity.

If the missing person is a minor girl or woman, photographs shall not be published. Make inquiry in the neighborhood, and place of work and study. Inquire whether any past incident of violence in the family is existing. In case of a missing child, whenever the child is traced or comes back on his/her own, the investigation officer shall enquire all relevant angles.

The state government also made clear the role of the investigation officer in missing persons cases. As per the guidelines, the officer shall visit the place from where the person was reportedly missing, contact the family of the missing person and record their statements.

Title: Jaipur Municipal Corporation removes picture of CM, minister from site after BJP complaint
Content:
File photo of Ashok Gehlot

JAIPUR: The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) on Friday lodged a complaint with the state election commission (SEC) that the names and photos of chief minister Ashok Gehlot and urban develpment and housing (UDH) minister Shanti Dhariwal appeared on the website of Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC), in violation of model code conduct (MCC), as the polls to the six newly-formed corporations were announced on Thursday. The JMC removed the photos from its website after the complaint was lodged by the party.

The MCC came into force on Thursday as the SEC on Thursday announced the elections to the posts of 560 ward members in the six newly formed municipal corporations in Jaipur, Kota and Jodhpur. In its complaint to SEC secretary Shyam Singh Rajpurohit and deputy secretary Ashok Kumar Jain, BJP election cell's state chief Nahar Singh wrote, "The election programme was published by the commission yesterday (Thursday). According to the law, the MCC came into effect immediately after the election schedule was announced." Singh stated screenshots bearing photos of CM and Dhariwal were also forwarded to the commission. TNN

Title: Coronavirus scare: For now, Delhi government bans all sports events
Content: NEW DELHI: Delhi government put a temporary ban on all sports gatherings, including the Indian Premier League 2020, seminars and conferences in the wake of novel coronavirus threat. On Friday, it also ordered the immediate shutting down of public swimming pools in the city till March 31.Addressing a press conference, deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia said district magistrates had been asked to ensure that all directives pertaining to the novel coronavirus were implemented. They have also been asked to keep close watch on the possible spread of infection in their respective areas.“Social distancing is the most effective way to stop the spread of Covid-19 in Delhi and India. So it is important to avoid any big event that sees huge public gatherings,” Sisodia said. Delhi has so far reported six cases of positive cases of nCov infection.During a discussion in the special Delhi Assembly session later in the evening, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal said that the coronavirus outbreak was at the containment stage and the Centre and state government had been working together to deal with it. “We have closed schools, cinema halls, universities to contain the spread of infection. The people have supported us in all the precautionary measures we have taken,” Kejriwal said.The CM also emphasised that healthy people shouldn’t use masks but rely on regular washing of hands and use of hand sanitisers to avoid infection. “If you wear a mask, you may touch it get infected. Only infected people should wear mask to avoid spreading the virus,” Kejriwal said.Health minister Satyendar Jain said home quarantine was the best solution for individuals with symptoms of coronavirus infection but revealed that over 500 hospital beds had been readied for Covid-19 cases. He also said that private hospitals should be permitted to run test laboratories.BJP’s Ramvir Singh Bidhuri, leader of the Opposition, urged the AAP government to rope in 96 private hospitals, which were given land on concessional rates, to set up isolation wards and provide free treatment to Covid-19 patients. “The administration must ensure these private health facilities place 5,000 free beds at the disposal of Delhi government and provide free medicines and investigation facilities to coronavirus patients,” Bidhuri said.The BJP legislator also asked the state government to provide masks and hand sanitisers to DTC and DJB workers and direct the daily disinfecting of ATM machines.

Title: This spring, coronavirus leaves Mount Everest out of bounds for mountaineers
Content: KOLKATA: Expedition dreams of scores of mountaineers from Bengal and other parts of India have come to a grinding halt after Nepal government suspended all permits for missions to Mount Everest and other peaks for this season in the wake of the worldwide nCoV outbreak.In a notification issued on Friday afternoon, the mountaineering section of Nepal’s tourism department stated: “This is to notify that climbing permits for expeditions that have already been issued or to be issued for the Spring Season 2020 have been halted at present.”The decision, first in recent memory, left mountaineers like school teacher Rumpa Das in a fix, who had been saving for the last two years and had taken a personal loan of Rs 10 lakh, along with training herself rigorously, to leave for the expedition in three weeks.“It’s like there has been a sudden halt in everything I have done over the years. I still can’t believe it. But there is nothing we can do in situations like these where global safety is the priority. But I will not back down and would continue to train myself harder to either leave for the expedition on August this year or during this time next year,” said Das, who teaches English at a Krishnagore school.Veteran Everester Debashis Biswas, too, had planned an expedition next month to celebrate 10 years of his first feat and this time, he had planned to climb from the China end of the mountain. “Since last month, climbers had started opting out of the expedition on account of worldwide regulations on coronavirus . I was mentally preparing myself for the worst and on Thursday night, I was informed that my permit was officially cancelled,” said Biswas, who now plans to climb the Shishapangma mountain in China some time between August and October if the situation becomes better by that time.Mount Everest lies on the border between Nepal and China-controlled Tibet. On Thursday, the Chinese government had announced that no expeditions would be allowed to run on the Tibet side.According to climbers, this year will be the quietest on the mountain since 2015, when a 7.8 magnitude earthquake had struck the region just as climbers were settling down at Base Camp. But this year, the climbers have been stopped even before setting foot, the first time since 1974. Nepal’s economy depends heavily on the tourism industry. According to an estimate, Everest permits earn the government around $4 million each year.“The cancellation will have a huge impact on the tourism industry in Nepal. It is a testing time for us. Sherpas and other people involved with this industry wait for the entire year for these two months and if there is no expedition, their entire family income is at stake. Even if the government allows permits post May, we can conduct some short expeditions and treks but an Everest expedition is not possible this year,” said Keshab Paudyal, the director of Peak Promotional Hiking agency in Nepal.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Pune: Many schools cancel non-board exams
Content: PUNE: Educational institutes are busy deciding how to go about their scheduled examinations with chief minister Uddhav Thackeray on Friday announcing that schools in the city and Pimpri Chinchwad would remain shut till further orders following the spread of Covid-19 in the state.A circular issued by the education department to all schools stated that teachers, students and other staffers were supposed to remain indoors during the closure period. “If students, teachers or others are found roaming outside, appropriate action will be taken against them by the administration or the police,” the circular stated, adding that the board examinations (standards X and XII) would continue as per schedule.Hutchings High School and Junior College principal Rita Katawati said she has cancelled the ongoing examinations for the non-board classes. “We have cancelled the examination on Saturday. We will wait and watch how long the schools remain closed. We will accordingly decide on re-examination or cancellation of examinations,” she said.A statement issued by Amanora School to the parents read: “With the perceptible threat of pandemic caused by the outbreak of coronavirus and following the orders issued by the Maharashtra government, the Amanora School shall remain closed till further notice for all its students (Nursery to X). Grades III-VIII will be awarded average marks for the exam scheduled tomorrow (Saturday). Parents will be notified of the subsequent updates via the school website and home app.”Vishwashanti Gurukul, an IB World School, has decided to remain closed indefinitely and told its students to study at home. “We request the parents of our boarding students to kindly make travel arrangements for their ward and update the respective ‘house master’ or ‘mistress’ about the same. We advise our boarding students to carry their study material for the Term 2 examinations,” the school said.The institute added that it would keep the students posted on the status of the Term 2 Examinations, if the schools were permitted to reopen. The school requested its Standard X and Standard XII students to remain in the country “as the IB board examinations will happen as per the schedule on the school premises”.HDFC School principal Amruta Prabhu said the scheduled examinations were over and the institute was planning to conduct extra-curricular classes from next week, which stand cancelled now. “We will wait and see how long the schools have to stay shut. Our academic session starts in April. If the closure period extends, we have a contingency plan to conduct online classes and send worksheets to the students,” Prabhu said.The Savitribai Phule Pune University said the authorities would take a decision on the scheduled examinations on Saturday after a review of the situation. “Most of the theoretical examinations were supposed to start after April 10. But other examinations, including viva and practicals, were scheduled. We will take a decision on exams and our future course of action by Saturday afternoon,” said Mahesh Kakade, director of the board of examinations and evaluation, SPPU.Vidya Yeravdekar, principal director of Symbiosis Society , said the school managed by it and the Symbiosis International University would also remain closed and support students through online learning.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Movement restricted across India-Bangladesh border
Content: KOLKATA: Urging people not to panic, chief minister Mamata Banerjee on Friday advised people to remain cautious and avoid large gathering.On Friday, the Centre and the state stepped up measures, including restricting entry/exit through all check-posts along the India-Bangladesh border and deciding to prosecute any retailer caught hoarding masks and sanitizers under The Essential Commodities Act, 1955, which is a non-bailable offence with a seven-year prison term.Speaking at the ‘Khel Samman’ programme, the chief minister said there was no need to panic but safeguards must be taken in wake of the global coronavirus outbreak . “So far, no medicine has been discovered to cure Covid-19 but experts are suggesting a 14-day rest period at home in case of high temperature, not shaking hands with anyone, and keeping 5-metre distance from a person during a conversation,” Banerjee said. “I am no expert, but some people are saying if the mercury rises, it (coronavirus) can be controlled to a great extent. Let's see. No handshakes until the virus goes, greet each other with a Namaste,” she added.Later in the evening, state consumer affairs minister Sadhan Pandey said raids will continue to probe complaints of mask and sanitizer shortage in some pockets. “Strict action will be taken,” he said. An officer said ESA will be slapped against unscrupulous practices by anyone.The India- Bangladesh border in Bengal has been sealed with permission for restricted movements across borders. Only four India-Nepal border check-posts will remain operational. Though the Kartarpur Corridor is currently open, the government will take a decision on it by Saturday. “India-Bangladesh passenger buses and trains will remain suspended till April 15. Along the India-Nepal border, four check posts will remain operational. For citizens of Bhutan and Nepal, visa-free entry to the country will continue,” Anil Malik, additional secretary in the Union home ministry, said.“While diplomats will be allowed to move, restrictions will be imposed on movement of Indians into Bangladesh and Bangladeshi nationals into India. Indians, now in Bangladesh with a valid visa, will be allowed to enter before expiry of their visas. Similarly, a Bangladeshi national with valid document and visa will be allowed to leave India,” said an BSF officer. “But apart from Indians, no one will be allowed to enter,” said RR Sharma, BSF DIG.Earlier in the day, the CM spoke at length on the issue. “Please don't start thinking that you are affected by coronavirus if you start coughing. That is a common symptom of any flu. But if there is high temperature for a prolonged period, get yourself treated by a doctor,” the chief minister said.(With inputs from Roshan Gupta in Siliguri)
