Shanker Singh Meghwanshi was injured in the fight when the accused allegedly attacked him with stones and used derogatory words against their caste. Police registered a case and investigation was started by deputy SP rural.

Title: 3 accused of abducting businessman in Jaipur arrested
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Three persons arrested for kidnapping a businessman for ransom, were on Friday sent to police custody till March 17. The three accused had abducted the diamond merchant Prakash Chopra from Bajaj Nagar police station area on March 11 and the cops found him 12 hours after the investigation was initiated.

The accused were identified as Vikram Gujjar, Rakesh Gujjar and Harish Singh. The victim’s son had lodged a complaint at the local police station that Vikram, who managed a PG hostel owned by his father, had called him on Wednesday afternoon to come to the hostel. Chopra went there but did not return home. The same evening, his wife received a phone call from the victim’s mobile number claiming that Chopra had been abducted and if a ransom of Rs 5 crore was not given, then the accused would bury him alive.

“Seeing the gravity of the situation, we immediately constituted teams and started the investigation. Based on the complaint, we started looking for Vikram and found him. Initially, he denied any knowledge about the abducted, but finally admitted to the crime,” said a police official.

Vikram managed the PG hostel with his cousin Rakesh. The two hailed from Sikar and decided to make quick money by kidnapping their employer. They also roped in Harish and called him from Sikar to Jaipur on March 5. They had been planning the crime for nearly a month.

Elaborating further, the official added, “After questioning Vikram through cyber intelligence, we found the other accused as well. The three accused after kidnapping Chopra had taken him to an isolated location in Shivdaspura following which they took him towards Sikar. Due to the fear of being caught, they left him in the forest area of Nechwa in Sikar. They left him there with his hands and feet tied as well as mouth taped. The teams managed to rescue Chopra within 12 hours of abduction and arrest all three behind the crime.”

According to officials, the accused did not have any significant criminal records and were looking to become rich overnight. Police are interrogating them further and also found the vehicle in which the victim was taken to Sikar after abduction.

Title: Staff roped in for ZP polls to use masks, hand sanitisers
Content:
Panaji: At least 6,000 polling staff, who will interact with lakhs of voters across the state during the March 22 zilla panchayat (ZP) elections, will use face masks and hand sanitisers during the process.

The message is expected to be communicated to all returning officers and assistant returning officers at a meeting to be held in Porvorim on Saturday morning, an official said.

“Supply of hand sanitisers will also be made available at 15 counting centres,” the official added.

Lakhs of voters are expected to show up at 1,210 polling stations across Goa to cast their vote in the elections that are being held on party lines. A total of 8.3 lakh citizens are eligible to vote for 50 ZP representatives out of a total of 203 candidates.

The ZP election will also use postal ballots. The distribution of these ballots as well as storage and collection of printed ballot paper will be discussed at the meeting scheduled for Saturday.

CCTV arrangements will be made at counting centres. The counting centre plan will also be finalised.

Title: Kin scan CCTVs, help Delhi Police nab killer car owner
Content:
Ayush Grover was returning from his coaching classes when a Creta car hit his bike from behind

NEW DELHI: Family members of a 21-year-old law student who was run over by an SUV scanned footage from about 30 CCTV cameras and managed to identify the car and its owner. The driver, identified as a businessman from West Delhi, was later arrested by police.

DCP(west) Deepak Purohit said that the accident took place near Tihar Jail’s gate number 4 around 12 noon on Wednesday. Ayush Grover, the victim, was returning from his coaching classes when a brown Creta car being driven by the accused, Sharad, hit his bike from behind.

The car dragged Grover and his bike for a few metres before the driver reversed and fled, eyewitnesses told the cops. Grover managed to pull himself up, but later collapsed due to excessive bleeding from his mouth. He was taken to a private hospital by a woman paaserby, but was declared dead there.

Doctors later told the family members that Grover’s rib had fractured and pierced his lungs leading to excessive internal bleeding.

An FIR was registered for causing death due to negligence and dangerous driving.

Baljeet Singh, a family friend who helped the family track down the driver, said that while the cops were probing the case, Grover’s relatives started scanning for CCTV camera footage from the area. "We scanned through several cameras some of which showed the car. We managed to track down the owner from the vehicle number using an app,” Singh added.

The data was shared with police following which a team tracked down the owner of the car and nabbed him.

During interrogation, Sharad told the cops that he had panicked after the incident. He had returned to check on Grover and found him sitting on the footpath. He presumed that the victim would recover and hence left the spot.

Title: TN MP raises Revanth’s arrest in LS
Content:
Hyderabad: Malkajgiri MP A Revanth Reddy ’s arrest was raised in the Lok Sabha by Congress MP from Tamil Nadu S Jothimani who said he was arrested for political reasons. She urged speaker Om Birla to seek reasons for Revanth’s arrest and take an appropriate action.

In a letter to Birla, she said Revanth was arrested for political reasons. She sought an adjournment motion over the issue and said Revanth was arrested without due procedure.

The supporters of Revanth also alleged that despite MPs Komatireddy Venkat Reddy and Uttam Kumar Reddy being from Telangana, it was unfortunate that they did not raise the issue in Parliament. However, both Venkat Reddy and Uttam had condemned the arrest and demanded his release.

T Cong infighting to the fore

Hyderabad: Infighting within Telangana Congress has once again come to the fore with supporters of Revanth Reddy and those of other leaders in race for TPCC chief post levelling allegations against each other and also complaining to party interim president Sonia Gandhi. Responding seriously to the situation, AICC general secretary incharge of Telangana RC Khuntia warned leaders against airing their views in public.

Title: FSTC to fly in with new airline FlyBig
Content:
Hyderabad: The promoters of Gurugram-based aviation training player Flight Simulation Technique Centre (FSTC), which has pilot training centres in Gurugram and Hyderabad, are all set to fly in a new airline -- FlyBig – by April this year and are awaiting the requisite approvals from the civil aviation regulator, a top FSTC official said.

“We are all set to launch our own airline FlyBig by the first week of April. We are currently undergoing AOC (air operator certificate) process with the DCGA and expect it to be completed by March end,” Capt Sanjay Mandavia, managing director & CEO, FSTC, told TOI here.

He said the promoters are pumping in $50 million into the airline, which will be based out of Indore. “We plan to launch our first flight from Indore to Gondia and through Gondia connect Indore to Hyderabad. We also plant to connect Ratnagiri via Pune,” Mandavia said, adding that the airline will also develop hubs at Varanasi and Guwahati in the second and third phase of operations.

The yet to be launched has already leased three ATR-72 aircraft and plans to lease another seven ATR-72s to reach a fleet of 10 aircraft for the next phases of rollout, Mandavia said.

“In the first phase, which we expect to launch by the first week of April, we will have the three aircraft stationed at Indore from where we will connect to Jabalpur, Pune and Lucknow. In the second phase, we will station three aircraft at Varanasi by the middle of this year and station another three aircraft in Guwahati by September 2020,” he explained.

Title: 74% Waqf land encroached, MIM wants judicial probe: Akbaruddin Owaisi
Content: HYDERABAD: Raising serious concerns over rampant encroachment of Waqf properties, AIMIM floor leader Akbaruddin Owaisi said in the assembly on Friday that 57,000 acres of a total 77,538 acres had been grabbed by land sharks in various parts of Telangana.Urging the state government to order a judicial inquiry by a retired high court judge or by CBI or CID into irregularities in Telangana State Waqf Board , the MIM MLA said a Waqf properties protection cell should be constituted with a corpus of Rs 100 crore.He said 74% of Waqf land being grabbed in the last 20 years was staggering and that no effort had been made to protect the land.Speaking during a debate on welfare schemes in the House, Akbaruddin said the worst hit is Medak where 99% of Waqf land was usurped. “In a survey done on properties being held by 33,929 Waqf institutions, 82% of land in Hyderabad is under clutches of land-grabbers,” he rued.Akbaruddin said a second survey was ordered in March, 2001 and a survey commissioner was appointed. According to the survey, there were more number of Waqf institutions with a higher acreage of land than what was reported in the first survey. “GHMC had taken over 44 Waqf properties for road-widening for Hyderabad Metro Rail project, but a compensation of Rs 361 crore is yet to be released for the affected parties,” he said.He alleged several irregularities were reported in the Waqf Board during recruitments. “Some persons who did not even complete class X and Intermediate have been given out of turn promotions,” he complained.He also urged the government to order a probe into the no-objection certificates (NOCs) issued by the Waqf Board in the last few years.Lauding the government on welfare schemes, Akbaruddin said the TRS government had been giving top priority for minority welfare and 53 new schemes were being implemented.

Title: Coronavirus in Bihar: Schools, colleges in Bihar to remain shut till March 31
Content: PATNA: Bihar government on Friday ordered closure of all schools, colleges, private coaching institutes, cinema halls, parks and several other public places till March 31 as a preventive measure against coronavirus (Covid-19). The state health department has cancelled all kinds of leave of doctors and support staff. The government also deferred its Bihar Diwas celebrations, which were scheduled from March 22 to 24.The state government will review the situation in a couple of days and, if needed, will invoke Epidemic Act to restrict public gatherings. The decisions were taken in a meeting chaired by CM Nitish Kumar on Friday.Briefing the media, chief secretary Deepak Kumar said no cultural and sports event will be held in the state till March 31 and all the bookings for such events will be cancelled. Even examination held by government organizations have been cancelled. The chief secretary said the state government will also ask private schools to defer their internal examinations. “The motive behind such measures is to ask people to stay indoors and limit their outdoor activities,” Deepak said.He also claimed that the state government was mulling to call government officials to offices on alternate days to prevent large gathering. “The general administration department will come up with a notification and office head will decide on whom to call and when,” he said.All government medical college and hospitals, including Patna Medical College and Hospital (PMCH) and Indira Gandhi Institute of Medical Sciences (IGIMS) will have additional 100 ventilators to tackle any emergency situation. Also, apart from Rajendra Memorial Research Institute of Medical Sciences (RMRI), the only centre for Covid-19 test in Bihar at present, the facility of test will also be started at AIIMS-Patna, PMCH and IGIMS.As on Friday, altogether 142 people were under observation for suspected symptoms and 73 had been discharged so far. No positive case has been detected in Bihar so far.Deepak said since anganwadi centres have been closed till March 31, the corresponding amount will be transferred in the bank accounts of the beneficiaries. Same process will be adopted for the beneficiaries of midday meal scheme.Though no decision on closure of commercial malls have been taken as of now, Deepak said it may be decided in another meeting on Monday if the Epidemic Act is invoked. He said steps were also being taken to increase the vigil and screenings at India-Nepal border.

Title: Covid-19 scare in Goa: To stay afloat, hoteliers slash tariffs, woo locals
Content: PANAJI: Hotels across the board slashed tariffs after the state government suspended all tourist visas to contain further spread of Covid-19. Occupancy at hotels had dropped slightly following booking cancellations amid the coronavirus crises during the last fortnight, but the latest development has compelled hotel operators to cut tariffs even further to keep them afloat for the next two months.While five-star hotels have reduced their rates by 25-30 %, the drop in tariffs of three-star properties is sharper. Non-starred hotels and guest houses have gone ahead and halved their rates. To stay afloat in these distressing times, some hotels operators have even chosen to woo the local population by offering attractive packages.Confirming this, Travel and Tourism Association (TTAG) president, Savio Messias, said while starred hotels always offered brunch deals aimed at locals, the packages have been broadened to include overnight stays as well.Francisco de Braganca, a hotelier based in North Goa, said ‘rationalisation of tariff’ was now the mantra. “Hotels that reacted immediately after the Centre suspended all tourist visas will be able to safeguard their interests to some extent,” he said. Braganca also said that although the situation is fluid, it remains difficult to predict if the condition will improve or only deteriorate further.Over the past decade, Goa has also become popular as a meeting, incentives, conferences and exhibitions (MICE) destination. Corporates events that have been held here during the monsoon have resulted in a considerable spike in hotel occupancy during the lean period. But Ralf de Souza, another North Goa-based hotelier, said this segment did not do well itself during the last monsoon, thanks to the economic slump. “As corporates cut costs, fewer conferences and exhibitions were held in the state,” he said.Under normal circumstances, Goa sees good tourist footfalls in April and May. While the domestic and foreign tourist flow generally ebbs by the first week of May, de Souza feels that the number of domestic holidaymakers, too, will dwindle earlier than usual due to Covid-19 fears.“The government has advised against mass gatherings, and we haven’t received many booking inquiries from domestic visitors so far,” he said, indicating that the next three months could be bleak for tourism-dependent trades.Braganca, however, said a lot will depend on how the Covid-19 scenario unfolds across India. “A cautious approach is the need of the hour during these trying times,” he said.

Title: Conduct awareness events in varsities: Governor Kalraj Mishra
Content: JAIPUR: Governor Kalraj Mishra directed officials on Friday to conduct awareness programmes on coronavirus in universities. He said universities too should run activities to spread awareness on COVID-19 among the people in their vicinity. The governor was chairing a high-level meeting with officials to review the situation in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak. He was briefed about the measures taken by the state government to control the situation.The governor asked officials to continue with the efforts and said active public participation in combating the situation was important. Chief secretary DB Gupta informed the governor that three persons, including an Italian couple, had tested positive for coronavirus in Rajasthan so far. He said the Disaster Management Act was being implemented effectively in the state. Additional Chief Secretary, Medical and Health, Rohit Kumar Singh, Medical Education Secretary Vaibhav Galaria , Secretary to the Governor Subir Kumar, SMS Medical College principal Dr Sudhir Bhandari and other officials were present at the meeting. PTI

Title: Smart app makes room for e-library
Content:
Lucknow: In addition to civic convenience, the Smart City app is designed to gift knowledge to residents young and old.

While the e-library section of the app hosts a number of books on various topics for children and teenagers, it also has study materials for CBSE students of Classes X to XII. A National Geography window for youngsters further comprises wildlife quiz and trivia, among other things.

For those with a knack for current affairs, the app has a ‘Press Reader’ section for daily news, besides access to magazines on sports, lifestyle, automobile, aviation, food, fashion and a lot more.

According to LMC officials, the civic body will upload different genre of tomes, including novels by famous authors, to attract bookworms. “We are in contact with a private firm for uploading novels and storybooks. The service will be provided on the app very soon,” said Smart City project general manager Fareed Zaidi. The app is available on both Android and iOS platforms. It offers services such as information on public toilets, food joints, parking lots and community halls.

Title: Rape & murder: Man gets double life term
Content:
Kannur: The additional district sessions court at Thalassery on Friday awarded double life imprisonment to a youth for raping and murdering a woman, besides ordering 10 years’ additional jail term for robbing of the victim.

Judge P N Vinod pronounced the sentence after finding K V Ansar guilty of rape , murder and robbery. The crime was reported from Peringathur in the district on August 14, 2017.

Ansar, a local resident, waylaid the 39-year-old woman, and suffocated her when she resisted. As she fell unconscious, he dragged her to a nearby canal and raped her.

After the act, he robbed the woman of her ornaments and held her head under the water till she died. The woman was on her way to a market when she was fatally assaulted. The judge also slapped a fine of Rs 1 lakh on the convict. He would undergo another year in prison if he failed to pay up. Ansar would spend 10 years in jail for robbery, before the concurrent double life imprisonment for rape and murder.

The victim’s husband and daughter were present when the court pronounced the punishment.

Title: 2k govt employees taken into custody
Content: Hyderabad: Over 2,000 state government employees were taken into preventive custody as they took out a protest rally towards assembly on Friday. They were demanding that government ensure Pay Revision Commission submits its report. They were released later. TNN

Title: Two more test negative for Covid-19 at GMC
Content: Panaji: Two persons isolated in ward 113 of the Goa Medical College (GMC) and Hospital (GMC) in Bambolim since the last two days, have tested negative for Covid-19.The laboratory report of the third person suspected of having the disease who was placed in isolation on Thursday evening, is awaited.Health minister Vishwajit Rane told reporters on Friday that two of the three quarantined in GMC have tested negative for Covid-19. “As many as 16 persons have been isolated in GMC so far. Fifteen tested negative for Covid-19, while the report of one is expected on Saturday. Goa government sent samples for testing to a laboratory in Nashik,” Rane said.As many as 39 persons have been home quarantined. Since January 29, there have been 95 cumulative cases under home quarantine.The state government has stepped up efforts after a spike in cases detected in neighbouring states. It has posted eight doctors at Dabolim International Airport and also a paramedic.GMC scheduled a training programme on Covid-19 for all doctors, healthcare workers and staff of the hospital during the next few days.

Title: Inbound travel show GITB falls victim to coronavirus
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Leading travel and tourism mart Great Indian Travel Bazaar (GITB), scheduled to be held from April 19-21 in Jaipur, was postponed on Friday by the government of Rajasthan and organising partner FICCI.

The inbound travel mart is dependent on foreign buyers but with the visa suspension in place till April 15, it was not feasible to hold the event, the organisers said. Last year, 280 foreign buyers had participated in the show.

Sreya Guha, principal secretary, department of tourism, art and culture, said, “While it is indeed a big disappointment for all of us, we have chosen to take this decision in the best interest of our participants. We look forward to come up with the new dates for the 12th edition of GITB once the situation stabilizes.”

GITB is one of the largest and exclusive inbound tourism marts. It is organized jointly by department of tourism, Union tourism ministry and FICCI since year 2008. In the 11th edition of GITB held from April 28 to 30 last year, 290 foreign tour operators from 47 countries had participated and 290 exhibitors from tourism industry had showcased their products for the global travel and tour operators. About 11,236 structured and pre-scheduled business-to-business meetings were held during the event.

ITB Berlin, one of the world’s largest annual travel trade shows, was cancelled on February 28 due to the coronavirus outbreak.

Title: Mumbai University parked Rs 142 crore in Yes Bank before crisis erupted
Content:
In a statement issued by the university, it said the money was deposited in 12 banks in 2019 and nine in 2020.

MUMBAI: Mumbai University deposited Rs 142 crore in crisis-ridden Yes Bank— all in February in three instalments, a decision that has drawn flak its senate members. The last deposit of Rs 37 crore was made on February 29, barely four days before Reserve Bank of India imposed a moratorium on withdrawals from the bank.

Senate members alleged “misappropriation” of funds and sought an immediate inquiry into the matter during the university’s budget meeting on Friday. Nagpur University is another public varsity to have parked Rs 193 crore in the bank.

The matter was brought to light by Supriya Karande, a senate member, on the second day of the senate’s budget session. The university has invested around Rs 697 crore across banks, of which Rs 142 was parked in Yes Bank as it offered the highest interest rate of 8.05%, said university officials. Members, though, said the bank was in the grips of a crisis for several months and it made no sense to deposit funds as late as in February this year.

They said though RBI has assured that depositors’ money is safe, investment policies need to be investigated. The funds are money collected as development fund, revaluation fees, exam fees and affiliation fees from colleges.

In a statement issued by the university, it said the money was deposited in 12 banks in 2019 and nine in 2020. During a senate proceeding, a university official said the varsity deposited Rs 45 crore on Feburary 11, Rs 59 crore on February 20, and the last instalment of Rs 37 crore on February 29 this year in Yes Bank. Senate member from Yuva Sena , Pradeep Sawant, alleged it was a scam.

“They claimed that a resolution was passed in a management council meeting in September 2018. However, that meeting was based on the government’s directive asking universities to invest in banks with a net worth of Rs 4,000 crore. Yes Bank was not mentioned specifically in the government directive. They could have invested in public sector banks,” said Sawant.

A senate member said even if a decision was taken earlier, it should have been revised, considering the bank’s status. On members’ demand, vice-chancellor Suhas Pednekar decided to form a fact-finding committee and appointed senate member Sanjay Shetye as its head. The committee will probe the decision and the varsity’s investment policies to suggest measures.

Late at night, the university senate passed a budget outlay of Rs 809 crore for 2020-21—Rs 114 crore more than last year. It set aside Rs 22 crore to make the campus disabled-friendly and Rs 40 crore for the sub-campuses.

Title: Canada to welcome one million immigrants over next 3 yrs
Content:
Mumbai: Canada aims to welcome over 10 lakh immigrants over the next three years, up to 2022. This spells good news for skilled Indians , especially those in the technology sector. Given the challenges thrown up by the US immigration policies, Canada has emerged as an attractive alternate destination.

According to a press release by Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC), the government agency that oversees immigration, the target is to admit up to 3.41 lakh permanent residents in 2020, increase it to 3.51 lakh in 2021 and 3.61 lakh in 2022.

TOI had, in its February 13 edition, analysed the open source data made available by the Canadian government for 2019. During this year, one in four foreigners granted permanent resident (PR) status was an Indian. Of the 3.41 lakh such individuals admitted in 2019, 25.1% or 85,585 were from India. According to immigration experts, India is likely to continue to be the top source country as a large number of skilled workers, especially in the tech sector, will be drawn from India. The Canadian PR is akin to a US green card , with the family acquiring the right to live, work or study anywhere in Canada with a subsequent path to citizenship.

The multi-year immigration plan was tabled in Canada’s Parliament recently, by IRCC minister Marco Mendicino.

“Our immigration system benefits all Canadians by strengthening the middle class, keeping families together and building strong and inclusive communities. This increase in immigration levels supports a system that will help Canadian business create good middle class jobs and grow the economy while ensuring Canada continues to meet its humanitarian obligations around the world,” he stated.

Over the past few years, Canada has increasingly widened its doors to welcome immigrants, especially skilled ones, to meet the demographic challenges of an ageing population and to compete and win in a competitive global marketplace.

More than half of the new immigrants will be via the economic class, such as through the Express Entry programs and the Provincial Nominee Programs. Canada’s immigration system is point based — the most recent round in March had seen a cut-off score of 471 points and 3,900 invitations for permanent residency will be issued.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Pune: CM advises to visit malls if absolutely necessary
Content: PUNE: Five new cases of coronavirus — two in Nagpur and one each in Mumbai, Pune and Ahmednagar — were reported on Friday, taking Maharashtra’s count of infected individuals to 19.The state government invoked the Epidemic Diseases Act on the day and chief minister Uddhav Thackeray ordered the closure of cinema-halls, gymnasiums and swimming pools in Mumbai, Thane, Navi Mumbai, Nagpur, Pune and Pimpri-Chinchwad till March 30. The order came into effect from Friday midnight.Schools and colleges in Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad will remain shut till further orders. “Since the number of cases in Pune is the highest (10), it has been decided to shut schools and colleges in Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad area till March 30. The ongoing 10th and 12th board exams will go on as per schedule,” Thackeray said. He clarified that there was no need to shut schools and colleges in any other city as of now.The 21-year-old Pune student who tested positive on Friday lives on Mangaldas Road and had returned to Mumbai from Seattle via Frankfurt on a Lufthansa flight on March 10. His close contacts were being tracked.The Ahmednagar man was isolated at a state-run hospital in his city on Thursday. State health officials said he was part of the 40-member group that had visited Dubai from February 23 to 29. A woman in Mumbai also tested positive on Friday. She is the wife of a 64-year-old man who was admitted to the ICU of a hospital after testing positive.In Nagpur, the 43-year-old wife of a man who was diagnosed as the city’s first case and his 45-year-old colleague tested positive. The two had returned from the US via Doha on the same flight on March 6.Meanwhile, Thackeray clarified that malls and restaurants were not being closed but people should not visit there unless absolutely necessary. He also urged private sector companies to allow employees to work from home.Event organisers have been asked not to hold social, political and religious gatherings, Thackeray said, adding that permissions granted earlier stand cancelled. He also urged people to avoid unnecessary travel but said bus and train services cannot be stopped as they are essential services.The Pune district administration has readied 510 beds to be used in isolation facilities — 370 in Pune city and 140 in Pimpri Chinchwad.“There is no need to panic as there is no local transmission. Containment measures are being carried out in areas from where people have tested positive,” divisional commissioner Deepak Mhaisekar said.Apart from 10 positive cases in Pune, three cases each are from Mumbai and Nagpur, and one from Thane. Of the total 17 cases in the state, 15 were people who had returned from places like Dubai, France and the US. Nine of the 10 patients in Pune were people who had travelled abroad, Mhaisekar said.As per the Centre’s advisory, passengers coming from China, South Korea, Italy, France, Germany, Spain and Iran are quarantined whether or not they show symptoms of coronavirus.Pune collector Naval Kishore Ram said data received from the house-to-house drive and tour operators showed that 170 people were out of the country in the last one month. “We are checking whether they had travelled to high-risk countries. The administration has also reached out to nearly 8 lakh mobile operators to ensure that they send out messages giving general information and on reporting foreign travel to the authorities,” he said.Mhaisekar said that on Friday, a Sangli woman was admitted to the Naidu hospital with her one-year-old child after she said she was not well and that she had travelled to Dubai.Mhaisekar said a notice would be issued and action would be taken against shops found hoarding or charging extra for masks and sanitisers or even providing substandard ones. He urged people to avoid panic buying and hoarding.

Title: Fewer flyers: Jaipur-Kuala Lumpur flight suspended amid coronavirus scare
Content: JAIPUR: Rapid decline in the passenger numbers amidst the corona scare, the Jaipur to Kuala Lumpur flight has been suspended till further orders. Also, the Oman Airways flight that operates between Jaipur and Muscat has been restricted for 18 days operations in a month. Airport authorities at Jaipur on Friday did not rule out the possibility of suspension of other international flights in the coming days.According to the airport sources, the Jaipur to Kuala Lumpur flight was getting a very poor load factory and initially it remained cancelled due to the excessive cancellations by the passengers.“Since the airlines is not getting the required load of the passengers, they have decided to suspend their operations from Jaipur to Kuala Lumpur till further orders,” said a senior officer at the air traffic control at Jaipur airport on Friday.Meanwhile, the Oman Airways that operates a regular flight between Jaipur to Muscat has also been affected amid the corona scare in Jaipur where three patients have been tested positive of corona virus.“We have decided to operate for 18 days in the month of March till further orders. Also, we will oversee and review the situation to take further decision on suspending the flight in the coming days,” said an officer with the airways.Every passenger visiting Jaipur airport in an international flight is been screened properly by a joint team of health officials and airport authorities. “At the arrivals we have also kept sanitizers for the utility and safety of the passengers. Any passenger who is having symptoms is been checked and taken for further examination by the health authorities from the airport,” said an officer.

Title: RTC revenue sees Rs 1.5cr rise per day
Content:
Hyderabad: The earnings of TSRTC have increased from Rs 11 crore per day to Rs 12.50 crore per day as a result of the hike in bus ticket charges from December 3, 2019. The salaries of the RTC employees are being paid from its own income for the past two months without depending on government to release funds.

During question hour on Friday, Transport minister P Ajay Kumar informed the assembly that several passenger friendly initiativeare being taken up to improve the occupancy ratio in RTC buses and earn more revenue.

Responding to requests from MLAs for new bus depots and other facilities in their constituencies, the minister appealed to them to allocate funds from their constituency development fund to help RTC overcome losses.

“ Once the finances of RTC stabilizes, every request would be looked into,” he said. TNN

Title: Delhi: Four bike-borne men shoot at, stab businessman; flee with Rs 60,000
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: Four men on two motorcycles chased, shot at and then stabbed a 54-year-old businessman before fleeing with a bag containing Rs 60,000 near a Delhi Metro station in west Delhi on Thursday night.

The incident took place near Ashoka Park metro station around 9.45pm. The victim, Alauddin, is a resident of Sadar Bazar in old Delhi but runs a business from west Delhi’s Madipur. On Thursday evening, he shut his shop as usual and got into an Eeco car with his brother and two staffers. He was seated in the rear and had a bag containing the day’s collection of around Rs 60,000.

The robbers began following the Eeco. The car was crossing Punjabi Bagh when the robbers opened fire. When the driver had to stop at the traffic signal at Ashoka Park metro station, four men on two bikes intercepted the car and threatened the occupants with a pistol.

One of the men opened fire, but the bullet hit the car’s panel. When Alauddin tried to open the door to escape, the robbers caught him and stabbed him with a dagger. The four men also assaulted one of the persons accompanying the victim.

As the businessman fell down bleeding, an assailant grabbed the cash bag from under the seat. The quartet then rode away waving their pistols and threatening the victims if they dared follow them.

Alauddin and the other men were rushed to the hospital and admitted for treatment. Their statements were recorded and a case lodged. DCP (West) Deepak Purohit said, “An FIR for armed robbery under IPC sections 392 (punishment for robbery) and 397 (robbery, or dacoity, with attempt to cause death or grievous hurt) was registered at Punjabi Bagh police station.”

Sources said that the Crime Branch and special staff unit of the district police will assist in the investigation. They are already probing the role of criminals of outer and southwest Delhi. CCTV footage from cameras around the metro stations on the route taken by the robbers is being checked for clues. The staffers who accompanied Alauddin are also being questioned.

A similar incident had taken place on February 29 in southeast Delhi’s Amar Colony and an employee of a businessman had been shot dead during a robbery bid. Contrary to earlier reports that Rs 2.7 lakh had been robbed, police recently arrested three men in the case and claimed Rs 16 lakh of the actual Rs 73 lakh looted had been recovered.

Title: Covid-19 scare in Aurangabad: Civic body’s GB meeting called off
Content: AURANGABAD: The meeting of the civic administration’s general body scheduled for Friday has been cancelled in the wake of the outbreak of coronavirus . Usually, around 250 to 300 individuals gather for the meeting.Mayor Nandkumar Ghodele said on Friday that the threat of coronavirus outbreak loomed large in Aurangabad . “While the state has had quite a few patients who have been infected with the virus, it is not advisable to have large gathering in enclosed spaces. Hece, the GB meeting scheduled to be held on Friday was cancelled,” said Ghodele. No other date for the meeting has been issued so far.Incidentally, during the GB meeting on March 4, civic chief Astik Kumar Pandey had raised concerns about the large number of people gathering at one location. There are 115 members of the general body. Apart from them, around 100 employees of the civic body and 50 to 60 news reporters are present in the GB hall during the meeting.tnn

Title: Rajasthan to adopt Centre’s norms for coronavirus screening at airports
Content: JAIPUR: The health department will adopt the Standard Operating Practice (SOP) fixed by the Union health ministry for the categorization of passengers for Covid-19 coming from China, Democratic Republic of Korea, France, Germany, Spain, Italy and Iran for the screening at various airports in the state.Senior officials of the health department on Friday given nod to the SOP which would be followed for the categorization of the persons having symptoms of corona virus.The passengers from these countries have been categorized into A, B and C. “Category A is kept for a high risk passenger who has fever, cough, shortness of breath with a history of travel to or residence of a country/area or territory reporting local transmission of Covid-19 during 14 days prior to the symptoms,” said Ravi Prakash , additional director, rural health.Under the category A, the patients with acute respiratory illness and having been in contact with the Covid-19 case in the last 14 days prior to the onset of symptoms would also be covered. “In this case, this category of patients would be segregated from other patients and would be sent for isolation,” said a senior officer.Officials added that category B is for patients with moderate risk. “Under this category, an asymptomatic passenger coming from China, Democratic Republic of Korea, France Germany , Spain, Italy, Iran and which are elderly (above 60 years) and have hypertension, diabetes and asthma are covered. These would be directly shifted place having quarantine facility and would be monitored by the government for next 14 days. In case they develop symptoms, they should be isolated,” said an officer.The category C for an asymptomatic passenger coming from any Covid-19 affected countries including the passengers coming from China, Democratic Republic of Korea, France Germany, Spain, Italy, Iran. “These would be kept under home quarantine and will be monitored by IDSP (Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme) network.

Title: 300 parks under LMC to get over Rs 4-crore makeover
Content:
Lucknow: Following in the footsteps of Lucknow Development Authority, Lucknow Municipal Corporation has decided to renovate and upgrade all the 300-odd parks under its jurisdiction.

According to LMC officials, these parks will be developed on the lines of the LDA project. Each park will have amenities like children’s zone, open-air gym and complaint kiosk, besides good seating arrangements and neat pathways. Wall paintings and sculptures will add the much-needed aesthetic touch. The civic body is also planning to provide Wi-Fi service in eight of the parks. At present, LMC offers free internet at Jhandi Wala Park in Lalbagh and Dayanidhan Park in Kaiserbagh.

Revamp of the parks, which are mostly in residential areas, is expected to begin in the first week of March and LMC will loosen its purse strings to spend around Rs 4 crore on the project.

LMC chief engineer Manish Singh said they expected work to be over in a couple of months.

Title: Coronavirus in Jaipur: Italian shows recovery signs, may be taken off ventilator
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: The condition of the Italian tourist, who was the first positive case of Covid-19 in the state, is improving day-by-day.

The oxygen saturation level without the BiPAP and other equipment is been maintained by the patient at regular intervals. Doctors treating him are now mulling over removing the lifesaving equipment if he continues to show similar signs in the coming days. Likewise, there was no further deterioration in the condition of the 84-year-old Indian who was tested positive when he arrived in Jaipur from Dubai. Till Friday, Rajasthan has registered three positive cases and 370 negative cases.

Health officials said the situation is under control and many who were quarantined have been discharged. “There is a patient from Jodhpur, whose reports are also negative. Also, the Italian tourist is gradually improving as per the doctors. His wife has already been shifted to the Rajasthan University of Health Sciences (RUHS) Medical College since she was tested negative on Thursday,” Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary (ACS), medical and health, told TOI on Friday.

Now, the state has only two patients undergoing treatment as coronapositive cases — the Italian tourist and an 85-year-old Indian who returned from Dubai.

About the clinical condition of the Italian tourist, Dr D S Meena, superintendent, SMS Hospital , said, “We are removing his BiPAP mask on and off for two hours. He is showing very good signs of improvement as his oxygen saturation is properly maintained while his mask is off. If he shows similar signs of improvement, we may remove the BiPAP and other equipment.”

He added that the 84-year-old Indian who came from Dubai and was tested positive is also showing signs of improvement. “His condition is stable. He is showing signs of improvement. A team of doctors and paramedical staff is treating him as per guidelines,” a senior doctor at the SMS hospital said.

Meanwhile, the ACS, medical and health, spoke to health officials of various districts via video conferencing to take stock of the measures taken in the wake of corona scare. “So far, we have identified 482 people who came in contact with those who were tested positive. These are the ones who are under observation at their respective homes by the paramedical staff and doctors,” Singh added.

“We have 23 patients admitted in the isolation wards, including 11 at SMS, five at RUHS, two in Kota, three in Jhunjhunu and one each in Jodhpur and Udaipur,” he added.

Title: Missing pharmacist from Delhi found murdered in UP
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: The 23-year-old woman pharmacist, who had gone missing from South Delhi’s Ambedkar Nagar area on February 5, was murdered and her body dumped in Rampur, Uttar Pradesh . After her body could not be indetified, the cops in the neighbouring state had cremated her on February 6.

The body of Priyanka was found with a rope in her neck. Her face was bludgeoned several times using a blunt object to conceal her identity.

A police probe has revealed that she was in a relationship with her distant relative, Harish, who also worked as a pharmacist at a hospital in South Delhi.

“We suspect Harish murdered Priyanka as his wedding was getting fixed elsewhere. He was earlier called for questioning after his calls surfaced in Priyanka’s call log, but he was not co-operative. He had also applied for anticipatory bail on February 22 which was dismissed by the court. He is absconding since then,” said a senior police officer.

The officer added that on the day of the crime, the mobile phone location of Harish was also near his ancestral home, which is hardly 100 kilometres away from the spot where the victim’s body was found. Priyanka’s mobile phone was switched off 50-60 kilometres away from that place.

On February 9, one of her uncles had reported about her absence. On February 18, another uncle of the victim gave a complaint to police. A case of abduction was subsequently registered. On March 10, Delhi Police received an information from a Rampur police station about an unidentified body found in their area. Priyanka’s photograph matched with that of the victim. Her parents who stay in Uttarakhand also confirmed the same. A team of Delhi Police officers, along with the parents of the victim, later left for Rampur.

Meanwhile, Priyanka’s roommate as well as the woman whom Harish was supposed to marry have also been questioned in this regard.

Title: Nagpur: Wife, colleague of Covid-19 patient test positive
Content:
More on Covid-19

NAGPUR: A 43-year-old woman and a 45-year-old man working with an IT firm in the city were found to have contracted the novel coronavirus after their test reports were found positive on Friday. While the woman, a training coordinator at a nursery school, is the wife of the IT professional who was the first from city to test positive for Covid-19 virus, the man is his colleague in the same company. The duo returned from the US via Doha in the same flight on March 6.Divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar told TOI that the condition of the new patients is stable and both are in the isolation ward at Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH). “The doctors have started treatment and they would be under observation,” he said.At GMCH, two teams of doctors and paramedical staff are treating these two patients. At present, they are not showing any symptoms. So, doctors are constantly monitoring various general health parameters like temperature and BP periodically. The treating doctors have been given special personal protective equipment, heavy-duty gloves, masks, face shield, long gowns and closed shoes.These two Covid-19 positive patients were among the 14 persons who were in close contact with the IT professional ever since he landed in the city on March 6. The remaining 12, including his son and daughter, were discharged after their test reports were found to be negative. But they were advised to remain in home isolation and take precautions for at least two weeks.Medical superintendent of GMCH Dr Avinash Gawande informed that four more suspects reported themselves to the GMCH on Friday. Two of them tested negative. The authorities said, “Other samples need to be tested again tomorrow as results are inconclusive.”“They are aged about 36, 43, 53, and 34 years. They are working in the same company and travelled with the first Covid-19 positive patient,” he said.The 45-year-old IT professional developed symptoms after he landed in the city and got himself admitted. He’s currently admitted in Indira Gandhi Government Medical College and Hospital (IGGMCH), where he’s undergoing treatment.“We’re now trying to trace out persons who came in contact with two new cases and also the places they visited in last six days. Those who contacted would be also be tested and kept in the isolation ward to avoid any further spread,” Kumar said.While asking the citizens not to panic, the commissioner ruled out closing down of schools and colleges due to increasing number of cases stating that the state government would take a final call on the issue as the problem arising out of it was not limited to Nagpur alone.“Anyone suspecting symptoms should immediately put himself/herself into the self-insolation for 14 days at their homes only, ” Kumar said.During the media interaction in afternoon, Divisional deputy director of health services Dr Sanjay Jaiswal informed that number of Covid-19 cases had rose to the tree following detection of two more cases. Collector Ravindra Thakare however adopted a cautious approach stating that divisional commissioner was taking a review and only after confirmation from doctors, he would officially declare addition of two more cases.Both Kumar and Thakre assured that the district administration had fully geared up for tackling the menace if it turned into an endemic. “We’ve set up isolation wards in MLA Hostel and also in GMCH and IGGMCH. Even private hospitals were asked to remain on alert. Over, 300 isolation beds have been kept ready for the patients as of now. We’ve also started round ‘o’clock helplines from Thursday. We’ve received about 28 complaints of which 20 received in the control room of collectorate and ten at the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) helplines,” they said.

Title: Foreigners choose to stay put in Goa despite coronavirus scare
Content: CALANGUTE/COLVA: The spread of coronavirus around the world is causing a ripple effect, with several countries, including India, imposing air travel restrictions. With many beginning to cancel their holidays to Goa, some foreign visitors who are already in the state have decided against altering their travel plans.Speaking to TOI, a group of Russian tourists in the Calangute-Candolim beach belt said they are enjoying their stay and have no plans to curtail their holiday. “There is no problem for us as we can still fly back. It’s only a problem for those who want to come to Goa and enjoy the lovely weather here,” they said.Some chartered tourists said they expect to fly back at the end of their 10-day holiday. Another group of Russian tourists who have been in Goa for nearly two months, said they would be staying for another month as scheduled.“I think this whole coronavirus scare is just a hype. I feel completely safe in India, and I’m not going to change my travel itinerary just because of coronavirus. I feel there is no need to panic,” Jan Graveson, a British musician who spends a lot of time in Goa and Mumbai, said.Graveson travels regularly travels between the UK and India, said she would be going to the UK shortly, but the visit has nothing to do the Covid-19 impact. “I want to visit my dad who is 86 years old. I’ll be back to enjoy Goa,” she said.Senior citizens Vincent James and his wife Blum have been holidaying in the state since the past fortnight. They have been visiting Goa every alternate season to give the chilly climes in England a miss, and both of them are relieved that they are here while their country is on the verge of a lockdown due to the virus.“We are just hoping that it does not strike Goa or India as hard as it has in England, otherwise we will have to undergo the misery of screening, 14 days quarantine, blood tests, et al,” said Vincent, and in a lighter vein added, “We have read that the virus cannot survive in heat, so we are spending a lot of time in the sunlight.”Tourism stakeholders said with the suspension of tourist visas, they do not expect any more foreign tourists in the near future.“Foreign tourist arrivals have been declining over the past few years. But the number of domestic tourists has remained steady,” a guesthouse owner in Calangute said.

Title: Events of over 50 people won’t get NOCs: Mayor
Content: AURANGABAD: The municipal administration has appealed to people to avoid large gatherings and asked shopping mall operators to undertake proper sanitation measures to keep coronavirus at a bay.Recently, divisional commissioner Sunil Kendrekar had instructed the district and the municipal administrations in Marathwada to take steps to avoid large gatherings.The exhibitions, processions, cultural and religious programmes organised in the city have to obtain a no-objection certificate (NOC). On Friday, mayor Nandkumar Ghodele said that Aurangabad Municipal Corporation would cease issuing NOCs for such programmes until further notice.“Any programme which has a gathering of more than 50 people will have to be cancelled as long as the threat of coronavirus is there,” said Ghodele.The municipal commissioner will be reviewing the weekly market at Jafar Gate on Sunday. AMC has lined up a meeting with the contractors of the market where in it would ask them to take steps to ensure people do not overcrowd the market.“Based on the review of the Sunday market, the civic body will decide whether permission should be granted for the market in the forthcoming weeks,” said Ghodele.253 beds reserved forsuspected patientsDistrict civil surgeon Sundar Kulkarni said that as many as 253 beds have been reserved to quarantine patients suspected to have been infected with coronavirus. Kulkarni was speaking at the first press briefing on coronavirus by the district administration at the colletorate on Friday.The work of screening and diagnosis of the suspected patients will be done at the district civil hospital in Chikalthana. Kulkarni said that 12 patients, who had come to the district civil hospital fearing that they have been infected, were counselled and sent home as they did show any symptoms of the disease. They have been instructed to self-quarantine at home.“While two suspects have been quarantined by the AMC’s health department in Chikalthana, three more have been quarantined by the rural health department,” he said.A release issued by the health department gave details about the number of beds reserved for quarantine in the district. While 52 beds have been reserved at the district-level, 140 at the taluka-level, one at Aurangabad airport , 30 by the AMC at its health centre and 30 more have been put at the isolation ward in GMCH, stated the release.

Title: Schools shut down on their own as govt delays decision
Content:
Nagpur: Even as government remains non-committal, several schools are taking the lead and shutting down their pre-primary sections with plans to go for an early vacation for all classes.

A Nagpur-based group, which has more than a dozen branches in and around the district, has closed down their pre-primary section till further notice. The school’s director told TOI it was a preventive step taken for safety of kids even though they had no direct connection with patients who tested positive in Nagpur.

Independent English Schools Association (IESA), a pan-Maharashtra group of school owners, has decided to go in for an early vacation in their over 4,000 schools. Rajendra Dayma, president of the association, said, “For classes up to Std IX, all exams are held internally. We requested our members to conduct them as soon as possible and wrap up the academic session by March 25.” He added otherwise the academic session will go on up to second week of April.

IESA urged all its members to first focus on exams so the logistical challenges are taken care of. “Board exams will obviously continue as usual and a dedicated staff is available for it. The gap days can be used to get over with the internal exams so there is no unnecessary stretching of schedule,” said Dayma.

District collector Ravindra Thakre has said any school closure decision will have to come from the government. Many principals expressed shock the government has decided to close down malls, theatres, gyms and swimming pool but no decision has been taken for schools. A principal said, “Don’t they realize schools are the biggest hub for spreading infection? Thousands of students together for almost six hours in confined spaces is a breeding ground for virus. They should shut schools down for at least a week so the spread of infection is slowed down.”

Title: Delhi Police got over 2,000 videos from public on riots
Content:
Soon after formation of the SIT in the riots, Delhi Police had appealed to people to share whatever video evid... Read More

NEW DELHI: Investigation in cases of riots often hits a roadblock due to lack of evidence. It becomes even more difficult to ascertain the correct sequence of events, let alone identifying the rioters. However, thanks to the video footage available with them, Delhi Police is sure that the perpetrators of the recent riots will be brought to books.

Apart from the CCTV footage from the affected areas, mobile videos shot by the residents have also helped the cops join the missing dots and place a verified sequence on record .

Soon after formation of the SIT in the riots, Delhi Police had appealed to people to share whatever video evidence they had recorded during the riots. According to additional commissioner, Mandeep Singh Randhawa, Delhi Police has till date received as many as 2,162 videos from public.

Police are carefully examining the authenticity of the videos before using them to identify the rioters, said a source. “The videos are carefully examined for any tampering by our video experts and then inventoried and categorised based on areas and case FIRs,” he added.

Of the 2,162 videos received, police have filtered out only 1,330 usable videos. Many of the videos received were similar too. “After categorisation, the videos are manually analysed by showing them to locals and informers. They are then run through a software, which uses facial recognition technology, to identify the suspects.”

Police are also selecting the videos sent by people who had recorded them themselves on their mobile phones. "These videos are being sent for forensic analysis and can be used as an evidence in the court as well. Forwarded videos can aide in investigation, but not be placed on record in court,” a senior cop said.

From the sensational murders of head constable Ratan Lal to the killing of IB official Ankit Sharma - the videos have played a crucial role during the probe. The mystery of four bodies recovered from the drains in northeast Delhi was largely solved using the video footage. Police had also managed to solve the case of arson at a house, in which a 85-year-old woman died of asphyxia, using video footage.

Title: Coastal body seeks green study for laying gas pipeline
Content:
Panaji: The Goa Coastal Zone Management Authority ( GCZMA ) told Goa Natural Gas to conduct a rapid environment impact assessment (EIA) after the latter sought an NOC to lay gas pipelines across three water bodies.

Goa Natural Gas has sought permission to use the horizontal directional drilling (HDD) method to lay pipelines across the Ribandar creek, the Banastarim river at Banastarim, Old Goa , and across the Mhadei river at Khandepar, Ponda.

“HDD utilises a drill to install the pipe. No excavation is necessary. The depth of the pipelines at each location will be 4m-5m below the bed of the water body,” Goa Natural Gas told the GCZMA.

The coastal authority then inspected the sites with a surveyor and, following its meeting in January, decided to ask Goa Natural Gas to conduct a rapid EIA and approach it again for approval.

“All three waterbodies are ecologically sensitive and come under tidal influences. The mangroves along the Ribandar creek and Banastarim river provide breeding/nesting grounds for various life forms such as fish, birds and crocodiles etc. Slight disturbance to the ecology by way of drilling and creating vibrations may negatively impact these species,” the GCZMA said.

To study the impact of drilling, Goa Natural Gas must study all the water bodies for their physical (including geotechnical), chemical and biological parameters, the authority has suggested.

“The Ribandar creek has well-established mangroves and is used by the locals for fishing. During the process of laying the pipeline, there are high chances that vibration may lead to disturbance of the delicate ecology. The distance the pipeline needs to cover is about 100m-120m,” the GCZMA said.

The Banastarim river is an ecologically sensitive zone too, and connects to the Cumbharjua canal, which is one of Goa’s known crocodile habitats, it has stated. “A stretch of well-established mangroves have been observed on both the sides of river. The pipeline distance to be covered is about 150m-170m,” the authority has observed based on the report of its expert member.

In the case of the Mhadei, the Goa Natural Gas pipeline is set to be laid between the old and new bridges at Khandepar. “The tidal influence reaches till the place where the proposed pipeline is marked,” the GCZMA stated.

The authority has also asked the company to refer to a report by the Mangrove Society of India on mangrove risk assessment and restoration plan for rivers. “The proponent must follow all the recommendations,” it told Goa Natural Gas.

Title: Scolded for playing PUBG, Gopalganj student ends life
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: A 14-year-old boy committed suicide in Gopalganj district on Friday morning allegedly after being scolded by his family members for playing online game PUBG.

Police said the Himanshu Kumar, a Class IX student of Gopalganj Kendriya Vidyalaya, was found hanging with the ceiling fan in his room at Rajendra Nagar under Town police station of Gopalganj town.

The victim’s relatives told the police that Himanshu was spotted playing the online game till 1am on Friday. He was very upset over frequently losing the game and was subsequently scolded by the parents. “Prima facie it appears that the boy took the extreme step in frustration,” an investigating officer said.

No suicide note was recovered from the room, which was found locked from inside. “The family members are not cooperating with the police in the investigation and not willing to share more information. They are trying to conceal something,” the officer said.

Town police station house officer (SHO) Prashant Kumar Rai said police would quiz Himanshu’s father Pappu Kumar once the situation becomes normal in the family. A case of unnatural death (UD) has been lodged, the SHO said, adding that an FSL team collected samples from the spot.

Gopalganj sub-divisional police officer (SDPO) Naresh Paswan said it was a case of suicide. The locals told the police that Himanshu was addicted to the online game and his parents used to scold him for wasting time and spoiling his career. “He had started showing indecent behaviour with some of his close relatives and preferred to live in solitude,” a police officer quoted a close relative as saying.

In another incident, a 22-year-old man was admitted to the Sadar hospital at Buxar on Wednesday after showing violent behaviour with his family members and close relatives. “The man’s father revealed that he was addicted to PUBG and had been upset after losing the game over the last three consecutive days,” a doctor attending on the boy said.

Expressing concern over the rise in the cases of addiction among children to the online game, an anthologist, Prof. S Narayan, said, “The parents must pay attention to the changes in the behaviour of their wards.”

He, however, attributed the reason for the rise in addiction cases among the children to parents’ time crunch and lack of interest among students in extracurricular activities.

Title: Faldessai is asst solicitor general
Content:
Panaji: Additional government advocate for the state of Goa in the high court of Bombay at Goa, who also presently holds responsibility as additional public prosecutor at the high court, Pravin Nilkanth Faldessai, has been engaged as assistant solicitor general of India.

Faldessai enrolled as an advocate on the roll of the Bar Council of Maharashtra and Goa on April 19, 2004 and practised with senior counsel S D Lotlikar between April 2004 and July 2007. He assisted the senior advocate in various civil and criminal cases before the high court and subordinate courts in Goa as well as other quasi-judicial authorities in Goa.

The department of legal affairs (Judicial Section) of the ministry of law and justice has stated that the order will be for a period of three years or until further orders.

Advocates Vishnuprasad Anand Lawande, Somnath Bhiku Karpe and Raviraj Ramesh Chodankar have been engaged as central government counsels for conducting central government litigations before the high court of Bombay at Goa.

Title: Coronavirus in Noida: 29 colleagues who came in contact with executive isolated
Content: NOIDA: A day after it came to light that a senior executive of a Noida-based private company - a Delhi resident who recently tested positive for Covid-19 - interacted with several of his colleagues, as many as 29 of them were screened and quarantined on Friday. Blood samples of seven have been taken for further testing, authorities said.District magistrate BN Singh said the company where the executive from Delhi had visited in Noida's Sector 80 has shut down its premises till March 20. "While 29 people who came in close contact with him have been screened and quarantined, CCTV footage in the office is being scanned to look for any further contacts with the executive," he said.A list of 717 people has also been handed over to the health department by the company where the executive worked, officials said.Fortunately, the DM said, the executive who'd returned from Italy and his last working day at the company outfit was March 6, was sitting in a separate cabin, which was away from the main factory. "The majority of staff, about 700, were in another building. But still, as a precautionary measure we are in the process of checking all staff," he said."Now that we have got a list of all the company employees, we are contacting them to check for symptoms of flu, cough or breathlessness. They have been asked to report any such symptoms to the district health department," said Dr Anurag Bhargava, chief medical officer of GB Nagar. "The company office has been sanitized, and samples of about 5-7 people taken from the premises for further testing. We are following up with all precautions and are taking all necessary steps," said Bhargava.

Title: Coronavirus in Jaipur: 35 people, who travelled with infected man, test negative
Content: JAIPUR: The health department managed to track 35 co-passengers of Dubai-returned man who was tested positive of coronavirus and presently undergoing treatment.An intimation to get the phone numbers and antecedents of the rest 65 passengers in Dubai-Jaipur flight has already been sent to the authorities and the Centre. In the preliminary screening, all the 35 passengers were found negative and were quarantined at their respective homes across the state.An 85-year-old person, who was tested positive for coronavirus had returned to Jaipur on February 28 from a flight from Dubai to Jaipur.“It was important for us to get the details of his co-passengers. Thus, we managed to track 35 passengers who are from different parts of Rajasthan . None of them have developed any symptoms and were found negative. Still as an SOP, they are quarantined at their homes itself,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary (ACS), health while talking to TOI on Friday.He added that out of the 65 passengers some of them were tracked and were foreigners. “We managed to speak to some of them while to others we are trying to get their Whatsapp number to get in touch with them,” he added.In an another development related to the 85-year-old person who was tested positive of corona virus, the health officials swung into action and sealed a private bank situated at Raja Park.“Initially there were rumours that an employee of private bank where this old man visited was tested positive. What we did is we have sealed the private bank at Raja Park and all the 14 employees were sent on leave. None of them are with any symptoms like fever, shortness in breath, cough and cold, still they are asked to remained isolated for the next 14 days,” said Ravi Prakash, additional director (rural health) said.Throughout the day there were rumours that one employee of a private bank at Raja Park and one at Gopalpura were tested positive. “None of them were positive. After noticing that the 85-year-old man who is tested positive and is under treatment had visited the private bank at Raja Park the bank is closed and sealed and employees were sent home,” said a senior officer. It may be recalled that the authorities of the health department have already started disinfecting temples, government offices and tourist places in Jaipur following three cases of coronavirus being detected here. The officials are conducting screening of residential and commercial areas in a 3-km area of the house of an 85-year-old person who tested positive for coronavirus early this week.

Title: Pune: Installation to capture FTII’s journey since Prabhat days through camera lens
Content:
Representative image

Pune: The theme of this year’s annual installation at the Film and Television Institute of India ’s (FTII) will be “Prabhat to FTII”.

The installation, to be inaugurated on Saturday, will be on the institute’s historic journey from Prabhat Film Company to FTII as a part of its diamond jubilee year celebrations.

The installation will be jointly inaugurated by the FTII alumni of its oldest batch and family representatives of the owner-partners, Prabhat Film Company, at 2.30pm on Saturday, read a statement issued by the institute on Friday.

FTII alumni Kuldip Sud (sound recording, 1961), Mehboob Khan (editing, 1961), R M Rao (motion picture photography, 1961), Yogesh Mathur (editing, 1962) and Suresh Naik (motion picture photography, 1962) will be present during the occasion.

The original Prabhat partners were V Shantaram (fondly called Anna), Keshavrao Dhaibar, Sitarampant Kulkarni, Vishnupant Damle (also known as Damle Mama) and Sheikh Fattelal (popular as Saheb Mama).

The installation comprises two giant cameras covering a century of transformation, from Mitchell (20th century) to ARRI Alexa (21st century) representing Prabhat and FTII, respectively.

The replica also represents the technological changes from the early era of Indian cinema (Prabhat) to the present Indian film industry (FTII) .

“To absorb this experiential journey, the visit will start with ‘entering’ into the Mitchell camera through its lens and lens hood, which would lead into the instrument’s body. Glimpses of the Prabhat Film Company and Prabhat era will be displayed through a photographic exhibition in the camera body chamber,” FTII director Bhupendra Kainthola said.

“Further inside the exhibit, Maharashtra’s unique ‘wada’ interior has been created inside the camera body to enhance the overall environment. When exiting the exhibition during the Prabhat era, a narrow passage will lead to the FTII era. Several iconic moments of the institute since 1961 will be on display as part of a photographic exhibition,” he said.

The concept, design and execution of this installation is by Ashutosh Kavishwar . He is part of the FTII’s department of art direction and production design.

“Moments captured on camera during the student days of many iconic film actors, actresses, directors and technicians will be on display. The FTII-era gallery will include several academic activities and events that took place over the six decades of the institute. In the end, the visitor will exit the FTII gallery from an ARRI Alexa camera lens at the tail end of the installation,” Kavishwar said.

Title: Four held for attacking man over dispute during Holi revelry in Pune
Content:
PUNE: The Koregaon Park police on Thursday night arrested four youths for abusing and attacking a 32-year-old hardware shop employee with a slab over a dispute during Holi revelry at the Residency Club here on Tuesday evening.

Zubair Kadlagi from Pargenagar in Kondhwa sustained serious injuries on his head and suffered two fractured ribs. He is recuperating in a private hospital.

A magisterial court on Friday sent Sikander Shaikh (21), Atique Sayyed (21), Allahbaksh Jamadar (18) and Rohan Reddy (22), all from Keshavnagar , in police custody remand till March 16.

The club’s general manager, Sanjay Singh , told TOI, “The security officials told me that no such incident had taken place inside the club on March 10.”

When TOI contacted Zubair over phone, his brother said, “My brother is not keeping well. He is suffering from severe pain and is not in a position to talk.”

Sub-inspector Shrikant Gaurav from Koregaon Park police said, “The suspects are all known to each other. They had visited the club to play Holi even though they were not official members. They got access inside the club because of a reference given by a club employee, who is a common friend of complainant Zubair and the suspects.”

Singh claimed, “No such employee has worked in the club in the past six years. We don’t know why the club’s name has figured in the police complaint. The police have not visited the club to conduct an inquiry.”

Zubair, in his FIR, said, “I had visited the club to meet my friend around 4.30pm. I played Holi with him and his other friends (suspects). My friend left the club about 7.30pm. I then washed the colours and was leaving the club when my friends urged me to play Holi with them. I requested them not to throw colours at me but they picked up an argument with me and hurled abuses at me.”

“The suspects beat me and hit me with a slab (tile) on my head and ribs and fled. I then called my friend who rushed me to the Sassoon General Hospital. My family members later shifted me to a private hospital,” the FIR stated.

Sub-inspector Gurav said, “The incident happened because the complainant had refused to play Holi with the suspects for the second time and one of them attacked him with a slab. We are questioning the youths to establish their individual role in the crime.”

“We have arrested the four for voluntarily causing grievous hurt among other charges of the Indian Penal Code ,” he added.

Title: Capital jumps 17 ‘Smart’ steps to hug 24th rank
Content:
Lucknow: The state capital has climbed 17 notches, since its last half-yearly assessment, to rank 24 among 100 cities evaluated on the basis of projects completed under the Smart City mission.

According to guidelines set by the ministry of housing and urban affairs, which releases these pan-India rankings, the more projects a city completes within stipulated time, the higher position it secures.

Lucknow Municipal Corporation officials said, following the Union ministry guidelines, the civic body had set for itself a target of 10 Smart City projects between October 1, 2019, and March 1, 2020.

Among these, the LMC completed seven — a smart bus shelter, a command and control centre, smart roads, pelican crossings, an e-library, compactors at open dumping points and merchandised sweeping of roads. The three other projects underway are area-based development of Kaiserbagh, smart parking and installing automatic variable signboards to guide commuters.

“Area-based development in Kaiserbagh is going on at a rapid pace. Also, we are going to float tenders for automatic commuter signboards by the end of this month,” said general manager, Smart City projects, Fareed Zaidi.

In terms of UP cities, Lucknow has dropped a rank though. Compared to its fourth position in the state in the last assessment, the city stands fifth this time after Agra (1st), Kanpur (3rd), Varanasi (7th) and Prayagraj (12th).

Title: Missing bullets: Why was CAG report given to home ministry, asks Kerala HC
Content:
Kerala high court

KOCHI: The high court on Friday asked why the report of the Comptroller and Auditor General ( CAG ) pointing out missing of bullets and rifles from Kerala Police was handed over to the central government.

Considering a public interest litigation seeking a CBI or NIA probe, a division bench comprising Chief Justice S Manikumar and Justice Shaji P Chaly asked under what circumstance the report was handed over to the home ministry. The report should have been handed over to the legislative assembly of the state as per Constitutional provisions and the CAG should not have tried to overcome the powers of the legislative assembly, the bench said. CAG’s reports on finance, performance, and compliance are to be submitted to the respective legislative assembly as per law, the court said while pointing out that there is a Supreme Court order specifying so.

During the hearing, assistant solicitor general had submitted to the court on behalf of the central government that the CAG report was handed over to the home ministry. State government had contended before the court that no other authority, including the court, can intervene in a matter that is under consideration of the legislative assembly.

State government had also informed the court that a crime branch probe launched on the basis of the allegations in the CAG report is progressing. The investigation is going in the right direction. The CAG report is being considered by the public accounts committee of the legislative assembly, the government had submitted through an affidavit.

In the PIL filed through advocate R Krishna Raj, P P Ramachandra Kaimal of Changanassery had contended that the alleged missing of 25 rifles and 12,061 live cartridges is a matter affecting the security of the citizens and national security. It was alleged by the petitioner that no steps have been taken by the authorities to trace and recover the missing rifles and bullets.

According to the PIL, the report by the CAG had mentioned a shortage of 25 5.56mm INSAS rifles and 12,061 live cartridges, which includes 1,835 cartridges for INSAS rifles and 1,578 cartridges for AK-47 rifles. It was also found out that out of the missing cartridges, 250 9mm drill cartridges were replaced by dummy bullets, the petition had stated. However, state government had replied in court that no rifles are missing. By Friday, the hearing on the PIL was completed and the case has been reserved for pronouncing orders.
