Title: Another corporator in Aurangabad says he, his family not in voters’ list
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: Among the allegations of over a lakh names missing from the voters’ list, MIM group leader and Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) corporator Gangadhar Dhage said that his and the names of 24 of his family members are missing from the first voters’ list.

On March 9, the AMC had published the draft voters’ list for the civic elections to be held in April. According to the election department of the AMC, the draft voters’ list was the same that was used for the state assembly elections which were held in October 2019. The list was broken down into 115 wards of the municipal corporation.

Dhage said that he was shocked when he found his name missing from the list. He belongs to ward no. 31 — Jai Bhim Nagar, Asifiya Colony. However, his astonishment knew no bounds when he found out that the names of 24 of his family members were also not in the list. “I have been living in Jai Bhim Nagar, Asifiya Colony ward with my family for the last 65 years, but could not find our names in the voters’ list published by the AMC,” Dhage.

Earlier, he had raised objections to the draft voters’ list stating that 1,500 names from Jai Bhim Nagar, Asifiya Colony ward have been moved to ward no 12 Aref Colony, Pragati Colony. However, he could not find his or his family members names in the list of that ward either, he said. Dhage demanded that the officials responsible for the botch up be suspended.

Earlier, former corporator Sameer Rajurkar had alleged that more than 1 lakh voters have been omitted from the voters’ list by the AMC’s election department. Sitting corporators Shabnam Kaleem Qureshi, Malika Habib Qureshi and Khatija Qureshi of the same family, including activist Kaleem Qureshi, were left out of the voters’ list.

Later during the day, municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey suspended four employees of the municipal corporation, including Sudarshan Ghule , assistant teacher, Ajay Yara , junior clerk, Syed Javed, Syed Chand, teaching staff and Vilas Badghane , health worker, for failing to execute their duties properly. The action has been taken under section 4 of the Maharashtra Municipal Corporation Act.

The municipal commissioner also issued showcause notices to deputy municipal commissioner Ravindra Nikam, sectional engineer KN Katkar and junior engineer Jagdish Padalkar for discrepancies in voters’ lists.

Title: Mahatma Gandhi’s book, exercising & web series keep patients in good spirits
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Mahatma Gandhi ’s views and philosophy, old films and web series have come to the rescue of the Covid-19 patients quarantined at Naidu Hospital .

The first Covid-19 patients in Pune, a couple and their daughter, are waiting patiently for their isolation period to get over. The couple has spent over four days while their daughter has spent three days in isolation at the facility.

Doctors have been visiting them regularly for two days and on Friday, a panel of doctors and experts came for a check-up. They were told that their cases would be studied and decisions made.

Since they have the time, the husband has requested friends for books and is currently reading the biography of Gandhi while his wife has downloaded old films on her cellphone. The daughter has also renewed her Netflix subscription to watch web series.

The quality of food they get has improved and since they are maintaining good health, the family is now waiting to be discharged. They hope the two tests coming up are favourable.

“It is our fourth day in the hospital. We have organised ourselves and found ways to keep ourselves engaged. In the last two days, my wife downloaded some movies on her cellphone and has been watching them. I speak to my friends and colleagues on social media, some call me and check on our health status. They dropped some books at the hospital and I am reading the biography of Mahatma Gandhi,” the man added.

Their daughter had downloaded a web series from Netflix and is watching the episodes apart from the routine like taking medicines, having food on time and doing the health checks.

Their son who tested negative but was quarantined as a precaution was in another building of the hospital. He too had his cellphone and was watching web series.

The quality of food had improved, the bed covers and linen were up to the mark and there was no reason to complain, they said. The husband said, “ Our samples will be sent once again for testing in 3-4 days and after that report, another sample will be sent to double check our recovery. Only then will they plan to discharge us.” Doctors have instructed them about the care and precautions they should take after discharge from the hospital.

The cab driver who drove the couple and their daughter from Mumbai to Pune on March 1 and another patient quarantined at the same hospital have been exercising regularly in the evening to improve their immunity.

The fifth positive person, who was admitted in Pune, said, “I did not even have any symptoms and I feel fit now. I came here since I was in contact with a person with Covid-19 and I tested positive, but healthwise I am just fine.”

He said, much of his time is spent on the phone as he gets numerous calls from colleagues, friends and family.

Some of them, who came in contact with him, are calling to ask about the symptoms while friends call to check on his health status. He said his colleagues had tested negative for the contagion. “I am avoiding the news channels. I’d rather spend time exercising so that I feel healthy and fit,” he said.

Title: Hyderabad: Chance to run PM Narendra Modi’s twitter handle a nod for my work says Kalpana Ramesh
Content:
Kalpana at an interactive session

HYDERABAD: City-based architect and a volunteer with SAHE (Society for Advancement of Human Endeavour) Kalpana Ramesh , who was recently selected as the PM’s ‘magnificent seven’ on Women’s Day, says she felt empowered by the oppurtunity and saw it as an acknowledgment of her work.

“I have been working on this mission to conserve water for the last eight years and to be selected to be a part of a small group of seven persons came as a huge surprise and honour. I also think water conservation is very close to the PM’s heart,” she said.

The dependence of people on water tankers was something that worried her after she moved to Hyderabad from the US more than a decade ago. “I noticed that residents in my locality in Gachibowli were heavily dependent on tankers. I began harvesting rainwater. In 2016, despite four months of intense summer, we did not requisition a single tanker. ”

The ‘Save 10k Bores’ initiative that was spearheaded by her has also helped revive defunct borewells with the help of rainwater. By directing rainwater to a harvesting pit, several borewells have been revived through community initiatives.

Taken aback by the condition of the lakes in the city, the water warrior says that most of the lakes have turned into cesspools. “During the TedX Salon event, I saw Gandipet lake which was sufficient to meet the city’s water requirements. With the lake going dry during summer, we are moving from one water body to another to meet our needs. We cannot go on sucking out the resources,” she said.

Title: Organisers to go ahead with Panaji Shigmo amid Covid-19 concerns
Content: Panaji: The much awaited Shigmo parade in the state capital is expected to be held on Saturday evening after a hiatus of one year. The Panaji parade was cancelled last year following the demise of chief minister Manohar Parrikar.The Panaji Shigmotsav Samiti decided to go ahead with the parade on Saturday evening. When asked about health issues in the wake of the Covid-19, ex-officio chairman Sanjit Rodrigues said precautions and advisories issued by the health ministry and disseminated to people must be followed.Following a meeting held by the Panaji Shigmotsav Samiti with all troupe leaders on Friday morning, Rodrigues said the Shigmo parade should abide by rules and avoid any violation of the code of conduct currently in force due to the zilla panchayat elections scheduled for March 22.“In the midst of an election code, timing is a serious issue. We should abide by the timing. We would not be able to support any violation of the timings with the code enforced. In the meeting with all troupe leaders, we impressed upon them to start at 4.30pm sharp and finish at 10pm - the time allotted by the administration,” Rodrigues said.Addressing the media after the meeting, Rodrigues said that lack of discipline on the parade route as well as delay in timing will destroy the charm of the festival. “It’s almost inhuman to keep people - elders and young kids - waiting beyond midnight. The committee took this into consideration. A lot of representations have been received regarding timings and discipline along the route,” he said.Each troupe will have one volunteer and police constable with them to maintain the time and rhythm of the parade flow, he added.“Members of the committee are also keen that timing is followed because this inconveniences everybody, both the organisers and spectators,” Rodrigues said.The parade route has been shortened by 1km and will follow the Caculo island - 18th June route, and turn left on the Azad Maidan stretch along Swami Vivekananda road from Panaji municipal corporation office junction. The old route along Panaji municipal garden and MG road to Azad Maidan will not be used.The committee instructed those transporting floats from South Goa to bring their floats past midnight to avoid any traffic congestion on the Zuari bridge that is already stressed with ongoing work and single laning.

Title: Home food allowed for quarantined inmates in Pune: Officials
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Institutional-quarantined persons can be provided food by their family members, who will have to leave them at the reception of these centres, stated administration officials.

However, those quarantined at these centres will not be allowed to meet their family members, said officials.

There are 21 quarantine centres in Pune and PCMC areas and additional facilities are being readied at 18 empanelled hospitals under the Disaster Management Act.

“While all the centres may not have television facility immediately, they will have basic facilities,’’ said PMC additional commissioner Rubal Agarwal, in-charge of quarantine facilities in the city. In the wake of the new directive issued by the Centre on 14-day quarantining for flyers reaching the city following travel to seven high-risk countries, the administration officials said that they have readied all the basic facilities and those quarantined can eat home food. “We have taken preventive measures as per the protocol and we request both the individuals and relatives to cooperate,” she said.

On Friday, 129 passengers reached the city from Dubai. None of them had travelled to the high-risk countries, so they were sent home and asked to go in for home quarantine for 14 days as per the health advisory.

Title: Traffic diversions at Dhole Patil Chowk on Bundgarden Road for metro work
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The Dhole Patil Chowk on Bund Garden Road near Wadia College will remain partially closed for vehicles till March end to facilitate ongoing Metro work on the stretch.

As a part of the traffic diversions, vehicles coming from Dhole Patil Road towards Mangaldas Road will not be allowed to cross the junction and those coming from Pune station via Bund Garden Road will have to take right turn on Mangaldas Road and vice-a-versa.

There will be no restriction on vehicles travelling from the chowk without taking any turns towards Pune station and Yerawada .

A temporary provision has been made about 300 metres ahead on the Bund Garden Road for vehicles to turn towards Mangaldas Road. The vehicles travelling from Mangaldas Road towards Dhole Patil Road will have to take a U-turn from Wadia College chowk , the traffic police said.

The MahaMetro said it had deployed additional workers at the Bund Garden Chowk area to assist the traffic personnel to streamline the traffic flow.

Heavy vehicles and buses of Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) will have to travel till Parnakuti Chowk at Yerawada to take a right turn and then travel towards Koregaon Park road, the traffic police said.

Officials from MahaMetro said the work of building pillars on Bund Garden stretch had been completed. The traffic restrictions were being imposed for launching of gantry and viaduct segments, the officials said, adding that the vehicular movement was not advisable during the launching of segments.

The ongoing Metro work on Bund Garden road is a part of the Vanaz-Ramwadi route that is a completely elevated corridor.

Title: Bike-borne duo snatch woman’s gold chain in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Two motorcycle-borne snatched a gold chain worth Rs40,000 of a 58-year-old woman in Manjri Budruk area on Thursday afternoon.

Police said the incident occurred around 2.15pm when the woman was playing with her 2-year-old nephew in Vignahartha Colony here. “The bike-borne duo came from behind and the pillion rider snatched the woman's chain before the vehicle sped away,” assistant inspector Sanjay Chavan of the Hadapsar police said.

The officer said the duo was booked under sections 392 (robbery) and 34 (common intention) of the Indian Penal Code following a complaint lodged by the woman later on Thursday. “The woman said the duo had their faces covered with masks,” Chavan said.

The officer said a probe revealed that the bike-borne men had first conducted a recce of the area. “They returned to the spot after a while and snatched the woman’s gold chain after finding her alone. The suspects are aged around 30-35 years,” Chavan said.

“We are checking the CCTV cameras around the area to ascertain the duo’s identity,” he added.

Title: Peon in Pune held on molestation charge
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A 62-year-old peon working at a private firm was arrested on Thursday on the charge of outraging the modesty of a 33-year-old woman employee on the company premises on Wednesday evening.

The woman stated in her complaint that the peon touched her inappropriately while telling her about his fortune teller.

After receiving the complaint, assistant inspector Savita Bhagwat arrested the suspect under sections 354 (assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty) and 509 (word, gesture or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman) of the Indian Penal Code.

Bhagwat told TOI that the suspect asked the complainant out for a movie. “He also asked her to come out with him to a restaurant,” the officer said, adding, “When the woman objected, the suspect told her that they could become friends as per the prediction of his fortune teller.”

She added that the suspect has been released on bail by a court.

Title: Odisha prepares battle plan to take on Covid-19
Content: BHUBANESWAR: In a pre-emptive move sparked by the global outbreak of novel coronavirus (Covid-19), the Odisha government on Friday declared it a “disaster for the state”, declared closure of schools, colleges and film theatres and approved a Rs 200 crore package to deal with the likely public health challenge that could arise out of the virus attack.Further, the government has notified a new ‘Odisha Covid-19 Regulations 2020’ under which anyone not going into isolation or failing to get admitted to a hospital over a suspected case of coronavirus may be prosecuted under IPC Section 188, which has a maximum jail term of six months.Though Odisha has not reported a positive case so far, the precautionary move was taken a day after India reported its first coronavirus death in Karnataka and two days after the World Health Organization termed the disease — that has spread to at least 114 countries — a pandemic.Announcing the government decision in the state assembly after chairing a cabinet meeting, chief minister Naveen Patnaik said, “The last 45 days has seen human beings as a race facing one of the biggest challenges of the century. We are faced with a threat that does not discriminate between developed countries and under-developed countries, between democratic or non-democratic countries. Rich and poor societies all are equally vulnerable.”By terming it a ‘disaster’ under the provisions of the Disaster Management Act, 2005, the government has delegated additional powers to certain officials to take steps like putting curbs on public activities and a free hand in purchase of required medicines, equipment and machines in case the situation so demands.The health and family welfare department and its directorates, district collectors and municipal commissioners can make emergency procurement of drugs and consumables, equipment and other required services necessary to contain Covid-19. The officers have been authorised to impose restrictions on congregations to ensure ‘social distancing’ to contain the spread of the disease. The Rs 200 crore will augment the public health response fund to combat the threat of the pandemic and for making required expenditure.Under the Odisha Covid-19 Regulations, anyone who has travelled to any corona affected country in the last 14 days has to voluntarily report it to the state control room and follow the authorities’ advice. If a Covid-19 case is reported in a locality, the district collectors can bar entry or exit of people to the area, designate any government building as a quarantine facility and initiate surveillance of positive cases.The chief minister also announced the closure of schools and colleges, film theatres and gymnasiums and asked people to cancel seminars and conferences till March 31. Educational institutions, however, will go ahead and conduct scheduled exams. For wedding receptions, one has to take permission from local authorities.The coronavirus scare was also felt in the assembly, with speaker S N Patro adjourning proceedings of the budget session till March 29. Stating that “This extra ordinary circumstance calls for an extra ordinary response,” Naveen said, “This response cannot be only at the individual, government or sectoral level. Each one of us in Odisha has to rise to the occasion, and be responsible. In the absence of any vaccine or treatment, our collective responsibility is the only hope we have to fight this epidemic.”He added, “We must remain calm but not complacent. We must remain prepared, but not panic.” Pointing out that social distancing is the only effective measure to prevent its spread, Naveen said, “All of us should ruthlessly practice social distancing. Just keep interactions to the most essential levels and even in that take all precautions. Being at home, reducing social interactions and avoiding gatherings will cut down the vulnerability to a great extent.”The chief minister also warned of stringent action against rumour-mongering, misinformation and irresponsible conduct. The government has also formed an empowered group of ministers and a committee of secretaries under the chairmanship of the chief secretary to evaluate the emerging situation and take all necessary steps to prevent and contain the possible spread of Covid-19 in the state.

Title: TP murder: Kerala HC grants bail to CPM leader on health grounds
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

KOCHI: The high court on Friday granted three-months’ bail to CPM local leader P K Kunhananthan , who is serving life term for the murder of party dissident TP Chandrasekharan .

Kunhananthan, 73, a native of Kunnothparamba panchayat in Kannur , was the Panoor area committee member of CPM. He was sentenced in January 2014 for the murder that took place on May 4, 2012.

A division bench comprising justices A Hariprasad and MR Anitha granted bail after considering Kunhananthan’s plea claiming that he is suffering from serious ailments and needs treatment outside jail. The court relied on a report by a medical board that said Kunhananthan is suffering from ailments. While granting bail, the high court has directed Kunhananthan to be present at the jurisdictional police station once in two weeks and to sign a register there.

An appeal filed by Kunhananthan, who was convicted by a trial court for conspiracy, is pending before the high court. The trial court had sentenced him to life imprisonment and fined Rs1 lakh.

In his plea, Kunhananthan had sought to stay his sentence in view of his health condition and to allow him bail. He has already served a jail term of seven years and seven months and availing treatment outside the jail is essential for saving his life, the plea had stated.

Title: 1 nat’l institute has e-classes, another defers convocation
Content:
Panaji: National educational institutes in Goa have begun taking pre-emptive measures in view of growing concerns about the Covid-19 pandemic. The Indian Institute of Technology ( IIT ), Goa, for instance, has decided to conduct classes online from March 16-31 for all its BTech, MTech and PhD students, and the Goa Institute of Management (GIM), Sakhali, has postponed its convocation ceremony.

Both, IIT and the National Institute of Technology (NIT), Goa, have also restricted student movements outside campus.

“Disinfection of the canteen, the mess, the academic buildings and all such commonly used areas has already begun. Students and faculty are not allowed to travel internationally and have been also told to reduce their domestic travel. Sports events, conferences and any activity that involves a group gathering at one place have been cancelled, too,” IIT Goa dean Sachin Kore, said.

He also said that a health check-up for all students on campus is ongoing and self-service of food in the canteen has been discontinued to ensure hygiene. The institute has even restricted campus entry to visitors.

Director of NIT Goa, Gopal Mugeraya, said students have been told to restrict their movements within the campus at Farmagudi. They’ve also been instructed not to venture outside.

GIM, in a statement, said it has postponed its convocation ceremony that was slated to be held this month. It has also suspended all student exchange programmes to universities abroad and international internships.

“The institute will assist with identifying summer internship opportunities within India instead. All international travel is to be reviewed and decided upon keeping in mind the advisory issued by the central health ministry. Remote meeting arrangements using secure, approved technology is advised,” GIM has said.

If anyone has recently returned from international travel, they must self-isolate for 14 days, the institute has told its students and faculty.

V M Salgaocar Institute of International Hospitality Education has resorted to healthier nutrition options. It has been encouraging its students and staff to drink hot water with cumin to boost immunity and has replaced tea and coffee with warm lemon grass tea at its cafeteria.

“Ice-creams and other cold items are not being served. All mega events have been kept on hold,” the institute has said.

Title: Discoms move MPERC, seek outstanding dues from Rlys
Content:
Bhopal: All the three discoms (power distributions companies) in the state have moved the MP electricity regulatory commission (MPERC) seeking directives to Railways to pay its outstanding dues.

The commission has issued a notice and scheduled the next hearing to April 7.

A recent order passed by the MPERC, while admitting the petition filed by the three discoms, namely — Madhya Kshetra Vidyut Vitaran Company, Purv Kshetra Vidyut Vitaran Company and Paschim Kshetra Vidyut Vitaran Company says, “Motion hearing in the subject matter was held on 25th February, 2020. The petition is admitted and the petitioners are directed to serve copies of the subject petition on all respondents in the matter and report its compliance to the Commission. The respondents in the subject matter are also directed to file their response on the petition by 20th March, 2020, after serving a copy of the same on other side also. Thereafter, the petitioners are required to file their rejoinder by 31st, March, 2020, after serving copy of the same on the other side also. The case is now fixed for hearing on 7th, April, 2020”.

Power distributions companies in the state are running into huge losses and have demanded a 15% tariff hike in domestic power consumption.

While transmission and distribution losses continues to be the cash-strapped discom’s Achilles heel outstanding payments from government bodies is another major problem. Earlier, in reply to a question on the issue by BJP MLA, Ajay Bishnoi, during the last session of MP assembly, energy minister Priyavrat Singh had said, “The demand letters of Rs121.41 crore, Rs330.31 crore and Rs152.98 crore for the years 2017-18, 2018-19 and 2019-20 (till August) had been issued to the railways, but we are still waiting for the payment. Overall, Rs882.03 crore is outstanding with railways since January 2016 when permission for open access was given to them. ”

There are provisions in the Electricity Act that if any industrial consumer is procuring power from open access, then the consumer is liable to pay a cross-subsidy, as determined by the regulatory commission of the respective state.

The concept of cross-subsidy is very simple. In normal tariff determination, the domestic and agricultural consumers are provided tariff at low rates, and the industrial consumers get power at higher rates.

For example, if the power procurement rate is Rs5 per unit, then the discoms can sell it to domestic and agricultural users at rates which are 20% lower than the procurement rate which comes around to Rs4 per unit, and the same is recovered from the industrial consumers by selling power at 20% higher rates. Thus, the effective rate of power sales comes to Rs5/unit said sources.

Besides these, there is an additional surcharge, which is recovered from open access consumers. Power discoms have industrial consumers and on the basis of existing consumers, discoms go into long-term power purchase agreements (PPAs). But if the same consumers opt for open access, then discoms lose the consumers. But the PPAs, which are long-term, are legally bound, hence discoms have to pay the fixed charges against the PPAs even if it does not buy power because its industrial consumers have shifted to open access.

Thus, to recover this loss, there is a provision of additional surcharge, added sources.

Title: Coronavirus in Pune: Anna Hazare’s village bans entry of tourists
Content: PUNE: Residents of Ralegan Siddhi — the village of social crusader Anna Hazare — on Friday announced a ban on entry of tourists amid Covid-19 scare.A statement issued by Hazare’s office said coronavirus seemed to be spreading in the country and prevention was the most effective option besides limiting human to human contact. “We request people not to visit the village till the threat of Covid-19 subsides,” the statement read.It said tourists from within the country and abroad regularly visit Ralegan Siddhi to see the watershed development work of Hazare and to meet him. Till date, over 16 lakh tourists have visited Ralegan Siddhi. TNN

Title: Sensors in Kaiserbagh sewers to prevent overflow
Content:
Lucknow: If Jal Sansthan has its way, Kaiserbagh will boast a ‘smart sewage system’ by April-end that will not only prevent overflowing of sewers, but also detect leaks.

A sensor-based underground drainage monitoring system is being procured for Rs 3.12 crore and will cover a 4.5km stretch in Kaiserbagh as a part of area-based development under the Smart City mission.

According to Jal Sansthan officials, the network of sensors will be installed along sewers and on manhole covers. If a sensor detects a leak, it will transmit an alert to the Smart City control room with the exact location of the damaged pipe, thus enabling authorities to fix the problem at the earliest and helping them prevent sewage spill.

Sensors under manhole covers will also detect rising level of sewage owing to blockage or excess water inflow, if any. As soon as sewage crosses a danger mark, the control room will receive an alert. This will once again help the authorities to take swift remedial measures before roads are soiled.

The underground drainage monitoring system in Kaiserbagh is a pilot project and will later be introduced in other Old City areas such as Daliganj, Golaganj, Wazirganj and Nazirabad.

“The new system is expected to start from April-end. At present, we are laying sewer lines. After that, we will install the sensors along with a private agency hired for the job,” said Jal Sansthan project manager Piyush Kumar. Once the project is commissioned, Lucknow will become the second city in India after Visakhapatnam to have a smart sewage system.

Title: Cong wants public assurance from PM
Content:
Panaji: Chief minister Pramod Sawant is “lying about getting assurances” from prime minister Narendra Modi after his meeting to seek support for the Mhadei water dispute and resumption of mining, Congress alleged on Friday.

“The prime minister must make a public statement on his assurance of protecting Goa’s interest on Mhadei and resumption of mining, as claimed by Sawant after his meeting,” state Congress president Girish Chodankar said.

A day earlier, Sawant met Modi in Delhi and said the prime minister had said that both these issues affecting the state would be addressed.

Calling Sawant’s meeting with Modi “another jumla to woo voters” ahead of the March 22 zilla elections, Chodankar said, “BJP has mastered the art of fooling people and this visit to Delhi is part of the same. In his meeting with the prime minister, Mhadei and mining issues were never discussed as mischievously disclosed by Sawant.”

He said Sawant and BJP expect “imminent defeat in the ZP polls” since both the Central and state governments have failed to resolve issues pertaining to the state.

Title: Aurangabad: Illegal water connections off focus as tax recovery rises
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has said that water collection has increased significantly over the last few days even as almost half of the water consumers do not pay taxes.

Incidentally, the water tax recovery over the last three years was affected as the data of water consumers was not shared by the Aurangabad City Water Utility Co. Ltd (ACWUCL) which managed water supply of city for two years until September 2016.

In January, the civic body received data of 1.35 lakh water consumers of the city from the water company in exchange of the payment of the company’s outstanding dues.

According to AMC tax officer Karan Chavan, the data has allowed the civic body to issue water bills to the consumers and, subsequently, the tax recovery has increased. “For financial year 2019-20, the AMC has registered a recovery of Rs 26.18 crore towards water tax. The collection is expected to increase by another Rs 10 to 15 crore,” Chavan said.

The data from the water works department of the municipal corporation shows 1.35 lakh registered water consumers. However, the actual number of water consumers is much higher. “There has not been any survey to bring all the water consumers on record,” Kiran Dhande , head of water works department, said.

The number of illegal water connections are estimated around 1.2 lakh.

Those paying taxes regularly have expressed discontent over the biased approach of the civic body in tax recovery.

The last drive against illegal water connections was carried out by the AMC in June 2019. When asked about the action on illegal connections, Chavan said that due to financial year-end, most staff is engaged in tax recovery work. “The drive can be conducted after March-end when the staff is available,” Chavan said. He said that the self-assessment drive of the municipal corporation has also reaped good response. The drive has seen 20,000 property holders pro-actively declaring their property details under which there is a section for tap water connection too.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Goa schools told to keep ‘social distance’, but assemblies stay
Content: PANAJI: Taking a cue from the Unicef advisory for schools on Covid-19, director of education Vandana Rao has come out with a diluted version for Goa to follow on Friday. The guidelines encourage students, teachers and staff who feel sick not to come to school.Daily disinfection of frequently touched surfaces in schools should be carried out, Rao has told schools, issuing to them part of Unicef’s guidelines on prevention and control of Covid-19 in schools.The Unicef advisory for schools has been modified by the state directorate and does not call for cancellation of morning school assemblies, like is already being implemented in many states in the country. The state circular, however, asks ‘social distancing’ to be practised.Goa’s guidelines explain what Covid-19 is, what its symptoms are and how the virus spreads.“Schools should provide water, sanitation and waste management facilities and follow environmental cleaning and decontamination procedures. Schools should promote social distancing (a term applied to certain actions that are taken to slow down the spread of a highly contagious disease, including limiting large groups of people coming together),” reads the circular, made applicable to all government, aided and unaided primary schools from the primary to the higher secondary level.Educational institutions have also been told to increase air flow and ventilation by opening windows and using air conditioning wherever available.Hand sanitisers should be placed in classrooms, toilets, halls, near exits where possible, the circular reads.Schools should enforce regular hand washing with safe water and soap, alcohol rub or hand sanitiser or chlorine solution, the education director said in the circular.Students should be encouraged to wash hands frequently and thoroughly for at least 20 seconds, institutes have been told.“Most importantly, it is to be mentioned that the protection of children and educational facilities is particularly important. Precautions are necessary to prevent the potential spread of Covid-19 in school settings; however, care must also be taken to avoid stigmatising students and staff who may have been exposed to the virus,” the guidelines state.

Title: Bhubaneswar: House panel formed on Puri temple funds
Content:
Representative image

BHUBANESWAR: Amid public outcry over deposit of Rs 545 crore of Puri Jagannath Temple in the crisis-hit Yes Bank, an assembly committee was constituted on Friday. It would submit a memorandum to the Centre and the Reserve Bank of India governor regarding release of the temple money.

The 12-member committee, led by speaker Surya Narayan Patro , has members of all parties, including leader of opposition Pradipta Kumar Naik, parliamentary affairs minister Bikram Keshari Arukh and Congress legislature party leader Narasingha Mishra. The committee is expected to meet soon to discuss its course of action.

Though the opposition members demanded a House committee probe into the deposit of Rs 545 crore of Jagannath Temple fund in Yes Bank, there is no clarity on whether the committee would inquire into the matter or only submit memorandum to seek release of funds. “Once all the 12 members of the committee meet, they would discuss the areas on which the committee will work in the days to come,” said committee member and government chief whip Pramila Mallik.

Earlier when the House assembled at 10:30am, members of the opposition BJP stalled the question hour, demanding formation of a House committee to take a call on the deposit of the temple funds. As the opposition members continued sloganeering in the well of the House, speaker Surya Narayan Patro adjourned the question hour till 11:30am.

Though the BJP MLAs continued protest during the zero hour, they allowed the House to run only after the speaker directed the government chief whip to move a proposal in the House for formation of a committee.

Opposition chief whip and senior BJP leader Mohan Majhi slammed the state government over the issue. Majhi said the state government is trying to run away, apprehending more criticisms over deposit of the temple funds in the crisis-hit bank. Senior Congress leader Suresh Routray said the Congress party take to the the streets if the state government fails to release the Jagannath Temple funds from the Yes Bank within a month. Both BJP and Congress had cornered the state government over the issue during an adjournment debate in the assembly on Thursday while state finance minister Niranjan Pujari had clarified that the money was deposited in Yes Bank after the it had agreed to give highest interest rate. A number of outfits on Friday hit the streets at the state capital and in Puri over the issue.

and came down heavily on the state government. The Puri district Congress committee members also met governor Ganeshi Lal, demanding safe release of the temple funds.

Title: Hyderabad: Case filed against Waris Pathan, Asaduddin Owaisi and Kapil Mishra for provocative speeches
Content:
Asaduddin Owaisi

HYDERABAD: A case was registered against Hyderabad MP, AIMIM president Asaduddin Owaisi , AIMIM’s former Byculla MLA Waris Pathan and Delhi BJP leader Kapil Mishra for allegedly promoting enmity among people through their provocative speeches.

Moghalpura police filed the case on Thursday following a complaint from Balkishan Rao Namdhari, a political activist from Old City. Recently, he moved a petition before a local court seeking legal action against the three politicians for delivering provocative speeches. As per the complaint, the accused were guilty of promoting enmity between people of various faiths.

“The petitioner cited that Mishra’s acts of leading a pro-CAA rally and delivering a provocative speech at Maujpur Chowk and Jaffarbad in Delhi had led to communal clashes in Delhi.

The petitioner alleged that Pathan had delivered a communally provocative speech at Kalaburgi in Karnataka in presence of Owaisi at an anti-CAA rally in February,” south zone additional DCP Syed Rafeeq said.

Based on the petition, the court had directed Moghalpura police to register a case.

A case was registered under Sections 295-A, 117, 153, 153-A, 120-B of IPC and 156 (3) of CrPC against the three. The relevant sections deal with charges relating to wanton vilification or attacks upon religion, abetting the commission of the offence, insulting religious beliefs, and criminal conspiracy.

Title: Shut down bars and liquor outlets in view of Covid-19: Sudheeran urges to CM
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: KPCC ex-president and Congress leader V M Sudheeran has urged the government to shut down bars and sales outlets of foreign liquor in the wake of Covid-19 outbreak.IMA state control unit for Covid-19 also demanded closure of bars as the crowd gathering there would be vulnerable.In his letter to chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan , a copy of which has been marked to health, revenue and excise ministers, Sudheeran said there is no justification on the part of the government to allow the functioning of sales outlets of IMFL when the government even took the extreme step of discontinuing the assembly session. He said a question has arisen among the public on why the government has allowed the beverages outlets and liquor selling places to function even in such a grave scenario. He added that the government’s approach of allowing the liquor sales outlets to function is condemnable and is gross injustice to the people of the state.Sudheeran urged that the same rules that have been applied to other places where there are likely to be gatherings should be applied to beverages outlets and liquor selling points also and added that the government should not play with the lives of the people.At the same time, he also lauded the government move to impose regulations in educational institutions, theatres, tourist places and other public places and government functions.

Title: Airport operators seek to levy ‘corona surcharge’
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: In a controversial move, private airport operators have sought levy of a corona surcharge to cover for the extra expenses being incurred by them on screening passengers amid a massive decline in air traffic — and hence their revenues from both aeronautical and non-aero streams — following the outbreak of the epidemic.The Association of Private Airport Operators (APAO) represents the PPP airports at Delhi, Mumbai, Bengaluru, Hyderabad and Cochin, and greenfield airports coming up in Navi Mumbai and Mopa in Goa.However, International Air Transport Association (IATA) slammed this demand. “India’s private airports need to do a reality check on their suggestion to impose a new levy at a time when passenger demand is plummeting on account of the Covid-19 outbreak. What is needed now are relief measures to help the aviation industry, and eventually when the situation is resolved to look at ways to grow demand, instead of a self-serving interest in protecting profits without recognizing what is happening in the world around us. It is imperative that we focus on reducing the overall cost of travel and work collectively to identify mutual cost saving opportunities,” said Amitabh Khosla, IATA country director for India.Given the large-scale cancellation of flights by airlines globally due to travel disruptions caused by Covid-19, the European Commission (EC) has temporarily suspended the 80/20 “use it or lose it” rule for airport slots till June 2020. Under this rule, if an airline doesn’t use 80% of slots allotted to it the airport operator may give them away to other carriers.Citing difficulties faced by Indian airport operators, Airport Council International (ACI) director-general Stefano Baronci wrote to aviation minister HS Puri on Friday seeking relief: “Reduce airport taxes on a per passenger basis … consider on a case-by-case basis to waive concession fees that the private airport operator has to [pay] to government.”In his letter, Baronci requested “a more pondered approach with respect to the airlines’ proposal to waive the 80/20 rule for current winter and forthcoming summer season. We are sympathetic with the airlines’ needs to avoid flying empty airplanes simply to retain airport slots … this should not jeopardise connectivity of passengers.”The APAO has written to aviation secretary PS Kharola, seeking levy of “a nominal passenger facilitation charge as part of airline fares to cover increased operating expenses being incurred by the operators.” The ACI World Airport Traffic Forecasts 2019-2040 projects revenue loss of $3 billion globally due to Covid-19.While revenues are falling, “ensuring compliance with government advisories on screening of passengers has required airports to significantly beef up its manpower deployment at airports as well as make expenditure on various items like masks, sanitizers and floor cleaners,” Nayar’s letter said.“This is unlike airlines which have got one major compensatory stream in terms of significantly reduced (more than 50%) crude oil prices,” it said.

Title: Delhi Rain: Delhi-NCR wakes up to a rainy morning
Content:
Rain lashes parts of #Delhi (Video from Delhi's Rohini) #DelhiRains https://t.co/Oa0CU1Uv0n — TOI Delhi (@TOIDelhi) 1584145169000

Watch: Heavy rain in eastern Noida with lightning and thunderstorm #DelhiNCRRain #delhirains https://t.co/2BiiovQub4 — TOI Noida (@TOINoida) 1584143563000

NEW DELHI: Parts of the national capital region (NCR) including Delhi, Noida and Gurugram witnessed moderate to heavy rainfall accompanied by lightning and thunder on early Saturday morning.While parts of Noida witnessed heavy rainfall, some areas in the national capital received moderate to light rainfall bringing down the temperature.

Title: GVMC polls: Rush to file nominations on last day
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Hundreds of nominees thronged to submit their nominations for the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation ( GVMC ) elections on Friday, the last day to file nominations. The rush piqued with around 900 people submitting their nominations.

The first day of the nomination filing process, March 11 had seen a paltry 24 nominations being filed. On March 12, more than 300 candidates submitted their nominations.

The delay in filing nominations and the consequent rush at the last minute is being ascribed to the reservation process put in place by the district administration.

With 49 of 98 wards of GVMC allocated to women, political parties found the search for suitable candidates a herculean task. This led to a delay in selection and thereby filing of nominations.

Moreover, the parties also sought to maintain confidentiality, apprehensive that those who don’t get tickets might rebel.

With political parties releasing their list of candidates at the last minute, there was a huge inflow of candidates at GVMC offices to file nominations.

The degree of the rush can be ascertained by the fact that officials had to give tokens to around 300 candidates, who could not file nominations before 3pm (the deadline), but had arrived in the offices. GVMC officials processed nominations till ______pm.

VMRDA metropolitan commissioner P Koteswara Rao, who is also the GVMC commissioner in-charge, said that GVMC has set up 1,712 polling stations for municipal polls.

“A total of 204 routes have been identified for the smooth conduct of elections. 234 route officers, including reserve officers, will oversee proceedings in all these 204 states,” Koteswara Rao said.

The nominations will be scrutinised on March 14, while deadline for the withdrawal of candidature is March 16 (till 3pm). The elections will be conducted on March 23 where over 17 lakh people are expected to vote.

Title: Training session for route officers
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Officials of the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation ( GVMC ) on Friday conducted a training programme for route officers deployed for municipal elections .

VMRDA metropolitan commissioner P Koteswara Rao, who is now in charge of GVMC as commissioner as well asked route officers to deliver their duties with utmost care and reminded them that they will be conferred with magisterial powers during the elections.

Joint collector L Siva Sankar told route officers to follow the route maps strictly. The route maps guide the process of distribution of election material and the process of getting them back to the reception centre.

“I request route officers to visit the poll stations assigned to them and get acquainted with the routes ahead of the elections,” he said while adding, “Coordination with zonal officers and other election personnel is crucial in order to make sure that there are no glitches in the election process.”

Koteswara Rao asked officials attending to election duties to apply for postal ballots. The officials will have to submit Form-XXI to the concerned returning officer a week before the elections (March 23), he informed.

Meanwhile, GVMC additional commissioner Thameem Ansariya visited zone-1 and zone-2 to monitor election arrangements. She asked polling personnel to arrange the election material ward-wise in order to easily identify shortages.

Title: 1.66cr ryots registered with e-NAM
Content:
Visakhapatnam/New Delhi: At least 1.66 crore farmers in Andhra Pradesh have registered with the National Agriculture Market (e-NAM) platform, according to Union minister of agriculture and farmer welfare, Nagendra Singh Tomar.

The minister made the statement at the Rajya Sabha on Friday in response to a question raised by YSRC Rajya Sabha MP V Vijayasai Reddy.

“As per the information received from the government of Andhra Pradesh, there are 216 mandis in AP. Out of 216 mandis, 22 markets have been integrated with (the) e-NAM platform,” the Union agriculture minister said. tnn

Title: First meet of new Simhachalam board
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The newly-constituted Simhachalam Trust Board conducted its first meeting under the chairpersonship of Sanchaita Gajapathi Raju at Goshala on Friday.

During the meeting, members of the trust board spoke about issues regarding the annual Kalyanotsavam and the Chandanotsavam events. Chairperson Sanchaita stressed upon the need to provide better amenities to visiting devotees.

Speaking on the occasion, Sanchaita said, “We wish to do away with the VIP culture and give greater importance and better facilities to common devotees. One must not forget that the Simhachalam deity is revered by the people of north-coastal AP as well as others.”

With regard to the arrangements being made for the annual Kalyanotsavam and Chandanotsavam, the newly-constituted board gave inputs of how to better manage the festivities.

All 16 board members were present on the occasion. This is the first board meeting after over a decade. The Simhachalam Devasthanam did not have an appointed board for a while. The new board was sworn in on March 3 this year after a major reshuffle which had taken many by surprise.

Title: YSRC announces 98 names for GVMC polls, TDP none
Content:
Visakhapatnam: While the ruling YSRC has already announced 98 candidates for the GVMC elections on the final day of nominations, TDP and Jana Sena did not announce any name till late night Friday.

YSRC’s local bodies’ elections in-charge Dadi Veerabhadra Rao had already announced 40 names earlier. The remaining 58 names were announced on Friday. YSRC reportedly conducted surveys twice at wards before finalising the list.

Dadi Veerabhadra Rao and tourism minister M Srinivasa Rao (Avanthi) asked candidates and party cadre to work hard to ensure a clean sweep for the party. They asked aspirants whose names did not feature in the list to not get discouraged.

Party sources said that the YSRC is fielding people from backward classes (BCs) and scheduled caste (SC) communities for general seats as well.

Now, there are at least half a dozen candidates from YSRC in the race for the mayor’s post including tourism minister M Srinivasa Rao’s daughter Priyanka, Tippala Nagireddy’s son Vamsi, Saragadam Chinaappala Naidu and Vamsikrishna Srinivas.

Meanwhile, sources within TDP said that the names will be released within a day or two. Sources further informed that Pendurthi MLA Gandi Babji has filed the nomination from ward number 95 and senior TDP leader Peela Srinivas has filed nominations from ward 97. Both candidates are apparently in a race for the mayor’s post.

There was some tension at the Madhurawada zone 1 office on Friday when tourism minister Avanthi’s daughter Priyanka entered the office directly while candidates of other parties were waiting their turn with tokens in their hands. Gajuwaka MLA’s son Vamsi also filed his nomination on Friday.

Till the end, the number of nominations is expected to reach 1,500. BJP has announced 49 candidates as their share. Jana Sena, its alliance partner is yet to make the names of their candidates’ public.

Title: Three hospitalised in Manipal, 2 test negative for Covid-19
Content: Mangaluru: Three people have been admitted to Kasturba Hospital, Manipal , with symptoms of Covid-19 . They had travelled recently to USA, Kuwait and Malaysia, said district health officer Dr Sudhir Chandra Suda.However, provisional reports of two of the patients were found to be negative. The reports of another patient will be out in a day or two. Suda said that trio are admitted to the isolation ward at Kasturba Hospital and kept under observation. Meanwhile, throat swabs of the trio have been collected and sent to a laboratory in Shivamogga.They had visited USA and Kuwait, and arrived at Udupi on Thursday, and another person who visited Malayasia reached Udupi on Friday. “The trio had symptoms of Covid-19. They have been asked to be shifted to hospital for treatment,” Suda added.Apart from them, two more people have been admitted to the isolation ward. Suda said one of them had visited Japan.Commenting on the health condition of a 68-year-old woman from Sagar, who was admitted to the hospital after she showed symptoms of Covid-19, Suda said that reports are negative. “We will conduct some other medical tests on her,” he said, adding that the woman had recently travelled to Saudi Arabia on pilgrimage.A total five people are being treated at the isolation ward in Udupi district.An official of the institute said the provisional report of two students was negative, and another report is awaited. The final reports will come from Pune.6 samples sent for testingThe district administration on Friday stated that six samples from travellers who arrived from abroad had been sent for testing. A total 685 people were screened at the airport and port. As of now, there are 54 people in quarantine, and none have completed the mandatory 14 days of isolation till date. Of the four samples sent for testing till now, all had returned negative for Covid-19.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Cyclist cuts short expedition in Mangaluru, gives Kerala a miss
Content: MANGALURU: Rase Rajan, 49, a cyclist and media professional, who is on a mission to enter the Guinness Book of Records for the longest journey by bicycle in a single country, has decided to end his trip at Mangaluru and not cycle to Kerala due to the Covid-19 outbreak.Rajan, who set a target of covering 40,000km, has completed 40,700km. He started his journey from Salem on October 2, 2017 and completed this expedition in 861 days (including breaks in between), in Mangaluru on Wednesday. The maximum distance covered by hims was 217km per day, while the minimum distance covered was 50km per day.“As per the original plan, I was supposed to travel to Kanyakumari and then to Puducherry and then head to Salem and Vishakapatnam. Due to the coronavirus outbreak , I have decided to cut short the expedition. The purpose of the expedition is to encourage people to use cycles for travel,” he said.He has visited 573 colleges and schools from 18 states, and analysed cycling tracks, pollution control measures, traffic faults, body mass and diabetes management. He has visited districts in Gujarat, Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan, Telangana, Andhra Pradesh, Tamil Nadu and Karnataka, and documented every aspect of the journey, including 14 times that he changed tyres, changed rims five times, changed tubes on 27 occasions, and changed the seat and pedal of his bicycle four times each.“I applied for the Guinness record on their online portal in June, 26, 2017 and got permission for the same on August 7. Christopher, a Guinness representative, is guiding me on this mission. The total cost of this expedition is Rs 8.4 lakh, and I have already spent about Rs 7.8 lakh from my personal savings, and sponsors too have chipped in. Every minute of this ride has been documented, I have a login on their website as well as maintain a log book where I enter elevation, distance, heart rate, temperature with a GPS watch that costs about Rs 30,000. I have visited more than 1,000 police stations and taken the signatures of policemen. The journey has been enjoyable and memorable. At times, I have missed family and felt lonely. I was also attacked by a mob that stole some of my belongings in Jharkhand, “ he said.He went beyond 40,000 km for a personal record. “I wanted to cover 48,000 km. Several clubs are following me. During this journey, I was moved by the way children prayed for me, and I have signed several autographs for them, and have been instrumental in promoting cycling clubs,” he said.

Title: No discernible change in daily life in Kalaburagi despite Covid-19 fatality
Content: Kalaburagi: Although the first confirmed death in India owing to novel coronavirus or Covid-19 , which was reported in Kalaburagi turned the attention of the national media towards the district in North Karnataka, in addition to making headlines across India, this momentous event appears to have little to no impact on the routine activities of the people here.Notwithstanding the order issued by the district administration closing down all malls, theatres, parks, schools and colleges, people could still be found milling about in crowds at markets, business establishments and temples. Very few people were found wearing masks in Kalaburagi city.Most small traders and merchants kept their stores open, and did not register a marked dip in their turnover despite the panic over the outbreak of the disease.The only discernible difference was in the turnout at the Sharanabasaveshwara Mela, a religious fare that is attended by nearly one lakh devotees every year. However, following restrictions clamped down by the district administration – the officials also appealed to the temple authorities to scale down the affair – the ritual was a markedly low-profile affair on Friday. Despite the temple authorities reaching out to the people to avoid coming to the fair, there was a considerable turnout.Shivalingappa H, one of the devotees who turned up at the Sharanabasaveshwara shrine on Friday, said that he had been coming to the temple for the ritual for the past many years, and did not want to snap the tradition owing to Covid-19. “To me, seeking the Almighty’s blessings is more important than the virus,” he said.Revanna Siddappa, who lives in a village not very far from Kalaburagi city, said, “I come to the city every day. And it does not look like there is any trouble. But if the situation worsens in the coming days, I will stop coming to the city.”

Title: PeTA asks Karnataka government to take cognisance of cruel methods used to kill poultry
Content:
Belagavi: Gripped by panic over the outbreak of the novel coronavirus or Covid-19, coupled with reports of bird flu in the country, poultry farmers across the state have taken to culling their livestock en masse. Taking cognisance of this panic-driven activity, People for Ethical Treatment for Animals ( PeTA ), India on Thursday wrote to the Karnataka government, seeking directions to stop culling of livestock using cruel and illegal means.

Among the more shocking incidents reported in the state was from Gokak in Belagavi, where a farmer buried 6,000 chickens alive on March 9. In all, roughly 16,000 chickens have reportedly been culled across Karnataka in the past week, and in many cases, the methods used to end their life have been brutal. Under these circumstances, PeTA India has urged the Karnataka department of animal husbandry to take note of the scale of the problem, and pursuant steps to put an end to the same.

Stressing the need to cull livestock in a humane manner, wherein they experience the least amount of pain possible, PeTA, in its letter, stated, “The department must promote methods of culling recommended by the Animal Welfare Board of India, the central government’s advisory body and the World Organisation for Animal Health, the international agency responsible for keeping a close watch on animal health across the world, and India is a member nation of this body.”

The animal rights body pointed out that killing of poultry using methods such as burying them alive was in violation of Sections 3 and 11 of the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act, 1960, and Section 429 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC). Violation of these laws can invite punishment as stringent as imprisonment for up to five years.

Veterinarian and PeTA India chief executive officer Dr Manilal Valliyate, in a mail to TOI, wrote, “The savagery displayed by the farmers is yet another stark reminder to the public that, regardless of how one goes about it – burying them alive or slitting throats – chickens are always killed in a cruel manner. Poultry farms breed bird flu and other diseases. Chickens used for production of eggs are also commonly mutilated, starved and severely confined. The condition of those used for the meat industry is worse as they are housed in filthy sheds. They are fed, and bred in such a manner that they grow to be so large wherein their bones cannot take the load, and they grow more prone to heart attacks. We urge the public to spare themselves and the chickens this misery by choosing to eat only vegan food.”

PeTA India has also interacted with the authorities concerned to communicate to farmers the need to report outbreak of diseases in their barns. “They must visit the nearest government veterinary hospital so that methods animals are killed in accordance with the rules of the Animal Welfare Board of India,” Dr Valliyate added.

Title: Price of jackfruit spirals up in Mysuru
Content:
Mysuru: Amid a fall in chicken rate, the price of tender jackfruit has increased four folds in the city market in the past few days. An average sized tender jackfruit, which was sold for Rs 5-10 two weeks ago, is now being sold for Rs 20 to 40.

According to the vendors, the sudden spike in the rate is due to a huge demand for the tender jackfruit from neighbouring states including Maharashtra while others feel that a low yield resulted in the price hike.

G Karunakaran, principal scientist & incharge head, central horticultural experiment station, Hirehalli, Tumakuru, confirmed the sudden spurt in the rate. “The tender jackfruit, which was available for Rs 5 and 10 have reached Rs.40,” he said.

“The tender jackfruit have several health benefits. That could be the reason for the huge demand in the market,” he said.

“I don't know the exact reason for the rate increase. But from Tumakuru market, tender jackfruit is supplied in huge quantity to Maharashtra,” he said.

Even local growers in Mysuru said that there is a sudden increase in the demand for the tender jackfruit and the rate is also very attractive. “Earlier, we used to sell them through vendors. But now the agents are approaching us. For a kilogram, we are offered nearly Rs 20-.25. Earlier, it was just Rs 5. The agents are saying that the demand has increased in Tamil Nadu, Andhra, etc, said Siddramappa, a farmer from Kemmanahalli on Bogadi-Gadige Road.

A few experts feel that the sudden jump in the rate may be the result of low yield. “Compared to previous years, this year, the yield is less. That may be the one of the reasons for the rate increase,” said G Krishnaprasad of Sahaja Samrudha organisation.

Title: Rangayana seeks Kukkarahalli Lake land to hold events
Content:
Mysuru: Citing shortage of space to host various camps, Rangayana , the theatre repertory, has requested University of Mysore to provide the adjacent Kukkarahalli Lake land for the events .

Every year, Rangayana hosts a summer camp after completion of schools exams in April.

The camp is generally held for children in the age group of 7 to 14 years where only 300 children are admitted under first-come-first basis. During the camp, children are exposed to theatre, acting, singing, folk, painting, games, environmental issues and various others activities.

While Rangayana hosts various activities during the summer camp for children, the authorities claim that it is facing shortage of space to host all the events.

As the lush green Kukkarahalli Lake area is maintained and managed by University of Mysore, the theatre group has requested the university authorities to provide nearly an acre land of the lake on the south part of the Rangayana premises near Bhoomigeetha auditorium.

Rangayana director Addanda C Cariappa told TOI that they have requested the university authorities to provide lake area which is adjacent to the Rangayana.

“We have requested the area near the food gallery. We conduct Chinnara Mela and there will be huge crowd. Children who participate in the summer camp should not feel congested. So, we have requested some space which will be used only during the Chinnara Mela. University of Mysore vice-chancellor Hemanth Kumar has assured to provide the land,” he said.

When TOI contacted registrar R Shivappa, he said that the university has received the request from Rangayana seeking Kukkarahalli Lake land for hosting Chinnara Mela. “We have to think on the issue, ”he said.

However, environmentalists and morning walkers at the lake expressed disappointment by the demand by Rangayana. Morning walker Sunil said that the Kukkarahalli Lake area is the lung space where hundreds of people walk morning and evening time.

“It should be preserved and protected. There is enough space in Rangayana to host big events. University authorities should not permit to use the lake area as it will disturb the birds and animals but also damage the vegetation,” he said.

No decision yet on Chinnara Mela

The Rangayana is yet to take a decision on conducting Chinnara Mela this year due to coronavirus scare. The summer camp for kids is from April 11 to May 10. Rangayana director Addanda C Cariappa told TOI, “We will wait till March 25, watch the development on coronavirus situation, consult the government and take a call on whether to conduct Chinnara Mela or not.”

Title: Coronavirus scare in Karnataka: Two couples in Belagavi tie the knot wearing N-95 masks
Content: BELAGAVI: Karnataka has unwittingly turned into the cynosure of the whole nation following the first fatality of novel coronavirus being reported in Kalaburagi. Against the backdrop of the government machinery pulling all stops to raise awareness about Covid-19 and contain its spread, two couples who tied the knot in Belagavi district on Friday decided to do their bit to educate the people.In Yaxamba in Chikkodi taluk, two couple that entered into matrimony on Friday, wore masks during the rituals and flashed banners, which contained messages to maintain cleanliness and take necessary precautions to tackle the disease. The two couples – Preeti and Shekar, Mallappa and Deepali – were provided sufficient assistance by the district health department in this endeavour. In addition to wearing N95 masks throughout the ceremony, the families of the brides and grooms had also arranged for talks on the disease, wherein the visitors were told about the need to wash their hands and maintain hygiene.Preeti’s father Arun Kamte said that a wedding offered a unique opportunity to reach a large cross-section of the demographic. “Also, it is our duty to extend our support to the government in such an hour of crisis,” he said.Chikkodi taluk health officer VV Shinde was appreciative of the couples’ initiative. “We felt very pleased when the parents approached us to discuss the possibility of using the weddings as an event to raise awareness. Many people have been educated in this manner,” Shinde told TOI.

Title: Slacklining introduced at St Mary’s Island
Content:
Adventurer: A team from Slack Mitra, in association with Malpe Beach Development Committee, rigged Udupi’s fir... Read More

Udupi: A team from Slack Mitra , in association with Malpe Beach Development Committee, rigged Udupi’s first slackline on Friday.

Sudesh Shetty, head, Mantra Tourism Development Company and in-charge of Malpe Beach, said that this was an attempt to promote St Mary’s Island as a geological marvel and an upcoming adventure sports destination. Zilla panchayat CEO Preeti Gehlot and assistant director, tourism, Chandrashekar, were present, and also tried their hand at slacklining .

Preeti Gehlot said, “It is just a workshop. We will try to hold such events more frequently. It is a good activity for all age groups, and also tests one’s patience and focus. The team had arrived from Pune. It was a good experience to see the demonstration and then try it out,” he said.

St Mary’s Island is a geological treasure trove as well as a hub for island biodiversity and ecology. The crew included Navin Devnani Torres, 27, owner at Slack Mitra, Adhwaith Manohar, 31, slackliner, Kshitij Mittal, 32, an adventure sports promoter and Vinay Tataria, 28, a conservationist.

At St Mary’s Island, the slackline has been set between two huge rocks for demonstration purposes. The next session in April will be for bigger crowds. This is going to be a regular attraction at the island, said Sudesh Shetty.
